Chapter 1.01 CODE ADOPTION*
* CodeAlert: This topic has been affected by Ordinance No. 20-2020. To view amendments and newly added provisions, please refer to the CodeAlert Amendment List.


1.01.010 Code adopted—Citation form—Effective date.
    A.  Pursuant to Title 31 of the Colorado Revised Statutes, there is hereby adopted the code of ordinances entitled “Code of the City of Cañon City, Colorado, 1988,” compiled, revised, and codified for the City of Cañon City by Book Publishing Company of Seattle, Washington, by authority of the City Council of the City, and containing a compilation, revision, and codification of the permanent and general ordinances of the City, hereinafter referred to as “code” or “primary code,” of which code not less than three copies have been and are now filed in and incorporated into the ordinance codified in this chapter as if set out at length herein, as provided by Part 2 of Article 16 of Title 31, Colorado Revised Statutes, 1986, as amended.

    B.   The code adopted may be cited as “Code of the City of Cañon City, Colorado, 1988,” or by the short title, “Cañon City Municipal Code.” When a change or changes have been prepared and inserted in the code, as provided herein, the words “as amended” may be added to the above citation or title when referring to the code as amended.

    C.   The code adopted hereby shall go into effect on January 8, 1989, at 12:01 a.m. (Ord. 40-1988; prior code § 1.01.010)

 

1.01.020 Inclusion of City Charter.
    The Charter of the City of Cañon City, Colorado is included in the code of the ordinances hereby adopted for convenience. (Ord. 40-1988; prior code § 1.01.020)

 

1.01.030 Reference applies to all amendments.
    Whenever a reference is made to this Code as the “Cañon City Municipal Code” or to any portion thereof, the reference shall apply to all amendments, corrections and additions made before, as of or after the effective date of the ordinance codified in this chapter. (Ord. 40-1988; prior code § 1.01.030)

 

1.01.040 Repeal of prior ordinances.
    All ordinances and parts of ordinances of a primary and general nature passed prior to July 5, 1988, and in effect at the time the Code of the City of Cañon City, Colorado, 1988, is adopted, but not included in said code, are repealed as of the time when the code goes into effect. Ordinances passed on or after July 5, 1988, shall not be repealed or amended by the adoption of the code and the ordinance codified in this chapter. (Ord. 40-1988; prior code § 1.01.040)

 

1.01.050 Matters not affected by repeal.
    The repeal of ordinances and parts of ordinances of a permanent and general nature by Section 1.01.040 shall not affect any offense committed or act done, or any penalty or forfeiture incurred, or any contract, right or obligation established prior to the time when such ordinances and parts of ordinances are repealed. (Ord. 40-1988; prior code § 1.01.050)

 

1.01.060 Ordinances saved from repeal.
    The repeal of ordinances of a general and permanent nature by Section 1.01.040 of this chapter shall not repeal any ordinance or part thereof saved from repeal specifically by the Cañon City Municipal Code; nor shall such repeal affect any ordinance:

    A.  Promising, guaranteeing or authorizing the payment of money by or for the City;

    B.   Authorizing or relating to specific issuances of bonds or other evidences of indebtedness;

    C.   Granting a franchise;

    D.  Establishing the compensation of city officers or employees;

    E.   Levying taxes, making appropriations or adopting a budget;

    F.   Creating specific local improvement districts;

    G.  Making special assessments for local improvements;

    H.  Vacating, accepting, establishing, locating, relocating or opening any street or public way;

    I.    Affecting the corporate limits of the City;

    J.    Which is of a special or temporary nature;

    K.  Dedicating or accepting any plat or subdivision;

    L.   Setting rates for any services or utilities provided by the City;

    M.  Creating contractual obligation on the part of the City. (Ord. 40-1988; prior code § 1.01.060)

 

1.01.070 Catchlines, headings and titles.
    Catchlines, headings, and titles of sections and other subdivisions in the code adopted by this chapter, or in changes made in the code, are inserted for the convenience of users of the code and shall have no legal effect. Notes indicating sources of sections, giving other information, or referring to the statutes or to other parts of the code or to the City Charter are inserted in the code, and may be inserted in changes to the code for the convenience of persons using the code, and shall have no legal effect. (Ord. 40-1988; prior code § 1.01.070)

 

1.01.080 Penalty for altering or tampering with code.
    Any person, firm, or corporation who shall alter, change or amend the Code of the ordinances adopted by this chapter except in the manner prescribed by this chapter, or who shall alter or tamper with the Code in any manner so as to cause the ordinances of the City to be misrepresented thereby, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor, and upon conviction thereof, shall be punished as provided by Section 1.28.010 of this Code. (Ord. 40-1988; prior code § 1.01.080)

 

1.01.090 Severability of ordinance provisions.
    Each section of this chapter is an independent section, and the holding of any section or part thereof to be unconstitutional, void or ineffective for any cause shall not be deemed to affect the validity or constitutionality of any other section or part thereof. (Ord. 40-1988; prior code § 1.01.090)

 

1.01.100 Severability of code provisions.
    If any sections, section or subsection or provision of this Code of ordinances, or the application thereof to any person or circumstances, is declared unconstitutional or otherwise invalid by any competent court, such invalidity shall not affect the other sections, section, subsection, or provision or application. (Ord. 40-1988; prior code § 1.01.100)

 

This topic has been modified. View the section for details. 1.01.110 Secondary codes adopted by reference.
    The following secondary codes as adopted by reference in the Code of the City are adopted and enacted by reference as if the same were set out in full in this chapter:

    A.  The Uniform Building Code, 1985 Edition, promulgated by the International Conference of Building Officials, which protects the residents of the city by prescribing minimum standards for buildings and other structures. The Code regulates erection, enlargement, construction, alteration, repair, moving, removal, conversion, demolition, occupancy, use, height, area, maintenance and other matters related to buildings and structures in the city.

    B.   The Uniform Housing Code, 1985 Edition, promulgated by the International Conference of Building Officials. The Code, in conjunction with the Uniform Building Code, protects the health and safety of residents of the City by providing for requirements affecting conservation and rehabilitation of housing.

    C.   The Uniform Code for the Abatement of Dangerous Buildings, 1985 Edition, promulgated by the International Conference of Building Officials. The Code, in conjunction with the Uniform Housing Code and Uniform Building Code, protects the health and safety of the residents of the city by setting forth orderly procedures for remedying dangerous buildings which comply with the requirements of due process.

    D.  The Uniform Mechanical Code, 1985 Edition, promulgated by the International Conference of Building Officials. The Code protects the residents of the city by regulating the installation and construction of heating, ventilation, refrigeration, and air-conditioning systems. (Ord. 40-1988; prior code § 1.01.110)

 

1.01.120 Penalty for violation of primary and secondary codes.
    Unless otherwise specifically provided, the maximum general penalty for violation of the primary and secondary codes of the City shall be as set forth in Section 1.28.010 of this Code. (Ord. 17-2013 § 1; Ord. 15-1993 §§ 1, 2)

 

This topic has been modified. View the section for details. 1.01.130 Codes to be kept on file.
    A.  At least one copy of the Code of the City of Cañon City, Colorado, 1988, and of each secondary code adopted therein, all certified by the Mayor and the City Clerk to be true copies of such codes as they were adopted by the ordinance codified in this chapter, shall be kept on file in the office of the City Clerk, available for public inspection. One copy of each such code may be kept in the office of the City Administrator.

    B.   The City Clerk shall cause to be prepared and published revised sheets of every looseleaf page in need of revision by reason of amendment, addition or repeal when directed by the City Council. The City Clerk shall distribute such revised looseleaf sheets for such fee as the City Council may direct.

    C.   A copy of this Code shall be kept on file in the office of the City Clerk in which it shall be the express duty of the City Clerk to insert in their designated places all amendments or ordinances which are intended to become a part of the Code of the City of Cañon City, 1988, when the same have been printed or reprinted in page form, and to extract from such code all provisions which may from time to time be available to all persons desiring to examine it and shall be considered the official Code of the City of Cañon City. (Ord. 40-1988; prior code § 1.01.130)

Chapter 1.04 GENERAL PROVISIONS
1.04.010 “Misdemeanor” and “offense” defined.
    The words “misdemeanor” and “offense,” wherever they occur in the City ordinances, shall be construed to mean, and shall severally stand in lieu of, a violation of ordinance, and shall not have the meaning prescribed by Colorado Revised Statutes 1973 Section 18-1-106. (Prior code § 1.08.010)

 

1.04.020 “Heretofore” and “ hereafter” defined.
    Whenever the term “heretofore” occurs in any ordinance of the City, it shall be construed to mean any time previous to the time when such ordinance takes effect; and whenever the term “hereafter” occurs, it shall be construed to mean any time after such ordinance takes effect. (Prior code § 1.08.020)

 

1.04.030 Plural and singular number.
    Whenever, in any ordinance of this city, words importing the plural number are used in describing or referring to any object, matter, parties or persons, any single object, matter, party or person shall be deemed to be included, although distributive words to that effect may not be used. (Prior code § 1.08.030)

 

1.04.040 Number and gender.
    When any subject, matter, party or person is described or referred to in any ordinance by words importing the singular number or the masculine gender, several things, matters and persons, and females as well as males, and firms and bodies corporate as well as individuals, shall be deemed to be included. (Prior code § 1.08.040)

 

1.04.050 Exceptions to Sections 1.04.030 and 1.04.040.
    The rules prescribed in Sections 1.04.030 and 1.04.040 shall apply in all cases unless it be otherwise expressly provided in any ordinance, or unless there is something in the subject or context repugnant to such construction. (Prior code § 1.08.050)

 

1.04.060 Phrases regarding the City or City Council.
    The phrases “the City” and “this city,” whenever such occur in city ordinances, shall be construed to mean the City of Cañon City, in the state of Colorado; and the phrases “the Council” and “the City Council,” when thus occurring, shall be construed to mean the City Council of the City, unless the context clearly indicates another meaning. (Prior code § 1.08.060)

 

1.04.070 “Law,” “state law” and “statutes” defined.
    Whenever the words “law,” “state law,” “statutes,” or other words are used in the ordinances of the City referring to the statutes of the state of Colorado, they shall have the meaning prescribed by the Charter, Article XV, Section 13. (Prior code § 1.08.070)

 

1.04.080 Officers and employees.
    The Mayor, Councilmembers, City Administrator, City Attorney and Municipal Judge are declared to be officers of the City, and all other persons serving the City in any capacity whatsoever are declared to be employees, in accordance with Article V of the Charter. (Prior code § 1.08.080)

 

1.04.090 Severability.
    If a court of competent jurisdiction should hold one or more sections or a part of a section of this Code or of an ordinance passed hereafter invalid, such holding shall not affect the remainder of the code or ordinance, nor the context in which such section, sections or part of a section so held invalid may appear, except to the extent that an entire section or part of a section may be inseparably connected in meaning and effect with the section, sections or part of a section so held invalid. (Prior code § 1.08.090)

Chapter 1.08 CITY SEAL
1.08.010 City seal designated—Description.
    A seal, the impression of which is as follows: In the center, the words, “Seal, Incorporated April 2, 1872” and around the outer edge the words, “The City of Cañon City, Colorado” shall be and is declared to be the seal of the City of Cañon City. (Prior code § 1.04.010)

Chapter 1.12 VOTING PRECINCTS AND ELECTIONS
1.12.010 District Map, Council member districts and voting precincts.
    A.  District Map Adopted. Effective June 1, 2011, the official City Council District Map shall be that certain “City Council District Boundary Map” formally approved by majority of Council at its May 16, 2011 regular meeting, the original of which shall be kept in the office of the City Clerk.

    B.   Posting of Official Map. The City Clerk is hereby authorized to prepare, post and/or otherwise display and/or distribute true and correct copies of the official map and of each of the four (4) districts designated thereon.

    C.   General Location of Districts. For purposes of general information:

    1.   District One shall include land within the incorporated limits of the city that is generally lying within the north-west section of the city, as more specifically designated on the official map.

    2.   District Two shall include land within the incorporated limits of the city that is generally lying within the south-west section of the city (including the Dawson Ranch area) as more specifically designated on the official map.

    3.   District Three shall include land within the incorporated limits of the city that is generally lying within the north-central section of the city, as more specifically designated on the official map.

    4.   District Four shall include land within the incorporated limits of the city that is generally lying within the south-central section of the city and in the Four Mile Ranch area, as more specifically designated on the official map.

    D.  Voting Precincts. With respect to elections where it is deemed necessary to establish voting precincts, the locations of such voting precincts shall be established in advance of the election by the duly designated election official for such election. (Ord. 5-2011 § 1)

 

1.12.020 Polling places.
    Polling places for regular and special municipal elections shall be determined and designated by:

    A.  The Fremont County Clerk, or such other person authorized to designate polling places under the Uniform Election Code of 1992, as amended (Articles 1 to 13 of Title 1, C.R.S.), in all cases where the City is participating in a coordinated election conducted by the Fremont County Clerk; or

    B.   The City Clerk, pursuant to the Colorado Municipal Election Code of 1965 (Article 10 of Title 31, C.R.S.), as amended, or other applicable law, with respect to all other municipal elections. (Ord. 2-2003 § 2)

 

1.12.050 Council member districts.
    A.  For purposes of defining and identifying the four (4) districts within which the four (4) Council members who are subject to district residency requirements must reside, the following shall apply and supersede any conflicting provision of the Charter and prior ordinances of the City:

    1.   The boundaries of “District One” shall coincide with the boundaries of District One, as shown on the official map identified in Section 1.12.010, and shall include all of the land within said boundaries and any land immediately adjacent to the land in District One that is annexed into the city after June 1, 2011.

    2.   The boundaries of “District Two” shall coincide with the boundaries of District Two, as shown on the official map identified in Section 1.12.010, and shall include all of the land within said boundaries and any land immediately adjacent to the land in District Two that is annexed into the city after June 1, 2011.

    3.   The boundaries of “District Three” shall coincide with the boundaries of District Three, as shown on the official map identified in Section 1.12.010, and shall include all of the land within said boundaries and any land immediately adjacent to the land in District Three that is annexed into the city after June 1, 2011.

    4.   The boundaries of “District Four” shall coincide with the boundaries of District Four, as shown on the official map identified in Section 1.12.010, and shall include all of the land within said boundaries and any land immediately adjacent to the land in District Four that is annexed into the city after June 1, 2011.

    B.   The foregoing designations are authorized and mandated by Subsection C of Section 1 of Article II of the Charter of Cañon City. Except as is otherwise provided in the Charter, one member of City Council, who is not a Council member At-Large, must reside in each district designated in Subsection A of this section. (Ord. 5-2011 § 2; Ord. 2-2003 § 4)

Chapter 1.16 MUNICIPAL COURT
1.16.010 Establishment.
    There shall be a Municipal Court presided over by a Municipal Judge, as provided by Section 3 of Article IV and Sections 1 to 4, inclusive, of Article V of the City Charter. (Prior code § 1.24.010)

 

1.16.020 Municipal Judge—Qualifications.
    The Municipal Judge, in addition to the qualification prescribed by the City Charter shall have been admitted to and currently licensed in the practice of law in Colorado. (Prior code § 1.24.012)

 

1.16.030 Jurisdiction of the court.
    The Municipal Court shall have exclusive original jurisdiction to hear, try and determine all cases arising under the City Charter and the ordinances of the City for the violation and enforcement thereof, and there shall be no change of venue therefrom. (Prior code § 1.24.020)

 

1.16.035 Municipal Court—Authority to issue restraining orders.
    A.  The Municipal Court is authorized to issue temporary and permanent civil restraining orders, as provided for in Part 1 of Article 14 of Title 13, C.R.S., provided that such authority shall be limited to restraining orders authorized in Subsection 13-14-102(4)(b), C.R.S., and further provided that the only “business entity” which shall be authorized to seek and receive the issuance of a restraining order under this subsection will be the City of Cañon City for the protection of one or more City employees.

    B.   For purposes of this section “City employee” means and includes all elected and appointed City officers and all full- and part-time City employees and all regular and alternate members of the City’s official boards and commissions.

    C.   The Municipal Court shall utilize the forms and process described in Article 14 of Title 13, C.R.S., with respect to any petition, motion or other request for the issuance of any temporary or permanent restraining order that it is authorized to issue and enforce under the limited authority granted in Subsection A of this section. (Ord. 16-2003 § 4)

 

1.16.036 Municipal Court—Authority to order restitution.
    A.  Discretionary authority is expressly granted to the judges of the Municipal Court to award, as restitution to any victim of any civil infraction or criminal violation of this Code, an amount equal to the actual damages suffered by said victim, or to order a person found, or pleading, guilty to any such violation to pay such restitution as ordered by the Municipal Court.

    B.   Discretionary authority is expressly granted to the Municipal Court to order restitution for any and all costs incurred by public safety and/or emergency response agencies of the City or other governmental or quasi-governmental entities in connection with the initial response to and all subsequent follow-up investigation of violations of this Code.

    C.   When granted, restitution shall be determined by the submission of a bill of costs by said victim or agency to the Municipal Court on a form approved by the Municipal Court, but the Municipal Court shall be limited to awarding as such restitution only actual costs incurred by said victim that can be determined with a reasonable amount of certainty and whenever it is determined by the court that the payment of restitution is fair and reasonable. The specific amount of restitution shall be determined within the ninety (90) days immediately following the order of conviction or imposition of deferred judgment or deferred sentence, unless good cause is shown for extending the time period by which the restitution amount shall be determined.

    D.  Any restitution ordered by the Municipal Court shall be in addition to any fine or imprisonment authorized by this Code and shall be applicable to any situation in which deferred judgment or deferred sentence is accepted and/or imposed by the Municipal Court. (Ord. 23-2018 § 1)

 

1.16.040 Rules of procedure.
    The Municipal Court Rules of Procedure, promulgated by the Supreme Court of the state from time to time, shall govern the procedures in the Municipal Court. (Prior code § 1.24.030)

 

1.16.050 Sentence may include useful community/public service.
    A.  A defendant convicted of a misdemeanor, petty offense, or infraction in the Municipal Court may be sentenced to perform useful community/public service. Such useful community/public service may be as a condition of or in addition to any other sentence provided by this Code.

    B.   For the purposes of this section, “useful community/public service” means any work which is beneficial to the public, any public entity or any bona fide nonprofit private or public organization, which work involves a minimum of direct supervision or other public cost and which work would not, with the exercise of reasonable care, endanger the health or safety of the person required to work. In addition, the Court may at its discretion order that a defendant participate in a specific useful community/public service program.

    C.   In addition to other court costs imposed by the Court, any defendant sentenced to useful community/public service shall pay court costs of five dollars ($5.00) for costs incurred by the City in obtaining insurance coverage. (Ord. 26-2019 § 1)

 

1.16.060 Contempt of court.
    The Municipal Judge shall have full power and authority to punish for contempt of his or her court; provided, however, that no person shall be punished for contempt by imprisonment unless the imposition of such punishment is preceded by a hearing at which such person may be represented by competent legal counsel, and further provided that no imprisonment for contempt shall exceed five (5) days. No fine for contempt shall exceed the maximum fine provided for in Section 1.28.010 of this Code. (Ord. 17-2013 § 2; prior code § 1.24.040)

 

1.16.070 Assessment of costs.
    Costs in an amount deemed appropriate by the Municipal Judge, but not in excess of three hundred dollars ($300.00), may be assessed by the Municipal Judge against any defendant who, upon conviction, is found guilty of a violation of any ordinance of the City. All costs incurred by the City with respect to the issuance of any warrant issued by the Municipal Court on account of the failure of any defendant or of any person previously convicted of an ordinance violation in Municipal Court to appear before the Municipal Court at a specified date and time for proceedings involving said defendant or convicted person shall be assessable by the Municipal Court against such defendant or convicted person as costs. (Ord. 15-1993 § 3)

 

1.16.080 Records of trial proceedings.
    The Municipal Court shall keep a verbatim record of the proceedings and evidence at trials by either electric devices or stenographic means, and shall in all respects be a “Qualified Municipal Court of Record” as such court is defined by the statutes of the state. (Prior code § 1.24.013)

 

1.16.090 Surcharge.
    A.  A surcharge equal to the greater of ten dollars ($10.00) or ten percent (10%) of the fine imposed for violation of all municipal ordinances, except parking violations, is levied on each Municipal Court action resulting in a conviction or in a deferred judgment and sentence, which municipal ordinance violation is charged pursuant to City of Cañon City ordinances. All calculated surcharge amounts resulting in dollars and cents shall be rounded down to the nearest whole dollar. If a portion of the fine is suspended, a proportionate amount of this surcharge levied shall also be suspended, but in no event shall the surcharge be reduced to an amount less than ten dollars ($10.00). If the suspension of the fine is thereafter revoked, the surcharge shall be reimposed on the total amount of the fine imposed. Such surcharges shall be paid to the Clerk of the Court by the defendant.

    B.   The moneys shall be deposited in the general fund of the City and are intended to be allocated for the following purposes, including, but not limited to, purchase of equipment, training programs, and additional personnel for a victims assistance program, and to domestic violence programs within the community. (Ord. 27-1989 § 1)

Chapter 1.20 TRIALS
1.20.010 Jury trial conditions.
    A.  Cases in the Municipal Court shall be tried by the court, unless the defendant is entitled to a jury trail under the Constitution and general laws of the state, the Charter of the City, or the ordinances of the City, and the defendant shall request a jury trial in writing.

    B.   A jury shall consist of three jurors unless the defendant demands a jury comprised of a larger number of jurors, but in no event shall a jury be comprised of more than six in number. (Prior code § 1.28.010)

 

1.20.020 Terms of court.
    For the purpose of selecting jurors for the Municipal Court of the City, the terms of the court shall be held in each and every year commencing on the second Monday of September and March. (Prior code § 1.28.020)

 

1.20.030 Selection of jurors.
    A.  The City Clerk, forty-five days or more before the commencement of a term of the court, shall select not less than fifty inhabitants of the City, having the qualifications as prescribed by the statutes of the state, for jurors of its district courts and who are not exempted by said statutes.

    B.   The City Clerk shall obtain a list of the names prescribed by this section from the City voter registration list, supplemented from other lists which may be available, such as water customers, utility customers, city directories, telephone directories, driver license registration and property taxpayers.

    C.   The City Clerk shall, upon the compilation of the list of names, certify it to the Clerk of the Municipal Court. (Prior code § 1.28.030)

 

1.20.040 Ballot box—Required Description.
    The Clerk of the Municipal Court shall keep a box of suitable dimensions, having two compartments, each of which shall be closed with a lid or cover and fastened with lock and key. An opening shall be made in each of said lids not exceeding two inches in length, and one-fourth inch in width, which shall be for the reception of ballots. The box shall remain in the possession of the court Clerk and shall not be opened except at the time and in the manner specified in Section 1.20.050. The keys to the same shall be kept by the City Administrator. (Prior code § 1.28.040)

 

1.20.050 Ballot box—Use to select jurors.
    The Clerk of the Municipal Court shall write the names certified to him on ballots in one compartment of the box. At least thirty days prior to the term of the court, and afterwards as often as the court shall order, the Clerk of the Municipal Court shall call to his assistance the City Administrator of the City, and in the presence of the City Administrator draw by chance from the compartment of the box in which names have been placed, a sufficient number of jurors for the next term of the Municipal Court. When so drawn, the ballots shall be placed in the other compartment of the box. (Prior code § 1.28.050)

 

1.20.060 Exemption from jury service.
    At the end of each term of court, the court Clerk shall certify to the City Clerk the names of all persons who have served on any regular panel of jurors at the preceding term, and the persons so certified shall not be again returned as jurors during a period of one year thereafter. The court Clerk shall also destroy all ballots remaining in the box, and for the succeeding term of court the names of persons shall be certified by the City Clerk, and the jurors be drawn in the manner provided in this chapter. The names of competent persons may be successively returned by the City Clerk, until they have been drawn as jurors, and until they have performed service as such, when they shall be omitted for at least one year. (Prior code § 1.28.060)

 

1.20.070 Summoning jurors.
    A.  If a jury is ordered to be drawn, the Clerk thereafter shall cause each person drawn for jury service to be served with a summons, either personally or by registered or certified mail, return receipt requested, addressed to him at his usual residence, business or post office address, requiring him to report for jury service at a specified time and place.

    B.   Whenever there is an unanticipated shortage of available jurors drawn from a qualified jury list, the court may require the court Clerk to summon a sufficient number of jurors from bystanders, but either party may show cause why bystanders should not be used, in which case additional jurors may be selected at random by the Clerk from the qualified jury list or in any other manner prescribed by the court. (Prior code § 1.28.070)

 

1.20.080 Excusal from jury service—Conditions.
    A person who is not disqualified for jury service may be excused from jury service by the court only upon a showing of undue hardship, extreme inconvenience, or public necessity, for a period the court deems necessary, at the conclusion of which the person shall reappear for jury service in accordance with the court’s direction. (Prior code § 1.28.080)

 

1.20.090 Peremptory challenge and discharge.
    If any juror summoned shall be interested in the event of the case or kin to a defendant, or shall have expressed this opinion on the matter about to be tried, or shall, for any cause (to be judged by the Municipal Judge), be considered as a partial or improper juror, the Municipal Judge shall discharge such juror. In all cases arising under the Charter or ordinances of the City wherein a jury trial is had, each party shall be entitled to three (3) peremptory challenges. (Prior code § 1.28.090)

 

1.20.100 Verdict and sentencing.
    Upon the jury returning a verdict of guilty, the Municipal Judge shall record the same and shall proceed to fix or determine the punishment or penalty, and to render judgment upon such verdict for the punishment or penalty so determined by him or her; but, if the jury returns a verdict of not guilty, the Municipal Judge shall record the same and shall discharge the defendant or defendants. (Prior code § 1.28.100)

 

1.20.110 Plea of guilty—Hearing by court.
    If any person accused of violating any of the provisions of the Charter or ordinances of the City, having a right of trial by jury for such alleged violation thereof, confesses him or herself guilty, the Municipal Court, without a jury, shall hear the evidence relating to such violation and fix and determine the punishment or penalty, and shall enter judgment and issue execution thereon. (Prior code § 1.28.110)

 

1.20.120 Jurors’ fees.
    Jurors shall receive for attending Municipal Court three dollars ($3.00) per day, to be paid out of the general fund of the City. (Prior code § 1.28.120)

Chapter 1.28 GENERAL PENALTY
1.28.010 Penalty for code violations.
    A.  Maximum General Penalty. Whenever in any provision in the Charter of Cañon City, or in this Code, or in any secondary code adopted by the City, or in any ordinance of the City that is not codified, or in any order, rule or regulation promulgated under the provisions of this Code, any act is prohibited, made or declared to be unlawful, an offense, a nuisance or a misdemeanor, any person who shall be convicted of the violation of any such provision shall be punished by a fine of not more than two thousand, six hundred, fifty dollars ($2,650.00), unless some other penalty is specifically provided therefor in such provision. A separate offense may be charged and a separate fine may be imposed upon conviction for each calendar day when any such violation occurs or continues to occur.

    B.   Annual Increases in Maximum Fine Amount. The limitation on Municipal Court fines set forth in Subsection A of this section shall be adjusted for inflation on January 1, 2014, and on January 1 of each year thereafter. As used in this Subsection B, “inflation” means the annual percentage change in the United States Department of Labor, Bureau of Labor Statistics, Consumer Price Index for Denver-Boulder, all items, all urban consumers, or its successor index.

    C.   Penalty for Proceeding Without a Required Valid License, Permit or Certificate. Any person who pursues any business, trade, or calling, or does any act for which a license, permit, or certificate is required, without holding or having a valid license, permit or certificate, is guilty of a misdemeanor, and upon conviction thereof, shall be punished by a fine that is not more than the maximum fine permitted under Subsection A of this section.

    D.  Person-All Inclusive Definition. As used in this Code, “person” shall mean and include a natural person, association, corporation, partnership, limited liability company and any other legal entity capable of owning, using, or occupying real property or of transacting business within the City, unless the context clearly indicates otherwise. (Ord. 17-2013 § 3; Ord. 15-1993 § 2)

Title 2 ADMINISTRATION AND PERSONNEL

Chapter 2.04 MAYOR AND COUNCIL
2.04.010 Council—Executive and administrative powers.
    All executive and administrative powers and duties of the City government, except those which have been delegated to the City Administrator pursuant to the Charter, Article IV, Sections 4 and 5, are vested in the Council; provided, also, that all powers and duties which have been delegated to the City Administrator shall also be vested in the Council during a vacancy in the office of City Administrator. (Prior code § 2.04.010)

 

2.04.020 Reservation of powers.
    A.  All legislative powers of the Council, approval of all bills, indebtedness and claims against the City, the granting or approval of all licenses, permits, contracts, agreements, obligations and instruments on behalf of the City, and all powers not included in or incidental to the powers and authority specifically set forth in Section 2.04.010, are reserved to the Council.

    B.   There are also excepted and reserved to the Mayor and other City officers all of the executive and administrative powers, authority and duties granted such officers by the City Charter or incidental thereto, and which may not be delegated by the Council to the City Administrator according to the City Charter. (Prior code § 2.04.020)

 

2.04.040 Compensation.
    A.  The compensation payable by the City to the Mayor shall be the annual sum of nine thousand dollars ($9,000.00), payable in installments on and according to the City’s schedule of regular pay days.

    B.   The compensation payable by the City to all other members of City Council shall be the annual sum of six thousand dollars ($6,000.00), payable in installments on and according to the City’s schedule of regular pay days. (Ord. 14-2017 § 1; Ord. 41-1999 § 1; Ord. 34-1995 § 1)

 

2.04.045 Ceremonial functions—Authority of the Mayor.
    The Mayor shall have the power and authority to perform ceremonial functions that are in keeping with the proper conduct of the affairs of the City. Such powers shall include the power to solemnize marriages and to complete and sign marriage certificate forms in accordance with the requirements of applicable Colorado statutes, including but not necessarily limited to Section 14-2-109, C.R.S. (Ord. 15-2012 § 1)

 

2.04.050 Council meetings—Time—Place—Special meetings.
    A.  Except as provided in subsection B of this section, the City Council shall hold regular meetings on the first and third Monday of each month, commencing at the hour of six p.m.

    B.   Rescheduling of Regular Meetings.

    1.   Whenever the date of a regular meeting shall fall on the date for the national celebration of Martin Luther King, Jr. Day, such meeting shall not be held on Monday, but shall be held on the following Tuesday, commencing at the hour of six p.m.

    2.   Except as provided in subsection (B)(1) of this section, whenever the date of a regular meeting shall fall on a legal holiday, such meeting may be held on such holiday, if determined by the Council to be appropriate. Otherwise, the meeting shall be rescheduled and held on the following Tuesday at the hour of six p.m.

    3.   Whenever the date of a regular meeting conflicts with another event deemed significant, Council may, by resolution, adopted by at least a two-thirds majority of the full Council, change the date of a regular meeting from a Monday to the following Tuesday; provided, that a copy of such resolution is published in a newspaper of general circulation in the city not sooner than twenty-five (25) days nor later than twenty (20) days prior to the date of the rescheduled regular meeting.

    C.   All regular or special meetings of the City Council shall be held in the Council room at the Cañon City Municipal Building, unless the Mayor, or three (3) Councilmembers acting jointly, designates that a meeting shall be held at a different location. If a meeting is held at a different location, notice thereof shall be posted on the front door of the municipal building on or before the date and time of such meeting.

    D.  Special meetings of the Council may be called by three (3) Councilmembers acting jointly, or by the Mayor or Mayor pro tem in the absence of the Mayor, with the concurrence of three (3) Councilmembers; provided, that notice of any such special meeting shall be given to all Councilmembers who have not concurred in the calling of the meeting at least twenty-four (24) hours before such meeting. Such notice may be given by letter or written message delivered to the home of a Councilmember or by personal telephone communication to a Councilmember. (Ord. 20-2012 § 1; Ord. 9-2000 § 1; Ord. 43-1993 § 1; Ord. 3-1990 § 1)

 

2.04.060 Council meetings—Administrator authority.
    The City Administrator shall have charge of the Council room and shall attend the meetings of the Council. (Prior code § 2.04.150)

 

2.04.070 Council meetings—Duties of Mayor and Mayor pro tem.
    The Mayor shall be the chief executive officer of the City and ex-officio president of the Council, and shall preside at all meetings of the Council when present. The Mayor shall vote upon all questions in case of a tie, but not otherwise. When the Mayor shall be out of the city or unable to act because of disability, the Mayor pro tem shall exercise the same powers, authority and duties as the Mayor. The Mayor pro tem shall preside when the Mayor does not attend a meeting of the Council but, unlike the Mayor, the Mayor pro tem shall have the right and obligation to vote on all matters presented during any meeting of the Council at which the Mayor pro tem presides. (Ord. 22-2007 § 3; Ord. 3-1990 § 2)

 

2.04.080 Council meetings—Rules of order.
    A.  The maintenance of order, rules of procedure and order of business in all respects not specifically provided in this chapter shall be in accordance with rules that the Council may from time to time adopt.

    B.   Robert’s Rules shall govern all questions not determined by this chapter or rules of Council adopted pursuant to this section.

    C.   The rules of order of Council shall be strictly adhered to by the Council, and shall be amended or suspended only by a two-thirds vote of the members present. (Ord. 3-1990 § 3)

 

2.04.090 Order of business.
    At the hour appointed for meeting, the members shall be called to order and the City Clerk shall proceed to call the roll, note the absentees, and announce whether a quorum is present. Upon the appearance of a quorum, the Council shall then continue with the business before them, which shall be conducted in the following order:

    A.  First, the Council shall correct and approve the minutes of the last preceding meeting. The reading of the minutes shall be dispensed with if a copy thereof has been made available to each member of the Council at least two (2) days prior to the meeting at which the same shall be approved, and if copies thereof are available for public inspection in the Council chambers at the time of the meeting.

    B.   Second, the Council shall adopt, with or without amendment, the agenda for the meeting. The agenda shall be prepared in advance of the meeting by the Mayor, with the assistance of the City Administrator and the City Clerk.

    C.   Third, Council shall proceed with the rest of the business pursuant to the agenda that has been adopted. (Ord. 3-1990 § 4)

 

2.04.110 Addressing the chair.
    Any member desirous of speaking shall address the presiding officer, but shall not proceed further until recognized and named by the presiding officer. (Ord. 3-1990 § 6)

 

2.04.120 Precedence of motions.
    When a question is under debate, no motion shall be received but to adjourn, to lay on the table, for the previous question, to postpone to a day certain, to commit, to amend, or to postpone indefinitely, which several motions shall have precedence in the order in which they are arranged. (Prior code § 2.04.110)

 

2.04.130 Quorum.
    Four (4) members of the Council constitute a quorum to do business at all meetings of the Council, but a minority may adjourn from day to day and compel the attendance of the absent members by any lawful means. (Prior code § 2.04.060)

 

2.04.140 Voting procedure—Open voting and when voting may be excused.
    A.  With respect to all matters requiring formal action, all votes of City Council must be by roll call or by another means which clearly identifies the vote of each member and results in the announcement and recording of each such vote.

    B.   Every Councilmember, and in case of a tie, the Mayor, shall be required to vote on all matters presented, unless such person believes he has a conflict of interest or potential conflict of interest with regard to the action under consideration, whereupon the person shall state the reason he does not believe his or her vote should be cast, in which case the remainder of the Council shall determine whether or not such person should be excused from voting. (Ord. 22-2007 § 1; Ord. 3-1990 § 7)

 

2.04.150 Preservation of order.
    The Mayor or person presiding shall preserve order and decide questions of order, subject to an appeal to the Council. The City Attorney shall act as parliamentarian to the Mayor and Council. (Ord. 3-1990 § 8)

 

2.04.160 Standing committees.
    A.  The Council may establish, by ordinance or resolution, standing committees of Council. Such committees shall be created and function with regard to matters involving the operation of City government and the provision of City services to the public.

    B.   At the time the Council establishes standing committees of Council, it shall specify the duties of each committee and determine the number of Councilmembers to sit upon each committee. The Mayor shall be an ex-officio and voting member of each standing committee. (Ord. 3-1990 § 9)

 

2.04.170 Study committees.
    A.  The Mayor, on his or her own initiative, or when directed to do so by Council action, may establish special committees for the purpose of studying specific issues.

    B.   Study committees may be composed of both Councilmembers and such other members as the Mayor may designate. In establishing such committees, the Mayor, and in the case of committees established at the direction of Council, the Council, shall set forth the general duties of each committee so established. (Ord. 3-1990 § 9)

 

2.04.180 Appointment and reports of committees.
    All committees shall be appointed by the Mayor. Committees shall report in writing when so ordered by the Council, and all written reports shall be addressed “To the City Council of the City of Cañon City.” (Prior code § 2.04.130)

 

2.04.190 Appointments to offices.
    In all instances where Council is required by Article V, Section 2 of the Charter of the City of Cañon City to make appointments to office, the majority of the Council shall be necessary for such appointment. (Ord. 22-2007 § 2; Ord. 3-1990 § 10)

Chapter 2.08 CITY ADMINISTRATOR
2.08.010 Authority, powers and duties.
    Pursuant to the authority vested in it by Section 5 of Article IV and Section 5 of Article VI of the Charter of Cañon City, the Council delegates to the City Administrator the following authority, powers and duties, and defines the authority, powers, and duties of the City Administrator as follows:

    A.  To appoint and remove all employees of the City; provided, that city appointive and legislative officers, members of the Planning Commission, members of the board of adjustment, members of the library association or its board of directors, and members of any other board or bureau serving the City without pay, shall not be considered employees of the City within the meaning of this chapter. All appointments as made shall be made subject to salary or wage limitations fixed by the Council;

    B.   To act as chief conservator of the peace, and to supervise the enforcement of all city ordinances and all penal and administrative laws of the state and United States to the extent that the City is required so to do or permitted so to do in the proper administration of city government;

    C.   To supervise all administrative departments and all other departments for which he appoints the heads or directors;

    D.  To keep the Council advised of the immediate financial and administrative needs of the City, and from time to time of the anticipated or future needs of the City;

    E.   To make such recommendations to the Council concerning the affairs of the City as may appear to him to improve the administration of city affairs;

    F.   To prepare and submit to the Council such reports as it may require;

    G.  To supervise all inspections required under city ordinances or the laws of Colorado;

    H.  To abate all nuisances, except in cases where this authority shall conflict with the authority of any other city officer or a state officer or board having exclusive jurisdiction in the matter;

    I.    To supervise the care and maintenance of all buildings and structures owned or controlled by the City, and of all public streets, avenues, boulevards, alleys, bridges, viaducts, sidewalks, curbs and gutters, and thoroughfares, and all construction thereof, and all improvements and repairs thereto;

    J.    To supervise the operation, care and maintenance of cemeteries owned or controlled by the City;

    K.  To supervise the operation, care and maintenance of all public parks of the City;

    L.   To supervise and control the care, maintenance and operation of the City waterworks and water system, and to supervise the construction, alteration or repair of any facility in the waterworks and water system;

    M.  To supervise the planting, care and maintenance of shade trees, shrubbery and lawns in public thoroughfares, public parks, and property owned or controlled by the City;

    N.  To supervise all public utilities operating in the city, or furnishing any service, commodity or convenience to the inhabitants of the City, insofar as they are subject to control by the City under its Charter or ordinances;

    O.  To be chief custodian of all personal property belonging to the City or which it may hold in trust, and to make such periodic inventories and account thereof to the City Council or other board, officer or employee of the City as the Council may by ordinance or resolution direct; to prevent, as far as he is able to do so, the misuse, misappropriation and destruction of such property; and to require the heads of the departments and other officers and employees of the City to account to him periodically for all property entrusted to their use and care; provided, that he shall not be personally liable to the City for any loss to the City because of the destruction, misuse or misappropriation of any such property, nor in case of theft or embezzlement thereof;

    P.   To prepare annually the City budget in accordance with the system and classification of accounts maintained by the Director of Finance, as such system and classification shall be prescribed by the City Council;

    Q.  To present to the Council or to such employees or officer as the Council may direct, all payrolls, bills and claims of every nature against the City, and see to it that the proper requisitions and vouchers are tendered and the required approval of the proper department head or officer procured before the same shall be submitted;

    R.   To make such investigation and inquiry with respect to payrolls, bills and claims against the City before presenting them to the Council, as may be proper and necessary to determine the validity thereof;

    S.   Subject to approval of the Council by resolution duly adopted, to establish administrative departments of the City, and make changes in the administrative departments of the City, as he may consider necessary to a proper and orderly administration of the City’s affairs;

    T.   Acting by or through the Director of Finance and in conjunction with such officer, to collect all moneys due and owing to the City, and, when authorized by the Council so to do, to institute such suits and proceedings for the collection thereof as may be necessary for that purpose;

    U.  To draw and sign all warrants issued on behalf of the City authorized by the Council, provided that the Director of Finance shall countersign the same, pursuant to Section 3, Article VII of the Charter;

    V.  To purchase all supplies and materials, and to purchase, rent or lease all equipment, machines and apparatuses needed in the administration of the City’s affairs, subject to budgetary limitations and subject to Section 3, Article VII of the Charter and any other provisions of the Charter in that regard;

    W.  To perform every function and duty and exercise every power which may be required of or granted to him by the Council by motion or resolution incidental to the functions, duties and powers above set forth. (Ord. 3-1990 § 11; prior code § 2.08.010)

 

2.08.020 Bond required.
    The City Administrator shall give bond, executed by a reliable corporate security in such amount as the Council may by resolution determine, that he will well and faithfully perform the duties of his office and shall account for and turn over all money, property, books and records of the City coming to his hands. The cost of such bond shall be borne by the City. (Ord. 3-1990 § 12)

 

2.08.030 Attendance at Council meetings.
    The City Administrator shall attend all Council meetings. (Prior code § 2.08.020)

 

2.08.040 Assignment of employees and equipment.
    The City Administrator shall have the authority and it shall be his duty to use employees and equipment in one department in prosecuting work in another department, and to assign employees to part-time work in two or more departments, providing proper charges shall be made against each department of the costs attributable to the work performed in each department. (Prior code § 2.08.030)

Chapter 2.12 CITY CLERK
2.12.010 Office established—Appointment.
    There shall be the office of the City Clerk, the head of which shall be the City Clerk, appointed and removable by the City Administrator subject to the consent of the City Council. (Prior code § 2.64.010)

 

2.12.020 Bond required.
    The City Clerk shall give a bond, issued by a reputable corporate surety in such amount as the Council may by resolution determine, that he will well and faithfully perform the duties of his office, and shall account for and turn over all moneys, property, books, investments and records of the City coming into his hands. The cost of such bond shall be borne by the City. (Prior code § 2.64.030)

 

2.12.030 Powers and duties.
    The City Clerk shall have the authority and be required to:

    A.  Keep suitable records of the proceedings of the Council, in which shall appear a record of all ordinances, resolutions, motions and actions of the Council;

    B.   Attend to the publication of ordinances and to the posting, publishing (when required), and the giving of all notices required to be given of ordinances, statements, expenditures, budgets, elections and other city matters wherein notice of any kind is required to be given;

    C.   Attest and affix the seal of the City to all deeds, bonds, coupons, contracts, licenses and other instruments and documents, when required or directed by the City Council;

    D.  Perform such duties with respect to the City elections as may be provided for in the Charter of the City and the ordinances and resolutions of the Council, the laws of the state of Colorado, and the Constitution of the state;

    E.   Be responsible for the safekeeping of all documents and records as required by the Charter, ordinances and resolutions of the City, and by the laws of the state of Colorado;

    F.   Be responsible for the issuance and recording of deeds for cemetery plots and for recording burial information from the City cemeteries;

    G.  Transcribe minutes of the Council and aid in the preparation of the Council agendas;

    H.  Issue all permits and licenses of the City, unless otherwise authorized by ordinance or resolution;

    I.    Attend all meetings of the City Council of Cañon City;

    J.    Perform such other duties as the City Administrator or Council from time to time may determine. (Prior code § 2.64.020)

Chapter 2.16 FINANCE DEPARTMENT
2.16.010 Department established—Director.
    There shall be a Department of Finance, the head of which shall be the Director of Finance, appointed and removable by the City Administrator subject to the consent of the City Council. (Prior code § 2.16.010)

 

2.16.020 Director of Finance—Bond.
    The Director of Finance shall furnish a bond, issued by a reputable corporate surety in such amount as the Council may by resolution determine, that he will well and faithfully perform the duties of his office, and shall account for and turn over all moneys, property, books, investments and records of the City coming to his hands. The cost of such bond shall be borne by the City. (Prior code § 2.16.040)

 

2.16.030 Director of Finance—Powers and duties.
    The Director of Finance shall have the authority and be required to:

    A.  Carry out the responsibilities and direct the activities of the Department of Finance;

    B.   Maintain financial records or accounts of budgeted items of revenue and appropriation, setting forth, among other things, the budgeted amount, expenditures therefrom or receipts thereto, the appropriation, the encumbered balance and the unencumbered balance, and such other information as the City Administrator or Council may direct;

    C.   Keep such moneys in such separate funds and in such depositories as may be required by the Charter of the City and by the ordinances and resolutions passed or adopted by the City Council consistent with the Charter;

    D.  Submit monthly, or from time to time as may be directed by the City Administrator or the Council, such statements of accounts and funds, including trust, pension and custodial funds, in such detail as the City Administrator or Council may direct;

    E.   Prepare annually at the end of each calendar year a current financial statement and report for the fiscal year then ended, in such detail as the City Administrator or the Council may determine, and to assist in the annual independent audit of the financial records of the City;

    F    Prepare, and certify to the appropriate authority, notices of such sums due and owing the City for items which the City has the authority to assess specially, and prepare and certify, or cause to be certified, such notices of taxes, mill levies, and special assessments as may be required by ordinance, the City Charter, or the laws of the state of Colorado;

    G.  Receive and receipt for all funds due the City from the treasurer of Fremont County, any agencies of the state of Colorado, or the United States, and to collect such other taxes, special assessments, fees and other revenues due the City;

    H.  Maintain custody of all funds and any pension moneys and assets under the jurisdiction of the City and of any office, department or agency of the City, and to deposit, invest and reinvest such moneys and funds as the Council or appropriate board or agency shall designate, subject always to the requirements of law relating to the investments for municipalities in the state and the provisions of the City Charter, and the laws of the state, and to make such reports of such investments and the income therefrom as the City Administrator or Council may direct;

    1.   Maintain the employment records for all employees and officials of the City;

    J.    Determine and prescribe the forms for city bills, vouchers, purchase orders, etc., to be issued by the offices, departments and agencies of the City, and the manner of keeping such records by the offices, departments and agencies of the City which are necessary for the proper operation of the Department of Finance;

    K.  Sign or countersign all city warrants and checks except as otherwise provided by City Charter, ordinance, or by directives of the Council;

    L.   To present to the Council, or to such employees or officers as the Council may direct, all payrolls, bills and claims of every nature against the City, and see to it that the proper requisitions and vouchers are tendered and the required approval of the proper department head or officer procured, before the same shall be submitted;

    M.  Make such investigation and inquiry with respect to payrolls, bills and claims against the City before presenting them to the Council or City Administrator as may be proper and necessary to determine the validity thereof;

    N.  Perform such other duties as the City Administrator or Council from time to time may determine;

    O.  Attend all regular meetings of the Council of Cañon City. (Prior code § 2.16.020)

 

2.16.040 Director of Finance—Other powers.
    The Director of Finance shall have access at all reasonable times to all papers, books, files, records and documents in any of the offices and departments of the City which are necessary for the performance of his duties as Director of Finance, and may require such reports from the officers and employees of the City relative to expenditures, purchases, purchase orders and receipts of funds on behalf of the City as may be necessary in the performance of his duties as Director of Finance. (Prior code § 2.16.030(A))

 

2.16.050 Director of Finance—Liability limitations.
    The Director of Finance shall not be liable for any losses resulting from any investments or deposits made at the direction of the Council, and he shall not be liable to the City for loss of any moneys or securities due to larceny or embezzlement by any person or persons other than himself. (Prior code § 2.16.030(B))

Chapter 2.20 FIRE AUTHORITY
2.20.010 Fire Department replaced by fire authority.
    The Cañon City Fire Department was superseded by the Cañon City district fire authority pursuant to an intergovernmental agreement with the Cañon City area fire protection district dated September 11, 1985. (Ord. 3-1990 § 13)

 

2.20.020 Appointments to fire authority board.
    A.  Appointments to the fire authority board of directors shall be made by the Mayor.

    B.   The city’s representatives to the board of directors of the Cañon City district fire authority may be removed by the Mayor or by a majority of the Council without cause. If removed by a majority of Council, such person shall not be reappointed to the board by the Mayor unless a majority of the Council concurs. (Ord. 3-1990 § 13)

Chapter 2.28 LAW DEPARTMENT
2.28.010 Department established—City Attorney appointment.
    There shall be a department of law, the head of which shall be the City Attorney appointed and removable by the Council as provided by the Charter, Article V, Sections 1 to 3. He shall have the qualifications prescribed by the Charter, Article VI, Section 3. (Prior code § 2.32.010)

 

2.28.020 City Attorney—Powers and duties.
    The City Attorney shall have the powers and duties prescribed by the Charter, Article VI, Section 1, and any other powers and duties prescribed by the Charter or ordinance. (Ord. 21-1987 § 2: prior code § 2.32.020)

Chapter 2.40 CITY ENGINEER
2.40.010 City Engineer—Appointment.
    There shall be a City Engineer who shall be appointed and removable by the City Administrator. (Ord. 3-1990 § 17)

 

2.40.020 City Engineer—Duties.
    The City Engineer shall perform such duties as the City Administrator shall, from time to time, prescribe, and such other duties as may be required by the Charter, the Cañon City Code or by law. (Ord. 3-1990 § 17)

Chapter 2.44 WATER DEPARTMENT
2.44.010 Department established—Powers and duties.
    There shall be a Water Department of the City which shall comprise raw water supplies and water rights, filtration plant, machinery, equipment and supplies, the distribution system of potable water, all pumps and pump housing, transmission lines, mains, and that portion of the service lines defined in Chapter 13.04 of this Code, all records, and plat books now maintained or to be maintained, together with all of the appurtenances of any of the equipment and machinery heretofore described and all rights-of-way and easements which have been acquired for purposes of conducting raw water supplies to the filtration plant and the distribution of potable water to water users. (Prior code § 2.40.010)

 

2.44.020 Water Superintendent authority.
    The head of the Water Department shall be the Water Superintendent, who shall be appointed by the City Administrator and is hereby designated as an employee of the City as such term is defined in the Charter. The City Administrator shall be responsible for the proper operation, management and control of the Water Department. (Prior code § 2.40.020)

 

2.44.030 Warrant required for access to premises.
    Except during emergency situations or where the consent of the property owner has been obtained, entrance upon residential property and the nonpublic portions of commercial property may be made by the City only pursuant to a search warrant. (Ord. 21-1987 § 3: prior code § 2.40.030)

Chapter 2.48 PLANNING COMMISSION
2.48.010 Authorization.
    There is authorized by this chapter in accordance with Section 31-23-202, C.R.S., the Cañon City Planning Commission. Except as superseded or modified by this chapter, the provisions of Parts 2 and 3, Article 23, Title 31, C.R.S., shall be applicable to the Planning Commission. (Ord. 24-2001 § 1)

 

2.48.020 Purpose.
    The purpose of the Planning Commission is to assist, advise and coordinate with the City Council with respect to the comprehensive study and review of issues relative to the planning, zoning and growth of the municipality, as more specifically set forth in this Chapter and as provided in additional ordinances, rules and regulations of the City promulgated by the City Council. The Planning Commission shall encourage coordinated and harmonious development of the municipality in accordance with the master plan, zoning ordinance and subdivision regulations of the City. (Ord. 24-2001 § 1)

 

2.48.030 Powers.
    A.  The Planning Commission shall be empowered and authorized to review, act upon and advise the City Council with respect to all zoning, rezoning, planning, subdividing, platting, annexation and other related activities as provided in the zoning and subdivision ordinances and regulations of the City.

    B.   The Planning Commission is empowered to make and submit to the City Council for the Council’s approval a master plan, and any comprehensive amendments thereto, for the physical development of the municipality. The Planning Commission shall initiate a comprehensive review of the master plan no less often than once annually. The master plan for the City and its environs shall contain the Planning Commission’s recommendations with respect to the following matters:

    1.   A comprehensive zoning and subdivision ordinance together with a zoning plan;

    2.   Appropriate plans showing the general location, character and extent of streets, bridges, boulevards, parkways and other types of transportation corridors within and without the City and its environs;

    3.   A plan for the location and extent of public utilities, including, but not limited to, water and sewer development, public communications, gas and electrical extensions, together with the location and extent of other public improvements to be created within the city, such as parks, Fire Departments, police stations, schools and other public buildings;

    4.   Any and all plans for the eventual redesignation of specific areas within the community, condemnation plans, change of use plans or other alterations regarding the existing community structure.

    C.   The Planning Commission is empowered with any and all further powers delineated within Part 2, Article 23, Title 31, CRS. and any and all of the powers and duties granted to a municipal zoning commission within Part 3, Article 23, Title 31, CRS. (Ord. 24-2001 § 1)

 

2.48.040 Duties.
    It shall be the duty of the Planning Commission to proceed expeditiously in accordance with the purposes and powers enumerated in this chapter, to communicate, coordinate and advise the City Council of its activities and accomplishments, to hold public meetings in conjunction therewith, to promulgate its own internal rules and regulations that are not in conflict with the charter and ordinances of the City, and to provide a public forum for discourse and proceedings concerning the further development and orderly growth of the City. (Ord. 24-2001 § 1)

 

2.48.050 Membership.
    A.  1.        The Planning Commission shall consist of eight members, each of whom shall be appointed by City Council. Seven “public members” shall be residents of the City who are not members of City Council or city planning staff. Public members shall be entitled to vote on all matters coming before the commission and shall be counted when the presence of a quorum is to be determined;

    2.   The eighth member of the Planning Commission shall be a member of City Council and be designated a “municipal member.” The municipal member shall have no voting rights and shall not be counted when the presence of a quorum is to be determined.

    B.   All members of the commission shall serve as such without compensation, and the public members shall hold no other municipal office. Any public member of the commission may also be a member of the zoning board of adjustment.

    C.   All members of the commission shall be bona fide residents of the City at the time of appointment, and the discontinuance of residency shall immediately terminate membership.

    D.  The municipal member shall be appointed to a one-year term each July and serve until July 1st of the following year; provided that if such municipal member’s term on the City Council ends prior to the expiration of such term, the municipal member’s position shall become vacant immediately and be filled as provided in Section 2.48.060(A).

    E.   Initially, the terms of all public members shall begin upon their appointment in 2001, following the adoption of the ordinance codified in this chapter, provided that: the terms of two such public members shall expire on July 1, 2002; the terms of two such public members shall expire on July 1, 2003; and the terms of three such public members shall expire on July 1, 2004. Thereafter, the terms of all public members will be three years and, in succession, each such term shall expire on July 1st of that year which is three years from the date upon which the term began.

    F.   Members, including the municipal member, may be removed, after public hearing before the City Council, for inefficiency, neglect of duty, or malfeasance in office, in which case the Council shall file a written statement of the reasons for the removal of such member. (Ord. 24-2001 § 1)

 

2.48.060 Selection.
    A.  Any vacancy occurring other than through the expiration of the term of a member shall be filled for the remainder of the unexpired term by appointment by the City Council. Any such appointment shall be made within ninety days following the creation of the vacancy.

    B.   Vacancies created by term expiration shall be filled by appointment by the City Council prior to July 15th of the year during which the vacancy occurred. The expiration of a term shall create a vacancy, without regard to whether the incumbent wishes to be reappointed.

    C.   When a vacancy to be filled under Subsection A of this section pertains to the unexpired term of a public member, notice seeking applications of qualified persons desiring to serve out the balance of such term shall be solicited at least thirty days prior to the date upon which the appointment to the vacant position is to be made.

    D.  Whenever the terms of public members are set to expire, requests for applications to fill the vacancies on the commission that will be created by the expiration of such terms shall be published no sooner than sixty nor fewer than thirty days prior to the expiration of such terms. Incumbent public members of the commission whose terms are set to expire may apply and be considered for reappointment. (Ord. 24-2001 § 1)

 

2.48.070 Chairperson.
    The Planning Commission shall elect from its public members a chairperson for a one-year term of office, for the purpose of officiating at meetings of the Planning Commission. The chairperson shall retain his or her voting rights. (Ord. 24-2001 § 1)

 

2.48.080 Meetings.
    The Planning Commission shall schedule and hold, whenever there is business to come before the commission, regular public meetings, not less often than once per calendar month. No official meeting shall take place unless a quorum is present. When a quorum is not present, a majority of those public members who are present may authorize the chairperson to continue the meeting to a date certain, but shall conduct no other business. A majority vote of the public members entitled to vote at a meeting where a quorum is present shall be required for all approvals, recommendations and other official actions of the commission. The commission may adopt rules of procedure for its meetings, which shall constitute official protocol. (Ord. 24-2001 § 1)

 

2.48.090 Rules.
    The Planning Commission may adopt rules which shall be binding upon its members. (Ord. 24-2001 § 1)

 

2.48.100 Record keeping.
    The Planning Commission shall maintain a record of its resolutions, transactions, findings, determinations, recommendations and other activities, which record regularly shall be presented to and reviewed by the City Council. The record shall be maintained for public inspection during normal working hours at the municipal office for the City. (Ord. 24-2001 § 1)

 

2.48.110 Advisory capacity.
    Except as specifically may be provided to the contrary in the City’s zoning ordinance, Title 17 of this Code, all recommendations, decisions, determinations, zoning and master plans, regulations, ordinance drafting and other actions taken by the Planning Commission are advisory in nature to the City Council, and as such shall neither be binding upon the City Council nor subject to judicial review. In all instances wherein Parts 1, 2 and 3, Article 23, Title 31, CRS, vest the planning or zoning commission with specific powers to make final decisions, this chapter shall prevail and all such actions shall constitute recommendations and advice to the City Council, rather than final actions. Planning commission recommendations that are made in accordance with the requirements of the City’s Charter, ordinances and regulations shall be given great weight by the City Council. (Ord. 24-2001 § 1)

 

2.48.115 Planning staff.
    A.  The city shall furnish for all regular and special meetings of the Planning Commission, and for all workshops if requested in advance by the chairperson, a recording secretary who shall: call the roll; tally and record all votes; prepare the official minutes of the commission; and maintain such official minutes and all other official records of proceedings before the Planning Commission.

    B.   The City Planner, under the direction of the City Administrator, shall provide technical and advisory support to the commission as one of the City Planner’s primary duties.

    C.   Other members of the City’s professional staff, including but not necessarily limited to the City Engineer and City Attorney, shall be made available by the City to provide reasonable and routine assistance to the commission. The level and extent of their participation shall be as determined by the City Administrator, who shall take into account the requests and expectations of the commission and its chairperson when making such determinations.

    D.  The commission may request and the City may agree to provide outside professional consultants to assist the commission when circumstances warrant. (Ord. 24-2001 § 1)

 

2.48.120 Scope of chapter.
    This chapter designates the purposes, powers and duties of the Planning Commission. The provisions of the statutory authority shall be applicable only in the instance of silence of this chapter, or where the general intent of the Legislature as to scope and authority deemed proper for a Planning Commission can lend meaningful direction and assistance in the interpretation of this chapter. (Ord. 24-2001 § 1)

Chapter 2.52 APPEALS OF ADMINISTRATIVE DECISIONS
2.52.010 Appeal rights and procedures.
    A.  City Council. Appeals to the City Council shall be made as set out in this subsection. Appeals to City Council are only authorized when expressly provided for in this section.

    1.   Any aggrieved person, upon receipt of written notice of the determination or decision of an administrative official may, in writing, and within thirty (30) days after receiving such notice, request a hearing on the matter before the City Council when specifically authorized to do so by this section. The City Clerk shall notify the appellants in writing, return receipt requested or by electronic mail, at least ten (10) days prior to the hearing date of the time and date of the hearing, to be held not more than thirty (30) days from receipt of the notice. The decision of the City Council upon such hearing shall be final, subject to judicial review.

    2.   Such request for hearing shall contain at least the following:

    a.   A brief statement of the order or action being appealed;

    b.   A brief statement of any material facts supporting the appeal;

    c.   A brief statement of the relief being sought (i.e., the order or action should be reversed, modified, or otherwise set aside) and why the relief should be granted; and

    d.   The signatures of all persons appealing the decisions and their mailing addresses.

    B.   Appeals to Board of Adjustment. Appeals to the Board of Adjustment shall be made in accordance with Section 17.36.050 of this Code.

    C.   Appeals to City Administrator. Appeals to the City Administrator shall be made as set out in this subsection.

    1.   Any aggrieved person, upon receipt of written notice of the determination or decision of an administrative official may, in writing, and within ten (10) days after receiving such notice, submit a written request for appeal to the City Administrator when specifically authorized to do so by this Code.

    2.   Such request for appeal shall contain at least the following:

    a.   A brief statement of the order or action being appealed;

    b.   A brief statement of any material facts supporting the appeal;

    c.   A brief statement of the relief being sought (i.e., the order or action should be reversed, modified, or otherwise set aside) and why the relief should be granted; and

    d.   The signatures of all persons appealing the decision and their mailing addresses.

    D.  Failure of any person to file a timely appeal in accordance with the provisions of this section shall constitute a waiver of the right to an appeal.

    E.   Only those matters or issues specifically raised in the written appeal shall be considered by the appellate body or official.

    F.   The decisions of the City Council, Board of Adjustment, and City Administrator shall be made in writing, and shall contain findings of fact and any conditions within thirty (30) days after the hearing or decision, as applicable. A copy of the decision shall be sent, return receipt requested or by electronic mail, to the appealing party and the administrative body or official of the City whose decision has been the subject of the appeal. (Ord. 18-2020 § 2)

 

2.52.020 Application of chapter provisions.
    The provisions of this chapter shall supersede all other appeal procedures provided for elsewhere in either the ordinances of the City or any codes adopted by the City by reference or otherwise.
