The procedures provided for in this chapter are not applicable to matters addressed in the personnel regulations of the City, including grievances and interpretation of agreements between the City and its employees, which matters must be determined through the grievance procedures prior to any employee appealing any employment decision to the City Council or the courts. (Prior code § 2.60.020)

Chapter 2.56 EMPLOYEES’ PENSIONS
2.56.020 Social Security insurance coverage for City personnel.
    The City is authorized to execute and deliver to the Department of Employment Security of the state a plan or plans and agreement required under Colorado Revised Statutes 1973 Section 24-51-704, and the Social Security Act, to extend coverage to employees and officers of the City and to do and perform any and all necessary acts or things necessary to effectuate coverage of employees and officers under the Old Age and Survivors’ Insurance System. (Prior code § 2.48.030)

 

2.56.030 Social Security contributions—Payroll deductions.
    The Director of Finance is authorized to establish a system of payroll deductions to be matched by payments of the City to be made into the contribution fund of the Social Security Act through the Department of Employment Security, and to make charges of this tax to the fund or funds from which wage or salary payments are paid and issued to employees of the City. Such payments shall be made in accordance with the provisions of Section 1400 of the Federal Insurance Contribution Act on all services which constitute employment within the meaning of that Act. Payments shall be made to the Department of Employment Security of the state of Colorado, and shall be due and payable on or before the eighteenth day of the month immediately following the completed calendar quarter, and such payments as are delinquent shall bear interest at the rate of one-half percent per month until such time as payments are made. (Prior code § 2.48.040)

 

2.56.040 Social Security contributions—Appropriations.
    There is appropriated from the contingent fund and from any proper fund or funds hereafter established for this purpose of the City the necessary amount required to pay into the contribution fund as provided in Colorado Revised Statutes 1973, Section 24-51-702. (Prior code § 2.48.050)

 

2.56.050 Exclusions from chapter provisions.
    This chapter shall not affect or be applicable to any department of the City government of the City or the employees thereof which is now operating under or is subject to any retirement or pension plan now in operation under the laws of the state. (Prior code § 2.48.060)

Chapter 2.60 CITY PARKS/CITY CEMETERY
2.60.010 Parks Department—Superintendent.
    There shall be a Parks Department, the head of which shall be the Parks Superintendent appointed and removable by the City Administrator. The Parks Superintendent shall have supervision and control of all City parks, forestry, trees and City cemeteries. (Ord. 43-1988; prior code § 2.52.010)

 

2.60.020 Parks Superintendent—Duties.
    The Parks Superintendent shall have charge of, maintain, and improve all parks, community forest, and the cemeteries owned by the City. The Parks Superintendent shall provide for supervision and care, irrigation, weeding, provide for repair, and shall do all such work about the City parks, community trees, and cemeteries as the City Administrator shall require. The Parks Superintendent shall issue permits and administer tests and inspections as required by ordinance. He or she shall hold him or herself in readiness to dig and prepare graves for all who may apply with the proper certificate of death and permit, and shall have graves in readiness for the appointed time of burial, provided, he or she shall enforce the rules and regulations adopted for the parks, forestry, and cemeteries as adopted from time to time by the City Council. (Ord. 43-1988; prior code § 2.52.020)

 

2.60.030 Charges to be determined by resolution.
    The City Council shall, from time to time, by resolution, prescribe:

    A.  The amount to be charged for burial spaces, grave vaults, interment and disinterment, and other services related to use of the City cemeteries;

    B.   Rules and regulations regarding the time, place, and manner in which funerals and other activities are to be conducted in City cemeteries;

    C.   The fees, service charges, rental rates, and other amounts to be charged for use of City parks, Parks Department equipment, and facilities;

    D.  Reasonable regulations regarding the time, place, manner, and type of use to which City park facilities and equipment may be used. (Ord. 43-1988; prior code § 2.52.050)

 

2.60.040 Payment for grave space and interment.
    The full purchase price and all interment charges as prescribed by resolution of the City Council as provided by Section 2.52.050, for each grave space, shall be paid before any permanent monument, cross, emblem, or marker of any kind shall be placed upon such grave space. Any interment placed prior to full payment of cemetery fees is temporary, and this right shall not be acquired by the purchaser of the interment space until all amounts owing the City have been paid in full. Grave spaces reserved for future use may be purchased by payment within six months. (Ord. 43-1988; prior code § 2.52.040)

 

2.60.050 Report of Parks Superintendent—Fees.
    All charges for use of City park facilities or equipment, and all charges relating to burial and administration of the City cemeteries, shall be paid to the Director of Finance. The Parks Superintendent shall make a written report annually to the City Council of all graves dug and burials attended, of all charges and fees received for use of the City cemeteries, and of all moneys received as service charges or rental fees for use of the City park facilities or equipment. The Parks Superintendent shall file all certificates and permits relating to the Parks Department with the City Clerk. (Ord. 43-1988; prior code § 2.52.030)

 

2.60.060 Reconveyance or transfer of ownership of burial space(s).
    No person, institution, association or corporation being the owner of a burial space(s) in any cemetery owned by the City shall sell or convey the same to any other person, institution, association or corporation except: (1) after the lawful owner of the cemetery space(s) surrenders all original deeds to the City Clerk; or (2) to the City for a purchase price set by the Council and paid to the City for the same; or (3) after making application for transfer of burial space(s) at the City Clerk’s office and paying the transfer of ownership fee. Ownership is not transferable without approval of the City Clerk, payment of all appropriate fees and the reissuance of a new certificate of ownership or deed to the new owner, or (4) transfer of ownership may be effected by will or intestacy as provided for in Colorado Revised Statutes. Any transfer of ownership by will or applicable laws of intestacy shall be reported to the City Clerk with proof thereof and appropriate transfer fee paid. All changes in address of owners of grave spaces should be reported to the City Clerk. (Ord. 6-1990; Ord. 43-1988; prior code § 2.52.060)

 

2.60.070 Abandoned burial spaces.
    A.  Reversion. The ownership or right in or to any unoccupied cemetery burial space shall upon abandonment revert to the City of Cañon City.

    B.   Presumption. Failure to inter in any burial spaces after one hundred years from purchase, transfer or interment in adjacent spaces commonly owned, whichever is the later in time, shall create and establish a presumption that the same has been abandoned; except that this presumption shall not apply when a letter of intent is filed by the owner or heir in title with the City Clerk stating that he/she intends to keep specified spaces vacant.

    C.   Notice Required. Abandonment shall not be deemed complete unless the registered owners or their heirs or assigns shall be notified in writing, by certified mail, mailed to the last known or registered address, by the City Clerk. In the event that the address of the owner or his heirs cannot be ascertained, then notice of such abandonment shall be published two times in the City’s official newspaper at least once a week.

    D.  Failure to Reply. If the registered owner or his heirs or assigns fail to inform the City Clerk within sixty days after receipt of notice of abandonment or sixty days after final publication of such notice of intention to retain the burial spaces remaining, then abandonment shall become final and the City may thereafter sell, transfer and convey title thereto. Funds derived from any sale of abandoned space shall be deposited in their entirety into the perpetual care fund. (Ord. 6-1990)

Chapter 2.62 PROTECTION OF PALEONTOLOGICAL RESOURCES
2.62.010 Definitions.
    A.  For the purposes of this chapter:

    1.   “Collection” means a specimen and the associated records documenting the specimen and its recovery.

    2.   “Critical paleontological resources” mean vertebrate fossils and other exceptional fossils that are designated as paleontological landmarks.

    3.   “Curation” means:

    a.   Management and care of collections according to standard professional museum practice, which may include inventorying, accessing, labeling, cataloging, identifying, evaluating, documenting, storing, maintaining, periodically inspecting, cleaning, stabilizing, conserving, exhibiting, exchanging, or otherwise disposing of original collections or reproductions; and

    b.   Providing access to and facilities for studying collections.

    4.   “Curation facility” means the Museum or an accredited facility meeting federal curation standards that is designated by the Museum through a memorandum of agreement.

    5.   “Excavate” means the recovery of critical paleontological resources.

    6.   “Museum” means the Dinosaur Depot Museum and/or any other curation facility operated by the Garden Park Paleontology Society.

    7.   “Paleontological resources” mean remains of prehistoric life.

    8.   “Permit” means a permit for paleontological investigations, excavations and/or collections of critical paleontological resources on City-owned lands required and issued pursuant to the provisions of this Chapter 2.62.

    9.   “Repository” means an accredited facility meeting federal curation standards.

    10. “Site” means any paleontological deposit or other location that is the source of a specimen.

    11. “Specimen” means remains of a critical paleontological nature found on or below the surface of the earth. (Ord. 22-2011 § 1)

 

2.62.020 Permit required to excavate critical paleontological resources on lands owned or managed by the City of Cañon City—Removal of specimen or site.
    A.  Before excavating for critical paleontological resources on lands owned by the City of Cañon City, a person must obtain a permit from the City or its designee.

    B.   Application for a permit shall be made on a form approved by resolution of City Council and furnished by the City or its designee.

    C.   The City Council may, by resolution, make rules for the issuance of permits specifying or requiring:

    1.   The minimum permittee qualifications;

    2.   The duration of the permit;

    3.   Research designs that provide for the maximum recovery of scientific, paleontological, and educational information, in addition to the physical recovery of specimens and the reporting of paleontological information meeting current standards of scientific rigor;

    4.   The need, if any, to submit data obtained in the course of field investigation to the City or its designee;

    5.   Proof of consultation with a designated Museum representative regarding curation of collections; and

    6.   Other information the City or its designee considers necessary.

    D.  All paleontological work requiring a permit shall be carried out under the supervision of the permittee.

    E.   No person shall remove from City-owned property any specimen, site, or portion of a specimen or site without permission from the City.

    F.   Unless otherwise agreed in writing by the City, no specimen, site or portion of a specimen or site shall be removed to any place other than the Museum or a repository or curation facility designated or approved by the City. (Ord. 22-2011 § 1)

 

2.62.030 Policies concerning curation and the selection of curation facilities.
    A.  From time to time City Council shall adopt, by resolution, policies to ensure the adequate curation of all collections from lands owned by the City of Cañon City. It is anticipated that most such policies will be recommended by the Garden Park Paleontology Society. Such policies shall:

    1.   Conform to, but not limited by, federal curation policy; and

    2.   Recognize that if, at its discretion, the curation facility makes and sells reproductions derived from collections found on lands owned by the City of Cañon City, any revenues after recovering the cost of preparation for sale and a reasonable fee for handling the sale shall be remitted to the City of Cañon City.

    B.   Subject to the approval of City Council, by resolution, the Museum may enter into memoranda of agreement with other repositories to act as its designee for the curation of collections and may, at its discretion, delegate some or all of its authority to curate.

    C.   From time to time, City Council shall adopt, by resolution, policies and procedures for the selection of curation facilities authorized to curate critical paleontological resources discovered on land owned by the City. It is anticipated that most such policies will be recommended by the Garden Park Paleontology Society. Such policies shall consider:

    1.   Whether the permittee is a curation facility;

    2.   The proximity of the curation facility or repository to the point of origin of the collection;

    3.   The nature of the collection and the repository’s or curation facility’s ability and desire to curate the collection in question, and ability to maximize the scientific and educational benefits for the people of the city; and

    4.   Selection of a second curation facility or repository, if the original curation facility or repository becomes unable to curate the collections under its care. (Ord. 22-2011 § 1)

 

2.62.040 Curation and deposit of specimen.
    All collections recovered from lands owned by the City of Cañon City shall be deposited at the Museum, or at a curation facility or repository approved by the City within a reasonable time after completion of field work. (Ord. 22-2011 § 1)

 

2.62.050 Loaning of specimen.
    A.  The Museum and/or a repository or curation facility that has accepted a collection removed from City-owned property pursuant to the provisions of this chapter may make specimens available through loans to museums and research institutions when, in the opinion of the repository or curation facility:

    1.   The use of the specimens is appropriate; and

    2.   Arrangements are made for safe custodianship of the specimens. (Ord. 22-2011 § 1)

 

2.62.060 Paleontological landmarks.
    A.  Sites of significance or sites with exceptional fossils may be recommended to and approved by the City of Cañon City, by resolution, as paleontological landmarks.

    B.   No person without a valid permit issued pursuant to the provisions of this chapter shall conduct paleontological investigations and/or excavations on any site designated as a paleontological landmark.

    C.   Privately-owned sites within the city also may be designated as paleontological landmarks pursuant to written agreement between the landowner and the City. All such agreements shall provide that the site described in the agreement shall be treated as land owned by the City for purposes of the applicability and enforcement of this chapter.

    D.  No person may conduct paleontological investigations and/or excavations on a privately-owned designated landmark without a valid permit from the City and written permission from the owner of the land so designated. (Ord. 22-2011 § 1)

 

2.62.070 Fossil collection sites.
    A.  The City may identify and designate fossil collection sites on lands owned by the City of Cañon City where it is appropriate to encourage the collection of fossils by individuals, families or school groups for educational purposes. No permit shall be required with respect to paleontological investigations at such sites. Fossils other than specimens may be removed from such fossil collection sites and be kept by the individuals, groups or institutions that removed them.

    B.   Designated fossil collection sites shall not include critical paleontological resources or paleontological landmarks.

    C.   Designated fossil collection sites shall be interpreted with appropriate signage. (Ord. 22-2011 § 1)

 

2.62.080 Unlawful acts and penalties for violations.
    A.  It is unlawful for any person to excavate critical paleontological resources on lands owned by the City of Cañon City without first having obtained a valid permit issued pursuant to the provisions of this chapter.

    B.   It is unlawful for any person to remove critical paleontological resources from land owned by the City of Cañon City without first having obtained a valid permit issued pursuant to the provisions of this chapter.

    C.   It is unlawful for any person holding a valid permit issued pursuant to the provisions of this chapter to excavate for, remove, deposit or dispose of critical paleontological resources on or from lands owned by the City of Cañon City in a manner prohibited by the other provisions of this chapter or in violation of any requirement or limitation set forth in the permit issued to such person.

    D.  It is unlawful for any person to violate the provisions of Subsections 2.62.020(A), (D), (E) or (F).

    E.   It is unlawful for any person to violate the provisions of Section 2.62.040.

    F.   Excavations on lands owned by the City that have been designated paleontological landmarks pursuant to Section 2.62.060 shall be presumed to be excavations for critical paleontological resources and any specimens removed from such paleontological landmarks shall be presumed to be critical paleontological resources.

    G.  Any person who violates any provision of this Section 2.62.080, is guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon conviction thereof, shall be punished by a fine in an amount that does not exceed the maximum fine provided for in Section 1.28.010.

    H.  In addition to any fine or jail sentence imposed, the Municipal Court may order any person convicted of removing critical paleontological resources from lands owned by the City to deliver such resources to the Museum or some other repository or curation facility designated by the City. The failure of any convicted defendant to abide by any such order within the time provided by the Municipal Court shall be a violation of this chapter for which such person may be charged and, if convicted, punished as provided in Subsection G of this section. (Ord. 17-2013 § 4; Ord. 22-2011 § 1)

Chapter 2.64 LIBRARY/MUSEUM ADVISORY BOARD
2.64.005 Establishment and operation.
    A.  The Cañon City Public Library is the official Library of the City of Cañon City. It was established and is operated and maintained pursuant to Article XI of the Charter of Cañon City. All references to the “Library” in this Chapter 2.64 are to the Cañon City Public Library.

    B.   The Royal Gorge Regional Museum and History Center is the official museum of the City of Cañon City. It also was established and is operated and maintained pursuant to Article XI of the Charter of Cañon City. All references to the “Museum” in this Chapter 2.64 are to the Royal Gorge Regional Museum and History Center.

    C.   While it is and will remain the intention of Council for the City to continue having both a Library and a Museum, Council has also determined that it would be prudent and proper for the Library and the Museum to share certain City-owned structures and facilities and for the day-to-day operations and administrative functions of the Library and the Museum to be handled by a single administrative department of the City, and for City officials to receive advice from a single citizen’s advisory board. The Library/Museum Advisory Board created under Section 2.64.010 shall be such single, unified advisory board. Unless the context clearly indicates otherwise, all references to “Board” in this Chapter 2.64 are to such Library/Museum Advisory Board. (Ord. 16-2004 § 1)

 

2.64.010 Library/Museum Advisory Board created.
    The Library/Museum Advisory Board shall be comprised of seven (7) members appointed in accordance with the provisions of this Chapter 2.64. Such Board shall be nonpolitical, shall advise the City and its officials on matters concerning the Library and the Museum, and shall have such powers, duties, responsibilities and functions as are set forth in this Chapter 2.64. The Board’s primary focus shall be on matters of policy and planning for the Library and Museum. (Ord. 4-2015 § 1; Ord. 3-2013 § 1; Ord. 28-2008 § 1)

 

2.64.020 Appointment of members and their terms.
    A.  The City Council shall appoint all members to the Board.

 

    B.   Terms of Board members generally shall be three (3) years, but Council shall appoint some new members to shorter initial terms to achieve the staggered term structure required under Subsection C of this section.

    C.   The terms of Board members shall be staggered so that the terms of no more than four (4) members will expire in any single calendar year.

    D.  All Board members shall serve without compensation. (Ord. 28-2008 § 2)

 

2.64.025 Qualifications.
    Applicants for positions on the Board shall be persons over the age of eighteen (18) years who reside within or near the boundaries of the City and have a sincere interest in both Library and Museum operations and policies. (Ord. 16-2004 § 1)

 

2.64.027 Applications.
    The existing members of the Board shall receive and review all applications from qualified persons seeking appointment to the Board to fill new positions and vacancies existing on and after January 1, 2009 when membership on the Board is increased as provided for in Section 2.64.010. Such members shall thereafter interview all qualified applicants and make written recommendations to City Council for the appointment of members in numbers sufficient to fill all then existing vacancies. Thereafter, from time to time, as new vacancies occur on the Board, the Board will receive and review applications, interview applicants and make its written recommendations to the City Council. The Board is hereby authorized to adopt a formal process (that is not inconsistent with the provisions of this chapter) for interviewing, evaluating and making recommendations with respect to the filling of new positions and other vacancies on the Board. (Ord. 28-2008 § 3)

 

2.64.030 Removal.
    City Council, at its sole discretion, shall have the authority to remove any Board member, with or without cause, prior to the expiration of his or her term. (Ord. 16-2004 § 1)

 

2.64.035 Filling vacancies.
    A.  City Council shall fill all vacancies on the initial Board and any vacancy thereafter occurring in the membership of the Board by appointment of persons who are qualified as provided in Section 2.64.025 and who have participated in the interview and evaluation process provided for in Section 2.64.027. City Council shall give great weight to the Board’s recommendations.

    B.   With respect to the filling of vacancies on the Board, Council’s priority for appointment should be qualified applicants who now serve or previously served as officers of local organizations and associations supporting the Library and/or the Museum.

    C.   Whenever a successor is appointed to fill a vacancy created by the resignation or removal of a member prior to the expiration of that member’s term, such successor shall serve out the balance of the unexpired term of the member he or she replaces. (Ord. 5-2020 § 1; Ord. 16-2004 § 1)

 

2.64.040 Meeting—Officers.
    The Board shall hold regular meetings as established by the Board, but not less than one meeting per quarter and may hold special meetings as it may from time to time determine to be necessary; provided that all such meetings shall comply with the open meeting requirements set forth in C.R.S. Section 24-6-401 et seq. On an annual basis, the Board shall elect from its membership a Chairperson, Vice Chairperson and a Secretary. The Chairperson shall preside over all meetings of the Board and function as the primary liaison between the Board and the City Administrator or designee. The Vice Chairperson shall act during the absence of the Chairperson. The Secretary shall keep accurate minutes of Board meetings and other Board proceedings, provide adequate notice of regular and special meetings to all Board members and the City Administrator, or designee, and perform such other and similar functions as are assigned by the Chairperson. (Ord. 5-2020 § 2; Ord. 16-2004 § 1)

 

2.64.045 Quorum needed to act.
    A majority of the members then in office shall constitute a quorum for the transaction of business at any meeting of the Board. No action taken or attempted in the absence of a quorum shall be valid, except that a meeting may be called to order to determine whether a quorum is present and be adjourned if a quorum is not present. (Ord. 3-2013 § 2; Ord. 28-2008 § 4)

 

2.64.050 Powers and duties.
    The Board shall have the following powers:

    A.  The Board shall advise the City Administrator and the City Council on matters associated with the operation of both the Library and Museum, with the primary focus of its recommendations being on the formulation, implementation, evaluation and, when appropriate, modification of policy and practices of both operations.

    B.   The Board shall receive and review complaints and comments concerning the operation, management and use of the Library and Museum and shall promptly forward such complaints, comments and its summaries, reports and recommendations, if any, to the City Administrator for consideration.

    C.   The Board shall establish in writing, subject to approval by City Council, a formal procedure by which complaints, objections and comments from citizens—concerning the type, content and display of materials, collections and exhibits available to the public—are received and reviewed, with an emphasis on better serving the public and enhancing the services of the Library and the Museum.

    D.  The Board shall make a written annual report to the City Council not later than July 31st of each year, in which the Board shall:

    1.   Assess the strengths and weaknesses of the Library and Museum’s service to the community;

    2.   Make recommendations on short and long-term goals that it believes will improve service;

    3.   Make prioritized recommendations on capital improvements it believes are needed to improve the Library and Museum; and

    4.   Recommend such other policies, programs, procedures and/or guidelines which the Board believes will enhance the operation of the Library and Museum, if adopted.

    E.   The Board shall assist the City Administrator and/or the City Council with respect to Library and Museum-related issues on a case-by-case basis, but only when requested to do so by the City Administrator and/or City Council;

    F.   The Board shall make recommendations concerning any proposed budget for the Library and Museum.

    G.  The Board shall assist, if requested by the City Administrator, in the selection process for screening of applicants for various professional positions within the Library and Museum staff.

    H.  The Board will coordinate with the leadership of other citizen groups and associations whose members are interested in and supportive of the functions and operations of the Library, the Museum, or both, with a view toward encouraging and enlarging their interest and support and, when appropriate, raising funds for the Library and Museum. (Ord. 16-2004 § 1)

 

2.64.055 Limitations of powers.
    A.  All budgetary powers, expenditures, and revenues of and with respect to the Library and Museum shall be exclusively controlled by the City Council and its designees.

    B.   All personnel matters, including but not limited to hiring, promotion, demotion, discipline and termination shall be exclusively controlled by the City Administrator in accordance with the provisions of applicable law and City policy.

    C.   Except as may be specifically provided otherwise in this chapter, all actions of the Board will be advisory in nature. The Board may exercise advisory functions by making recommendations to the City Administrator, who shall forward such recommendations to City Council when and if Council action is necessary or desirable with respect to any matter covered by the Board’s recommendations. Nothing in this chapter shall authorize the Board or any of its members to exercise any supervisory or other direct control over any employee of the Library or Museum, or to exercise any direct control over the expenditure of funds of the Library or Museum. (Ord. 16-2004 § 1)

 

2.64.060 Legal advisor, personnel manager and funds custodian.
    A.  The City Attorney shall be the legal advisor of the Board and shall render all legal services required by the Board; provided that the performance of such legal services must first be authorized by the City Council or by the City Administrator.

    B.   The City Administrator, or designee, shall act as an ex-officio member of the Board. The City Administrator, or designee, shall receive notice of and shall attend all regularly scheduled and special Board meetings, and shall make him or herself reasonably available to the Board and its Chairperson for purposes of consultation and advisement concerning the implementation of any policy of the City of Cañon City. The City Administrator, or designee, shall not have a vote on any matter being considered by the Board.

    C.   The Director of Finance shall act as the legal custodian for any funds generated through operation of the Library and Museum. The accounts of the Library and Museum shall annually be audited by a certified public accountant selected or approved by the City Council and may be audited as a part of the City’s annual audit. (Ord. 16-2004 § 1)

 

2.64.065 Personnel.
    All personnel of the Library and Museum shall be subject to the terms and provisions of the Personnel Policy adopted and/or amended from time to time by the City Council. The City Administrator, or designee, shall have sole and exclusive authority over all said employees. (Ord. 16-2004 § 1)

 

2.64.070 Operating manager.
    The City Administrator, or designee, shall be the operating manager of the Library and Museum and all related facilities, with the powers, duties and responsibilities given him or her by the Charter, ordinances, regulations and rules of the City of Cañon City. (Ord. 16-2004 § 1)

Chapter 2.68 ADMINISTRATIVE DEPARTMENTS
2.68.010 City Administrator to establish other departments—Council approval.
    There shall be such other administrative departments as the City Administrator shall from time to time establish, subject to approval of the Council by resolution. The City Administrator, and Council in its resolution approving the establishment of the department, shall set forth the powers and duties of each of the departments so established. (Ord. 3-1990 § 18)

 

2.68.020 Appointment of department heads—Authority of department heads.
    The head of each administrative department of the City established as provided in this chapter shall be appointed and removable by the City Administrator. Each such department head shall have supervision and control of the department he heads. (Ord. 3-1990 § 18)

Chapter 2.73 PROHIBITED GIFTS TO CITY OFFICIALS
2.73.010 Definitions.
    As used in this chapter, the following words, terms and phrases shall have the following meanings, except where the context clearly indicates otherwise:

    A.  “Appointed officer” shall mean the City Administrator, the City Attorney or the Municipal Judge, without regard to whether such officer is or is not considered for federal income tax purposes to be an independent contractor.

    B.   “Board and Commission member” shall mean any person duly appointed by the Mayor or City Council to any Board or Commission of the City, as authorized in the City Charter or this Municipal Code.

    C.   “City official” shall mean a member of City Council, an appointed officer, an employee, a designated independent contractor or a Board and Commission member.

    D.  “Designated independent contractor” means and shall include any person who: (1) provides services on behalf of the City as an official who has discretionary authority with respect to the interpretation and/or enforcement of any code, regulation or published standard applicable in the City; (2) is compensated pursuant to contract by the City for performing such services; and (3) is considered for federal income tax purposes to be an independent contractor.

    E.   “Employee” shall mean each compensated person in the service of the City who is designated as an employee in accordance with the City’s personnel rules and regulations.

    F.   “Gift” shall mean the transfer of a thing of value by one person to another person without the person transferring the thing of value receiving in return lawful compensation or consideration of equal or greater value from the person receiving the thing of value. However, a “gift” shall not mean any thing of value given to a person by the federal government or by a state or local government as authorized by law.

    G.  “Official act” or “official action” means any vote, decision, recommendation, approval, disapproval, or other action, including inaction, which involves the use of discretionary authority.

    H.  “Person” shall mean any individual, corporation, business trust, estate, trust, limited liability company, partnership, labor organization, association, political party, committee or other legal entity. Person shall not include the federal government, a state or local government, or the Colorado Municipal League.

    I.    “Thing of value” shall mean any tangible or intangible thing having a market value, including, without limitation, money, real property, personal property, services, loans of money or property, favors, gratuities, rewards, awards, grants, scholarships, stipends, discounts, promises of future employment, honoraria, event tickets, travel, lodging, meals, and the forbearance and forgiveness of debt. (Ord. 5-2007 § 1)

 

2.73.020 Prohibited gifts.
    A.  A City official shall not solicit or accept any gift or thing of value from any person, either directly or indirectly through the City official’s spouse or dependent child, which the City official knows, or which a reasonable person in the City official’s position should know under the circumstances, is either:

    1.   A gift or thing of value that would tend to improperly influence that City official to depart from the faithful and impartial discharge of his or her public duties; or

    2.   Is a gift or thing of value being solicited or given for the primary purpose of rewarding the City official for an official action he or she has taken.

    B.   A City official shall not solicit or accept any gift or other thing of value from a “professional lobbyist” as that term is defined in Subsection 2(5) of Article XXIX of the Colorado Constitution. This provision is not intended and shall not be construed to prohibit City officials from attending and/or participating in seminars, workshops, conferences, business meetings and similar sessions and events hosted, sponsored or arranged by the Colorado Municipal League or to partake of food, beverages and/or entertainment offered or provided at such functions. (Ord. 5-2007 § 1)

 

2.73.030 Permitted gifts.
    A.  The prohibitions of Section 2.73.020 shall not apply if the gift or thing of value is:

    1.   A campaign contribution as defined by law;

    2.   A non-monetary award, publicly presented, in recognition of public service;

    3.   An educational scholarship, stipend, grant or other form of student financial aid that is offered and available to members of the general public similarly situated and is given based upon: (i) merit; (ii) demonstrated financial need; (iii) athletic ability; or (iv) any other factor unrelated to the anticipated or past performance of an official act by a City official;

    4.   A donation, loan, grant or service provided for medical, respite or hospice care or other social welfare needs; provided that such donation, loan, grant or service is available to members of the general public similarly situated and is unrelated to the anticipated or past performance of an official act by a City official;

    5.   A donation, loan, grant, service or item of tangible personal property offered or given to assist a person or family impacted by a natural disaster or as the victim of a crime; provided that such donation, loan, grant, service or item of tangible personal property is available to similarly situated members of the general public and is unrelated to the anticipated or past performance of an official act by a City official;

    6.   An occasional, unsolicited gift having a fair market value of less than fifty dollars ($50.00);

    7.   Unsolicited informational material, publications, or subscriptions related to the City official’s performance of his or her official duties;

    8.   An unsolicited token or award of appreciation in the form of a plaque, trophy, desk item, wall memento or similar item;

    9.   Payment of or reimbursement for actual and necessary expenditures for registration, travel, lodging and meals for attendance at a convention, training seminar, or other meeting at which the City official is scheduled to participate as a representative of the City or to attend as part of his or her official duties;

    10. An occasional, unsolicited opportunity to participate in a business meeting or social function where a meal is served and/or entertainment is provided if the City official’s attendance would not be considered extraordinary when viewed in light of the position held by the City official;

    11. A payment received by a City official for a speech, appearance or publication required to be reported by the City official pursuant to C.R.S. Section 24-6-203;

    12. Compensation received by a City official from the City as authorized in the City’s Charter, ordinances, policies and/or personnel rules and regulations;

    13. An unsolicited gift given by a relative or a personal friend to a City official on a special occasion that is unrelated to his or her performance of duties for or on behalf of the City and is not intended to influence the City official in the performance of official acts or to reward such City official for official action previously taken; and

    14. A gift solicited or received by the spouse or by a dependent child of a City official that is unrelated to the City official’s performance of his or her official duties for the City and which is not intended to influence the City official’s performance of official acts or to reward the City official for official action previously taken. (Ord. 5-2007 § 1)

 

2.73.040 Violations.
    A.  It shall be unlawful for any City official to violate Section 2.73.020. Proof of a violation shall be established by the evidence admitted at trial before the Cañon City Municipal Court. The standard of proof in any such trial shall be “proof by a preponderance of the evidence.”

    B.   The Cañon City Municipal Court is hereby authorized to conduct trials with respect to alleged violations of Section 2.73.020 by City officials and to impose the civil penalties provided for in Subsection C of this section.

    C.   Any City official determined by the Municipal Court to have violated Section 2.73.020 shall be deemed to have committed a civil infraction. The penalty for a City official who is found to have violated said Section 2.73.020 shall be a civil judgment in an amount equal to twice the fair market value of the prohibited gift solicited or received by the City official, as determined by the evidence admitted by the Municipal Court. If the City official fails to pay such judgment within thirty (30) days following the entry of the final judgment, or such longer period as may be authorized by order of the Municipal Court, the City may pursue any legal means available to it for the collection of the judgment.

    D.  Nothing in this chapter is intended to preclude the bringing and prosecution of criminal proceedings in a state court of competent jurisdiction against a City official who is accused of committing any crime described in Part 3 of Article 8 of Title 18, Colorado Revised Statutes. A civil judgment entered by the Municipal Court in a proceeding brought pursuant to this chapter shall be in addition to, and not in lieu of, any criminal penalty that might be imposed upon conviction in any such criminal proceeding. (Ord. 5-2007 § 1)

 

2.73.050 Municipal Ethics Commission.
    A.  There is hereby created a Municipal Ethics Commission to be composed of three (3) members. The purposes of the Municipal Ethics Commission shall be: to receive and review complaints; to investigate alleged violations of Section 2.73.020; to dismiss frivolous or unfounded complaints; to propose and effectuate settlements with respect to complaints that appear to be valid in appropriate cases; and to recommend the instigation of Municipal Court proceedings in appropriate circumstances. The Municipal Ethics Commission also may issue advisory opinions on ethics issues and questions arising under this chapter and may establish a local repository for disclosure statements voluntarily filed by City officials respecting permitted gifts received by them, their spouses and/or their dependent children.

    B.   The Municipal Ethics Commission shall have authority to adopt reasonable rules that are not inconsistent with the provisions of this section which may be necessary for purposes of administering and enforcing the provisions of this section.

    C.   City Council shall do those things necessary to provide staff assistance and the funding necessary to allow the Municipal Ethics Commission to carry out its duties pursuant to this section. Members of the Commission shall receive no compensation for their services on the Commission, but may have their reasonable expenses paid or reimbursed by the City.

    D.  Membership on the Municipal Ethics Commission shall be established as follows:

    1.   The City Council shall appoint two (2) members of the Commission at a regular or special meeting of City Council;

    2.   Each of the two (2) appointed members shall be a resident of the City and neither shall be a City official;

    3.   Public notice of the availability of positions on the Municipal Ethics Commission shall be given prior to City Council’s selection and appointment of Commission members from among the several applicants;

    4.   The City Attorney shall be the third member of the Commission.

    E.   The terms of the two (2) appointed members of the Commission shall be two (2) years, except that one such member initially shall be appointed to a one-year term to achieve staggered terms.

    F.   If a member is appointed to fill an unexpired term, that member’s term shall end at the same time as the term of the person being replaced was set to expire.

    G.  Each member shall continue to serve until a successor has been appointed, except that if a member is unable or unwilling to continue to serve until a successor has been appointed, City Council shall fill the vacancy promptly.

    H.  Any resident of the City may file a written complaint with the Municipal Ethics Commission alleging that a City official has violated Section 2.73.020 and stating the factual basis for such claim. No allegation in any such complaint shall refer to an act occurring prior to the effective date of the ordinance adopting this chapter and, after this chapter has been effective for longer than twelve (12) months, no allegation with respect to a violation occurring more remotely than twelve (12) months prior to the filing date of the complaint shall be considered.

    I.    The Commission shall adhere to the procedure set forth in paragraphs 1 through 5 of this Subsection I when dealing with any complaint filed pursuant to Subsection H.

    1.   The Commission may dismiss frivolous and unfounded complaints without conducting or completing an investigation. Complaints dismissed as frivolous or unfounded shall be maintained confidentially by the Commission.

    2.   Except as provided in paragraph 1 of this Subsection I, the Commission shall conduct an investigation with respect to all complaints.

    3.   Following any investigation, the Commission shall dismiss the complaint or refer the complaint to the City’s Municipal Court Prosecutor with its recommendation that proceedings against the City official named in the complaint be initiated, as provided for in Section 2.73.040.

    4.   If the Commission’s decision is to refer the complaint, the Commission, prior to such referral, shall have the right, but not the obligation, to propose to the City official named in the complaint a settlement pursuant to Subsection J of this section under which a resolution penalty would be paid in lieu of the matter proceeding to Municipal Court.

    5.   All decisions of the Commission that are required or permitted in this subsection shall require a majority vote of the Commission.

    J.    Settlement Offers.

    1.   The Commission may propose settlements with respect to alleged violations of Section 2.73.020 to the City official named in a complaint. Such proposals shall be made in writing and shall designate the amount of a proposed resolution penalty. Settlement proposals shall be accepted or rejected in writing by the City official within twenty (20) days following the date of the offer. A failure to respond shall be deemed a rejection.

    2.   The proposed resolution penalty shall represent the amount that the Commission believes, based upon its investigation, is equal to twice the value of a gift or thing of value improperly solicited or accepted by the City official (or, when applicable, the City official’s spouse or dependent child).

    3.   If a resolution penalty is proposed, accepted and paid, the name of the City official, the essential details of the alleged violation and the amount of the resolution penalty paid by the City official shall be included in a summary report prepared by the Commission and filed with the City Clerk. Such summary report shall be a public record.

    4.   If a proposed settlement is not accepted or if an agreed-upon resolution penalty is not paid with thirty (30) days following the acceptance of a settlement offer, the matter will be referred to the City’s Municipal Court Prosecutor, who shall make the ultimate decision regarding whether Municipal Court proceedings will be instigated.

    5.   The Municipal Prosecutor shall do what is necessary to instigate and prosecute such proceedings unless he or she believes in good faith that sufficient evidence to support a civil judgment authorized in Section 2.73.040(C) could not be presented in a Municipal Court proceeding. If the matter is referred, the fact that a settlement proposal was made shall be kept confidential and shall not be offered or admitted as evidence at trial.

    6.   Resolution penalties paid by City officials shall be deposited into the City’s General Fund.

 

    K.  During the course of its investigations, the Municipal Ethics Commission shall have the power to request copies of documents that are relevant to the allegations in a complaint and to interview witnesses, including but not necessarily limited to the person who filed the complaint and the accused City official.

    L.   If a City official who is accused in a complaint of violating Section 2.73.020 is a member of the Municipal Ethics Commission, that member shall be disqualified and replaced by a temporary member appointed by the Mayor for purposes of investigating, considering and disposing of the complaint.

    M.  Any City official may submit a written request to the Municipal Ethics Commission for an advisory opinion on whether any conduct by that person would constitute a violation of Section 2.73.020. The Commission may render an advisory opinion pursuant to written rules adopted by the Commission, but in any event shall respond to such request within fifteen (15) days of its receipt. Any City official who acts in specific reliance upon an advisory opinion shall have the right to offer a copy of the opinion as a part of his or her defense in any trial of such City official conducted pursuant to the authority granted in Section 2.73.040(B). Unless otherwise provided in the Commission’s rules, requests for advisory opinions shall be filed with the City Attorney. (Ord. 5-2007 § 1)

Chapter 2.78 ROYAL GORGE REGIONAL TOURISM COUNCIL
2.78.010 Created—Purpose.
    A.  The City Council hereby creates the Royal Gorge Regional Tourism Council, which shall have principal responsibility for matters of marketing the City and the Royal Gorge region.

    B.   The purpose of this chapter is to create and empower the Royal Gorge Regional Tourism Council to promote, market, manage and coordinate tourist-related activities. (Ord. 18-2017 § 1)

 

2.78.020 Membership—Terms of office.
    A.  The Royal Gorge Regional Tourism Council shall consist of eleven (11) members appointed by the City Council. Except for the initial appointments as set forth in this Section 2.78.020, members shall serve three (3) year staggered terms from the date of appointment. Members may continue to serve until their successors have been appointed. Appointments to fill the vacancies on the Royal Gorge Regional Tourism Council shall be made by the City Council. All members of the Royal Gorge Regional Tourism Council shall serve without compensation except for such amounts determined appropriate, in advance, by the City Council to offset expenses incurred in the performance of their duties. Members of the Royal Gorge Regional Tourism Council may be removed by the City Council without cause being stated and without a hearing.

    B.   The eleven (11) members of the Royal Gorge Regional Tourism Council shall be constituted as follows:

    1.   Three (3) members shall be representatives determined by the City Council to be current lodging industry leaders with significant marketing, tourism, lodging, and/or promotional experience;

    2.   One (1) member shall be a senior management representative of the Royal Gorge Bridge Company;

    3.   One (1) member shall be a senior management representative of the Royal Gorge Route Railroad;

    4.   Two (2) members shall be senior management representatives of the outdoor recreation industry; and

    5.   Four (4) members shall be current or past tourist industry leaders with significant marketing, tourism, lodging, and/or promotional experience.

    C.   Initial Appointments. The initial appointments to the Royal Gorge Regional Tourism Council were made as follows: three (3) members were appointed to three (3) year terms; three (3) members were appointed to two (2) year terms; and three (3) members were appointed to one (1) year terms.

    D.  Additional Appointments. The appointments of the two (2) additional members appointed in 2018 upon expansion of the membership from nine (9) members to eleven (11) members shall be one (1) member from the tourist industry appointed to a three (3) year term and one (1) member from the outdoor recreation industry be appointed to a two (2) year term. (Ord. 16-2018 § 1; Ord. 18-2017 § 1)

 

2.78.030 Quorum and voting.
    A quorum for the Royal Gorge Regional Tourism Council shall consist of at least six (6) of its sitting members. A quorum is necessary for the Royal Gorge Regional Tourism Council to conduct business. (Ord. 16-2018 § 2; Ord. 18-2017 § 1)

 

2.78.040 Officers.
    At the first regular meeting of each calendar year, the Royal Gorge Regional Tourism Council shall, by majority vote, elect one (1) of its members to serve as chairperson to preside over the meetings and one (1) member to serve as vice chairperson. The members so designated shall serve in these capacities for terms of one (1) year. (Ord. 18-2017 § 1)

 

2.78.050 Meetings.
    The Royal Gorge Regional Tourism Council shall establish a regular meeting schedule. Minutes shall be kept of all proceedings. (Ord. 18-2017 § 1)

 

2.78.060 Powers and duties.
    The Royal Gorge Regional Tourism Council shall have the following powers and duties:

    A.  To enter into contracts and agreements, except as otherwise provided in this article, affecting the affairs of the City regarding the powers enumerated in this chapter, including contracts with the United States, the State of Colorado, and any of their respective agencies or instrumentalities;

    B.   To adopt such bylaws, rules and regulations for its own guidance as it deems appropriate;

    C.   Submit annually a budget to the City Council no later than September 15 of the preceding year of the proposed budget to be included within the City’s budget. The submitted budget shall reflect annual lodging tax revenues and the City’s obligation to match the annual lodging tax revenues from the General Fund;

    D.  Operate and expend the revenue generated by the City’s lodging tax and those General Fund revenues provide by the City for the purposes set forth in this Section 2.78.060, except that no revenue collected from the lodging tax or the General Fund revenues provided by the City shall be used for any capital expenditures, with the exception of tourist information centers;

    E.   To provide any of the following services within the City and Royal Gorge region:

    1.   Organization, promotion, marketing, and management of public events,

    2.   Coordinating tourism promotion activities;

    F.   To have the management, control and supervision of all the business and affairs of the City’s provision of promotion, marketing, managing and coordinating tourist-related activities; and

    G.  To hire employees or retain agents, engineers, consultants, attorneys, and accountants as determined necessary. (Ord. 18-2017 § 1)

 

2.78.070 Conduct of business.
    The Royal Gorge Regional Tourism Council shall conduct its business in accordance with the Colorado Public (Open) Records Act, C.R.S. § 24-72-200.1, et seq., the Colorado Open Meetings Law, C.R.S. § 24-6-401, et seq., and other laws applicable to local public bodies. (Ord. 18-2017 § 1)
