Chapter 3.04 SALE OF CITY PROPERTY
3.04.010 Sale of City-owned property—Council authority.
    The Council of the City shall have the power, by ordinance, to sell, dispose of and convey any and all real property owned by the City, of whatsoever nature and used or held for any purpose, upon such terms and conditions as the Council may determine at a regular meeting, and all deeds of conveyance duly executed and acknowledged by the Mayor and attested by the City Clerk, with the seal of the City affixed thereto, purporting to have been made in pursuance of the ordinance codified in this section, shall be deemed prima facie evidence of due compliance with all requirements of this section and the Charter and ordinances of the City. (Prior code § 3.04.010)

Chapter 3.08 TAX COLLECTION
3.08.010 Tax levy and collection—Charter authority.
    Taxes for City purposes shall be levied and collected in the manner prescribed by the City Charter, Article VII, Section 7. (Prior code § 3.08.010)

Chapter 3.12 SALES TAX
3.12.010 Sales tax imposed.
    A.  There is levied a tax upon all sales of tangible personal property and taxable services specified in Section 3.12.030. The rate levied shall be two percent (2%).

    B.   In addition to the sales tax levied in subsection (A) above, there is an additional sales tax of a rate of one percent levied on all sales of tangible person property and taxable services specified in Section 3.12.030 which shall be used exclusively for street-related infrastructure improvements and repairs. This additional sales tax shall terminate on December 31, 2026. (Ord. 19-2020 § 1)

 

3.12.020 Definitions.
    The definitions of the words contained in this chapter shall be as defined in Title 39, Article 26, C.R.S. as may be amended, which definitions are incorporated herein by this reference. The City further adopts all rules and regulations adopted by the Colorado Department of Revenue and such rules and regulations are incorporated herein by this reference. (Ord. 19-2020 § 1)

 

3.12.030 Transactions subject to sales tax and exemptions.
    A.  The transaction subject to the sales tax shall be as set forth below and as required by Colorado state law.

    1.   The tangible personal property and services taxable hereunder shall be the same as the tangible personal property and services taxable pursuant to C.R.S. Section 39-26-104, except as provided herein, and shall be subject to the same exemptions as those specified in Part 7 of Article 26 of Title 39, C.R.S., expressly including the following exemptions:

    a.   For vending machine sales of food specified in C.R.S. Section 39-26-714(2).

    b.   For sales by a charitable organization specified in C.R.S. Section 39-26-718(1)(b).

    c.   For sales of items of personal property through vending machines in the amount of fifteen cents or less as specified in C.R.S. Section 39-26-714.

    d.   For sales of farm equipment and farm equipment under lease or contract as specified in C.R.S. Sections 39-26-716(2)(b) and (2)(c).

    e.   For sales that benefit a Colorado school specified in C.R.S. Section 39-26-725.

    f.    For sales by an association or organization of parents and teachers of public school students that is a charitable organization as specified in C.R.S. Section 39-26-718(1)(c).

    g.   For manufactured homes as specified in C.R.S. Section 39-26-721(3).

    2.   The sales tax shall not be imposed on the sale of construction and building materials, as the term is used in C.R.S. Section 29-2-109, if such materials are picked up by the purchaser and if the purchaser of such materials presents to the retailer a building permit or other acceptable documentation that a local use tax has been paid or is required to be paid on the value thereof.

    3.   The sales tax shall not be imposed on the sale of personal property on which a specific ownership tax has been paid or is payable if: (a) the purchaser is a nonresident of or has its principal place of business outside the City, and (b) such personal property is registered or required to be registered outside the limits of the City under the laws of the State of Colorado.

    4.   The sales tax shall not be imposed on the sale of tangible personal property at retail or the furnishing of services if the transaction has been previously subjected to a sales or use tax lawfully imposed on the purchaser or user by another statutory or home rule county equal to or in excess of the amount imposed by this chapter. A credit shall be granted against the sales tax payable with respect to such transaction equal in amount to the lawfully imposed sales or use tax previously paid by the purchaser or user to such other statutory or home rule county, provided that such credit shall not exceed the amount imposed by this chapter. (Ord. 19-2020 § 1)

 

3.12.040 Determination of place at which sales are consummated.
    All retail sales shall be considered consummated at the place of business of the retailer, unless the tangible personal property sold is delivered by the retailer or its agent to a destination outside the City or to a common carrier for delivery to a destination outside the limits of the City. The gross taxable sales shall include delivery charges, when such charges are subject to the state sales and use tax imposed by Article 26 of Title 39, C.R.S., regardless of the place to which delivery is made. If a retailer has no permanent place of business in the City, or has more than one place of business, the place or places at which the retail sales are consummated for the purpose of this sales tax shall be determined by the provisions of Article 26 of Title 39, C.R.S., and by the rules and regulations promulgated by the Colorado Department of Revenue. The amount subject to the sales tax shall not include the amount of any state sales and use tax imposed by Article 26 of Title 39, C.R.S. (Ord. 19-2020 § 1)

 

3.12.050 Credit for sales taxes previously paid.
    The City’s sales tax shall not apply to the sale of tangible personal property at retail or the furnishing of services if the transaction was previously subjected to a sales or use tax lawfully imposed on the purchaser or user by another statutory or home rule municipality equal to or in excess of the sales tax imposed by the City. A credit shall be granted against the City’s sales tax with respect to such transaction equal in an amount to the lawfully imposed local sales or use tax previously paid by the purchaser or user to the previous statutory or home rule municipality. The amount of the credit shall, however, not exceed the sales tax imposed by the City upon the sale. (Ord. 19-2020 § 1)

 

3.12.060 Collection, administration and enforcement.
    The collection, administration and enforcement of the sales tax shall be performed by the Executive Director of the Colorado Department of Revenue (the “Executive Director”) in the same manner as the collection, administration and enforcement of the Colorado state sales tax. The provisions of Article 26 of Title 39, C.R.S. and all rules and regulations promulgated thereunder by the Executive Director shall govern the collection, administration, and enforcement of the sales tax. (Ord. 19-2020 § 1)

 

3.12.070 Vendor fee.
    A.  A retailer’s collection and remittance expense (vendor’s fee) equal to 3.33 percent of the amount of sales taxes collected and reported may be claimed on each sales tax return timely filed in accordance with the requirements of this Code and retained by such retailer as a credit against sales taxes paid on or before the date upon which such taxes were due, except that the amount of such credit shall not exceed two hundred dollars ($200.00) per month.

    B.   Any vendor’s fee that otherwise would be available as a credit to any retailer shall be forfeited if the sales tax return upon which such vendor’s fee may be claimed is not filed on or before its due date or if the sales taxes payable to the City with respect to such sales tax return are not paid when due. (Ord. 19-2020 § 1)

Chapter 3.13 USE TAX
3.13.010 Use tax imposed.
    A.  There is levied a tax upon the privilege of using, storing, distributing or consuming in the City any article of tangible personal property or taxable services specified in Section 3.13.030. The rate levied shall be two percent (2%).

    B.   In addition to the use tax levied in subsection A above, there is an additional use tax of a rate of one percent levied upon the privilege of using, storing, distributing or consuming in the City any article of tangible personal property or taxable services specified in Section 3.13.030, which shall be used exclusively for street-related infrastructure improvements and repairs. This additional use tax shall terminate on December 31, 2026.

    C.   Imposition and Collection. The taxes specified in this section are imposed upon and payable by the taxpayer. The taxes shall be computed in accordance with schedules or systems approved and specified by the Finance Director.

    D.  Continuation. The taxes imposed in this section shall continue to be levied and collected until amended or repealed by ordinance.

    E.   Tax Cumulative. The taxes imposed in this section shall be in addition to all other taxes imposed by law. (Ord. 19-2020 § 2)

 

3.13.020 Definitions.
    The definitions of the words contained in this chapter shall be as defined in Title 39, Article 26, C.R.S. as may be amended, which definitions are incorporated herein by this reference, except as provided in this section.

    A.  “Automotive Vehicle” means any vehicle or device in, upon, or by which any person or property is or may be transported or drawn upon a public highway, or any device used or designed for aviation or flight in the air. Automotive vehicle includes, but is not limited to, motor vehicles, trailers, semi-trailers, or mobile homes. Automotive vehicle shall not include devices moved by human power or used exclusively upon stationary rails or tracks.

    B.   “Construction Materials” means tangible personal property which, when combined with other tangible personal property, loses its identity to become an integral and inseparable part of a completed structure or project including public and private improvements. Construction materials include, but are not limited to, such things as: asphalt, bricks, builders’ hardware, caulking material, cement, concrete, conduit, electric wiring and connections, fireplace inserts, electrical heating and cooling equipment, flooring, glass, gravel, insulation, lath, lead, lime, lumber, macadam, millwork, mortar, oil, paint, piping, pipe valves and pipe fittings, plaster, plumbing fixtures, putty, reinforcing mesh, road base, roofing, sand, sanitary sewer pipe, sheet metal, site lighting, steel, stone, stucco, tile, trees, shrubs and other landscaping materials, wall board, wall coping, wall paper, weather stripping, wire netting and screen, water mains and meters, and wood preserver. The above materials, when used for forms, or other items which do not remain as an integral or inseparable part of a completed structure or project are not construction materials.

    C.   “Consumer” means any person in the City who purchases, uses, stores, distributes or otherwise consumes tangible personal property or taxable services, purchased from sources inside or outside the City.

    D.  “Storage” means any keeping or retention of, or exercise dominion or control over, or possession of, for any length of time, tangible personal property not while in transit but on a stand still basis for future use when leased, rented or purchased at retail from sources either within or without the City from any person or vendor.

    E.   “Taxpayer” means any person obligated to pay tax under the terms of this chapter.

    F.   “Use” means the exercise, for any length of time by any person within the City of any right, power or dominion over tangible personal property or services when rented, leased or purchased at retail from sources either within or without the City from any person or vendor or used in the performance of a contract in the City whether such tangible personal property is owned or not owned by the taxpayer. Use also includes the withdrawal of items from inventory for consumption. (Ord. 19-2020 § 2)

 

3.13.030 Transactions subject to use tax and exemptions.
    A.  The use tax levied by Section 3.13.010 shall apply only to the price of the following:

    1.   Construction or building materials which are used or consumed in the City and upon which a sales or use tax has not been paid.

    2.   All items of stock or inventory originally purchased at wholesale by a person engaged in business in the City, but only to the extent that such item is removed from stock or inventory and consumed by such person or distributed to any other person for use or consumption by any means or transaction other than a retail sale. Items with respect to which the use tax will apply shall include, but not be limited to, goods given as samples or prizes for purposes of promoting business, sales or goodwill by persons engaged in business in the City.

    3.   All items of tangible personal property originally purchased at wholesale and stored by any person engaged in manufacturing in the city, but only to the extent that such item is removed from stock and consumed by such person or distributed to any other person for use or consumption by any means or transaction other than a retail sale.

    4.   All items of tangible personal property leased or rented from persons outside the City by persons residing in the City or persons engaged in business in the City, if such item of tangible personal property is used in the business, but only to the extent that a sales tax on the price of such item has not been paid to the City.

    5.   Automotive vehicles required by the statutes of Colorado to be registered at an address inside the City on which a municipal sales tax has not been paid. The County Clerk of the County in which the registration occurs is authorized to collect such tax for the City prior to or at the time of registration.

    a.   The determination of vehicle registration requirements for individuals shall be the same as for the determination of residency for voter registration purposes.

    b.   The determination of vehicle registration requirements for automotive vehicles which are owned by a business and operated primarily for business purposes shall be based on the address from which such automotive vehicles are principally operated and maintained.

    B.   The use tax levied by Section 3.13.010 shall not extend or apply to the following:

    1.   The storage, use or consumption of any tangible personal property the sale of which is subject to a retail sales tax imposed by the City;

    2.   Automotive vehicles if the owner is or was, at the time of purchase, a nonresident of the City who purchased the vehicle for use outside the City, and if the vehicle was previously registered, titled and licensed outside the City.

    C.   The list of exemptions shall not be increased by implication or similarity.

    D.  The burden of proving that any consumer is exempt from paying the use tax shall be on such consumer under such reasonable requirements of proof as the Finance Director may prescribe. (Ord. 19-2020 § 2)

 

3.13.040 Provisions relative to building permits.
    A.  Except as otherwise provided by subsection C of this section, every person who shall build, construct, reconstruct, alter, expand, modify or improve any building dwelling unit, or other structure, or improvement to real property and who shall purchase construction materials as defined in this chapter, supplies and other tangible personal property used, consumed or stored on real property, improvements and/or attached or affixed structures located within the City, shall pay the City the use tax provided for in this chapter on construction materials, whether purchased from sources inside or outside the City, in either of the following two (2) ways, at the option of the Finance Director:

    1.   Estimated Prepayment. The estimated cost of such construction materials shall be calculated by multiplying the estimated value of this construction project, entered on the building permit by the City, by a percentage established by the Finance Director. Use tax on such estimated cost of construction materials shall be paid at the time the building permit is issued. If use tax is prepaid, interest on any tax deficiency related to construction materials shall be computed from the date of issuance of the certificate of occupancy or temporary certificate of occupancy, whichever is earlier.

    2.   Actual Cost. The actual cost of such construction materials shall be reported and tax paid on monthly returns if the permit issued is in the amount of fifty thousand dollars ($50,000.00) or more, and on quarterly returns if the permit issued is for less than fifty thousand dollars ($50,000.00). If use tax is paid on actual cost basis, interest on any tax deficiency shall be computed from the date on which tax is due.

    B.   No final certificate of occupancy or final inspection in lieu of permanent certificate of occupancy shall be issued unless all tax due on construction materials for the project for which the building permit was issued has been paid or arrangement therefor has been made with the Finance Director. Any temporary certificate of occupancy shall be revoked if the use tax payable pursuant to this chapter has not been paid within ninety (90) days of issuance.

    C.   No use tax shall be due on construction materials used in construction projects undertaken and managed directly by the City.

    D.  No person shall make any false statement in connection with this section. (Ord. 19-2020 § 2)

 

3.13.050 Duty to keep books and records—Audit.
    A.  It shall be the duty of every person, firm or corporation liable to the City for any use tax under this section to keep and preserve records for a period of at least three (3) years after completion of construction activities subject to a use tax. Such records shall include all books, accounts and records, together with all bills, receipts, invoices, cash register tapes or other documents of original entry supporting the entries in the books, including subcontractor’s detailed invoices for goods and services.

    B.   Every person shall provide all such records for audit by the Finance Director during normal business hours.

    C.   The City may conduct an audit to recompute the use tax by reviewing and evaluating the actual cost of construction materials. If any recomputed use tax is less than that shown and paid by the taxpayer, the difference shall be refunded to the taxpayer. If the recomputed use tax is more than that shown and paid by the taxpayer, the taxpayer shall be notified of the deficiency and shall be required to pay the same. (Ord. 19-2020 § 2)

 

3.13.060 Refunds.
    A.  Within sixty (60) days of the date of final inspection by the building official, if no certificate of occupancy will be issued, or on the date of issuance of a certificate of occupancy, temporary or otherwise is issued, the taxpayer may submit a request for a refund to the Finance Director with the cost of materials as verified by records kept pursuant to Section 3.13.050. The taxpayer will be allowed one thirty (30) day extension of time, if the taxpayer requests the extension prior to the expiration of the sixty (60) day period of time described herein. Failure to so notify the Finance Director and provide the required records shall be grounds for denying a refund request. Upon receipt of the timely request for a refund, complete with required records, the Finance Director shall determine whether, in his or her reasonable opinion, receipts for all of the material used have been provided and shall make a determination of whether a refund of any excess use taxes paid may be given.

    B.   Whenever the Finance Director discovers from the examination of a return or pursuant to an audit of a taxpayer’s records that the taxpayer has overpaid use taxes due the City, the Finance Director shall issue a refund for payment of the excess taxes to the taxpayer, plus interest at the rate established by this chapter, unless the overpayment and interest are applied to offset other tax due. The Director shall keep a duplicate of said refund and also a statement that sets forth the reason why such refund was ordered. (Ord. 19-2020 § 2)

 

3.13.070 Interest.
    Any use tax due and unpaid shall be a debt to the City and shall draw a monthly interest rate of one percent at the rate. (Ord. 19-2020 § 2)

 

3.13.080 Lien upon property.
    The City use tax payable by virtue of the storage, use or consumption in this City of any construction and building material and any penalties and interest thereon shall be a first and prior lien upon the real and personal property of the person from whom such tax is due, subject only to preexisting liens of a bona fide mortgagee, pledgee, judgment creditor or purchaser whose right was attached prior to the filing of the notice of such lien by the City. The notice of lien to claim the lien for any such delinquent use tax, when filed in the office of the clerk and recorder of any county in which the delinquent taxpayer owns real or personal property or both, shall constitute notice to all persons of such delinquent taxpayer. (Ord. 19-2020 § 2)

 

3.13.090 Enforcement.
    A.  The City may institute such legal actions, suits or proceedings in any court of competent jurisdiction against any person from whom a use tax is due and payable, to establish the amount due and to collect such delinquent tax and any applicable interest.

    B.   Repeated violations of this chapter could preclude issuance of further building permits to the violator by City’s Building Department. (Ord. 19-2020 § 2)

 

3.13.100 Penalty.
    Any person convicted of violating any of the provisions of this chapter shall be punished by a fine in accordance with the provisions of Chapter 1.28 of this Code. (Ord. 19-2020 § 2)

Chapter 3.20 CAPITAL ACQUISITION AND IMPROVEMENT FUND
3.20.010 Establishment.
    There is established for the planned growth, general welfare and proper administration of the affairs of the City, a fund of the City which shall be known as the “capital acquisition and improvement fund.” (Prior code § 3.22.010)

 

3.20.020 Composition.
    The capital acquisition and improvement fund shall consist of such revenues as the Council may annually appropriate to or designate for such fund. (Prior code § 3.22.020)

 

3.20.030 Expenditures.
    Expenditures of moneys from the capital acquisition and improvement fund shall be made from time to time, and at any time, as the Council may determine (consistent with Charter provisions relating to annual budget and the appropriation ordinances), for the purposes of acquiring, constructing or improving any land, building, structure or other capital asset of the City, or for retiring any bonded indebtedness created for these purposes. (Prior code § 3.22.030)

Chapter 3.24 EQUIPMENT ACQUISITION AND IMPROVEMENT FUND
3.24.010 Establishment.
    There is established for the convenience and proper administration of the affairs of the City a fund of the City, which shall be known as the “equipment acquisition and improvement fund.” (Prior code § 3.20.010)

 

3.24.020 Composition.
    The equipment acquisition and improvement fund shall consist of such sums of money as the City Council may from time to time appropriate or otherwise deposit to such fund. (Prior code § 3.20.030)

 

3.24.030 Transfer of funds.
    There is transferred into the equipment acquisition and improvement fund all sums heretofore appropriated to the “reserve for equipment purchase” account in the general fund of the City. (Prior code § 3.20.020)

 

3.24.040 Revenues from investment of funds.
    Revenues derived from earnings from investment of funds appropriated to or deposited to the equipment acquisition and improvement fund shall be transferred annually to the general fund. (Prior code § 3.20.040)

Chapter 3.26 MUSEUM FUND
3.26.010 Establishment.
    There is established for the planned growth, general welfare and proper administration of the affairs of the City, a fund of the City which shall be known as the “museum fund.” (Ord. 14-1990 § 1)

 

3.26.020 Composition.
    The museum fund shall consist of all revenues received by way of donations, gifts, bequests, grants and similar conveyances to or for the benefit of the City’s museums; revenues generated by fund-raising efforts and events for the benefit of City museums; and such other revenues as the Council may annually appropriate or otherwise designate for such fund. (Ord. 14-1990 § 1)

 

3.26.030 Expenditures.
    Expenditures of moneys from the museum fund shall be made from time to time, and at any time, as the Council may determine (consistent with Charter provisions relating to annual budget and the appropriation ordinances), for the purposes of operation of the City’s museums, maintenance of museum buildings and grounds, and for the preservation, enlargement, construction, reproduction, improvement, acquisition and maintenance of any artifact, historically significant item or building, diorama, display, land, building, structure or other asset of the City’s museums. (Ord. 14-1990 § 1)

Chapter 3.28 RAW WATER ACQUISITION AND PRESERVATION FUND
3.28.010 Establishment.
    There is established for the planned growth, general welfare and proper administration of the affairs of the City, a fund of the City which shall be known as the “raw water acquisition and preservation fund.” (Ord. 36-1988; prior code § 3.21.010)

 

3.28.020 Transfer of funds.
    There are transferred into the raw water acquisition and preservation fund all sums heretofore appropriated and not encumbered to the “reserved for acquisition of raw water and protection of city’s water rights” account in the water fund. (Ord. 36-1988; prior code § 3.21.020)

 

3.28.030 Composition.
    The raw water acquisition and preservation fund shall consist of.

    A.  The moneys transferred pursuant to Section 3.28.020 of this chapter;

    B.   Fourteen percent of the amount collected for raw water and plant investment charges, pursuant to Section 13.08.030 of this Code;

    C.   All revenues or sums derived from investment of funds of the raw water acquisition and preservation fund. (Ord. 29-1995 § 1; Ord. 1-1993 § 2; Ord. 15-1990 § 1)

 

3.28.040 Expenditures.
    Appropriations and expenditures of moneys of the raw water acquisition and preservation fund shall be made from time to time and at any time, as the Council of the City may determine, in the acquisition and preservation of raw water and raw water sources for the City water system. (Ord. 15-1990 § 1)

 

3.28.050 Termination Disposition of moneys.
    Should the Council of the City determine that the raw water acquisition and preservation fund is at any time unessential for any reason, all funds and moneys in the fund shall be transferred to the water fund for appropriation and expenditure pursuant to Section 5-A, Article VII, of the Charter of the City. (Ord. 36-1988; prior code § 3.21.050)

Chapter 3.30 QUALITY OF LIFE FUND
3.30.010 Establishment.
    There is established for the planned growth, general welfare and proper administration of the affairs of the City, a fund of the City which shall be known as the “quality of life fund.” (Ord. 13-1990 § 1)

 

3.30.020 Composition.
    The quality of life fund shall consist of such revenues as the Council may annually appropriate to or designate for such fund. (Ord. 13-1990 § 1)

 

3.30.030 Expenditures.
    Expenditures of moneys from the quality of life fund shall be made from time to time, and at any time, as the Council may determine (consistent with Charter provisions relating to annual budget and the appropriation ordinances), for the purposes of repairs, replacements, enlargements, construction, improvements, acquisition and maintenance of any land, building, structure or other asset of the City, for retiring any bonded indebtedness created for these purposes, or for purchases or grants the Council determines Will enhance the quality of life that distinguishes a vital, attractive and functional city from a static, less attractive or less utilitarian city. (Ord. 13-1990 § 1)

Chapter 3.32 EMERGENCY TELEPHONE CHARGE
3.32.010 Imposed.
    There is imposed, pursuant to Colorado Revised Statutes, Section 29-11-101 et seq., upon all telephone exchange access facilities within the city an emergency telephone charge in an amount not to exceed two percent of the tariff rates as approved by the Public Utilities Commission or fifty cents, whichever is less, per month. Upon recommendation of the emergency telephone service authority the City Council may, by resolution, raise or lower the emergency telephone charge, but in no event shall such charge exceed the amount of two percent of the tariff as approved by the Public Utilities Commission or fifty cents, whichever is less, per month. (Ord. 18-1987 § 2)

 

3.32.020 Collection.
    Telephone service suppliers providing telephone service in the city are authorized to collect the emergency telephone charge imposed by this chapter in accordance with Colorado Revised Statutes Section 29-11-101 et seq. (Ord. 18-1987 § 3)

Chapter 3.34 SEIZURE/FORFEITURE FUND
3.34.010 Establishment.
    There is established for the convenience and proper administration of the affairs of the City a fund of the City, which shall be known as the “seizure/forfeiture fund.” (Ord. 14-1997 § 1)

 

3.34.020 Composition.
    The seizure/forfeiture fund shall consist of such sums of money that are delivered to and received by or on behalf of the Cañon City Police Department with respect to law enforcement activities that resulted in the seizure and forfeiture of real or personal property pursuant to applicable federal or state laws. The moneys to be deposited in this fund may include, without limitation, any sums payable to and received by or on behalf of the Cañon City Police Department as a seizing agency from state of Colorado sources identified at Parts 3 and 5 of Title 16, Article 13, C.R.S. or from federal sources pursuant to federal laws, rules and regulations, the receipt, use and disposition of which are authorized by Section 16-13-601, C.R.S. (Ord. 14-1997 § 1)

 

3.34.030 Special provisions.
    A.  The seizure/forfeiture fund is designated as the lawfully created fund to receive proceeds from property forfeited to the federal government and allocated to the Cañon City Police Department pursuant to federal law and regulation.

    B.   For accounting purposes, the seizure/forfeiture fund shall be treated as a special reserve account which will have two divisions. One such division shall receive proceeds from federally forfeited property allocated by an agency or officer of the United States government and the other division shall receive proceeds from property forfeited pursuant to state law. The assets of each division shall not be commingled.

    C.   All forfeited property and all proceeds from forfeited property received by or on behalf of the Cañon City Police Department shall be subject to the reporting and audit requirements set forth at Section 1631-701, C.R.S.

    D.  All such forfeited property and all proceeds from forfeited property received by or on behalf of the Cañon City Police Department shall be used and expended only as approved and authorized by the committee on disposition required under Section 16-13-702, C.R.S. No expenditure shall be authorized except by a majority vote of all committee members. A memorandum regarding each expenditure authorized by the committee shall be made and shall reflect the vote of each committee member.

    E.   The composition of the committee shall be as provided in Section 16-13702(3), C.R.S. The initial representative of the Council of Cañon City shall be the City Administrator. The Council reserves the right to designate a replacement representative at any time and from time to time by resolution. The committee is specifically authorized to establish and maintain one or more bank accounts to be used for law enforcement purposes designated by the committee and to deposit into such account or accounts assets of the seizure/forfeiture fund.

    F.   In accordance with applicable federal and state law, moneys in the seizure/forfeiture fund shall not be subject to appropriation by the Council of Cañon City, nor shall such moneys be used or expended for any purpose that is prohibited by applicable federal or state law or for any permitted purpose that is not specifically authorized by the committee.

    G.  Any interest or other revenue generated on account of the investment of moneys in the seizure/forfeiture fund shall remain in the fund. (Ord. 14-1997 § 1)

Chapter 3.36 RECOVERY OF FEES AND DAMAGES with respect to dishonored checks
3.36.010 Bookkeeping charge authorized for checks not paid upon presentment.
    Any person who obtains goods, property, services, including but not limited to water service, or any other thing of value from the City, or who makes any payment of any obligation owing to the City by means of making any check, draft, or order for the payment of money upon any bank, depository, person, firm, or corporation which is not paid upon its presentment is liable to the City, as holder of such check, draft, or order for an amount equal to the face amount of the check, draft, or order and the amount of any reasonable posted or contractual bookkeeping charge not exceeding twenty dollars ($20.00), or such greater amount as might be specified in Section 13-21-209(1)(b)(I), C.R.S. (Ord. 20-2002 § 1)

 

3.36.020 Relief from liability for bookkeeping charge.
    As to any check, draft or order that is not paid upon its presentment, the bookkeeping charge authorized in Section 3.36.010 shall not be imposed if the maker thereof establishes any one of the following:

    A.  That the account contained sufficient funds or credit to cover the check, draft, or order at the time the check, draft, or order was made, plus all other checks, drafts, and orders on the account then outstanding and unpaid;

    B.   That the check, draft, or order was not paid because a paycheck, deposited in the account in an amount sufficient to cover the check, draft, or order, was not paid upon presentment;

    C.   That funds sufficient to cover the check, draft, or order were garnished, attached, or set off and the maker had no notice of such garnishment, attachment, or setoff at the time the check, draft, or order was made;

    D.  That the maker of the check, draft, or order was not competent or of full age to enter into a legal contractual obligation at the time the check, draft, or order was made;

    E.   That the making of the check, draft, or order was induced by fraud or duress;

    F.   That the transaction which gave rise to the obligation for which the check, draft, or order was given lacked consideration or was illegal. (Ord. 20-2002 § 1)

 

3.36.030 Additional remedies with respect to water services accounts.
    If the Director of Finance, or his or her designee, elects to impose the bookkeeping charge authorized in Section 3.36.010, and if the check, draft or order that was not paid upon its presentment was tendered in payment of a water bill, the Director of Finance, or his or her designee, shall be authorized to:

    A.  Add the amount of the bookkeeping charge to the applicable customer account and to bill such amount as a current charge on the customer’s next regular water bill, even if the dishonored check, draft or order is honored on its second presentment.

    B.   Order the disconnection of water service, without further notice to the water customer, in cases where a shut-off notice was given to the affected water customer (in accordance with the provisions of Section 13.08.150 of this Code) prior to the tender of a check, draft or money order that is twice dishonored upon its presentment.

    C.   If water service is disconnected under circumstances described in Subsection B of this section, turn-on and turn-off fees authorized in Section 13.08.095 of this Code may be assessed against the account of the affected water customer. (Ord. 20-2002 § 1)

 

3.36.040 Cash only status authorized.
    If, during the same calendar year, any person tenders two or more checks, drafts or orders to the City that are not paid upon their first presentment, the City may place such person, and any account such person has with the City, on a cash-only basis with respect to all future transactions between that person and the City, by giving written notice to such person. After such notice is given, the City may require that all of such person’s payments to the City be made in cash and may refuse to accept as payment for any obligation owing to the City anything other than cash. The City may remove a person from “cash-only” status by written notice, signed by the Director of Finance, or his or her designee. For purposes of this subsection, cash means and includes United States currency, certified checks, cashier’s checks and money orders payable to the City. (Ord. 20-2002 § 1)

 

3.36.050 Statutory damages available.
    Nothing in this chapter shall preclude the City and its officers, employees, agents and assigns from exercising any right or option under Section 13-21-109, C.R.S., that is available to the holder of a check, draft or order that is not paid upon its presentment; provided that the “bookkeeping charge” provided for in Section 3.36.010 and the charge authorized under Section 13-21-109(1)(b)(I), C.R.S., shall not both be imposed with respect to any single check, draft or order. (Ord. 20-2002 § 1)

Chapter 3.40 INTEREST CHARGEABLE ON MISCELLANEOUS ACCOUNTS RECEIVABLE
3.40.010 Legal rate of interest.
    Unless a different rate is specified in a written agreement signed by the City or a greater rate is specified in another ordinance of the City, interest calculated at the monthly rate of one and one-half percent (1-1/2%) may be charged with respect to any money owing to the City that is not paid when due. Such interest will be calculated on past due outstanding balances. (Ord. 18-2008 § 1)

Chapter 3.50 ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT INCENTIVE PROGRAM
3.50.010 Water tap fee deferrals and waivers.
    A.  In an effort to encourage the construction of new residential, commercial and industrial buildings within the corporate boundaries of the City and the associated creation and/or preservation of construction-related employment opportunities for local citizens and sales of building materials by local businesses, the Council of Cañon City established a temporary program that began in 2014 and which will end on December 31, 2017 pursuant to which qualifying applicants will become entitled to deferrals and thereafter waivers of water tap fees otherwise payable before a building permit is issued in accordance with the provisions of Chapter 13.08 of the Cañon City Municipal Code (“CCMC”).

    B.   Definitions.

    1.   For purposes of the temporary water tap fee deferral and waiver program outlined in this section, “building” means and includes any new single family residence, new duplex, new multi-family building, new commercial building, new industrial building and also includes newly-constructed residential and/or commercial units within existing buildings that require new water taps as a precondition to the issuance of a certificate of occupancy for such unit.

    2.   “Person” for purposes of this chapter, shall mean and include individuals, corporations, LLCs, partnerships and other entities capable of owning property in Colorado.

    C.   “Qualifying applicants” will include only those persons who apply for water taps and who also satisfy each of the following conditions:

    1.   A qualifying applicant must own or otherwise control land located within the water service area served by the Cañon City Water Department with respect to which a completed application for water service to new residential, commercial or industrial buildings was filed in accordance with the provisions and requirements of Section 13.08.030, CCMC.

    2.   A qualifying applicant must have complied with all provisions and requirements of Section 13.08.020, CCMC, except for that portion of Subsection 13.08.020(A)(2) which requires the tender of payment of the full water tap fee.

    3.   Notwithstanding the provisions of this section that provide for a waiver of the water tap fee, a person who seeks to become a qualifying applicant shall become entitled to a deferral of the obligation to pay the water tap fee for such person’s project once such person has signed a statement prepared and presented by the City Engineer certifying that the City and the applicant agree on the amount of the water tap fee for applicant’s entire project, which shall be calculated in accordance with the provisions of Section 13.08.040, CCMC. Such statement shall reflect the maximum water tap fee payable by an applicant with respect to the applicant’s project and also shall clearly state the maximum water tap fee waiver offered by the City as a set-off to the maximum water tap fee otherwise payable. Such signed statement also shall contain the applicant’s agreement to pay the applicable water tap fee for any unit, units, building or buildings, as a condition precedent to the issuance of a permanent certificate of occupancy, if a permanent certificate of occupancy for such unit(s) or building(s) is not issued on or prior to December 31, 2017.

    4.   A qualifying applicant must pay when due all costs, if any, charged by the City for meters, meter pits, water line installations, service line connections and/or inspections associated with the establishment of water service to the properties where the applicant’s project is situated and restore any affected City-owned property to a condition equal to or better than the condition that existed prior to the making of such water system improvements.

    5.   Nothing in this section will relieve a qualifying applicant from any obligation to pay impact fees provided for at Section 13.08.140 and/or water line rebates required under Section 13.08.127. In addition, nothing in this section will relieve any qualifying applicant from any obligation provided for in a written improvements agreement executed by such person in order to comply with provisions and requirements of subdivision and/or site plan approval obtained by such person through any approval process required or permitted under the ordinances, resolutions, regulations or rules of the City, including all applicable written City standards.

    6.   A qualifying applicant must have been issued a building permit by the City and must have paid in full all applicable City fees—other than building permit fees and use taxes waived by the City pursuant to this chapter—with respect to such new unit(s) or building(s) and also must have obtained the issuance of a permanent certificate of occupancy for each building or unit with respect to which a water tap fee waiver will apply. All such permanent certificates of occupancy must be issued no later than December 31, 2017.

    7.   If permanent certificates of occupancy for some, but not all, units or buildings of a multiple-unit or multi-building project have been issued on or before December 31, 2017, water tap fee waivers will be available on a pro-rated basis only with respect to those newly constructed units or buildings for which permanent certificates of occupancy were issued on or prior to December 31, 2017.

    8.   Water tap fees with respect to those units or buildings for which permanent certificates of occupancy were not issued on or before December 31, 2017 shall be paid for in accordance with the provisions of the statement signed by the applicant pursuant to Subsection (C)(3) of this Section 3.50.010.

    9.   Water tap fees otherwise payable to the City will be waived for all persons who become qualifying applicants in accordance with the provisions of this Section 3.50.010.

    10. If a person becomes a qualifying applicant with respect to some, but not all, units or buildings in a project, for the sole reason that the applicant failed to receive the issuance of a permanent certificate of occupancy on or before December 31, 2017 with respect to some, but not all, of the units or buildings of a project, the applicant shall be entitled to a waiver of water tap fees for those units or buildings with respect to which permanent certificates of occupancy were issued on or before December 31, 2017.

    D.  Persons who fail to qualify as qualifying applicants pursuant to Section 3.50.010 of this Chapter shall nevertheless be entitled to water service for their projects; provided that such persons comply with all requirements of applicable local law and pay the full water tap fee set forth in the agreement required under Subsection (C)(3) of this section for each and every unit or building with respect to which the applicant has failed to qualify for a water tap fee waiver pursuant to the provisions of this section.

    E.   The City will be unable to waive tap fees for or with respect to new units or buildings located outside of the City or within the City but outside of the water service area of the Cañon City Water Department. (For example, no waiver will be available with respect to new buildings located on properties within the service area of the Park Center Water District that will be served by that District.) (Ord. 2-2015 § 1)

 

3.50.020 Building permit fee deferrals.
    A.  As additional incentives to persons who undertake certain new construction projects within the City, building permit fees otherwise payable by such persons to the City prior to the issuance of a building permit may be deferred.

    B.   Building permit fees shall be deferred under the following circumstances:

    1.   In all cases where the owner of land upon which new construction is to take place qualifies for the deferral of water tap fees pursuant to the provisions of Section 3.50.010.

    2.   In cases where a new residential, commercial, industrial or mixed use building is constructed on vacant land in any zone district where such building is an allowed use; provided that no building previously existed on such land.

    3.   In cases where a principal commercial, residential, or industrial building (or significant portions thereof) is (are) remodeled or renovated to make the remodeled space suitable for occupancy for an allowed commercial, residential or industrial use that did not exist prior to the application for a building permit; provided that the property on which the building is situated is located in a C, CB, I-1, or mixed use zone district of the City.

    4.   In cases where a commercial, mixed use or industrial building in a C, CB or I-1 zone district of the City is demolished or torn down and promptly rebuilt in accordance with the provisions of applicable law.

    5.   In cases where a historical building façade of a property situated within the designated downtown historic district of the City is renovated in accordance with applicable standards within such historic district. (Ord. 2-2015 § 1)

 

3.50.030 Building permit fees—Waiver.
    A.  In those cases where building permit fees for a project are deferred pursuant to Section 3.50.020, such building permit fees will be waived if, but only if, a permanent certificate of occupancy is issued for the project on or before December 31, 2017 and the person seeking such waiver has complied with applicable law in the construction of such person’s unit, building or project.

    B.   Persons who become eligible for a deferral of building permit fees pursuant to Section 3.50.020, as a prerequisite to the subsequent waiver of such building permit fees, shall be required to sign an agreement with the City that sets forth the amount of the deferred building permit fee and provides that the person entitled to such deferral agrees to pay the deferred building permit fee if a permanent certificate of occupancy is not issued for the project on or before December 31, 2017. Such agreement also shall provide that the City will waive the building permit fee if a permanent certificate of occupancy covering the project is issued on or before December 31, 2017.

    C.   Owners of projects with respect to which building permit fees were deferred, but not waived, will not be issued permanent certificates of occupancy until deferred building permit fees identified in the agreement required under Subsection B of this section have been paid in full.

    D.  Notwithstanding the foregoing provisions of this Section 3.50.030, if a certificate of occupancy is not required to be issued for any project identified in Section 3.50.020, the building permit fee will be waived with respect to such project if, but only if, on or before December 31, 2017, all elements of the project have been approved following a final inspection by a City Building Inspector. (Ord. 2-2015 § 1)

 

3.50.040 Use tax deferrals and waivers.
    A.  The owner of any land upon which any building, unit or project is to be constructed who becomes eligible for a deferral of building permit fees pursuant to Section 3.50.020 shall also be entitled to obtain a building permit without first paying estimated use taxes for such owner’s building, unit or project.

    B.   Persons whose use tax obligation was deferred pursuant to this section shall be relieved of any obligation to pay use taxes to the City with respect to such person’s construction project if a permanent certificate of occupancy is issued for their unit, building or project on or before December 31, 2017.

    C.   If a permanent certificate of occupancy for such unit, building or project is not issued on or before December 31, 2017, the owner of such unit, building or project shall be obligated to pay to the City, prior to the issuance of a permanent certificate of occupancy, use taxes on the value of all building materials incorporated into such owner’s unit, building or project on or prior to December 31, 2017, unless such owner is able to show proof acceptable to the City that sales taxes on such building materials were paid at the times and places of their purchase. Use taxes also will be owing to the City with respect to building materials purchased after December 31, 2017 that are incorporated into any unit, building or project.

    D.  Owners who wish for the City to defer prepayment of use taxes pursuant to this section must first sign an agreement with the City that identifies the estimated use tax for the building materials to be incorporated into the owner’s unit, building or project that would have been payable to the City prior to the issuance of a building permit had the use tax deferral outlined in this Section 3.50.040 not been available. Such agreement also must contain the owner’s promise to pay any use taxes that might become payable with respect to building materials incorporated into their units, buildings or projects to the extent that such owner is unable to adequately document the payment of sales taxes with respect to such building materials. Such agreement also shall contain the owner’s promise to pay use taxes on all building materials purchased after December 31, 2017 if such materials are incorporated into such owner’s unit, building or project.

    E.   Nothing in this section shall constitute a deferral or waiver of any owner’s obligation to pay sales taxes when and where the payment of state or local sales taxes is required by applicable law.

    F.   All owners are encouraged to purchase building materials locally as their contribution to stimulating the local economy.

    G.  Nothing in this section shall relieve any owner of its obligation to prepay or pay estimated or actual use taxes to other jurisdictions, including but not necessarily limited to the County of Fremont.

    H.  Notwithstanding the foregoing provisions of this Section 3.50.040, if a certificate of occupancy is not required to be issued for any project with respect to which the owner was not obligated to prepay estimated use taxes, such owner shall be relieved of any obligation to pay use taxes to the City respecting such project if, on or before December 31, 2017, all elements of the project have been approved following a final inspection by a City Building Inspector. (Ord. 2-2015 § 1)

 

3.50.050 Codification and expansion of stimulus program.
    A.  This Chapter 3.50 codifies and expands the scope of the economic stimulus program first established by the City through Ordinance No. 19, Series of 2014, which is superseded by this chapter. Any person who qualified for the deferral of a water tap fee, a building permit fee and/or who was issued a building permit without first being required to pay estimated use taxes to the City shall be eligible to qualify for waivers of such water tap fee, building permit fee and/or use tax obligation by complying with the provisions of this chapter.

    B.   Unless extended by subsequent ordinance of the Council of Cañon City, the economic stimulus program provided for in this chapter shall expire on January 1, 2018; provided that any person who becomes obligated to pay water tap fees, building permit fees or use taxes to the City because a permanent certificate of occupancy was not issued for such person’s unit, building or project on or before December 31, 2017 shall remain obligated to make such payment or payments until such obligation or obligations have been paid in full.

    C.   Agreements required under the provisions of Sections 3.50.010, 3.50.030 and/or 3.50.040 may be included in a single document if the City so decides. (Ord. 2-2015 § 1)

 

3.50.060 Sunset of Economic Development Incentive Program.
    A.  The Economic Development Incentive Program outlined in this Chapter 3.50 shall sunset and terminate for all purposes on December 31, 2017 and this Chapter 3.50 shall be repealed as of said date.

    B.   Applications for participation in the Economic Development Incentive Program shall not be considered or acted upon after December 31, 2016.

    C.   Deadline for Execution of Agreements for Deferrals.

    1.   No deferral of water tap fees shall be considered or granted unless both the applicant for such deferral and the City have executed the statement and agreement required by Subsection 3.50.010(C)(3) of this chapter on or before December 31, 2016.

    2.   No application for the deferral of building permit fees shall be considered or granted unless both the City and the applicant shall have executed the agreement required by Subsection 3.50.030(B) of this chapter on or before December 31, 2016.

    3.   No application for the deferral of the obligation to prepay estimated use taxes prior to the issuance of a building permit shall be considered or granted unless both the City and the applicant have executed the agreement required by Subsection 3.50.040(D) of this chapter on or before December 31, 2016.

    D.  No waiver of water tap fees, building permit fees or use taxes shall be offered or allowed by the City for any project with respect to which the agreements provided for in this chapter have been timely executed unless the project is completed on or before December 31, 2017, as evidenced by the issuance of a certificate of occupancy for any project requiring the issuance of a certificate of occupancy, or by the Building Official’s final inspection and approval of all elements of a project for which a certificate of occupancy is not required.

    E.   Agreements executed pursuant to the requirements of this Chapter 3.50 shall be enforceable by the City following the sunset of the Economic Development Incentive Program and the repeal of Chapter 3.50. (Ord. 16-2016 § 1)

Chapter 3.60 BUDGETING PROCEDURES
3.60.010 Budget transfers and amendments.
    A.  Pursuant to the City’s Charter, City Council is required to approve transfers of monies to satisfy the expenditure related to any object and/or purpose, specified within the City’s annual budget.

    B.   The phrase “objects and purposes” or each term individually, as used in the City’s Charter, shall include personal services, supplies and purchased services, and capital outlay.

    C.   Amendments to the annual budget due to the receipt of unanticipated revenue shall be made in accordance with applicable state law.

    D.  The City Council may, by resolution, set the minimum amount of a budget transfer that requires City Council approval and delegate transfers of monies which are less than that established amount to the authority of the City Administrator. (Ord. 1-2019 § 1)

Chapter 5.08 AUCTIONEERS
5.08.010 “Auctioneer” defined.
    Whoever shall sell, or offer to sell, any goods, wares or merchandise, or any horses or other livestock, or any vehicles of any description, or any other personal property, or any real estate or interest therein, at any store, stand or other place in the city, by public outcry, for his or her own gain or profit, or shall advertise or in any other way hold him or herself out as an auctioneer for public patronage, or shall receive fees as a commission for his or her services, is defined to be an auctioneer. (Prior code § 5.08.020)

 

5.08.012 Colorado Revised Statutes apply.
    Notwithstanding any other provisions of this chapter, laws relative to auctioneers and sales at auction set forth in the Colorado Revised Statutes, as the same exist now or may be amended in the future, shall apply to all auctioneers and sales at auction. (Ord. 33-2010 § 2)

 

5.08.015 Direct purchase for resale.
    Any auctioneer that directly purchases merchandise or items from a seller with the intent to directly resell such merchandise or items, either through auction or other means, for which the auctioneer will receive the entire proceeds of the sale (as opposed to a percentage of each item auctioned on behalf of a seller), shall be obligated to comply with all provisions as set forth in Chapter 5.46 of this Code (pertaining to Secondhand Dealers and Flea Market Businesses) with respect to such merchandise and items. (Ord. 33-2010 § 3)

 

5.08.020 Exceptions to chapter application.
    A.  No provisions in this chapter shall be construed to apply to sales made at public auction under and by virtue of any legal process or proceeding through a court of law or equity, or to sales under any mortgage or trust deed, or to sales under any ordinance of the City by any municipal officer.

    B.   Auctioneers who donate auction services for the direct benefit of bona fide non-profit organizations are not required to obtain any license required in this chapter with respect to such donated auction services. In such cases, the auctioneer shall not be publicized or advertised as an auctioneer related to the event and the auctioneer calling the sales shall receive no remuneration or benefit for donating such services. (Ord. 33-2010 § 4; prior code § 5.08.010)

 

5.08.030 License—Required.
    No person shall sell any property at public auction within this city without a license therefor first had and obtained from the City Clerk according to the provisions of this chapter. (Prior code § 5.08.030)

 

5.08.040 License—Types and fees.
    A.  Auction Room License. For a license limited in character to maintain an auction room or place as a regular business within this city, and to sell at auction therein, there shall be paid to the City a license fee of three hundred dollars ($300.00) per year or portion thereof.

    B.   Annual Auctioneer License. For an annual license to conduct auctions at places other than a licensed auction room or place of business, there shall be paid to the City, a license fee of one hundred dollars ($100.00) annually. Auctioneers who acquire a one-year license contemplated in this subsection shall notify the City Clerk’s office of the location of each auction to be held inside city limits at least five (5) business days prior to the auction date. Failure to timely provide such notification shall result in a twenty-five dollar ($25.00) late reporting fee being charged to the licensee in addition to any other applicable fees provided for in this section.

    C.   One-Day Auctioneer License. For a one-day license to conduct auctions in places other than a licensed auction room or place of business, there shall be paid to the City a license fee of twenty-five dollars ($25.00). Such application for license and payment shall be made no less than five (5) business days prior to the date of the scheduled auction. Failure to apply for such license at least five (5) business days prior to the date of the scheduled auction shall result in an additional twenty-five dollar ($25.00) late application fee. (Ord. 33-2010 § 5)

 

5.08.045 Renewals.
    Renewals of the licenses provided for in this Chapter 5.08 shall be governed by the provisions of Chapter 5.66 of this title. (Ord. 33-2010 § 6)

 

5.08.050 Violation—Misdemeanor—Administrative penalty.
    Penalties for violation of any of the provisions of this Chapter 5.08 shall be as provided in Chapter 5.66 of this title. (Ord. 33-2010 § 7)

Chapter 5.12 CONTRACTOR LICENSING
5.12.010 Definitions.
    As used in this chapter:

    A.  “Contractor” means any person or entity who undertakes, within the City, to perform any work on any building or structure or any portion thereof for which a permit is required by Title 15 of this Code, or the improvement, excavation or installation of utilities, or any work accomplished on City property or in a public right-of-way.

    B.   “Trade” means one component of the work on any building or structure or work within or on infrastructure in the public right-of-way. These trades shall include, by example but not be limited to, the following: awnings, demolition, excavation/concrete, fencing, foundation repair/mud jacking, framing/carpentry, insulation, signage, swimming pools, masonry, dry wall, glazing/window replacement, roofing, siding/stucco, structural steel fabrication/carports, ornamental iron, and right-of-way work carried on in the construction, alteration, or repair of buildings or structures requiring special knowledge and skill for the performance thereof. (Ord. 9-2020 § 1)

 

5.12.020 License—Required.
    A.  No contractor shall perform any work without having obtained a license to perform such work from the City under this chapter.

    B.   No contractor that is not a natural person shall perform any work without having in its employ a natural person licensed as a contractor under this chapter for the type of work performed. The name of such person shall be registered with the Building Official. If such person should leave the employ of the licensee, the license shall be deemed suspended until another licensed natural person is registered with the Building Official. Such person shall provide personal supervision at the work, job or project site adhering to reasonable attention to the job site to insure proper construction as determined by the City.

    C.   The following persons are exempt from the licensing requirements of this chapter:

    1.   A person working under the supervision of any other person licensed under this chapter;

    2.   A homeowner who builds, constructs, alters, repairs, adds to or demolishes any building or structure or any portion thereof that constitutes the owner’s residence, or a building or structure accessory thereto, and that is intended for the owner’s personal use. This section shall not apply to the installation or repair of fire alarms and fire sprinklers;

    3.   A public utility company and its employees, when engaged in the installation, operation and maintenance of its equipment used for the production, generation or distribution of the utility, product or service through the facilities owned or operated by the utility company to the point of customer service;

    4.   Persons who perform work with homeowners as volunteers on projects for which a homeowner is not required to obtain a license.

    D.  Licenses are nontransferable. (Ord. 9-2020 § 1)

 

5.12.030 Applications.
    A.  Any person, firm or corporation applying for a new license or to renew a license shall:

    1.   Submit a complete and accurate written application on a form provided or specified by the City;

    2.   Provide proof of passage of examination, if applicable, as required by Section 5.12.050; and

    3.   Pay to the City the application or renewal fee, established by resolution of City Council.

    B.   No license shall be issued to an applicant until the applicant has successfully passed an examination to test the applicant’s qualifications for the category of license requested, as required by Section 5.12.050.

    C.   Trade class licenses may be issued for up to four (4) different trades under one licensee. (Ord. 9-2020 § 1)

 

5.12.040 Classification of contractor licenses.
    A.  General Contractor Class A. This license entitles the licensee to construct, remodel or repair any commercial or residential structure or addition thereto, including tenant finish, for which a building permit is required. This license does not allow work that includes electrical, plumbing, mechanical, signs, fire and burglar alarms, fire protection, and trades outside the license holder’s area of expertise.

    B.   General Contractor Class B. This license entitles the licensee to construct, remodel or repair commercial or residential buildings not exceeding three stories in height for which a building permit is required. This license does not allow work that includes electrical, plumbing, mechanical, signs, fire and burglar alarms, fire protection, and other trades outside the license holder’s area of expertise.

    C.   General Contractor Class C. This license entitles the licensee to construct, remodel or repair any residential building. This license does not allow work that includes electrical, plumbing, mechanical, signs, fire and burglar alarms, fire protection, and other trades outside the license holder’s area of expertise.

    D.  Mechanical Class M. A mechanical license entitles the holder to install, maintain, alter, or repair mechanical systems that are permanently installed and utilized to provide control of environmental conditions and related process within buildings. This shall include evaporative refrigeration systems and related appurtenances.

    E.   Trade Class D. A trade license may be issued to a contractor who specializes in a specific trade listed in this Section 5.12.010. An applicant may obtain a trade license for up to four (4) trades. (Ord. 9-2020 § 1)

 

5.12.050 License—Denial or revocation conditions.
    Any license issued pursuant to this chapter may be revoked, suspended or refused to any person, firm or corporation that intentionally violates the federal, state or municipal laws, rules and ordinances pertaining to the building trades. A contractor’s license may be revoked or suspended immediately by the Building Inspector if the situation warrants such action. The contractor may appeal the decision of the Inspector to the City Administrator pursuant to Section 2.52.010(C) of this Code. (Ord. 18-2020 § 3)

 

5.12.060 Denial of license.
    A.  The Building Official may deny a license under this chapter upon a finding of any of the following:

    1.   The applicant has failed to provide information requested on the application form;

    2.   The applicant is not qualified by experience, training or education to engage in the activity authorized by the license;

    3.   The applicant’s license for the same or similar work is under suspension or revocation in the City or another jurisdiction; or

    4.   The applicant has been convicted of an offense relating to the conduct of the activity licensed by this chapter within the last year prior to the application.

    B.   If the Building Official denies a license application under this section, he or she shall notify the applicant in writing stating the specific grounds for the denial. The applicant may thereafter appeal the denial of the application to the City Administrator in writing within ten (10) days of the denial. (Ord. 9-2020 § 1)

 

5.12.070 Renewal.
    A.  All licenses expire on December 31st of each year.

    B.   A licensee under this chapter shall renew his or her license every year by filing a completed application for renewal with the Building Official and paying the fees required in this chapter.

    C.   A renewal application may be denied as provided in Section 5.12.060. (Ord. 9-2020 § 1)

 

5.12.080 Insurance.
    All contractors who work within the public right-of-way, unless exempted from licensing in this chapter, shall meet the insurance requirements in Section 12.12.070 of this Code. (Ord. 9-2020 § 1)

 

5.12.090 Suspension or revocation of license.
    A.  The Building Official shall, upon the verified complaint in writing of any person, require the licensee to appear before the City Administrator for hearing on the possible suspension or revocation of the licensee’s license. The licensee shall be given a copy of the complaint and at least twenty (20) days written notice of the time and place of the hearing. The notice shall be served personally, or shall be mailed by first class mail to the licensee’s last known mailing address. At the hearing the licensee shall have the right to present his or her case by oral or documentary evidence, to submit rebuttal evidence, and to conduct such cross-examination as may be required for a full and true disclosure of the facts. The licensee shall be entitled at said hearing to have the benefit of legal counsel of his or her own choosing and own expense.

    B.   The City Administrator, after review of the evidence presented, shall have the power to suspend or revoke the license or take other disciplinary action on the license, including the issuance of a formal letter of reprimand; or order the licensee to pay unpaid permit fees and inspection or investigative costs incurred by the City; or impose a probationary period during which time any further violations would result in automatic suspension or revocation of the license. The City Administrator may take any of the foregoing actions if the City Administrator finds that the licensee committed one or more of the following acts related to work as a contractor:

    1.   Violation of any provision of Titles 3, 15, and 17 of this Code;

    2.   Failure to comply with any lawful order of the Building Official or any other authorized representative of the City;

    3.   Use of the license or registration to obtain permits required under the building codes for any other person;

    4.   Misrepresentation of a material fact when applying for a license, or fraud in obtaining a license;

    5.   Gross negligence in the work done by the licensee;

    6.   Failure to obtain a permit required under this Code;

    7.   Failure to give written notice to the Building Official of any matter for which notice is required by this chapter; or

    8.   Conviction of an offense involving misapplication of funds or property received from another.

    C.   Emergency Suspension. If the Building Official finds that an emergency exists which justifies immediate suspension or revocation of a license, he or she may enter an order for immediate suspension of such license, pending further investigation and proceedings for suspension or revocation as provided in this chapter. The licensee may, upon notice of such suspension, request an immediate hearing before the Building Official.

    D.  The Building Official may suspend licenses upon the written consent and approval of the licensee.

    E.   If the license of any contractor is revoked, another such license shall not be granted to such contractor within twelve (12) months after the effective date of the revocation. If a license is suspended, the City Administrator shall state the period and terms of the suspension. Unless otherwise ordered by the City Administrator, a license shall not be reinstated following a suspension or renewed following revocation unless the contractor has successfully passed an examination as specified in Section 5.12.050. (Ord. 9-2020 § 1)

Chapter 5.24 TRASH, GARBAGE, REFUSE AND RUBBISH COLLECTION
5.24.010 Definitions.
    As used in this chapter:

    “Compensation” means any money, property, service or thing of value charged or received or to be charged or received whether directly or indirectly.

    “Motor vehicle” means any automobile, truck, tractor, bus, or other self-propelled vehicle or any trailer drawn thereby excluding vehicles operated upon fixed rails.

    “Person” means any individual, partnership, limited liability company, corporation, association or other legal entity, but does not include the City of Cañon City or any of its departments or employees.

    “Trash haulage license” means a license issued to a trash hauler pursuant to the requirements and other provisions of this chapter.

    “Trash haulage purpose” means any activity of a trash hauler involving the use of streets, alleys and other public thoroughfares in the city for the collection, hauling or transportation, for compensation, of any trash, garbage, refuse, rubbish or other waste material of any kind.

    “Trash hauler” means any person who uses the streets, alleys and other public thoroughfares in the city for the collection, hauling or transportation, for compensation, of any trash, garbage, refuse, rubbish or other waste material of any kind. (Ord. 36-1998 § 1)

 

5.24.020 License—Required.
    A.  Beginning January 1, 1999, no person shall use any street, alley or other public thoroughfare in the city for the collection, hauling or transporting, for compensation, of any trash, garbage, refuse, rubbish or other waste materials of any kind unless such person holds a valid trash haulage license issued pursuant to this chapter or is exempt under Subsection B of this section.

    B.   The following persons are not required to obtain a trash haulage license:

    1.   A civic, community, benevolent or charitable nonprofit organization that collects, transports and markets materials for resource recovery solely for the purpose of raising funds for a charitable, civic or benevolent activity;

    2.   A person who transports trash or recyclable materials produced by such person;

    3.   A property owner or agent thereof who transports trash or recyclable materials left by a tenant upon such owner’s property, so long as such property owner does not provide trash collection service for compensation for tenants on a regular or continuing basis;

 

    4.   A demolition or construction contractor or landscaper who produces and transports trash other than garbage in the course of such occupation, where the trash produced is merely incidental to the particular demolition or construction work being performed by such person;

    5.   A tree trimming service, lawn care service or garden care service contractor who in the normal course of his or her occupation produces yard rubbish, including tree branches, twigs, grass, shrub clippings, weeds, leaves and other general yard, garden and organic waste material, and transports such materials from places where such contractor works as an incidental portion of the work being performed by such contractor.

    6.   A person hauling trash as the City’s agent pursuant to a nuisance abatement action. (Ord. 44-2017 § 2; Ord. 36-1998 § 1)

 

5.24.030 Trash haulage license—Application and fee.
    A.  Applications for trash haulage licenses shall be made to the City Clerk on forms provided for that purpose.

    B.   No application for a trash haulage license shall be complete and no trash haulage license shall be issued until the applicant has:

    1.   Submitted a copy of each registration for all motor vehicles owned or controlled by the trash hauler that will be used for trash haulage purposes during the effective period of the license being applied for. Such list shall identify each such motor vehicle by make, model, VIN and State of Colorado vehicle registration number and shall state where each such vehicle will be parked or kept when not in use for trash haulage purposes;

    2.   Submitted valid and current certificates of general liability insurance coverage for all such listed vehicles indicating that each such vehicle is insured in accordance with Section 5.24.040;

    3.   Submitted such other forms and documents that may be required by the City Clerk;

    4.   Paid an annual trash haulage license fee of seventy-five dollars ($75.00), with respect to any one vehicle to be used for trash haulage purposes, plus an additional fee of twenty-five dollars ($25.00) for each additional vehicle shown on or added to the applicant’s list.

    C.   During the effective period of the license, any person holding a valid trash haulage license may add to its list of vehicles available for use for trash haulage purposes any motor vehicle that is insured pursuant to Section 5.24.040. No motor vehicle shall be used for trash haulage purposes unless such vehicle is first included on the licensee’s list of registered vehicles and a copy of the registration and proof of insurance has been submitted to the City Clerk.

    D.  Each trash haulage license shall be nontransferable and shall remain in effect from its date of issuance until the last day of January of the following year.

    E.   For all vehicles to be used for trash haulage purposes after March 31, 2000, the Clerk shall also require that such vehicle be inspected and certified pursuant to Section 5.24.050 before such vehicle will be authorized for use for trash haulage purposes during the remainder of calendar year 2000 and thereafter under any license issued by the Clerk. (Ord. 33-2010 §§ 8—10; Ord. 36-1998 § 1)

 

5.24.040 Liability insurance requirements.
    A.  Before any license provided for in this chapter shall be issued, the applicant for such license shall file a certificate of insurance evidencing that the applicant is covered by comprehensive general liability insurance in amounts equal to or greater than those minimum coverage amounts specified by the City Administrator or designee for the type of license to be issued pursuant to this chapter. Such certificate shall provide that the City of Cañon City is named as an additional insured. All such insurance must be maintained and remain in full force and effect during the period for which the license will be issued.
