Entering the armed forces or attending school outside of the boundaries of Cañon City Fire District shall not automatically terminate residency unless upon review of the totality of the circumstances, it is determined that the individual cultivators primary home has changed. (Ord. 2-2017 § 1)

 

5.60.260 Tracking marijuana.
    A.  All licensees shall operate a tracking system to track the weight of marijuana that leaves the facility and the number of plants that are brought into and removed from the facility.

    B.   All tracking systems shall include the measurement of the weight of the unprocessed marijuana by a scale prior to the marijuana being transported out of the facility. The scale used to weigh the marijuana to be transported out of the facility shall be of a type provided or approved by the City. Calibration of the scale shall be performed at least annually by the licensee and all testing and results shall be recorded. All weighing shall be observed by the licensee or licensee’s employees and recorded in the tracking system.

    C.   The tracking system shall record the name of the individual cultivator, the weight of marijuana, the number of plants being cultivated, and the date and time the marijuana is being transported out of the facility. (Ord. 2-2017 § 1)

 

5.60.270 Visibility of activities—Paraphernalia—Control of emissions.
    A.  All activities of a Community Marijuana Cultivation Facility shall be conducted indoors, except for outside construction or maintenance related to the license premises.

    B.   No marijuana shall be visible from outside the licensed premises.

    C.   Sufficient measures and means of preventing smoke, odors, debris, dust, fluids and other substances from discharging from a Community Marijuana Cultivation Facility shall be provided at all times. Such measures should include, at a minimum, carbon filters and scrubbers.

    D.  In the event that any odors, debris, dust, fluids or other substances are discharged a Community Marijuana Cultivation Facility, the owner of the subject premises and the licensee shall be jointly and severally liable for such conditions and shall be responsible for immediate, full clean-up and correction of such condition. If the licensee fails to clean up or correct such a condition, the City may abate the condition pursuant to Section 8.38.080 of the Cañon City Municipal Code.

    E.   Any off-site odor from a Community Marijuana Cultivation Facility shall not exceed a ratio adopted by the Air Control Division of the Colorado Department of Public Health and Environment, as may be amended from time to time, for areas used predominately for commercial purposes, when measured from any location along the building exterior of the licensed premises, as measured by an instrument, device or method designated by the Colorado Air Pollution Division to be used in the determination of the intensity of an odor.

    F.   Lighting used to cultivate marijuana shall be contained solely within the interior of the facility and shall not emit any light that is visible from the outside of the facility. (Ord. 2-2017 § 1)

 

5.60.280 Disposal of marijuana byproducts.
    A.  Liquid Waste. Liquid waste from a Community Marijuana Cultivation Facility shall be disposed of in compliance with the applicable Water Quality Control Division statutes and regulations.

    B.   Solid Waste. Disposal of hazardous and chemical waste shall be conducted in a manner consistent with federal, state and local laws. Solid waste disposal shall be conducted in accordance with this section.

    C.   Waste Shall Be Made Unusable and Unrecognizable. Marijuana waste must be made unusable and unrecognizable prior to leaving the Licensed Premises.

    D.  Methods to Make Waste Unusable and Unrecognizable. Marijuana waste shall be rendered unusable and unrecognizable through one of the following methods:

    1.   Grinding and incorporating the marijuana waste with non-consumable, solid wastes listed below such that the resulting mixture is at least fifty (50) percent non-marijuana waste:

    a.   Paper waste;

    b.   Plastic waste;

    c.   Cardboard waste;

    d.   Food waste;

    e.   Grease or other compostable oil waste;

    f.    Bokashi or other compost activators;

    g.   Other wastes approved by the City that will render the marijuana waste unusable and unrecognizable; and

    h.   Soil.

    E.   After waste is made unusable and unrecognizable, licensees shall only dispose of marijuana waste in a secured waste receptacle in possession and control of the licensee. Licensee or licensee’s contracted agent shall be solely responsible for the disposal of waste under this section. After the marijuana waste is made unusable and unrecognizable, then the rendered waste shall be:

    1.   Disposed at a solid waste site and disposal facility that has a Certificate of Designation from the local governing body;

    2.   Deposited at a compost facility that has a Certificate of Designation from the Department of Public Health and Environment; or

    3.   Composted on-site at a facility owned by the generator of the waste and operated in compliance with the Regulations Pertaining to Solid Waste Sites and Facilities (6 CCR 1007-2, Part 1) in the Department of Public Health and Environment. (Ord. 2-2017 § 1)

 

5.60.290 Business license required.
    At all times while a license is in effect the licensee shall possess a valid business license. (Ord. 2-2017 § 1)

 

5.60.300 Required books and records.
    A.  Every licensee shall maintain an accurate and complete record of the following:

    1.   all leases and maximum allowable plants for each individual cultivator, including proof of residency within the boundaries of the Cañon City Fire District.

    2.   a daily log of all individuals who enter the licensed premises.

    3.   the tracking system as described in Section 5.60.260.

    4.   calibration of all scales as described in Section 5.60.260.

    B.   All records required to be kept under this chapter shall be kept in the English language, in a legible manner and shall be preserved and made available for inspection for a period of three (3) years. Information inspected by the Cañon City Police Department or other City departments pursuant to this chapter shall be used for regulatory and law enforcement purposes only and shall not be a matter of public record.

    C.   The City may, at any time and within its sole discretion, perform an audit of the licensee’s facility records. Licensee shall cooperate with any such audit.

    D.  Financial records submitted as part of the application or renewal process and/or obtained by the City through any inspection or audit shall be considered confidential and not subject to disclosure under the Colorado Open Records Act, C.R.S. § 24-72-100.1 et seq. (Ord. 2-2017 § 1)

 

5.60.310 Inspection of licensed premises.
    As a condition of every license under this chapter, all licensed premises shall be subject to inspection at any time by the Local Licensing Authority, the Cañon City Police Department, by law enforcement officers, or such other departments or individuals duly authorized by the City for the purpose of investigating and determining compliance with the provisions of this chapter and any other applicable state and local laws or regulations. Said inspection may include, but need not be limited to, the inspection of records. Where any part of the licensed premises consists of a locked area, such area shall be made available for inspection, without delay, upon request. (Ord. 2-2017 § 1)

 

5.60.320 Nonrenewal, suspension or revocation of license.
    A.  The Local Licensing Authority may, after notice and hearing, suspend, revoke or refuse to renew a license for good cause, including suspension or revocation of the licensee’s license. The Local Licensing Authority is authorized to adopt rules and procedures governing the conduct of such hearings.

    B.   The Local Licensing Authority may, in its discretion, revoke or elect not to renew any license if it determines that the licensed premises has been inactive, without good cause, for at least three (3) months. (Ord. 2-2017 § 1)

 

5.60.330 Violations and penalties.
    In addition to the possible denial, suspension, revocation or nonrenewal of a license under the provisions of this chapter, any person, including, but not limited to, any licensee, manager or employee of a Community Marijuana Cultivation Facility, or any customer of such facility, who violates any of the provisions of this chapter, shall be subject to the following penalties:

    A.  Any person convicted of having violated any provision of this chapter shall be punished as set forth in Section 1.28.010 of the Cañon City Municipal Code.

    B.   The operation of a Community Marijuana Cultivation Facility without a valid license issued pursuant to this chapter may be enjoined by the City in an action brought in a court of competent jurisdiction, including the Cañon City Municipal Court.

    C.   The operation of a Community Marijuana Cultivation Facility without a valid license issued pursuant to this chapter is also deemed to be a nuisance pursuant to Title 8 of the Cañon City Municipal Code. (Ord. 12-2019 § 13; Ord. 2-2017 § 1)

 

5.60.340 No City liability—Indemnification.
    A.  By accepting a license issued pursuant to this chapter, the licensee waives and releases the City, its officers, elected officials, employees, attorneys and agents from any liability for injuries, damages or liabilities of any kind that result from any arrest or prosecution of a Community Marijuana Cultivation Facility owners, operators, employees, clients or customers for a violation of state or federal laws, rules or regulations.

    B.   By accepting a license issued pursuant to this chapter, all licensees, jointly and severally if more than one, agree to indemnify, defend and hold harmless the City, its officers, elected officials, employees, attorneys, agents, insurers and self-insurance pool against all liability, claims and demands on account of any injury, loss or damage, including, without limitation, claims arising from bodily injury, personal injury, sickness, disease, death, property loss or damage, or any other loss of any kind whatsoever arising out of or in any manner connected with the operation of the Community Marijuana Cultivation Facility that is the subject of the license. (Ord. 2-2017 § 1)

 

5.60.350 No waiver of governmental immunity.
    In adopting this chapter, the City Council is relying on and does not waive or intend to waive by any provision of this chapter, the monetary limitations or any other rights, immunities and protections provided by the Colorado Governmental Immunity Act, C.R.S. § 24-10-101, et seq., C.R.S., as from time to time amended, or any other limitation, right, immunity, or protection otherwise available to the City, its officers or its employees. (Ord. 2-2017 § 1)

 

5.60.360 Other laws remain applicable.
    A.  Any licensee may be required to demonstrate, upon demand by the Local Licensing Authority, the Cañon City Police Department, by law enforcement officers, or such other departments or individuals duly authorized by the City, that the source and quantity of any marijuana found upon the licensed premises are in full compliance with any applicable state or local law or regulation.

    B.   If the State prohibits the cultivation of marijuana in a facility like the type described in this chapter, any license issued hereunder shall be deemed immediately revoked by operation of law, with no ground for appeal or other redress on behalf of the licensee.

    C.   The issuance of any license pursuant to this chapter shall not be deemed to create an exception, defense or immunity to any person in regard to any potential criminal liability the person may have for the cultivation, possession, sale, distribution or use of marijuana. (Ord. 2-2017 § 1)

 

5.60.370 Review.
    City Council, or a designated committee, shall review this chapter at least once every two (2) years from its effective date. Failure to perform such a review shall not void or repeal this chapter. Nothing in this section shall prevent City Council from reviewing this chapter more frequently. (Ord. 2-2017 § 1)

Chapter 5.66 PROCEDURAL MATTERS PERTAINING TO LICENSES
5.66.010 Applicability.
    Unless otherwise provided to the contrary elsewhere in this Municipal Code, the provisions and conditions set forth in this chapter shall apply with respect to all licenses issued pursuant to Chapters 5.08, 5.24, 5.32, 5.34, 5.36, 5.40, 5.46, 5.52, 9.10 and 17.30 of the Cañon City Municipal Code. (Ord. 33-2010 § 43)

 

5.66.020 Term of licensure.
    Licenses and permits issued pursuant to the provisions of any chapter enumerated in Section 5.66.010 shall be effective for the calendar year or portion thereof specified on the license. (Ord. 33-2010 § 43)

 

5.66.030 Renewals.
    A.  Each license issued pursuant to the provisions of any chapter enumerated in Section 5.66.010 shall be renewed no later than January 31st of the calendar year that follows the year such license was issued. Renewals shall be requested by filing an application on forms supplied by the City Clerk (including any certificates and/or information required by this Code and requested by the City Clerk) and paying the applicable renewal fee to the City Clerk.

    B.   In addition to the license renewal fee, a late renewal fee of twenty-five dollars ($25.00) shall be charged for each renewal received after January 31st and before March 1st of each calendar year.

    C.   Any person or business submitting an application for renewal on or after March 1st of any calendar year shall be charged, in addition to the licensing fee, a one hundred dollar ($100.00) administrative penalty fee for renewal. (Ord. 33-2010 § 43)

 

5.66.040 Penalties for violations and administrative penalty fee option.
    A.  Any person who violates any provision of any chapter enumerated in Section 5.66.010, is guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon conviction thereof, shall be punished by a fine in an amount that does not exceed the maximum fine provided for in Section 1.28.010.

    B.   In lieu of Municipal Court proceedings where the penalties provided for in Subsection A may be imposed, any person, firm or corporation operating without an appropriate license as required under any chapter enumerated in Section 5.66.010 shall be given the option and opportunity to apply for such license by filing a complete application, paying the applicable license fee, and also paying an administrative penalty fee of one hundred dollars ($100.00). No Municipal Court proceedings respecting charges for operating without a valid license or permit will be initiated or continued upon the City’s receipt of such application and payment of the licensing fee and administrative penalty fee. (Ord. 17-2013 § 12; Ord. 33-2010 § 43)

 

5.66.050 Suspensions, revocations or denials.
    In addition to any other penalties imposed pursuant to state law or the City Municipal Code, the licensing official may, on his or her own motion or on complaint, and after investigation and a show-cause hearing at which the licensee shall be afforded an opportunity to be heard, suspend, revoke or deny any license previously issued or applied for on grounds that the applicant violated provisions, requirements, or conditions of Chapters 5.08 – Auctioneers; 5.24 – Trash, Garbage, Refuse and Rubbish Collection; 5.32 – Merchant Patrol and Security Guard Services and Security Guards; 5.34 – Mobile Home Parks; 5.36 – Pawnbrokers; 5.46 – Secondhand Dealer and Flea Market Businesses; 9.10 – Alarm Companies; and Section 17.30.100 – Outdoor Advertisers. (Ord. 33-2010 § 43)

Title 6 ANIMALS
Chapter 6.04 ANIMALS AND LIVESTOCK
Chapter 6.08 DOGS
Chapter 6.10 DOGS BANNED FROM CEMETERIES
Chapter 6.11 DEER HARVESTING PROGRAM

Chapter 6.04 ANIMALS AND LIVESTOCK
6.04.010 Animal defined.
    “Animal,” when used in this chapter, means and shall be construed to include horses, mules, cattle, sheep, swine, fowl and goats, as well as all other animals, except dogs and cats. (Prior code § 6.04.010)

 

6.04.020 Cruelty to animals prohibited.
    Any person who shall, in this city, cruelly beat, injure or otherwise abuse any dumb animal is guilty of a misdemeanor. (Prior code § 6.04.020)

 

6.04.030 Hitching animals to trees, hydrants or other items.
    Whoever shall, in this city, hitch or fasten any horse or other animal to a hydrant, to any ornamental or shade tree, lamppost, or any ornamental fence or railing, is guilty of a misdemeanor. (Prior code § 6.04.030)

 

6.04.040 Hitching or grazing animals in public places.
    No person shall hitch, tie, herd, picket, stake out or otherwise fasten any animal whatever in any place upon any public street or upon any public ground in the city, for the purpose of such animal eating grass or any other feed, or so as to get into or in anywise interfere with or damage any ditch in the city; provided, that this section shall not be deemed to apply in case of any animal which is being used for business or pleasure in the premises, for a reasonable length of time and in a manner not to obstruct the highway; and in no case shall any such animal be so hitched or otherwise fastened so as to enable it to get upon any sidewalk in the city. (Prior code § 6.04.040)

 

6.04.050 Animals at large—Nuisance.
    No animals shall run at large within the corporate limits of the city, and any animal so found running at large is declared a public nuisance. (Prior code § 6.04.070)

 

6.04.060 Animals at large—Owner in violation.
    Any owner of any animal or animals running at large within the city limits is guilty of a misdemeanor. (Prior code § 6.04.060)

 

6.04.070 Nuisance abatement—Impoundment authority.
    The members of the City police force, and every citizen of the City, are authorized and empowered to abate such nuisance by impounding in the City pound or humane shelter any such animal, or delivering same to the City pound keeper or person in charge of the pound or shelter. (Prior code § 6.04.080)

 

6.04.080 Impoundment—Notice required.
    A.  The Chief of Police, or his authorized agent, when any such animal is impounded, if the owner is not known, shall forthwith give notice thereof by posting notices, one at the entrance of the pound or shelter, and one at the post office of the City, giving the location of the pound or shelter, and shall give, immediately, seven days’ notice of sale, and publish same in a newspaper of general circulation within the city.

    B.   The notice shall contain, as near as may be, a description of the animal or animals impounded, giving color, sex and brand, and stating that, unless the animal or animals are claimed and the costs of feeding and advertising same are paid to the Chief of Police prior to the date named in the notice, which date shall be at least eight days from the date of first publication, he will sell such animal or animals at public sale.

    C.   If the owner is known, the notice shall be served on him only, either personally or by registered letter. (Prior code § 6.04.090)

 

6.04.090 Impoundment—Release conditions—Fee.
    The animal impounded pursuant to this chapter may be redeemed by the owner within the time specified in the notice provided for in this chapter, and by payment to the Chief of Police, between the hours of seven a.m. and five p.m., of all costs then accrued on account of the feeding, advertising and impounding. The Chief of Police shall then authorize release of the animal. (Prior code § 6.04.100)

 

6.04.100 Sale of unclaimed impounded animals.
    A.  If the animal or animals are not claimed within the time named, the Chief of Police shall, on the day named in the notice, proceed to sell the animal or animals at public auction to the highest bidder for cash. The sale shall commence at ten a.m.

    B.   The proceeds of such sale shall first be applied to the payment of the cost of feeding and advertising, and any surplus shall be turned over to the Director of Finance of the City.

    C.   The owner of the animal or animals so sold may, within a year from the date of such sale, obtain the surplus from the Director of Finance by making satisfactory proof of the ownership of such animal or animals. (Prior code § 6.04.110)

 

6.04.110 Unauthorized release from impoundment.
    Any person who opens the pound for the purpose of releasing any animal therein, except on the authority of the Chief of Police, is guilty of a misdemeanor. (Prior code § 6.04.120)

 

6.04.120 Violation—Penalty.
    Any person, firm or corporation violating any of the provisions of this chapter is guilty of a misdemeanor. (Prior code § 6.04.130)

Chapter 6.08 DOGS
6.08.010 Definitions.
    For all purposes under this chapter, the following words and phrases shall be construed as follows:

    A.  “Animal Control Officer” means any person employed by the City to enforce the provisions of this chapter, and any and all Police Officers of the City.

    B.   “City” means the City of Cañon City, Colorado.

    C.   “Destructive dog” means and includes any dog that injures or destroys or molests the property of persons, other than the owner, including particularly, among all other property, gardens, shrubbery, trees, vines, flowers, grass, and seed beds.

    D.  “Dog” means any dog, whether male or female, regardless of age, except that for purposes of licensing, registration and vaccinations, “dog” shall mean a male or female dog that is at least four months old.

    E.   “Dog kennel” means a “kennel,” as described in Chapter 17.08 of this Code, in which dogs are kept.

    F.   “Noisy dog” means and includes any dog that barks, yelps or howls loudly and at frequent intervals, or continuously, or for extended periods of time.

    G.  “Owner” means and includes any person, partnership, corporation, organization or other entity, without regard to residency, that owns, keeps, harbors, possesses, has an interest in, or has temporary or permanent control or custody of a dog within the city, including but not limited to any dog running at large at any place within the city.

    H.  “Pound” means the enclosure provided by the City for keeping dogs, or a humane shelter not operated by the City for impounding animals.

    I.    “Registration period” means and includes the biannual period commencing on the first day of January of each even-numbered year and ending on the thirty-first day of December of each odd-numbered year. The first such registration period shall commence on January 1, 1982, and end on December 31, 1983. Each registration period shall be designated by the calendar year in which such period ends.

    J.    “Run at large” and “running at large” means any dog when off or away from the premises of the owner, possessor or keeper thereof and not under the control of such owner, possessor or keeper, or his agent or servant, or member of his immediate family, by leash, cord or chain of not more than ten (10) feet in length.

    K.  “Vicious dog” means any dog which at any place in the city, whether on public or private property, attacks or bites a human being or other domestic animal or livestock, with the exception of fowl, or engages in or is harbored primarily or in part for the purpose of fighting as described and prohibited in Section 18-9-204, C.R.S., or any animal trained for fighting; provided, however, that no dog shall be deemed vicious solely by reason of having attacked, threatened, attempted to bite or bitten under the following circumstances:

    1.   When a dog is used by an authorized peace officer while the officer is engaged in the performance of peace officer duties;

    2.   When a person attacked such dog or engaged in such conduct reasonably calculated to provoke such dog to attack, threaten, or bite such person or another person or animal;

    3.   When any person is engaged in unlawfully entering into or upon any vehicle in which such animal is kept or confined;

    4.   When any person or other domestic animal or livestock, except fowl, is engaged in the unauthorized entry into or upon the fenced or enclosed portion of the premises upon which such animal is kept;

    5.   When any person is engaged in attacking or molesting another person;

    6.   Any affirmative defenses contained in Section 18-9-204.5(3)(h), C.R.S., as amended; or

    7.   Any exclusions contained in Section 18-9-204.5(6), C.R.S., as amended. (Ord. 25-2018 § 1; Ord. 19-2003 § 1; Ord. 21-87 § 8; prior code § 6.10.010)

 

6.08.020 Licensing, registration and vaccination.
    A.1. All dogs in the city shall be licensed and registered by their owners:

    a.   Between January 1st and March 1st for the current registration period in the event the dog was licensed and registered for the preceding year by the City; and

    b.   Within thirty (30) days after the owner acquires ownership of a dog not licensed and registered, and within thirty (30) days after the dog reaches the age of four (4) months.

    2.   Dog licenses shall be issued, and the registration of dogs shall be made by any veterinarian licensed by the state, upon forms furnished to the veterinarian by the City, upon the payment of the veterinarian’s charge, if any, for inoculating the dog with an antirabies vaccine, a veterinarian’s processing fee of two dollars ($2.00), and a license fee, as follows:

    a.   For any dog licensed during an even-numbered year, the sum of twenty-two dollars and fifty cents ($22.50) for each unspayed female, and twelve dollars and fifty cents ($12.50) for each male dog and each spayed female dog for each registration period; and

    b.   For any dog licensed during an odd-numbered year, the sum of fifteen dollars ($15.00) for each unspayed female dog, and seven dollars and fifty cents ($7.50) for each male dog and each spayed female dog for the remaining term of the registration period.

    3.   No dog shall be licensed and registered unless the dog, at the time of the issuance of the license, shall have been inoculated with a triennial antirabies vaccine approved by the State Department of Health, within a period of six (6) months next preceding the issuance of the license. The veterinarian who licenses and registers a dog shall certify that the dog has been inoculated within the time and with a vaccine specified hereinabove.

    4.   A duplicate original of each registration, which shall contain the name and address of the owner, the type of vaccine with which the dog was inoculated, the name, age, breed, color and sex of the dog, together with a duplicate original of the veterinarian’s inoculation certificate, and the license fees collected by the veterinarian, shall be forwarded by him to the Director of Finance, monthly.

    B.   Whenever a registered dog changes ownership, within thirty (30) days thereafter the new owner shall again register such dog in the manner required by this chapter and shall pay a processing fee as provided for in Subsection A of this section.

    C.   The provisions of this section shall not apply to dogs whose owners are non-residents temporarily within the city, nor to dogs brought into the city for the purpose of participating in any dog show; provided, however, that if a dog whose owner is a nonresident shall remain in the city more than thirty (30) days, such dog shall be licensed and registered within thirty (30) days after being brought into the city. (Ord. 2-2005 § 1; prior code § 6.10.020)

 

6.08.030 Tags.
    A.  The veterinarian who licenses and registers a dog shall issue to the owner or party registering the dog a standard tag of the World Health Organization, serially numbered and supplied to the veterinarian by the City, which tag shall designate the year the registration shall expire. The veterinarian shall record the number of such tag in the registration record of the dog for which such tag was issued.

    B.   Every dog so registered shall at all times wear the tag issued, except when confined in an enclosure.

    C.   Any owner may procure a new standard dog tag to replace one which has been lost upon the application to any veterinarian who issues dog licenses, by showing to such veterinarian the dog’s registration and upon paying a fee to the veterinarian of two dollars ($2.00). When a new tag is issued, the veterinarian shall record the number of the new tag upon the registration record of such dog, and forward a copy of the registration record to the City Clerk. (Prior code § 6.10.030)

 

6.08.040 Kennel license requirements.
    A.  Every person, firm or corporation desiring to keep or maintain a kennel shall make application for licensing therefor to the City Clerk. Such license may issue for a period of one year, stating the name of the applicant and size of the place or places where the kennel is proposed to be kept. The applicant shall file with the City Clerk the written consent of all property owners residing within three hundred (300) feet in any direction from the place or places of the proposed kennel and shall pay to the Director of Finance a license fee of twenty-five dollars ($25.00) per year. The City Clerk shall thereupon issue a kennel license to the applicant, which shall expire one year from date of issuance thereof unless sooner revoked for violation of this chapter.

    B.   No person, firm or corporation shall maintain a kennel of more than twenty-five (25) dogs, nor permit any dog or dogs belonging to such kennel to run at large. If any person or persons, firm or corporation violating the provisions of this subsection holds a kennel license, the same shall be and be deemed revoked upon conviction as aforesaid.

    C.   No person or persons, firm or corporation shall keep any such kennel without having procured a license therefor, as provided in this section, and if any person or member or agent of a firm, or officer or agent of a corporation, violates any provision of this section in respect to the keeping or maintaining of a kennel, he or she shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. Each day that a kennel is kept and maintained in violation of the provisions hereof shall be deemed a separate offense.

    D.  The provisions of this section are specifically subject to the provisions contained in the zoning ordinance of the City. (Ord. 3-1989; Ord. 1-1988 § 7; prior code § 6.10.120)

 

6.08.050 Running at large prohibited.
    It is unlawful for the owner of any dog to permit the same to run at large, either within the corporate limits of the City or in areas outside the City the use of which the City has jurisdiction and authority to regulate, including, but not limited to, Temple Canyon Park, Red Canyon Park and Royal Gorge Park. (Prior code § 6.10.040)

 

6.08.060 Rabies—Impoundment—Quarantine.
    A.  Any dog within the city which is known to have or is suspected of having bitten or injured any person so as to cause a breaking of the skin, or any dog within the city which, in the opinion of any licensed physician or any licensed veterinarian of the state, appears to be infected with rabies, and when such fact shall be made known or reported to the Animal Control Officer or any police officer of the City, such dog shall be impounded and closely confined as directed by the City Administrator for a period of ten (10) days; and if during such period such dog displays symptoms of illness, its disposition shall be determined by a licensed physician or veterinarian employed by the City.

    B.   A dog which is known to have been exposed to an animal infected with rabies shall be impounded, and the disposition of such dog shall be made as directed by a licensed physician or veterinarian employed by the City or, when permitted by such physician or veterinarian, shall be closely confined by its owner in a sufficiently fenced, locked area, or in the county shelter, or at a private kennel, all at the expense of the owner and in accordance with the directions of such physician or veterinarian for a period of not less than six (6) months from the date of exposure.

    C.   If the owner of any such dog cannot be determined or located, then such dog shall be confined under the direction of such physician or veterinarian, and if such dog is not claimed, then such physician or veterinarian may order such dog destroyed.

    D.  All costs of the confinement of any dog confined under the provisions of this section, and all costs incurred in destroying such dog and examining the dog or any part thereof shall be the expense of the owner of the dog. (Prior code § 6.10.110)

 

6.08.070 Noisy, destructive or vicious dog—Nuisance.
    A.  No person, firm or corporation shall own, keep, harbor or possess any noisy, destructive or vicious dog, or any dog which is not registered in accordance with this chapter.

    B.   Noisy dogs and vicious or destructive dogs shall be deemed nuisances.

    C.   Upon a complaint made to the Animal Control Officer as to any such dog, the Animal Control Officer shall investigate the truth of the complaint and, if he or she shall find it sustained, shall file in the Municipal Court a complaint charging violation of this section by the owner of such dog. If such owner shall be found guilty of the offense charged in such complaint, the dog as to which such complaint shall be made shall be conclusively proved to be a noisy, vicious or destructive dog, as the case may be, for all purposes under this chapter (Prior code § 6.10.050)

 

6.08.080 Impoundment authorized when.
    A.  The Animal Control Officer shall impound any dog running at large, or which is proven, in the manner provided in Section 6.08.070, to be a vicious or destructive dog, even though such dog is under the direct supervision and control of a person while it is off the premises occupied by its owner.

    B.   The Animal Control Officer shall also impound any dog proved to be a noisy dog in the manner provided in Subsection B of Section 6.08.070 upon any complaint made to the Animal Control Officer as to any such dog, subsequent to the complaint mentioned in Subsection B of Section 6.08.070.

    C.   The Council of the City shall have the authority to contract with third parties to provide facilities for the impoundment provided for in this section. (Prior code § 6.10.060)

 

6.08.090 Impounded dogs—Listing.
    The Animal Control Officer shall list with the budget and accounting officer of the county and with the Clerk of the City all dogs impounded, giving the names of the owners, if known, and if unknown, a description of each dog so impounded; and the filing of such list with the Budget and Accounting Officer of the County and the Clerk of the City shall be deemed to be notice to the owner of such impoundment, and no other notice need be given by the Animal Control Officer or the City. (Prior code § 6.10.090)

 

6.08.100 Impounded dogs—Care and feeding.
    The Animal Control Officer, or contractor housing the animals, shall cause all dogs impounded to be properly fed and watered until redeemed or disposed of as provided in this chapter. (Prior code § 6.10.080)

 

6.08.110 Impounded dogs—Redemption.
    A.  Any dog impounded, other than a vicious or destructive dog, may be redeemed by its owner at any time within five (5) days after being impounded, during the hours of seven a.m. until five p.m., upon payment to the Chief of Police the fee for the dog’s kennel care, as provided in Subsection B of this section, and in the event the impounded dog is not then currently licensed and registered under the provisions of this chapter, upon payment of the additional sum to the Chief of Police for the license fee provided in Subsection (A)(2) of Section 6.08.020. The owner of the unlicensed and unregistered dog shall, within five (5) days of its redemption:

    1.   Obtain a certificate from a veterinarian licensed in the state, certifying that the dog has been inoculated with the vaccine and within the time prescribed by Subsection (A)(3) of Section 6.08.020; and

    2.   Furnish a copy of the veterinarian’s certificate to the Chief of Police, who shall then provide to the owner the tag provided for in Subsection A of Section 6.08.030.

    B.   Fees for kennel care of impounded dogs shall be the sum of twelve dollars and fifty cents ($12.50) for the first twenty-four (24) hours or fraction thereof, and five dollars ($5.00) for each additional twenty-four (24) hours or fraction thereof.

    C.   Any dog not redeemed within the five (5) day period provided for in Section 6.08.090 may be disposed of as directed by the City Administrator or by such other person as the City Administrator may designate. (Ord. 2-2005 § 2; prior code § 6.10.100)

 

6.08.120 Vicious or noisy dogs—Destruction when.
    The Animal Control Officer may kill any vicious dog running at large, at any time or place, when there is a grave and imminent danger of its doing harm or injury to any person; and if a dog which proves to be noisy, vicious or destructive is impounded, the Animal Control Officer, or contractor housing the animal, may kill the same after five (5) days from the filing of the list provided for in Section 6.08.090, unless the owner shall dispose of such dog within five (5) days after the same shall be impounded, in such manner that the inhabitants of the city shall be assured that any such dog shall no longer molest the inhabitants of the City. (Prior code § 6.10.070)

 

6.08.130 Cruelty or poisoning prohibited.
    No person or persons shall treat any dog in a cruel or inhumane manner, or poison any dog or dogs, or distribute poison in any manner or place whatsoever within the city, with the intent or purpose of poisoning any dog or dogs. (Prior code § 6.10.130)

 

6.08.140 Violation—Penalty.
    A.  The owner of any dog which is found running at large or found off or away from the premises of the owner, possessor or keeper thereof, and not under the control of such owner, possessor or keeper or its agent, servant or member of his or her immediate family, by leash, cord or chain of not more than ten (10) feet in length, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and shall be punished in accordance with the following schedule:

    1.   Upon conviction of a first offense within any twelve (12) month period, by a fine of thirty dollars ($30.00);

    2.   Upon conviction of a second offense occurring within twelve (12) months of the date of the first offense, by a fine of sixty dollars ($60.00);

    3.   Upon conviction of a third or any subsequent offense occurring within twelve (12) months of the date of the first offense, by a fine in an amount that is not less than seventy-five dollars ($75.00), nor more than the maximum fine provided for in Section 1.28.010.

    B.   Any person or persons, firm or corporation whose dog has not been properly licensed as provided for in Section 6.08.020, and whose dog is not confined in an enclosure, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and shall be punished in accordance with the following schedule:

    1.   Upon conviction of a first offense within any twelve (12) month period, by a fine of twenty-five dollars ($25.00);

    2.   Upon conviction of a second offense occurring within twelve (12) months of a prior offense, by a fine of fifty dollars ($50.00);

    3.   Upon conviction of a third or any subsequent offense occurring within twelve (12) months of the date of the first offense, by a fine in an amount that is not less than seventy-five dollars ($75.00), nor more than the maximum fine provided for in Section 1.28.010.

    C.   Any person (or persons) who owns, keeps, harbors or possesses any noisy, destructive or vicious dog in violation of Section 6.08.070 is guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon conviction thereof, shall be punished by a fine in an amount that is not less than forty-five dollars ($45.00), nor more than the maximum fine provided for in Section 1.28.010.

    D.  Any fine or penalty provided for in this chapter shall be in addition to any shelter fees as provided for in Section 6.08.110 for impounding the dog.

    E.   Any person who violates any provision of this Chapter 6.08, for which a penalty is not otherwise specifically provided, is guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon conviction thereof, shall be punished by a fine in an amount that does not exceed the maximum fine provided for in Section 1.28.010. (Ord. 17-2013 §§ 13—16; Ord. 2-2005 § 3; Ord. 15-1993 § 1)

Chapter 6.10 DOGS BANNED FROM CEMETERIES
6.10.010 Definitions.
    For purposes of this chapter:

    A.  “Cemetery” means and includes Lakeside Cemetery, Greenwood Cemetery and any other cemetery owned or operated by the City, regardless of whether such cemetery is within or outside of the corporate boundaries of the city.

    B.   “Dog” means and includes any dog, male or female, of any age.

    C.   “Owner” means and includes any person or persons, firm or corporation who owns, keeps, harbors or possesses a dog which enters into or remains upon the grounds of a cemetery. (Ord. 10-2000 § 1)

 

6.10.020 Prohibition against dogs in cemeteries.
    It is unlawful for the owner of any dog to permit that dog to enter into or remain upon the grounds of any cemetery. Signs advising of this prohibition may be placed at or near all entrances to all cemeteries and elsewhere within all cemeteries. (Ord. 10-2000 § 1)

 

6.10.030 Limited exception to general requirement.
    Notwithstanding any other provision of this chapter, it is not unlawful for a disabled person, such as a visually impaired person, who routinely relies upon a specially trained dog for assistance in performing normal life functions, to enter into and remain upon the grounds of a cemetery while accompanied by such specially trained dog. (Ord. 10-2000 § 1)

 

6.10.040 Applicability of other laws.
    A.  Nothing in this chapter shall be construed to prevent the owner of a dog from being charged and convicted of any violation described in Chapter 6.08 in addition to a violation of Section 6.10.020. Any dog found running at large in a cemetery may be captured and impounded in accordance with the applicable provisions of Chapter 6.08.

    B.   When the owner of any dog found on the grounds of a cemetery refuses to voluntarily remove such dog from the cemetery upon the request of any parks or cemetery employee, any police officer, or any Animal Control Officer, such dog shall be subject to immediate impoundment in accordance with the procedures set forth in Chapter 6.08. (Ord. 10-2000 § 1)

 

6.10.050 Violation—Penalty.
    The owner of any dog who violates any provision of this chapter, upon conviction of such violation, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and shall be fined and otherwise punished in accordance with the following schedule:

    A.  For the first offense occurring within any twelve (12) month period, the fine shall be twenty-five dollars ($25.00);

 

    B.   For the second offense occurring within any twelve (12) month period, the fine shall be fifty dollars ($50.00);

    C.   For the third or any subsequent offense occurring within any twelve (12) month period, the owner shall be punished by a fine in an amount that is not less than one hundred dollars ($100.00), nor more than the maximum fine provided for in Section 1.28.010.

    D.  All calculations of time for purposes of Subsections A through C of this section shall be based upon dates of violations, and not upon dates of convictions. (Ord. 17-2013 § 17; Ord. 10-2000 § 1)

Chapter 6.11 DEER HARVESTING PROGRAM
6.11.010 Deer Harvesting Program.
    A.  In an effort to reduce the overpopulation of deer in the City, the Council of Cañon City hereby establishes a Deer Harvesting Program wherein Colorado Parks and Wildlife will issue additional deer hunting rifle and archery licenses to allow additional individuals to harvest deer within City limits by crossbow, recurve bow, or compound bow.

    B.   Any individuals wishing to participate in the Deer Harvesting Program must first obtain a deer hunting rifle or archery license from Colorado Parks and Wildlife subject to Colorado Parks and Wildlife hunter competency and safety guidelines.

    C.   Hunters possessing a lawful deer rifle or archery hunting license must comply with all state regulations while participating in this Deer Harvesting Program. In addition, each hunter participating in the Program:

    1.   Shall shoot from an elevated stand with a minimum height of four (4) feet, except for hunters who are eligible for a mobility-impaired hunting license pursuant to Colorado Parks and Wildlife Regulations;

    2.   Shall acquire written or verbal permission from private landowners prior to hunting or dressing on private property;

    3.   Is prohibited from hunting on private property that is less than one acre; and

    4.   Is prohibited from targeting, wounding, or killing the rare albino deer species.

    D.  Nothing in this section is intended to supersede Section 9.56.010 of this Code relating to the discharging of weapons.

    E.   Nothing in this section is intended to supersede state regulations relating to hunting, including, but not limited to, state license requirements. (Ord. 36-2018 § 1)

Chapter 8.10 PURPOSE AND GENERAL PROVISIONS
8.10.010 Purpose, scope and authority.
    A.  It shall be the policy of the City to promote the health, safety, morals, convenience, order, prosperity and welfare of the present and future inhabitants of the City and, therefore, the City Council declares that every nuisance shall be unlawful, and shall be restrained, prevented, abated and enjoined. This title governs the prohibition and control of nuisances throughout the City. Authority to enforce the provisions of this title is vested in any authorized City Community Services Officer. Community Services Officers shall have the same authority as peace officers with respect to the limited matters addressed in this title.

    B.   Whenever any action, activity, operation, condition or circumstance is described in this title or in any other title of this Code as a nuisance, the enforcement and abatement tools, processes and remedies authorized and otherwise provided for in this title shall be available to Community Services Officers charged with the responsibility and authority to identify and thereafter take action intended to restrain, prevent, or cause the abatement of such nuisances. Sanctions and remedies available to the Municipal Court pursuant to this title shall also be available to the Municipal Court with respect to nuisances described in other sections of this Code. (Ord. 12-2019 § 3)

 

8.10.020 Voluntary compliance—Discretionary authority of Community Services Officers.
    In furtherance of the City’s policy of encouraging voluntary compliance, any person deemed or alleged to be in violation of, or not in compliance with, any of the provisions of this title shall, to the extent possible or practical, in the sole discretion of the Community Services Officer, be notified of such alleged violation or lack of compliance prior to the initiation of either abatement or enforcement proceedings, and shall be offered an opportunity to bring the property or use of the property into compliance. Community Services Officers are authorized to exercise discretion in the investigation and enforcement of violations of this title in furtherance of this policy. (Ord. 12-2019 § 3)

 

8.10.030 Right of entry.
    A.  Whenever necessary to make an inspection to enforce this title, or whenever a Community Services Officer has reasonable cause to believe there exists in any building or upon any premises any condition which constitutes a nuisance, the Community Services Officer shall first present proper credentials and request entry. If entry is refused, the officer shall give the responsible party, or if the responsible party cannot be located after a reasonable effort, he or she shall leave at the building or premises, a written notice of intent to inspect not sooner than twenty-four (24) hours after the time specified in the notice. The notice shall state that the responsible party has the right to refuse entry and that in the event such entry is refused, inspection may be made only upon issuance of a search warrant by a Municipal Judge of the City, or by a judge of any other court having jurisdiction.

    B.   The Community Services Officer may appear before the Municipal Judge and upon a showing of probable cause shall obtain a search warrant entitling him or her to enter the building or upon the premises, using such reasonable force as may be necessary to gain entry. The person applying for such warrant shall not be required to demonstrate specific knowledge of the condition of the particular structure or premises at issue in order to obtain a search warrant, but must show some factual or practical circumstances that would cause an ordinary prudent person to act. The Municipal Court Judge or any Associate Judge of the Municipal Court of the City shall have the power to issue search warrants upon a proper showing of probable cause as provided in this subsection.

    C.   Whenever an emergency situation exists in relation to the enforcement of any of the provisions of this title, a Community Services Officer may enter into any building or upon any premises within the City, using such reasonable force as may be necessary. An emergency situation includes any situation of imminent danger of loss of, or injury or damage to, life, limb, property or threat to public safety. It is unlawful for any owner or occupant of the building or premises to deny entry to any Community Services Officer or to resist reasonable force used by the officer acting pursuant to this section. (Ord. 12-2019 § 3)

Chapter 8.12 DEFINITIONS
8.12.010 Interpretation.
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this title, shall be broadly interpreted to achieve the purposes intended. It is the intent of the City Council that the definitions not be considered mutually exclusive and liberal construction is deemed necessary by the City Council in order to fulfill the public purpose of this title, which is to ensure that the City is maintained in a clean, safe, healthy and attractive condition. (Ord. 12-2019 § 3)

 

8.12.020 Words and terms.
    A.  “Abate” shall mean to bring into compliance, halt, eliminate or remedy.

    B.   “Advisory commission” means the City Council or those individuals appointed by City Council to advise on matters of undesirable plant management.

    C.   “Alien plant” means a plant species which is not indigenous to the State nor to the native plant community in which it is found.

    D.  “Approved trash receptacle” means and includes any durable, leak-proof container with a tight-fitting cover, any securely tied or sealed refuse bag made of heavy paper or plastic material and designed for outdoor storage of trash, recyclables, and/or any container that might be specified in regulations adopted pursuant to Section 8.16.030. When and where permitted under this chapter, commercial containers also are approved trash receptacles.

    E.   “Biological management” means the use of an organism to disrupt the growth of undesirable plants.

    F.   “Business dumpster” means a commercial container having a capacity of more than ninety-six (96) gallons, but less than or equal to three (3) cu/yards, including recycling dumpsters.

    G.  “Chemical management” means the use of herbicides or plant growth regulators to disrupt the growth of undesirable plants.

    H.  “City Administrator” means the City Administrator of the City of Cañon City or his or her designee.

    I.    “Community Services Officer” shall mean the City Administrator or the City Administrator’s designee, including, but not limited to, any person employed by the City as a Community Services Officer, the City Engineer, the City’s Building Official, any City building property inspector or any other City official or employee charged with enforcing the provisions of this title.

    J.    “Commercial container” means a dumpster or other container having a capacity exceeding ninety-six (96) gallons used for the containment of large quantities of trash and, in certain circumstances, construction waste. For purposes of this chapter, there are two (2) types of commercial containers, “business dumpsters” and “construction dumpsters.”

    K.  “Construction dumpster” means a commercial container having a capacity greater than three (3) cu/yards, including containers commonly known as “rear-loaders” or “roll-off containers.”

    L.   “Construction waste” means waste material associated with or resulting from the construction, remodeling, repair or demolition of a house, dwelling unit, building or other structure.

    M.  “Control” means preventing a plant from forming viable seeds or vegetative propagules.

    N.  “Cultural control” means those methodologies or management practices conducted to favor the growth of desirable plants over undesirable plants, including, but not limited to, maintaining an optimum fertility and plant moisture status in an area, planting at optimum density and spatial arrangement in an area, and planting species most suited to an area.

    O.  “Effectively screened” means screening utilized in an outdoor storage area that may be accomplished through the use of materials such as solid fencing, dense vegetation, or earth berms; provided that the effect of such screening is that any and all personal property and/or other materials in the outdoor storage area are not visible to a person standing upon any public street, alley, sidewalk or right-of-way or to any person standing at ground level upon any adjoining piece of property.

    P.   “Garbage” means waste resulting from the handling, preparation, cooking and consumption of food or wild animal carcasses, and wastes from handling, storage and sale of produce.

    Q.  “Hazardous materials” means any substance, material, or waste which poses a hazard to persons or property and which is or becomes regulated by any local governmental authority, the State of Colorado, or the United States Government, including, but not limited to, any oil or petroleum compounds, flammable substances, explosives, radioactive materials, asbestos, or any material or substance which is designated as a hazardous or regulated substance.

    R.   “Integrated management” means the planning and implementation of a coordinated program utilizing a variety of methods for management of undesirable plants, which methods may include, but are not limited to, education, preventive measures, good stewardship, and control methods. The purpose of integrated management is to achieve healthy and productive plant communities by the least environmentally damaging methods.

    S.   “Junk” means scrap brass, scrap copper, scrap iron, scrap lead, scrap tin, scrap zinc and all other scrap metals and alloys, bones, rags, used cloth, used rope, used rubber, used tinfoil, used bottles, old or used machinery of any type, used tools, used appliances, used fixtures, used utensils, used lumber, used boxes or crates (fabricated of any material), used pipe or pipe fittings, used conduit or conduit fittings, inoperable motor vehicles, used tires and other manufactured goods that are so worn, deteriorated or obsolete as to make them unusable in their existing condition.

    T.   “Junkyard” has the same meaning as provided in Title 17 of this Code.

    U.  “Land” means any lot or parcel of land within the City, including the following, as may exist:

    1.   Area from the edge of the rear or side boundary of such lot or parcel to the center of the alley.

    2.   Area from the edge of the front or side boundary of such lot or parcel to and including the curb and gutter, if any, or to the edge of the pavement if no curb or gutter exists.

    3.   Rights-of-way for roads and ditches shall be deemed to constitute “land.”

    V.  “Landscaping” means a combination of living plants, such as trees, shrubs, vines, groundcover, flowers, vegetable plants, sod or grass; and may include natural features, such as rock, stone and bark; and structural features, including, but not limited to, fountains, reflecting pools, art work, screen walls, fences and benches. Uncontrolled weeds shall not be considered as landscaping. Sidewalks, whether paved or gravel, which serve as functional links between parking areas and principal structures, or which serve as general public access routes around a principal structure, or between a principal structure and a public street or alley, is not landscaping. Other sidewalks or paths which serve as casual access to or through landscape areas on private property may be considered nonliving landscape features.

    W.  “Litter” means and includes any and every waste material, refuse, garbage, trash, debris, excrement, urine, offal composed of animal matter or vegetable matter or both, or any noxious or offensive matter whatever, including, but not limited to, any discarded dead animal, fishing line, bait, chemical, chemical compound, petroleum product or compound, automobile part or accessory, tire, wheel, junk, paper, cardboard, can, lid, bottle, cap, carton, wrapper, box, wooden object, plastic object, clothing, cloth, metal object, rubber object, leather object, hide, feathers, grass clippings, leaves, cut weeds, branches cut from trees or bushes, brick, cinderblock, building material, paint, concrete, soil, sand, gravel, stone, glass, asphalt, ashes, cigarette, cigar, food or food product, solvent, dye, beverage, and liquid except water.

    X.  “Management plan” means the undesirable plant management plan developed by City Council, using integrated management.

    Y.  “Mechanical control” means those methodologies or management practices that physically disrupt plant growth, including, but not limited to, filling, mowing, burning, flooding, mulching, hand-pulling and hoeing.

    Z.   “Motor vehicle” shall have the same meaning as defined pursuant to Title 42 of the Colorado Revised Statutes.

    AA. “Motor vehicle, Extensively damaged” means a motor vehicle that has significant visible damage including, but not limited to, broken or missing windows, a broken or missing windshield, significant body damage which would make the motor vehicle un-drivable or a missing wheel, tire, motor or transmission.

    BB. “Motor vehicle, Inoperable” means any motor vehicle that does not have a current license plate and registration sticker lawfully affixed thereto or that is in a condition of being extensively damaged, junked, wrecked, wholly or partially dismantled, discarded, abandoned, flat tire(s), or unable to perform the functions or purpose for which it was originally constructed.

    CC. “Native plant” means a plant species which is indigenous to the State.

    DD. “Non-residential zone district” means General Commercial Zone District, Central Business Zone District, and/or Class 1 Industrial Zone District.

    EE. “Noxious plant” means an alien plant or parts thereof, which meets one (1) or more of the following additional criteria:

    1.   It aggressively invades or is detrimental to economic crops or native plant communities;

    2.   It is poisonous to livestock;

    3.   It is a carrier of detrimental insects, diseases or parasites; or

    4.   The direct or indirect effect of the presence of such plant is detrimental to the environmentally sound management of natural or agricultural ecosystems.

    FF. “Noxious plant infestation” means the direct or indirect presence of a noxious plant on any land that has a detrimental effect on the environmentally sound management of the natural or agricultural ecosystem of the land and the surrounding area.

    GG. “Nuisance” includes, but is not limited to, the following:

    1.   The conducting or maintaining of any business, occupation or activity prohibited by Colorado statute or regulation, or by any provision of this Code;

    2.   Any building, structure or land open to or used by the general public, the condition of which presents a substantial danger or hazard to public health or safety;

    3.   Any unlawful pollution or contamination of the surface or subsurface of any land within the City or of any water intended for human consumption;

    4.   Any activity, operation or condition which, after being ordered abated, corrected or discontinued by a lawful order of an agency or officer of the State of Colorado or of any Community Services Officer, continues to be conducted or continues to exist in violation of any Colorado statute or regulation or in violation of any provision of this Code;

    5.   Any activity, operation, condition, building, structure, place, premises or thing which is injurious to the health or safety of the citizens of the City, or which is indecent or offensive to the senses so as to interfere with the comfortable enjoyment of life or property;

    6.   Any activity, operation, condition, building, structure, place, premises or thing that has been declared to be a nuisance in any other chapter or section of this Code or in the Charter of Cañon City;

    7.   Any violation of the Uniform Housing Code adopted by the City;

    8.   Any violation of the Uniform Code for the Abatement of Dangerous Buildings adopted by the City;

    9.   Any condition which, in the reasonable judgment of a Community Services Officer, constitutes a nuisance within the scope of this title;

    10. The unlawful cultivation, manufacturing, sale, offer for sale, or distribution of medical marijuana without a license; or

    11. The unlawful cultivation, manufacturing, sale, offer for sale, or distribution of retail marijuana without a license.

    HH. “Occupant” means and includes any person who occupies the whole or a part of a building, premises, or land, whether alone or with others, whether for residential or commercial purposes. “Occupant” means and includes the terms “tenant” and “lessee.”

    II.   “Owner” means and includes:

    1.   Any owner or holder of any legal or equitable estate in real property, including a dominant or servient tenement, except a future or reversionary interest and except the interest of a public trustee, lienholder, mortgagee, or beneficiary of a deed of trust; or

    2.   The owner of record, as reflected by the records of the office of the county assessor.

    JJ.  “Person” includes a natural person, association, corporation, partnership, limited liability company and any other legal entity capable of owning, using, or occupying real or personal property.

    KK. “Place of collection” means a place for the collection of trash that is adjacent to or abuts the traveled portion of a public street or alley where trash may be temporarily placed for collection by a trash hauler without interfering with the movement of vehicles or pedestrians.

    LL. “Place of storage” means a place established in Chapter 8.16 for the storage of trash receptacles, business and construction dumpsters on private property during periods when the trash receptacle is not in the place of collection as allowed by Chapter 8.16.

    MM. “Plant growth regulator” means a substance used for controlling or modifying plant growth processes without appreciable phytotoxic effect at the dosage applied.

    NN. “Property, private” means any property, including any improvements thereon, that is not public property. Private property includes any privately owned vacant lot or parcel.

    OO. “Property, public” means any property, right-of-way or other real or personal property owned or controlled by any public entity.

    PP. “Refuse” means any grass clippings, leaves, hay, straw, manure, shavings, excelsior, paper, ashes, boxes, glass, cans, bottles, garbage, waste and discarded building and construction materials, including, but not limited to, plaster, broken concrete, bricks, cinderblocks, stones, wood, roofing material, wire or metal binding, sacks or loose discarded or unused material; all trash of any kind or nature whatsoever; and any other materials commonly known as trash or refuse of any kind or character or by any means known.

    QQ. “Residential zone district” means Rural Living Zone District, Low Density Residential Zone District, Low Density, Small Lot Residential Zone District, Medium Density Residential Zone District, High Density Residential Zone District, Mobile Home Park Zone District, Mobile Home Subdivision Zone District, and/or Planned Development Zone District.

    RR. “Responsible party” means any person who makes or causes any nuisance to exist, or who has possession or control of any real property or premises, whether as owner, occupant or tenant, where any nuisance is found, or, in the case of a motor vehicle, as owner or operator of the same.

    SS. “Right-of-way” or “ROW” means an area of land that is dedicated for public or private use to accommodate a transportation system and/or necessary public utility infrastructure (including, but not limited to, stormwater easements and conveyances, water lines, sewer lines, power lines, and gas lines).

    TT. “Trailer” means a wheeled vehicle, without motive power, which is designed to be drawn by a motor vehicle and to carry its cargo load wholly upon its own structure and which is generally and commonly used to carry and transport property over the streets and highways, including, but not limited to, any camper trailer, semitrailer, trailer, trailer coach or utility trailer, as defined by the applicable Model Traffic Code, as amended.

    UU. “Trash” means any type of refuse or garbage, including, but not limited to, animal and vegetable waste and waste material resulting from the handling, storage, preparation, cooking, consumption of sale of food or foodstuffs, ashes, debris, yard and household waste and other portable solid waste material, but does not include construction waste or hazardous material.

    VV. “Unsheltered” means located outside a garage or other building in such a manner as to be visible to a person standing upon any public street, alley, sidewalk or right-of-way or to any person standing at ground level upon any adjoining piece of property.

    WW. “Undesirable plant” means a noxious plant species that is designated as undesirable by this chapter or by City Council or by the advisory commission.

    XX. “Undesirable plant management” means the planning of an integrated program to manage undesirable plant species.

    YY. “Weed” means any unsightly or noxious plant or vegetation in excess of eight (8) inches in height which is out of place at the location where the same is growing and which is regarded as a common nuisance. The word “weed” shall not include flower gardens, plots of shrubbery, vegetable gardens, and grain plots.

    ZZ. “Vegetative growth” includes all plant material, grass, weeds, shrubs, bushes, trees or parts thereof, whether growing or not, that constitute or could present a fire hazard, mosquito breeding site, source of contamination of waters of the state, obstruction of the public right-of-way, or menace to the public health, safety or welfare.

    AAA. “Vision clearance area” shall have the same meaning as “vision triangle” in Section 12.12.020 and as described in Section 17.20.200 of this Code. (Ord. 12-2019 § 3)

Chapter 8.14 NUISANCE PROHIBITED
8.14.010 General provisions.
    A.  It shall be unlawful for any person:

    1.   To create, operate, maintain, conduct or permit any nuisance.

    2.   To interfere with or prevent, or attempt to interfere with or prevent, the abatement of any nuisance by an officer or agent of the City acting pursuant to a provision of this title or pursuant to a court order.

    B.   Every day, or portion thereof, any nuisance exists or continues, shall constitute a separate offense. (Ord. 12-2019 § 3)

Chapter 8.16 TRASH DISPOSAL
8.16.020 Limitations regarding trash haulage for compensation.
    Except for those who are exempt under Section 5.24.020(B), no person other than a trash hauler holding a valid trash haulage license issued pursuant to Chapter 5.24 of this Code is authorized to collect, remove, haul or transport, for compensation, trash generated by others to or from any private property or public property within the city. (Ord. 13-2018 § 1)

 

8.16.030 Additional regulations.
    The City Council may adopt, by resolution, reasonable rules and regulations to govern the manner and time for the preparation, collection, removal, and/or haulage of trash and the characteristics and locations of containers, dumpsters, receptacles and other vessels that may be used for the outside storage of such materials prior to collection. The violation of any regulation adopted pursuant to and in compliance with the provisions of this section shall be a violation of this chapter; provided that the resolution through which such regulation was adopted is appended to this chapter and otherwise made available for public inspection. (Ord. 13-2018 § 1)

 

8.16.040 General regulations.
    A.  All trash that is stored outdoors, including, but not limited to, trash located at a place of collection, shall be contained in an approved trash receptacle. All trash stored outdoors shall be stored and secured so that it is not susceptible to being spilled or spread by animals, wind, rainfall, stormwater or other elements or forces and in a manner so that it does not become a potential threat to the health, safety, welfare and/or reasonable enjoyment of surrounding properties.

    B.   No trash receptacle shall be placed on a sidewalk, a public or private right-of-way, or in any other location that interferes with the regular flow of vehicles or pedestrian movement on the traveled portions of any street, alley or other public right-of-way. Trash receptacles may be in a public or private right-of-way for collection, as provided for in this chapter, but may not be located on the sidewalk or impede the regular flow of vehicles or pedestrian movement on the traveled portions of any street, alley or other public right-of-way. No place of storage for a trash receptacle may be in a public right-of-way, unless expressly permitted in this chapter.

    C.   Yard waste and other similar waste material that is of such size and nature that it cannot readily be placed or stored in an approved trash receptacle may be carefully placed or stacked in neat bundles at a place of collection. Such bundles shall meet the size and weight requirements of the trash hauler servicing that place of collection and shall not be located at a place of collection in the front yard area of any property for longer than twenty-four (24) hours prior to collection.

    D.  It shall be the duty of every person owning, using, managing or occupying any property that is actively used for residential, business, commercial or industrial purposes to maintain one or more approved trash receptacles of sufficient size and number to contain the trash that will accumulate from one regular collection date to the next regular collection date. Under most circumstances, regular trash collection dates should be one week apart. (Ord. 13-2018 § 1)

 

8.16.050 Trash disposal sites.
    No trash collected or hauled within the city shall be disposed of anywhere within the city other than at a site, such as a transfer station, specifically established and operated for the purpose of receiving trash in accordance with all applicable zoning laws and public health regulations that are enforceable within the city. If no such site lawfully exists within the boundaries of the city, such materials shall be disposed of outside of the city, but only at places lawfully established for such purpose. (Ord. 13-2018 § 1)

 

8.16.060 Certain trash receptacles—Residential zones.
    A.  Except as otherwise provided in this chapter, no approved trash receptacle used in a residential zone district of the city for regular trash service shall have a capacity exceeding two (2) cubic yards.

    B.   The place of storage for trash receptacles of ninety-six (96) gallons or less under this section may be at any location on a property, subject to the limitations in Section 8.16.040(B) of this chapter.

    C.   The place of storage for business dumpsters under this section shall be a place on the property which is located behind front façade of the principal structure, as that line extends across the entire property to the edge of the public right-of-way, including sidewalks, subject to the limitation in Section 8.16.040(B).

    D.  On scheduled trash collection days, the trash receptacle must be located in a place of collection, no earlier than twenty-four (24) hours prior to collection and must be moved back to its place of storage location within twenty-four (24) hours of the trash collection. This limitation shall not apply if the place of collection and the place of storage for a trash receptacle of ninety-six (96) gallons or less are the same under subsection B above.

    E.   Persons may obtain an exemption to the requirements of subsection D above, upon the execution of an affirmation on forms provided by the City that the person is not physically able to move the trash receptacle to and from the place of collection. Persons with this exemption must comply with all other provisions of this chapter.

    F.   Persons may obtain an exemption from the requirements of subsection C above, upon application to the City, based upon unique property conditions, including, but not limited to, topography and/or lot size or configuration. Upon application, City staff shall verify the unique conditions and ability of owner to place the trash receptacle in the place of storage as required by this section and may approve the application, may designate an alternative place of storage on the property which complies with the spirit of this chapter but addresses the property’s unique conditions or deny the application. Persons with this exemption must comply with all other provisions of this chapter. (Ord. 13-2018 § 1)

 

8.16.070 Use of business dumpsters—All zones.
    A.  Notwithstanding the limitation on the size of business dumpsters in residential zones set forth in Section 8.16.060(A), business dumpsters may be located on private property and used as approved trash receptacles by any of the following:

    1.   Commercial businesses located within any non-residential zone district;

    2.   Commercial businesses which a principal use and lawfully located within any residential zone district;

    3.   Churches, meeting halls and other buildings and facilities owned, operated or occupied by religious, charitable, fraternal, civic and/or other tax-exempt organizations in any zone district;

    4.   Apartment buildings and other multi-family structures and/or complexes having four (4) or more residential units in any zone districts;

    5.   Mobile home parks, wherever lawfully located within the city;

    6.   Approved multiple-use structures in TMU zone districts;

    7.   Public buildings, structures and facilities in any zone district;

    8.   Residential properties where livestock are allowed and lawfully kept.

    B.   Business dumpsters permitted pursuant this section are subject to the following restrictions:

    1.   On scheduled trash collection days, the business dumpster must be located in a place of collection, no earlier than twenty-four (24) hours prior to collection and must be moved back to its place of storage within twenty-four (24) hours of the trash collection.

    2.   Business dumpsters used in residential zone districts are subject to Section 8.16.060(C) through (F) of this chapter.

    3.   Business dumpsters used in non-residential zone districts:

    a.   The place of storage for business dumpsters under this section shall be a place on the property which is located behind front façade of the principal structure, as that line extends across the entire property to the edge of the public right-of-way, including sidewalks, subject to the limitation in Section 8.16.040(B); and

    b.   Every effort shall be made to screen all business dumpsters so they are not visible from any adjacent residential property or public rights-of-way, except alleys.

    4.   Persons may obtain an exemption from the requirements of subsection (3)(a) above, upon application to the City, based upon unique property conditions, including, but not limited to, topography and/or lot size or configuration. Upon application, City staff shall verify the unique conditions and ability of owner to place the trash receptacle in the place of storage as required by this section and may approve the application, may designate an alternative place of storage on the property which complies with the spirit of this chapter but addresses the property’s unique conditions or deny the application. Persons with this exemption must comply with all other provisions of this chapter.

    C.   A business dumpster may be temporarily placed on private property at any location, for no more than thirty (30) days, at an unscreened location to assist with the cleanup of such property or for some other temporary purpose.

    D.  A business dumpster may be utilized for construction and placed in the right-of way pursuant to Section 8.16.080(D). (Ord. 13-2018 § 1)

 

8.16.080 Use of construction dumpsters—All zones.
    A.  No person shall place or use a construction dumpster at any location within the city unless such placement and use is in compliance with this chapter.

    B.   Construction dumpsters lawfully situated upon public or private property may not be used for the disposal of household or hazardous waste or any type of permanent storage. Commercial dumpsters shall not be used as a receptacle for regular and continuous trash produced by residences or businesses. All such construction dumpsters must be emptied or removed within twenty-four (24) hours of becoming full.

    C.   No construction dumpster shall be kept on public or private property for a period longer than fifteen (15) days after construction has been completed.

    D.  Placement of a construction dumpster in the right-of-way shall be governed by Chapter 12.12 of this Code in addition to the limitations in this subsection.

    1.   Construction dumpsters must be placed:

    a.   In residential zones, abutting the property using the dumpster;

    b.   Within twelve (12) inches of the curb or shoulder;

    c.   Parallel to the curb or shoulder;

    d.   At least thirty (30) feet from an intersection;

    e.   At least five (5) feet from any driveway;

    f.    At least fifteen (15) feet from fire hydrant;

    g.   At least twenty (20) feet from a crosswalk at an intersection;
