Before any property, other than property having an estimated value of $50.00 or less, or money having a face value of $100.00 or less, is distributed under this paragraph a notice of the proposed distribution under this paragraph shall be published in a newspaper of general circulation in the city at least ten (10) days prior to its distribution. If no claim is made for such property within ten (10) days following publication of such notice, such property will be distributed to the individual who delivered the property to the Police Department and otherwise complied with all requirements of this paragraph.

    4.   If the lost property is property having an estimated value of $50.00 or less or money having a face value of $100.00 or less, publication of the notice shall not be required.

    5.   Claims to the property made following publication of notice pursuant to this section shall be determined in accordance with the provisions of Section 9.28.050.

    B.   Such property may be disposed of in any manner permitted under the statutes of the state of Colorado, provided that the procedures for such disposal, as specified in the applicable statute, shall then be followed.

    C.   Such property may be declared abandoned and thereafter be distributed to any agency or department of the City for use by such department or agency for city purposes, provided that notice of such disposition shall be published at least once in a newspaper of general circulation in the city at least ten (10) days prior to the distribution of the property. Such notice shall describe the property and provide that the owner or a person entitled to possession thereof may claim such property within ten (10) days of the date of the publication of the notice. Any such claim shall be determined in accordance with the provisions of Section 9.28.050. Property distributed under this subparagraph shall become city property upon its distribution.

    D.  Such property may be distributed pursuant to resolution of City Council to a charitable organization which has first submitted to the City Administrator a plan for distribution or use of the property for charitable purposes which is acceptable to City Council. Any such resolution shall describe the property to be distributed and provide that such property shall be used or disposed of only in accordance with the provisions of the plan for distribution or use. Such resolution shall be published at least once in a newspaper of general circulation in the city, and also provide that any property described therein may be claimed within ten (10) days from the date of publication of such resolution by its owner or a person entitled to possession thereof. Property so claimed shall be excluded from the distribution to the charitable organization. Claims to property made after the publication of the resolution shall be determined in accordance with the provisions of Section 9.28.050.

    E.   Such property may be sold for cash to the highest bidder at a public auction. Notice of any such auction, including time, place and a brief description of the property to be sold, shall be published at least once in a newspaper of general circulation in the county where the auction is to be held at least ten days prior to such auction. Property claimed by its owner or a person entitled to possession thereof shall be excluded from the sale. All such claims shall be determined in accordance with the provisions of Section 9.28.050. (Ord. 14-1992 § 1)

 

9.28.040 Deposit of sale proceeds.
    Proceeds of the sale of property at public auction will first be applied to pay the costs of the auction and the proceeds remaining after such payment shall then be deposited in the general fund of the City. (Ord. 14-1992 § 1)

 

9.28.050 Recovery of property—Conditions.
    A.  The owner or person entitled to possession of property described in this chapter may claim and recover possession of the property at any time before its sale or other disposition upon providing reasonable and satisfactory proof of ownership or right to possession and after reimbursing the City for all reasonable expense of custody and handling thereof, including all publication costs, if any.

    B.   Any owner or person entitled to possession of such property who fails to make claim and recover possession of the property prior to its sale or other disposition under Section 9.28.035 shall forfeit all rights to such property.

    C.   No property with respect to which a claim has been made shall be disposed of under Section 9.28.035 until such claim has been denied in writing by the Chief of Police and the time for challenging such denial under paragraph D has expired. All determinations of claims made by the Chief of Police shall be final.

    D.  Any legal action filed challenging a decision of the Chief of Police shall be filed pursuant to rule 106 of the Colorado Rules of Civil Procedure within thirty (30) days of such decision or shall be forever barred. If any legal action is timely filed, the property shall be disbursed by the Chief of Police pursuant to the order of the court having jurisdiction over such claim. (Ord. 14-1992 § 1)

 

9.28.060 Damages—Liability limitations.
    No person or agency shall be responsible for consequent damages to another occasioned by an act or omission in compliance with this chapter. (Ord. 14-1992 § 1)

 

Chapter 9.30 DISPOSITION OF UNCLAIMED PROPERTY NOT OTHERWISE PROVIDED FOR UNDER OTHER PROVISIONS OF THE MUNICIPAL CODE
9.30.010 Purpose.
    The purpose of this ordinance is to provide for the administration and disposition of all unclaimed property which is in the possession of or under the control of the City for which the disposition thereof is not provided at other chapters of this Code. (Ord. 15-1992 § 1)

 

9.30.020 Definitions.
    Unless otherwise required by context or use, words and terms shall be defined as follows:

    A.  “Unclaimed property” means any tangible or intangible property, except for property described at Section 9.28.010 of this Code, which shall be disposed of in accordance with the provisions of Chapter 9.28, including any income or increment derived therefrom, less any lawful charges, that is held by or under the control of the City and which has not been claimed by its owner for a period of more than one year after it became payable or distributable or was otherwise acquired by the City. “Unclaimed property” shall specifically include any and all property, the disposition of which is not governed by other provisions of this Code, held or controlled by the City which, in the absence of this ordinance, would be subject to the provisions of the Colorado Unclaimed Property Act, Section 38-13-101 et seq., C.R.S. 1973, as amended.

    B.   “Owner” means a person or entity, including a corporation, partnership, association, governmental entity other than this city, or a duly authorized legal representative or successor in interest of same, which owns unclaimed property held by the City.

    C.   “City Administrator” shall mean the City Administrator or designee thereof. (Ord. 15-1992 § 1)

 

9.30.030 Procedure for notice and claims relative to and forfeiture of unclaimed property.
    A.  Prior to disposition of any unclaimed property having an estimated value of $50.00 or more, the City Administrator shall send a written notice by certified mail, return receipt requested, to the last known address, if any, of any owner of unclaimed property. The last known address of the owner shall be the last address of the owner as shown by the records of the municipal department or agency holding the property. The notice shall include a description of the property, the amount or estimated value of the property, and, when available, the purpose for which the property was deposited or otherwise held. The notice shall state where the owner may make inquiry of or claim the property. The notice shall also state that if the owner fails to provide the City Administrator with a written claim for the return of the property within 60 days of the date of the notice, the property shall become the sole property of the City and any claim of the owner to such property shall be deemed forfeited.

    B.   Prior to disposition of any unclaimed property having an estimated value of less than $50.00 or having no last known address of the owner, the City Administrator shall cause a notice to be published in a newspaper of general circulation in the city. The notice shall include a description of the property, the owner of the property, the amount or estimated value of the property and, when available, the purpose for which the property was deposited or otherwise held. The notice shall state where the owner may make inquiry of or claim the property. The notice shall also state that if the owner fails to provide the City Administrator with a written claim for the return of the property within sixty (60) days of the date of the publication of the notice, the property shall become the sole property of the City and any claim of the owner to such property shall be deemed forfeited.

    C.   If the City Administrator receives no written claim within the above sixty (60) day claim period, the property shall become the sole property of the City and any claim of the owner to such property shall be deemed forfeited.

    D.  If the City Administrator receives a written claim within the sixty (60) day claim period, the City Administrator shall evaluate the claim and give written notice to the claimant within ninety (90) days thereof that the claim has been accepted or denied in whole or in part. The City Administrator may investigate the validity of a claim and may request further supporting documentation from the claimant prior to disbursing or refusing to disburse the property.

    E.   In the event that there is more than one claimant for the same property, the City Administrator may, in the City Administrator’s sole discretion, resolve said claims, or may resolve such claims by depositing the disputed property with the registry of the district court in an interpleader action.

    F.   In the event that all claims filed are denied, the property shall become the sole property of the City and any claim of the owner of such property shall be deemed forfeited.

    G.  Any legal action filed challenging a decision of the City Administrator shall be filed pursuant to rule 106 of the Colorado Rules of Civil Procedure within thirty (30) days of such decision or shall be forever barred. If any legal action is timely filed, the property shall be disbursed by the City Administrator pursuant to the order of the court having jurisdiction over such claim. (Ord. 15-1992 § 1)

 

9.30.040 Disposition of unclaimed property.
    The City Administrator is authorized to establish and administer procedures for the administration and disposition of unclaimed property covered by this Chapter 9.30 consistent with the terms of this chapter, including compliance requirements for other municipal officers and employees in the identification and disposition of such property, subject to the following guidelines:

    A.  All intangible property subject to disposition under this Chapter 9.30 which is held in any fund of the City at the time such property becomes the property of the City under paragraph 9.30.030.C hereof, shall be distributed to such fund.

    B.   All other intangible property held by any agency or department of the City which is subject to disposition under this Chapter 9.30 shall be distributed to the general fund.

    C.   All tangible personal property subject to disposition under this Chapter 9.30 shall be distributed in any manner permitted under Chapter 9.28 with respect to distribution of property covered by such Chapter 9.28 by the Chief of Police or designated representative, except that publication prior to distribution in any such manner shall not be required.

    D.  Upon application by the City Administrator, City Council may authorize a manner or method of distribution not otherwise provided for herein.

    E.   No property subject to return or other distribution shall be returned or distributed to any owner or person or entity other than the City or a charitable organization until the City has been reimbursed for all reasonable expenses of custody and handling thereof, including costs of mailing and publication, if applicable. (Ord. 15-1992 § 1)

 

9.30.050 Damages—Liability limitations.
    No person or agency shall be responsible for consequent damages to another occasioned by an act or omission in compliance with this chapter. (Ord. 15-1992 § 1)

Division V. Offenses Against Property
Chapter 9.32 DISTURBING PUBLIC MONUMENTS
9.32.010 Unauthorized excavations and removal of landmarks.
    Whoever, in this city, makes or causes to be made, without lawful authority, an excavation in any highway, street, alley, sidewalk or other public place, or otherwise digs up or removes any stone, rock, gravel or earth in or from any such place, or removes any stones, stakes, or other landmarks placed by any officer of the City under authority thereof, or by any other duly authorized person, is guilty of a misdemeanor. (Prior code § 9.56.010)

 

Chapter 9.36 VANDALISM
9.36.010 Damaging, defacing or destruction of public property.
    A.  It shall be unlawful for any person knowingly to damage, deface, destroy or injure the real or personal property of the City.

    B.   “Deface” as used in Subsection A of this section shall include, but not be limited to, the writing, painting, inscribing, drawing, scratching or scribbling upon any public wall of public surface owned, operated or maintained by the City, unless the City grants written permission for such writing, painting, inscribing, drawing, scratching or scribbling. (Ord. 19-2003 § 5: prior code § 9.60.010)

 

9.36.012 Protection of fire and Police Department property.
    A.  It shall be unlawful for any person to deface any fire station, fire apparatus, police station or police apparatus.

    B.   It shall be unlawful for any person to obstruct, destroy or interfere with any public hydrant, fire plug, fire alarm, fire signal or any related apparatus of the Fire Department. (Ord. 19-2003 § 6)

 

9.36.015 Painting or decorating public buildings.
    It shall be unlawful for any person to paint or decorate any building, fence or other structure or property owned, leased or used by the City without the written permission of the City Administrator or of the department head responsible for such building, fence or other structure or property, if authority to grant such permission has been delegated by the City Administrator to such department head. (Ord. 19-2003 § 7)

 

9.36.018 Damaging, defacing or destruction of private property.
    A.  It shall be unlawful for any person knowingly to damage, deface, destroy or injure the real or personal property of one or more other persons.

    B.   “Deface” as used in Subsection A of this section means and includes, but is not limited to, the writing, painting, inscribing, drawing, scratching or scribbling upon any wall or surface owned, operated or maintained by any person, unless there is written permission from the owner thereof or the owner’s agent or other person legally authorized to give such permission for such writing, painting, inscribing, drawing, scratching or scribbling. (Ord. 19-2003 § 8)

 

9.36.020 Obscene materials in public places.
    A.  Any person who, in this city, writes, draws, paints, stains, cuts, carves, marks, scratches, brands, engraves or otherwise makes any gross, indecent or obscene word or words, language, picture or device whatsoever, so that the same shall be exposed to public view, upon any wall, fence or other thing, or on any highway, street, avenue, alley or other public place, or place visible to persons in such public place, or sticks or puts up on, in any place aforesaid, any paper, wood or other thing on which or from which any such word or words, language, picture or device has been expressly shaped or made, in any way, is guilty of a misdemeanor.

    B.   “Obscene writings or pictures” are those specifically defined at Section 18-7-101(2), Colorado Revised Statutes. (Ord. 21-1987 § 14; prior code § 9.60.020)

 

9.36.030 Violation—Penalty.
    Any person who violates any provision of this Chapter 9.36, or suffers or allows the same to be violated, is guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon conviction thereof, shall be punished by a fine in an amount that does not exceed the maximum fine provided for in Section 1.28.010. (Ord. 17-2013 § 39; Ord. 15-1993 § 1)

 

Chapter 9.40 TRESPASS
9.40.010 Trespass.
    A.  A person commits the violation of criminal trespass if such person:

    1.   Knowingly and unlawfully enters or remains in a dwelling of another or if such person enters any motor vehicle with intent to commit a crime therein;

    2.   Unlawfully enters or remains in or upon the premises of another which are enclosed in a manner designed to exclude intruders or are fenced;

    3.   Knowingly and unlawfully enters or remains in or upon the common areas of a hotel, motel, condominium, or apartment building;

    4.   Knowingly and unlawfully enters or remains in a motor vehicle of another;

    5.   Unlawfully enters or remains in or upon premises of another. (Ord. 19-2003 § 9)

 

9.40.020 Definitions.
    As used in this chapter, “premises” means real property, buildings, and other improvements thereon, and the stream banks and beds of any nonnavigable fresh water streams flowing through such real property. (Ord. 19-2003 § 9)

 

9.40.030 Trespassing and intruding on privacy unlawful.
    A.  It is unlawful for any person to enter upon the premises then in possession of some other person, without permission of the person in possession thereof, and thereupon invade or intrude upon the privacy of any person then lawfully in or upon said premises.

    B.   The following acts, among others, are declared to be an invasion or intrusion of privacy: viewing or peeping at persons or property through any window, door, screen, shutter, blind or other opening of any building or structure located on the premises owned or lawfully used or occupied by another person. (Ord. 19-2003 § 9)

 

9.40.040 Violation—Penalty.
    Any person who violates any provision of this Chapter 9.40, or suffers or allows the same to be violated, is guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon conviction thereof, shall be punished by a fine in an amount that does not exceed the maximum fine provided for in Section 1.28.010. (Ord. 17-2013 § 40; Ord. 19-2003 § 9)

 

Chapter 9.44 PUBLIC PARKS
9.44.010 Application of chapter provisions.
    The prohibitions herein shall apply to all parks, except as otherwise specifically provided in this chapter. (Prior code § 9.68.090)

 

9.44.020 Hours of operation.
    A.  General Rule. Except as is otherwise provided in this chapter, the public parks of the City that are located within the city limits and the recreational facilities within such parks shall be open daily to the public from five a.m. until eleven p.m., and no person who is not an authorized invitee, permittee, agent or employee of the City shall enter into or remain in any such public park at any other time.

    B.   Extended Hours. The City Administrator is authorized to issue written park use permits extending the hours during which any such park may remain open for special events.

    C.   Specific Hours of Operation for Certain Recreational Facilities. The hours during which a skatepark, basketball court or tennis court will be open for public use shall be those hours that are posted by the City at the skatepark, basketball court or tennis court. If no hours of operation are posted, the hours during which a skatepark, basketball court or tennis court will be open for public use shall be the hours specified in Subsection A of this section for public parks. The City Administrator, after consultation with the Director of Parks and City Council, is authorized to determine and cause the posting of the hours of operation for all skateparks, basketball courts and tennis courts. The hours so posted need not be the same for all similar facilities within the city. The hours of operation for any such recreational facility may be modified as seasons, climate, neighborhood needs and other circumstances might warrant.

    D.  Temporary Closures. The City Administrator, or his or her designee, is authorized to order the temporary closure of any public park, skatepark, basketball court, tennis court, or sections thereof, to use by the general public, with or without advance notice, when it has been determined that:

    1.   The closure is necessary to protect members of the public from possible injury due to actual or anticipated circumstances or conditions; or

    2.   The closure is necessary to protect the recreational or other facilities within a public park from damage or destruction due to actual or anticipated circumstances or conditions; or

    3.   The closure is necessary to facilitate maintenance or repairs; or

    4.   The closure is warranted because the public park or facilities within a public park have been reserved for use by authorized persons, teams or organized groups for athletic events, practices, contests, tournaments or other special events authorized by City Council or the City Administrator pursuant to resolution, contract, agreement or a park use permit. (Ord. 3-2002 § 1)

 

9.44.025 Regulations pertaining to the use of City parks and facilities in City parks.
    A.  Council may, by resolution, adopt and amend regulations pertaining to the use of City parks and the use of facilities within the City’s parks, including, but not limited to, restrooms, playground equipment and tennis courts.

    B.   It is unlawful for any person to violate any regulation set forth in any such resolution once each of the following requirements has first been met:

    1.   The resolution containing the regulation must have been adopted pursuant to and specifically mention Section 9.44.025(A);

    2.   The resolution containing such regulation, or a summary of the regulations set forth in such resolution, which summary specifically identifies the resolution by number and year of adoption, is printed in a public notice published in a newspaper of general circulation in the city; and

    3.   One or more copies of the resolution containing such regulation are made available for inspection, copying and distribution in the office of the City Clerk.

    C.   At such time as the requirements set forth in Subsection B of this section have been met, regulations adopted pursuant to Subsection A for all purposes shall be treated as if fully set forth in this Chapter 9.44. Violation of any such regulation shall be punishable in accordance with the provisions of Section 9.44.110. (Ord. 19-1996 § 1)

 

9.44.030 Enforcement authority.
    It shall be the duty of any Park Policeman or any person designated by the City Administrator to enforce the rules and regulations set out in this chapter. (Prior code § 9.68.110)

 

9.44.040 Vehicle operation and parking restrictions.
    No person shall, within any public park owned by the City, located within and without the city:

    A.  Drive, operate or cause to be operated any motor vehicle, including, but not limited to, any self-propelled vehicle, moped, go-cart, golf cart, motor scooter, electric personal assistive mobility device or “EPAMD,” as defined in C.R.S. § 42-1-102(28.7), engaged electronic assisted bicycle, hoverboard, or similar mode of transportation, except upon established roads and trails specifically designated by the City Council and marked for such purpose. A person may operate an electrical assisted bicycle, as defined in C.R.S. § 42-1-102(28.5), as may be amended, with the electrical motor disengaged on park paths where bicycles are authorized to travel. Electric personal assistive mobility devices or “EPAMDs” shall be permitted only if the user is dismounted. Nothing in this subsection shall prohibit or restrict the use or operation of an “other power-driven mobility device” (OPDMD), as used and defined by the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) Title II and III;

    B.   Stop, stand or park, or cause the stopping, standing or parking of a motor vehicle except in areas specifically designated and marked for such purpose; provided, however, this Subsection B shall have no application when necessary to avoid conflict with other traffic or in compliance with directions of a police officer or park attendant designated as such by the City Administrator. (Ord. 43-2017 § 1; prior code § 9.68.030)

 

9.44.050 Skyline Drive—One-way road.
    Skyline Drive is declared to be a one-way road; therefore, it is unlawful for any vehicle to enter such road at the east approach thereof, or to drive over any portion of the driveway, entering from the east. All vehicles, in order to drive over Skyline Drive, shall enter at the west approach. (Prior code § 9.68.040)

 

9.44.055 Rafting facilities—River Station and Centennial Park.
    A.  Portions of the River Station project area that abut the Arkansas River, as designated by the City Administrator, may be used for the launching and take-out of commercial and private river rafts, kayaks, canoes and other river vessels floating the Arkansas River. The authorization contained in this section shall supersede and control over any other provision of the Cañon City Municipal Code, including any provision in Title 17, that is in conflict with this section.

    B.   City Council, by resolution, may authorize the City Administrator to issue licenses to qualified river outfitters; to charge and collect reasonable deposits, fees and late charges with respect to such licenses; and to adopt and enforce reasonable rules, regulations and restrictions concerning the use of the River Station project area by river outfitters and others that are consistent with the guidelines set forth in such resolutions.

    C.   It is unlawful for any river outfitter to use any portion of the River Station project area for purposes of embarkation, disembarkation or transportation of river vessels and clients without first having applied for and obtained a valid license for such purposes, issued pursuant to the provisions of any resolution adopted pursuant to Section 9.44.055B.

    D.  It is unlawful for any river outfitter, whose license to use either Centennial Park (prior to 1997) or the River Station project area (during 1997 or in subsequent years) has expired or been revoked, to use the River Station project area for purposes of embarkation, disembarkation or transportation of river vessels or clients at any time following the expiration or revocation of such license until a new license has been issued to such river outfitter by the City Administrator or until such revoked license has been reinstated.

    E.   As used in this section and in any resolution adopted pursuant to Section 9.44.055(B) and in any license issued pursuant to the authorization provided for in this section, the following terms shall have the following meanings:

 

    1.   “River outfitter” means and includes any person soliciting to provide or providing, for compensation, facilities, guide services or transportation for the primary purpose of river running; except that “river outfitter” does not include any person whose only service is providing motor vehicles, vessels, and other equipment for rent or any person whose only service is providing instruction in canoeing or kayaking skills.

    2.   “Vessel” means every description of watercraft used or capable of being used as a means of transportation of persons and property on the water, other than single-chambered air-inflated devices or seaplanes.

    3.   “Client” means and includes any person, other than a river outfitter or an employee of a river outfitter, who is transported on the Arkansas River for the primary purpose of river running in a vessel owned or used by a river outfitter for such primary purpose. The payment of a fee to the river outfitter shall be prima facie evidence that the person paying the fee is a client.

    F.   All rafting take-out facilities within Centennial Park and all other portions of Centennial Park which abut the Arkansas River are closed to use by all river outfitters, without regard to whether such river outfitters are licensed by the City. Centennial Park is available for use by non-commercial users of river vessels as points of embarkation and disembarkation, subject to such rules, regulations and restrictions as may be imposed pursuant to applicable municipal law. It is unlawful for any person, including but not limited to river outfitters, to use Centennial Park in any manner prohibited in this Section 9.44.055F.

    G.  It is unlawful for any person to violate any provision of any resolution adopted pursuant to Section 9.44.055B. Any such resolution shall clearly provide that it was adopted pursuant to Section 9.44.055B.

    H.  Any conviction of any river outfitter of a violation of any provision of this Section 9.44.055 shall be reported to the Colorado Division of Parks and Outdoor Recreation and any other division or agency of the state of Colorado having jurisdiction over or with respect to the activities of river outfitters using any portion of the Arkansas River which flows through Royal Gorge Park or within the boundaries of the city. (Ord. 10-1997 § 1: Ord. 18-1994 § 1)

 

9.44.057 Guidelines and rules pertaining to skateparks.
    A.  Definitions. Unless otherwise required by context or usage, words and terms used in this chapter shall be defined as follows:

    1.   “Free-style bicycle” means a metal frame with two inline nonmetallic wheels on separate axles with no pegs, wheels not more than twenty inches in diameter, with handle bars and a seat designed for athletic stunts on flat or contoured surfaces of constructed of native soils, asphalt or concrete.

    2.   “Inline skate” means a shoe with a set of nonmetallic wheels attached in a straight line commonly used for skating over a flat surface, but not including a tricycle, scooter, or razor.

    3.   “Riding surface” means a flat or contoured hard surface or course within a park or a skatepark that is constructed of asphalt, concrete or another durable material and which is available to users for inline skating, skateboarding and/or free-style cycling, where permitted.

    4.   “Skateboard” means a short board mounted on a small set of nonmetallic wheels, which is used for coasting and often for performing athletic stunts.

    5.   “Skatepark” means any skatepark facility available for public use by skateboarders, inline skaters and, where not prohibited, free-style cyclists that is owned or operated by the City, including, but not limited to the skate park facility in Mountain View Park.

    6.   “User” means any person who uses a skate park for skating or riding.

    B.   Guidelines. The following guidelines shall apply in all skateparks:

    1.   Use of the skatepark shall be at the user’s own risk. All users are cautioned to know their own skills and limitations.

    2.   Helmets, knee, elbow, and wrist pads are strongly recommended at all times.

    3.   Users are strongly encouraged to know their abilities, to use only those elements of the skatepark that are within their abilities, to be courteous and respectful to others, to take turns, and to have fun.

    4.   Special events or organized group use shall be scheduled by obtaining a park use permit from the City Administrator, or his designee.

    C.   Rules. The following rules shall apply in all skateparks:

    1.   Appropriate shoe wear must be worn. Sandals and bare feet are prohibited on riding surfaces at all times.

    2.   The following items are prohibited and shall not be used on or near any riding surface within any skate park at any time:

    a.   Bicycles with wheels over twenty inches in diameter;

    b.   Bicycles with pegs or similar devices protruding from the wheels of the bicycle;

    c.   Scooters;

    d.   Razors;

    e.   Tricycles;

    f.    All forms of motorized equipment;

    g.   Any other item or device prohibited by signage posted at the skatepark.

    3.   Adding to or modifying skatepark features with makeshift items, such as jumps or ramps, is prohibited, as is skating or riding on any park structure outside of the riding surfaces that is not intended or suitable for such use.

    4.   No food, drinks or tobacco products are permitted on riding surfaces.

    5.   The use of profanity in a skatepark is prohibited.

    6.   No glass containers are permitted anywhere in a skatepark.

    7.   No illegal drugs or alcohol beverages are permitted anywhere in a skatepark.

    8.   No metal shovels, sand or salt may be used on any riding surface.

    9.   Destroying or defacing public property is prohibited. Tagging or placing stickers or graffiti upon any skatepark surface or structure is defacing public property and is illegal.

    10. Spectators and pets are not allowed on riding surfaces.

    11. No person shall ride a bicycle or skate in a skatepark in such a manner as to indicate a wanton and willful disregard for the safety of another person or of property. Willful and wanton conduct consists of an affirmative act, purposefully committed, which the person who committed the act must have realized as dangerous, done heedlessly and recklessly, without regard to consequences or the rights and safety of others.

    12. No unauthorized person shall enter, use, remain in or refuse to leave a skatepark when the skatepark is not open for public use. (See Section 9.44.020.)

 

    D.  Revocation of Privilege to Use Skatepark.

    1.   Use of the skatepark shall be a privilege, and the City, acting through the Director of Parks or his or her designee, shall have the right and authority to revoke, either temporarily or permanently, the privilege of any person to use a skatepark if that person does not obey or otherwise adhere to the guidelines and rules contained in Subsections B and C of this section, or if that person violates any other municipal ordinance or regulation pertaining to the use of a public park, a skatepark or any facility therein. All such revocations shall be documented in writing and shall identify the person whose privilege has been revoked by name and address, when known, and clearly state the date when the period of revocation will end.

    2.   The revocation of a person’s privilege to use the facilities of a skatepark shall be in addition to any penalty that may be imposed by the Municipal Court upon the conviction of such person for a violation of any rule set forth or otherwise provided for in this section.

    3.   A person’s physical presence at or use of a skatepark or any facility therein, when such person’s privilege to use such skatepark or facility has been revoked pursuant to paragraph 1 of this Subsection 9.44.057(D), shall be unlawful and, upon such person’s conviction of such violation, shall be punishable as provided for in Section 9.44.110. (Ord. 3-2002 § 2)

 

9.44.060 Unlawful activities designated.
    A.  Except as provided in Subsection B of this section, it is unlawful within any City park for any person to:

    1.   Possess or consume ethyl alcohol, as that term is defined in Chapter 9.13 of the Cañon City Municipal Code;

    2.   Sell, offer for sale or give away ethyl alcohol;

    3.   Sell or offer for sale any item, article or service or to conduct any other commercial activity;

    4.   Play any game of chance or conduct gambling activities;

    5.   Carry or discharge any firearms unless specifically authorized by law to do so;

    6.   Carry, possess or use fireworks at any place or in any manner which is not specifically authorized or permitted under Chapter 9.58 of the Cañon City Municipal Code;

    7.   Violate any posted safety rules established by authority of the City;

    8.   Paint, post or place any bill, notice, sign or banner in any park or in or on any tree, structure or facility within any City park;

    9.   Attach any permitted sign, banner or similar object to any tree, facility or improvement within any park by using damaging anchoring devices, including but not limited to nails, screws or staples;

    10. Molest, kill, move or transport any wildlife located in parks;

    11. Take, remove, cut, destroy any vegetation, plants, shrubs, or trees or any other natural feature, such as rocks, or the excavation of gravel or soil from any park;

    12. Remove from Temple Canyon Park, Red Canyon Park or Royal Gorge Park, any dead or fallen timber, except for gathering of fallen tree parts for use in the park from which the tree parts came for permitted camp fires in designed campfire rings;

    13. Wear, ride or otherwise use any type of rollerblade, roller skate, skateboard, bicycle or any other similar device, with or without wheels, on the tennis court surfaces at Rudd Park or Centennial Park or upon any tables, benches, shelters, stages, walls or hand or guard rails in any City park. For purposes of this section, “tennis court surfaces” means and includes all surface area inside of fencing surrounding the tennis courts in each park. Footwear and other devices identified and prohibited under this paragraph shall not be worn, carried into or stored within any such fenced area. Prohibited activities shall include skateboarding, rollerblading, roller skating, grinding and bicycle riding upon or within any of the surfaces and structures identified in this paragraph;

    14. Pound, drive, screw or excavate any stake, post, pipe, peg or anchor into the ground of any park without having first called for utility line locates from the Parks Department for the purposes of installing temporary tents or facilities for events;

    15. Build, light or maintain any fire in any park, or place within a park, when or where fires are banned or prohibited, either temporarily or permanently, or to leave any permitted fire unattended or unextinguished;

    16. Permit any dog or other animal in that person’s custody or control to defecate within such park, unless the person having custody or control of the dog or other animal immediately picks up and removes the waste matter deposited by such animal;

    17. Dispose of or leave behind any feces or other waste matter from a dog or other animal in that person’s control or custody in any street, alley, roadway, parking lot, playground, vegetated area or other place within or adjacent to any City park, except that such waste matter may be bagged or wrapped and then deposited in trash receptacles within any such park. The provisions of this paragraph and paragraph 16 of this subsection shall not apply with respect to persons with severely impaired vision who use and depend upon guide dogs to assist them in performing significant life activities.

    18. Camping within any City park, trail or open space, except as permitted by Section 9.44.065 of this Code. For purposes of this section, all terms shall have the same meaning as provided in Section 9.22.030 of this Code. Enforcement of this subsection shall be the same as provided in Section 9.22.030.

    19. Use the bandshell and stage structure within Veteran’s Park, unless permitted by the City.

    20. Lead or ride upon any horse or any other hoofed animal in areas designated and posted as identifying such use as being prohibited. This subsection shall also apply to all trails within City parks located outside the City boundaries.

    B.   Authority to Issue Certain Permits. The City Administrator is authorized to issue written permits authorizing one or more of the activities enumerated in paragraphs 1, 2, 3, 8, 10, 11, 12, 18 and 19 of Subsection 9.44.060(A). Any such activity identified in any such permit shall not be unlawful if conducted in accordance with the terms and provisions of the permit. Any permit which also requires Council approval pursuant to this section shall not be valid until Council approval is obtained.

    C.   No permit authorizing the sale, possession or consumption of ethyl alcohol within any City park shall be issued in the absence of prior formal approval by Council.

    D.  No permit authorizing overnight camping in any City park located within the boundaries of the city shall be issued in the absence of prior formal approval by Council.

    E.   No permit authorizing the sale of goods or services or any other commercial activity, including performances for which admission fees are charged, within any City park shall be issued in the absence of prior formal approval by Council, unless such permit is issued to a charitable or other nonprofit organization and the proceeds generated from such sales or other commercial activities are to be used for the charitable or other nonprofit purposes of such organization.

    F.   The City Administrator may refuse to issue any permit involving the sale of goods or services or other commercial activities in any City park requested by a charitable or nonprofit organization. If the City Administrator refuses to issue any such permit, the application for such permit will be referred by the City Administrator to Council for determination by Council if requested in writing by the applicant. Council will not consider any application for a park permit that is not submitted in writing on application forms prescribed or approved by the City Administrator.

    G.  Any permit issued pursuant to this section shall contain such restrictions and other limitations as were imposed by Council, in cases where Council’s prior approval was requested and obtained, and such other reasonable restrictions and limitations as are imposed in writing in the permit for purposes of protecting City parks and facilities from damage and those who use City parks from injury. All such permits shall require that the person receiving the permit will clean and restore the park or portion of a park to which the permit applied to the condition the park was in immediately prior to the conduct of the permitted activity and may require the posting of security or damage deposits when deemed necessary by the City Administrator to ensure compliance with such provisions.

    H.  For purposes of this section “person” means and includes any natural person, corporation, limited liability company, partnership, society, association, organization or other groups, regardless of whether formed or operated for profitable or not-for-profit purposes. (Ord. 8-2020 § 1; Ord. 25-2019 §§ 3,4; Ord. 12-2019 § 15; Ord. 13-2005 § 1; Ord. 23-2003 §§ 1, 2; Ord. 19-1996 § 2)

 

9.44.065 Overnight camping and open fires in Red Canyon Park, Temple Canyon Park and the Royal Gorge Park.
    A.  Overnight Camping.

    1.   Overnight camping in Red Canyon Park, Temple Canyon Park and the Royal Gorge Park shall be limited to designated overnight camping areas only. Camping in Red Canyon Park, Temple Canyon Park and the Royal Gorge Park shall not exceed seventy-two (72) hours during any two-week period of time; provided, however, that the Superintendent of Parks, or his or her designee, may, by permit, extend the time provided in this section. A time extension not to exceed an additional seventy-two (72) hours may be allowed if a written request is submitted to the Superintendent of Parks, or his designee, no less than twenty-four (24) hours in advance of the start of the requested time extension and at least one of the criteria below is met:

    a.   Breakdown of mode of transportation;

    b.   Medical emergency;

    c.   Special approved group events requiring longer than seventy-two (72) hours;

    d.   Any reason for which it is determined by the Park Superintendent, or his or her designee, that denial of a time extension would work an undue hardship on the requesting party or parties.

    2.   The City may require proof of time extension.

    B.   Open Fires. Open fires in Red Canyon Park, Temple Canyon Park and Royal Gorge Park shall be allowed in designated picnic and camping areas only, and all open fires shall be kept inside an open fire containment device approved by the Superintendent of Parks or his or her designee. It shall be unlawful for any person to leave unattended any fire within such parks. Any person who starts or causes to be started an open fire in said parks shall ensure such open fire is completely extinguished prior to leaving said park. The Superintendent of Parks, or his or her designee, may limit or ban open fires in Red Canyon Park, Temple Canyon Park or Royal Gorge Park when weather or other conditions create a high potential for forest or range fires. (Ord. 19-1989 § 1)

 

9.44.070 Throwing objects into Royal Gorge prohibited.
    No person shall throw, roll or push any rocks, missiles or other objects from the top of the Royal Gorge Canyon, or declivities or precipices therein, within the boundaries of the Royal Gorge Park, as defined in Section 9.44.080. (Prior code § 9.68.050)

 

9.44.075 Livestock within the Royal Gorge Park.
    Livestock are prohibited in the Royal Gorge Park, unless specifically authorized by the City Administrator or the City Administrator’s designee. Owners of livestock may not transport, release, or permit livestock to roam or graze into the Royal Gorge Park. For purposes of this chapter, livestock means cattle, mules, asses, goats, sheep, swine, buffalo, and cattalo, but does not include horses with riders and “alternative livestock” as defined in C.R.S. § 35-41.5-102, as may be amended. (Ord. 6-2019 § 1)

 

9.44.080 Climbing, hang gliding and other unlawful activities.
    A.  All parachuting, skydiving, hang gliding or other restrained or unrestrained form of ascent to or descent from the bridge, incline railway, train or canyon walls, located in Royal Gorge Park described as: Sections 21, 22, 23, 24, 25, 26, 27, or 28, Township 18 South, Range 71 West of the 6th P.M., is prohibited.

    B.   Any descent or ascent in:

    1.   Royal Gorge Park described above; or

    2.   Red Canyon Park, described as: The S 1/2, SW 1/4 and NW 1/4 SW 1/4 of Section 5, the SE 1/4, SE 1/4 of Section 6, the N 1/2 NE 1/4 of Section 7, and the NE 1/4, SE 1/4 and N 1/2 of Section 8, Township 17 South, Range 70 West of the 6th P.M.; or

    3.   Temple Canyon Park, described as: Section 10, Township 19 South, Range 71 West of the 6th P.M.;

by method of rock climbing or rappelling is prohibited.

    C.   Any of the above activities may, however, be permitted by the Royal Gorge Company of Colorado, by written agreement, in that portion of the Royal Gorge Park which is leased to the Royal Gorge Company, and the Royal Gorge Company shall notify the City of any such agreements. (Prior code § 9.68.060)

 

9.44.090 Firearms prohibited—Exceptions.
    No person, except a peace officer, shall carry any firearm into, or upon, or across any public park, playground or other property held, owned or controlled by the City; provided, that any person holding a permit from the City to kill or trap predatory animals may carry firearms for such purpose. (Prior code § 9.68.020)

 

9.44.095 Additional prohibitions concerning fireworks, firearms, explosives and other incendiary devices.
    The provisions of Chapter 9.44, with respect to the sale, possession or use of fireworks, firearms, explosives and other incendiary devices, shall apply and be strictly enforced in all parks owned or controlled by the City, whether within or outside of the corporate limits of the city. (Ord. 25-1993 § 2)

 

9.44.100 Trapping and hunting prohibited—Exceptions.
    A.  Except by permit, no person shall trap, hunt for, kill, or attempt to kill or trap any wild animal or game in any public park, playground or other property held, owned or controlled by the City; provided, that predatory animals may be trapped or killed by a person or persons holding a permit from the City to do so.

    B.   Permits to kill or trap predatory animals in or upon any public park, playground or other property held, owned or controlled by the City, shall be issued by the City Administrator after approval by the Council, upon application therefor, stating the public park or other place where such hunting or trapping is to be carried on, the animals to be killed or trapped, and such other information as may be material to a determination of whether or not a permit should be issued. (Prior code § 9.68.010)

 

9.44.110 Violation—Penalty—Liability for costs.
    A.  Any person who commits any unlawful act described at Section 9.44.060, or who otherwise violates any provision of this Chapter 9.44, including any rules adopted pursuant to Section 9.44.057 or Section 9.44.025, or who suffers or allows the same to be violated, is guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon conviction thereof, shall be punished by a fine in an amount that does not exceed the maximum fine provided for in Section 1.28.010.

    B.   Any person, firm, corporation or association engaging in those activities proscribed by this Chapter 9.44 shall be liable for any and all costs of rescue, extrication, first aid administration or transport arising from such activities, in addition to any other penalties provided for by law. (Ord. 17-2013 § 41; Ord. 3-2002 § 3; Ord. 19-1996 § 3; Ord. 15-1993 § 1; prior code 9.68.100)

 

Chapter 9.46 PUBLIC TRAILS
9.46.010 Definitions.
    A.  “Public Trail” shall mean and include any trail situated within the boundaries of the City of Cañon City that is owned, operated and/or maintained for public use by the City of Cañon City or by the Cañon City Area Metropolitan Recreation and Park District, or by both the City and the District.

    B.   “Trail Rules and Regulations” shall include those rules and regulations set forth in Section 9.46.020 and any additional rules or regulations adopted by resolution or ordinance of City Council. (Ord. 7-2012 § 1)

 

9.46.020 Rules and regulations.
    The trail rules and regulations that shall apply to all public trails within the City are as follows:

    1.   Take only memories, leave only footprints;

    2.   Hunting, trapping and firearms are prohibited;

    3.   Campfires and overnight camping are prohibited;

    4.   Motorized vehicles, including, but not limited to, any self-propelled vehicle, moped, go-cart, golf cart, motor scooter, electric personal assistive mobility device or “EPAMD,” as defined in C.R.S. § 42-1-102(28.7), engaged electronic assisted bicycle, hoverboard, or similar mode of transportation, are not allowed except upon established trails specifically designated by the City Council and marked for such purpose. A person may operate an electrical assisted bicycle, as defined in C.R.S. § 42-1-102(28.5), as may be amended, with the electrical motor disengaged on park paths where bicycles are authorized to travel. Electric personal assistive mobility devices or “EPAMDs” shall be permitted only if the user is dismounted. Nothing in this subsection shall prohibit or restrict the use or operation of an “other power-driven mobility device” (OPDMD), as used and defined by the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) Title II and III;

    5.   Cutting trees and other vegetation is prohibited;

    6.   Alcoholic beverages allowed by special permit only;

    7.   Pets must stay on the trail and be leashed and pet waste must be collected and deposited into trash receptacles;

    8.   Only authorized uses are allowed on the trail;

    9.   Vehicles must be parked in authorized areas;

    10. Trail hours shall be dawn to dusk.

    11. The riding or leading of a horse, or any other hoofed animal is authorized, except in areas designated and posted as prohibiting such use. (Ord. 8-2020 § 2; Ord. 43-2017 § 2; Ord. 7-2012 § 1)

 

9.46.030 Posting of trail rules and regulations.
    Notice of trail rules and regulations shall be posted at various locations within and along the public trail system at locations to be determined by the City or by the District or by the City and District jointly. (Ord. 7-2012 § 1)

 

9.46.040 Violations—Penalties.
    Any person violating any posted trail rule or regulation is guilty of a misdemeanor and upon conviction thereof shall be punished by a fine not to exceed fifty dollars ($50.00) for a first violation and one hundred dollars ($100.00) for any subsequent violation committed in any twelve (12) month period. (Ord. 7-2012 § 1)

Division VI. Consumer Protection (Reserved)

Division VII. Offenses By or Against Minors
Chapter 9.48 LOITERING
9.48.010 Definition.
    A.  As used in this ordinance, “loitering” shall mean remaining idle in essentially one location and shall include the concept of spending time idly; to be dilatory; to linger, to stay; to saunter; to delay; to stand around and shall also include the colloquial expressions “hanging around” and “hanging out.” (Ord. 14-1995 § 1)

 

9.48.020 Juvenile loitering during nighttime hours.
    A.  It shall be unlawful for any person under the age of eighteen (18) years to loiter or to aimlessly drive or ride about, on or about any street, avenue, highway, road, sidewalk, curb, gutter, parking lot, alley, vacant lot, park, playground, yard, building, place of amusement, or eating place, whether public or private, without the consent or permission of the owner or occupant thereof, during the hours beginning at 12:01 a.m. on Saturday and Sunday mornings, and ending at six a.m.; and beginning at ten p.m. on Sunday night through Thursday night, and ending at six a.m. the following morning. No violation of this Section 9.48.030 will have occurred if the person under the age of eighteen (18) years is accompanied by a parent, guardian or other adult person over the age of twenty-one (21) years who is authorized by a parent or guardian of such juvenile to take said parent’s place in accompanying said juvenile for a designated period of time and purpose within a specified area. (Ord. 14-1995 § 1)

 

9.48.030 Parental responsibility.
    A.  It shall be unlawful for the parent, guardian, or other adult person having the care and custody of a juvenile under the age of eighteen (18) years to knowingly permit or allow such juvenile to loiter or to aimlessly drive or ride about at the places and within the time prohibited by Section 9.48.020 of this chapter. The term “knowingly” includes knowledge which a parent should be reasonably expected to have concerning the whereabouts of a juvenile in that parent or guardian’s custody. It shall be no defense that a parent, guardian, or other person having the care and custody of the juvenile was indifferent to the activities, conduct or whereabouts of such juvenile. (Ord. 14-1995 § 1)

 

9.48.040 Penalties.
    A.  Any person who violates any provision of this Chapter 9.48 shall be punished by a fine in an amount that is not less than fifty dollars ($50.00), nor more than the maximum fine provided for in Section 1.28.010.

    B.   In addition to the fine provided for at Subsection A, any person who violates any provisions of this chapter may be ordered to perform not fewer than twenty-four (24) hours nor more than forty-eight (48) hours of useful public service and to pay all fees required by the agency through which the useful public service will be arranged, performed and monitored. (Ord. 17-2013 § 42; Ord. 14-1995 § 1)

Division VIII. Weapons
Chapter 9.52 CONCEALED WEAPONS
9.52.010 Carrying concealed weapons prohibited—Exceptions.
    A.  A person commits a misdemeanor if such person knowingly and unlawfully:

    1.   Carries a knife concealed on or about his or her person; or

    2.   Carries a firearm concealed on or about his or her person; or

    3.   Carries concealed upon his or her person any other deadly weapon, as described in Section 18-1-901(3)(c), C.R.S.

    B.   It shall not be an offense if the defendant was:

    1.   A person in his or her own dwelling or place of business or on property owned or under his or her control at the time of the act of carrying; or

    2.   A person in a private automobile or other private means of conveyance who carries a weapon for lawful protection of such person’s or another’s person or property while traveling; or

    3.   A person who, at the time of carrying a concealed weapon, held a valid written permit to carry a concealed weapon issued pursuant to Section 18-12-105.1, C.R.S., as it existed prior to its repeal, or, if the weapon involved was a handgun, held a valid permit to carry a concealed handgun or a temporary emergency permit issued pursuant to part 2 of Article 12 of Title 18, C.R.S.; except that it shall be an offense under this section if the person was carrying a concealed handgun in violation of the provisions of Section 18-12-214; or

    4.   A peace officer, as described in Section 16-2.5-101, C.R.S., when carrying a weapon in conformance with the policy of the employing agency as provided in Section 16-2.5-101(2), C.R.S.; or

    5.   A United States probation officer or a United States pretrial services officer while on duty and serving in the State of Colorado under the authority of rules and regulations promulgated by the judicial conference of the United States.

    C.   The provisions of paragraph 3 of Subsection B of this Section 9.52.010 will operate to allow persons holding valid concealed handgun permits and otherwise acting in compliance with applicable state law to carry their concealed handguns into and within the City’s parks and on trails within the City for so long as such activities are permitted by applicable state law, but shall not operate to permit the open carrying of firearms into or within specific places and areas within the City, including, but not necessarily limited to, parks and trails, where City ordinances or other regulations of the City prohibit firearms and signage advising the public of such prohibition has been posted in and around such places and areas, as specifically permitted by Section 29-11.7-104, C.R.S. and generally authorized by Article XX of the Colorado Constitution. (Ord. 27-2014 § 3; Ord. 6-2013 § 1)

 

9.52.020 Violation—Penalty.
    Any person who violates any provision of this Chapter 9.52, is guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon conviction thereof, shall be punished by a fine in an amount that does not exceed the maximum fine provided for in Section 1.28.010. (Ord. 17-2013 § 43; Ord. 15-1993 § 1)

 

Chapter 9.56 DISCHARGING WEAPONS
9.56.010 Discharging firearms and air rifles—Misdemeanor.
    Any person who, in this city, discharges a firearm of any kind or an air rifle, when not acting in line of duty or not otherwise authorized by law, is guilty of a misdemeanor. (Prior code § 9.92.010)

 

9.56.015 Exceptions for firearms.
    A.  The City Administrator and the Chief of Police may jointly authorize certain City employees assigned to manage or operate the City’s water plant and facilities, including, but not limited to, raw water storage ponds and surrounding lands, to discharge firearms within the city for purposes of controlling or attempting to control muskrats, beaver and other destructive animals and rodents which are causing damage to any of the City’s water plant facilities. Such authorization, if given, shall be made in writing and shall contain the following:

    1.   The names of those authorized under this section;

    2.   A description of the location or locations with respect to which the authorization applies;

    3.   Restrictions as to days and times of day when the discharge of firearms may take place;

    4.   Restrictions as to the types of firearms which may be used by the identified employees; and

    5.   Such other restrictions or limitations as are deemed appropriate by the City Administrator and the Chief of Police for purposes of ensuring the safety of water plant employees and the inhabitants of the City and minimizing, to the extent practicable, disturbances to the peace of inhabitants which may be caused as a result of the discharge of firearms by authorized water plant operators.

    B.   The discharge of firearms authorized under Subsection A of this section in accordance with the terms, requirements, restrictions and limitations of a written authorization, as provided for in said subsection, shall not be a violation of Section 9.56.010.

    C.   True and correct copies of all written authorizations made under Subsection A shall be kept and maintained in the offices of the City Administrator, City Clerk and Chief of Police.

    D.  It should be an exception to Section 9.56.010 for a starter’s gun or other firearm, including muzzle loaders, which fires blanks or blank cartridges to be used in a recognized athletic event or contest, public performance, theatrical event or in a public event if such use is sanctioned by the City Administrator or Chief of Police. (Ord. 12-2019 § 5; Ord. 3-1992 § 1)

 

9.56.020 Using devices to throw objects—Misdemeanor.
    Any person who knowingly, intentionally or recklessly throws or causes to be thrown, by means of any peashooter, beanshooter, slingshot, or by means of any other machine or contrivance, any stone or other similar object at or toward any other person or persons, or at, toward or against the property of another, including, but not limited to, motorized vehicles, buildings and other structures, is guilty of a misdemeanor. (Ord. 19-2003 § 10; prior code § 9.99.020)

 

9.56.025 Throwing objects—Misdemeanor.
    Any person who knowingly, intentionally or recklessly throws or causes to be thrown, any stone, egg, ice ball or other similar object, at or toward any other person or persons, or at, toward or against the property of another, including, but not limited to, motorized vehicles, buildings and other structures, is guilty of a misdemeanor. (Ord. 20-2019 § 1)

 

9.56.030 Violation—Penalty.
    A.  Except as provided in Section 9.56.030(B), any person who violates any provision of this Chapter 9.56, is guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon conviction thereof, shall be punished by a fine in an amount that does not exceed the maximum fine provided for in Section 1.28.010.

    B.   Any person convicted of unlawfully discharging a firearm at any place within the City or within any park or other land owned or controlled by the City, if the court finds that such firearm was discharged from within a vehicle, shall be punished by a fine of not less than one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) nor more than the maximum fine provided for in Section 1.28.010. (Ord. 12-2019 § 6; Ord. 17-2013 § 44; Ord. 15-1993 § 1)

Division IX. Fire and Explosives Regulations
Chapter 9.58 FIREWORKS AND EXPLOSIVES
9.58.010 Fireworks—Provisions of Colorado Revised Statutes adopted by reference pursuant to Section 9 of Article XII of the Charter of Cañon City, Colorado.
    There is adopted by reference Article 33.5 of Title 24 of the Colorado Revised Statutes (“C.R.S.”) as amended, all to have the same force and effect as if set forth herein in every particular, except for deletions, amendments and additions hereinafter in this chapter set forth. (Ord. 12-2019 § 7)

 

9.58.020 Certification—Copies for public use.
    The City Clerk shall certify the passage of the ordinance codified in this Chapter 9.58 and make not less than three (3) copies of Part 20, Article 33.5 of Title 24, C.R.S., and the ordinance codified in this chapter available for inspection by the public during regular business hours. Copies of said Part 20, Article 33.5 of Title 24, C.R.S., together with a certified copy of the ordinance codified in this chapter shall be available for sale to the public through the office of the City Clerk for an amount equal to the City’s cost of reproducing the same. (Ord. 12-2019 § 7)

 

9.58.030 Additions, amendments and deletions.
    Penalties for violations of this chapter shall be as set forth in Section 9.58.070 and the provisions of C.R.S. § 24-33.5-2010 are therefore deleted. (Ord. 12-2019 § 7)

 

9.58.040 Violations within city limits.
    Any act or omission which is described as a violation of any provision of Article 33.5 of Title 24, C.R.S. shall constitute a violation of this chapter if committed or omitted within the corporate limits of the City. (Ord. 12-2019 § 7)

 

9.58.050 Violations outside of city limits.
    A.  Any act or omission which is a violation if committed or omitted within the corporate limits of the City shall be a violation if committed or omitted within any park or other land owned or controlled by the City that is situated outside of the corporate limits of the City, including, but not limited to, Royal Gorge Park, Red Canyon Park, Temple Canyon Park, Skyline Drive, Tunnel Drive, and the Cañon City water treatment plant and facilities.

    B.   Within any park or other land owned or controlled by the City which is located outside of the City limits, it shall also be unlawful for any person, firm, corporation or association to possess outside of a vehicle, cast, throw, explode, ignite, set off or otherwise fire:

    1.   Permissible fireworks, as defined at C.R.S. § 24-33.5-2001(11)(a), as may be amended.

    2.   Any device described at C.R.S. § 24-33.5-2001(5), except that it shall not be a violation of this Subsection 9.58.050(B) that a highway flare, railway fusee, ship distress signal, smoke candle or other emergency signal device was possessed, if such device was not ignited, and it also shall not be a violation that such device was ignited if:

    a.   The device was placed upon or near the edge of an existing roadway in a place that is a safe distance away from growing vegetation or other combustible materials; and

    b.   The device was ignited for the sole purpose of signaling the approximate location of a person or persons involved in an actual emergency situation involving death or serious bodily injury or other circumstances that constituted an actual and immediate threat to human life, health or safety. (Ord. 12-2019 § 7)

 

9.58.060 Firearms and explosives.
    A.  No person shall discharge a cannon nor cause to explode any gunpowder, blasting powder, giant powder, dynamite, TNT, nitroglycerine or other dangerous explosive, within the City or within the boundaries of any park or other land or facility owned or controlled by the City located outside of the corporate limits of the city, except:

    1.   A mechanical device utilizing an explosive powder or cartridge used in the construction trades may be used in the ordinary course of business; and

    2.   Explosives used in construction excavation projects, may be used in such projects, but only when a written permit for same shall have been previously obtained from the City Building Inspector, for which no fee shall be charged. (Ord. 12-2019 § 7)

 

9.58.070 Penalties for violations.
    A.  Any person who violates any provision of Section 9.58.040, is guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon conviction thereof, shall be punished by a fine in an amount that is not less than fifty dollars ($50.00), nor more than the maximum fine provided for in Section 1.28.010.

    B.   Every person who violates any provision of Section 9.58.050 or of Section 9.58.060, is guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon conviction thereof, shall be punished by a fine in an amount that is not less than two hundred dollars ($200.00), nor more than the maximum fine provided for in Section 1.28.010.

    C.   No portion of minimum fines provided for at Subsections A and B of this section shall be suspended by any court. (Ord. 12-2019 § 7)

 

Chapter 9.60 OPEN BURNING
9.60.010 Definitions.
    A.  “Fire Chief” means and refers to the Chief of the Fire Department operated by the Cañon City Area Fire Protection District.

    B.   “Jurisdiction of the City” means and includes all property within the boundaries of the City and all other land in the vicinity of the City that is owned or controlled by the City, including, but not limited to: Royal Gorge Park, Red Canyon Park, Temple Canyon Park, Skyline Drive, Tunnel Drive, Lakeside Cemetery, Greenwood Cemetery and all land containing facilities of the Cañon City Water Department.

    C.   “Official order,” as used in this chapter, means and includes any order issued by the City Administrator pursuant to the authority granted in subsection A of Section 9.60.020 which is distributed and posted in accordance with that subsection, and any certified written order of the Fire Chief delivered to the City Administrator which is posted and distributed as provided for in subsection B of Section 9.60.020.

    D.  “Open burning” means as any outdoor fire, including but not limited to, bonfires, campfires, warming fires, charcoal grill fires, fires in wood-burning stoves, the use of explosives, outdoor welding or hot work, fireworks of all kinds or brands, including fireworks otherwise permissible pursuant to C.R.S. § 24-33.5-2001, and the prescribed burning of fence lines or rows, fields, farm lands, rangelands, wildlands, trash and debris. Open burning shall not include:

    1.   Fires in camp stoves or grills fueled by bottled gas or pressurized liquid and specifically designed for cooking or heating purposes;

    2.   Fires in permanently constructed stationary masonry or metal fireplaces specifically designed for the purpose of combustion; and

    3.   Fires in commercially operated wood and/or charcoal-fired grills designed for cooking.

    E.   “Hazardous fire area” shall have the same meaning as the fire code adopted by the Cañon City Area Fire Protection District, as approved and ratified by resolution or ordinance of City Council. (Ord. 12-2019 § 7)

 

9.60.020 Authority for issuance and enforcement of official orders banning open burning and restricting access to hazardous fire areas.
    A.  Whenever the City Administrator determines that conditions in and around the City are such that there is a high risk of fire, in consultation with the Fire Chief and other local governmental entities with authority regarding fire restrictions, the City Administrator shall have the authority, by written order to:

    1.   To temporarily ban or otherwise restrict open burning;

    2.   To ban or restrict the use of fireworks; and

    3.   To deny or restrict public access to any hazardous fire area within the jurisdiction of the City.

    B.   Copies of all such orders by the City Administrator shall be promptly distributed to a newspaper of general circulation in the city, posted on the City’s official bulletin board at City Hall and on the City’s website. Notice of the City Administrator’s order also may be given to the general public using other means of communication available to the City Administrator.

    C.   Whenever the Fire Chief shall issue a written order banning or otherwise restricting open burning or denying or restricting public access to a hazardous fire area within the boundaries of the Cañon City Area Fire Protection District and deliver a certified copy of such order to the office of the City Administrator, such order shall be enforceable within the jurisdiction of the City by the Fire District. Copies of such orders by the Fire Chief shall be distributed and posted in the same manner and places as are provided for in subsection A of this section with respect to the written orders of the City Administrator.

    D.  In the event of a conflict between a provision of a written order of the City Administrator and a provision of a written order of the Fire Chief, the more stringent provision shall apply, unless the written order of the City Administrator provides otherwise. (Ord. 12-2019 § 7)

 

9.60.030 Duration.
    The City Administrator, or his or her designee, is authorized to impose restrictions of a limited duration based on the nature and scope of the current conditions. Any such duration may be extended or modified by subsequent administrative order of the City Administrator, or his or her designee, based on continuing adverse fire conditions. (Ord. 12-2019 § 7)

 

9.60.040 Presumption.
    After the terms of an official order have been posted on the City’s official bulletin board, City’s website, and printed or summarized in a newspaper of general circulation in the City, all persons physically present within the jurisdiction of the City shall be presumed to have actual knowledge of the terms of such official order. (Ord. 12-2019 § 7)

 

9.60.050 Unlawful acts.
    It shall be unlawful for any person to conduct any open burning in the City, including public, private, state and federal lands, in violation of this Code or in violation of an administrative order issued by the City Administrator, or his or her designee, in accordance with this section. (Ord. 12-2019 § 7)

 

9.60.060 Penalty for violation.
    Any person convicted of violating any provision of this section, with the exception of 9.60.020(C), shall, upon conviction, be punished as follows:

    A.  First offense, a fine of one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00).

    B.   Second offense, a fine of two hundred and fifty dollars ($250.00).

    C.   Third offense, summons and a fine between three hundred fifty dollars ($350.00) to not more than four hundred ninety-nine dollars ($499.00).

    D.  The City also may seek an injunction, abatement, restitution or any other remedy to prevent, enjoin, abate or remove the violation.

    E.   Each day a violation of this section continues shall constitute a separate offense. Any remedies provided for herein shall be cumulative and not exclusive and shall be in addition to any other remedies provided by law. (Ord. 12-2019 § 7)

 

9.60.070 Additional remedies.
    The remedies provided in this section shall be cumulative and in addition to any other federal, state or local remedy, criminal or civil, which may be available. Nothing contained herein shall be construed to preclude prosecution under any other applicable statute, including but not limited to prosecution under C.R.S. § 18-13-109 or any other applicable statute, ordinance, rule, order or regulation. (Ord. 12-2019 § 7)

Title 10 VEHICLES AND TRAFFIC
Chapter 10.04 MODEL TRAFFIC CODE
Chapter 10.08 RAILROAD REGULATIONS

Chapter 10.04 MODEL TRAFFIC CODE
10.04.010 Document adopted by reference.
    Pursuant to Section 9 of Article XII of the Charter of Cañon City, Colorado, there is adopted by this reference Articles I and II, inclusive, of the 2003 Edition of the “Model Traffic Code” promulgated and published as such by the Colorado Department of Transportation, Safety and Traffic Engineering Branch, 4201 East Arkansas Avenue, EP 700, Denver, Colorado 80222, all to have the same force and effect as if set forth herein in every particular, except for the deletions, amendments and additions hereinafter in this chapter set forth. (Ord. 27-2003 § 1: Ord. 10-2001 § 1)

 

10.04.020 Certification—Copies for public use.
    The City Clerk shall certify the passage of the ordinance codified in this chapter and make not less than three (3) copies of the adopted Model Traffic Code and copies of this chapter, together with three (3) copies of any ordinance amending this chapter subsequent to the adoption of the 2003 Edition of the Model Traffic Code, available for inspection by the public during regular business hours. The Model Traffic Code, together with a certified copy of this chapter and copies of subsequent ordinances amending this chapter, shall be available for sale to the public through the office of the City Clerk. (Ord. 27-2003 § 2: Ord. 10-2001 § 1)

 

10.04.030 Purpose of Model Traffic Code provisions.
    The subject matter and purpose of the Model Traffic Code is to provide a system of traffic control and regulation within the city and within certain areas outside the city which are under the City’s jurisdiction, generally conforming to similar regulations throughout the State of Colorado and the United States. (Ord. 10-2001 § 1)

 

10.04.040 Interpretation of provisions.
    This chapter shall be interpreted and construed so as to effectuate its general purpose to conform with the State’s uniform system for the regulation of vehicles and traffic. Article and section headings of this chapter and the adopted Model Traffic Code shall not be deemed to govern, limit, modify or in any manner affect the scope, meaning or extent of the provisions of any article or section thereof. (Ord. 10-2001 § 1)

 

10.04.050 Application.
    A.  This chapter shall apply to every street, alley, sidewalk area, driveway, park, and to every other public way or public place or public parking area, either within or outside the corporate limits of the city, the use of which the City has jurisdiction and authority to regulate, including, but not limited to, Temple Canyon Park, Red Canyon Park, Royal Gorge Park and Skyline Drive. All land within the corporate boundaries of the city, together with the land included within such designated parks and Skyline Drive shall constitute the “jurisdiction of the City” for purposes of the applicability and enforcement of the Model Traffic Code.

    B.   The provisions of Sections 606, 607, 610, 1401, 1402 and 1413 of the Model Traffic Code, respectively concerning the display of unauthorized signs or devices, the interference with official devices, the display of unauthorized insignia, reckless driving, careless driving, and eluding or attempting to elude a police officer, shall apply to both public places and ways and private places throughout the jurisdiction of the City, as described in Subsection A of this section. (Ord. 10-2001 § 1)

 

10.04.060 Violations and penalties.
    A.  It is unlawful for any person to violate any provision of the Model Traffic Code, as adopted and amended in this chapter.

    B.   If no other fine is specified or otherwise provided for in this chapter, including Subsection C of this section, every person who violates any provision of this Chapter 10.04, is guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon conviction thereof, shall be punished by a fine in an amount that does not exceed the maximum fine provided for in Section 1.28.010.

    C.   Every person who is convicted of violating any provision of the Model Traffic Code (“MTC”) shall be punished according to the following schedule:

 

 

OFFENSE—MTC SECTION

FINE

1. Parking Violations:

 

a. Violations of Section 1203 (Time restricted parking)

$5.00

b. Violations of Section 1208 (Concerning spaces reserved for persons with a disability and related matters)

$100.00

c. Violations of Section 1202, 1204, 1205, 1206 or 1207

$30.00

d. Violations of Section 1212 (Prohibiting the parking or storage of commercial vehicles, recreational vehicles and/or trailers on residential streets)

$30.00 for a first violation within any 12-month period;
