    I.    Within fifteen (15) days of the effective date of the designating ordinance, the Commission shall record with the county clerk and recorder a certified copy of the ordinance.

    J.    If the Commission determines that a proposed district, site or structure does not meet the criteria for designation as a historic resource, any of the affected property owners may appeal the Commission’s decision by filing a written appeal with the City Council within thirty (30) days of the Commission’s decision. (Ord. 27-2018 § 1)

 

12.30.090 Criteria for designation.
    The Commission shall consider the following criteria when reviewing nominations for designation:

    A.  Designation as an Historic Resource. All resources proposed for historic designation shall be at least fifty (50) years old and shall possess architectural, social, geographic or environmental importance by meeting one (1) or more of the following criteria:

    1.   Exemplifies specific elements of an architectural style or period.

    2.   Is an example of the work of an architect or builder who is recognized for his or her national, statewide, regional or local expertise.

    3.   Demonstrates superior craftsmanship or high artistic value.

    4.   Represents an innovation in construction, materials or design.

    5.   Represents a style particularly associated with the area.

    6.   Represents a built environment of a group of people in an era of history.

    7.   Represents a pattern or grouping of elements representing at least one criteria in this Subsection A.

    8.   Has undergone a significant historic remodel.

    9.   Is the site of a historic event that had an effect upon society.

    10. Exemplifies cultural, political, economic or social heritage in the community.

    11. Represents an association with a notable person.

    12. Is identified with historical personages or groups or which represents important events in national, state or local history.

    13. Enhances a sense of identity with the community.

    14. Is an established and familiar natural setting or visual feature in the community.

    B.   Historic Districts. In addition to complying with Subsection A above, districts proposed for historic designation shall demonstrate a pattern of physical elements or social activities. Significance is determined by applying the criteria of this chapter to patterns and unifying elements.

    1.   Historic district designation will not be considered unless the application contains written approval of all property owners within the proposed historic district boundaries.

    2.   Properties that do not contribute to the significance of the proposed historic district may be included within the boundaries if the noncontributing buildings do not noticeably detract from the proposed historic district’s sense of time, place and historic development. Noncontributing elements will be evaluated for their magnitude of impact by considering their size, scale, design, location or information potential.

    C.   Any historic landmark listed on the National Register of Historic Places or the Colorado State Register of Historic Properties shall be deemed to qualify for local designation under this chapter; however, such landmarks shall not be locally designated until an application for designation is filed and processed pursuant to this chapter. (Ord. 27-2018 § 1)

 

12.30.100 Alteration certificate required.
    A.  No persons shall cause or permit to be caused on or in a designated historic resource any construction, alteration, restoration, removal or demolition without first obtaining an alteration certificate for the proposed work from the Commission.

    B.   The Building Division shall not issue a building permit for work on or in a designated historic resource until an alteration certificate or exemption certificate has been obtained by the property owner.

    C.   An application for any construction, alteration, or demolition on or in a historic resource must be filed with the Commission on a form provided by the Commission.

    D.  The Commission shall consider the application and determine whether the proposal preserves the criteria for which the resource was designated, or adds to the architectural, cultural or historical significance of the resource. The Commission shall make its review pursuant to the procedures in Section 12.30.080.

    E.   Criteria to Review Alteration Certificate Application. In reviewing a proposed alteration, the Commission shall consider the project in terms such as design, finish, material, scale, mass and height and if the alteration is compatible with the historic designation. The Commission shall use the following criteria to determine compatibility of a proposed alteration:

    1.   The effect upon the general historical and architectural character of the district, site or structure;

    2.   The architectural style, arrangement, texture and material used on the existing and proposed structures and their relation and compatibility with other structures;

    3.   The size of the structure, its setbacks, its site, location and the appropriateness thereof, when compared to existing structures and the site;

    4.   The compatibility of accessory structures and fences with the main structure on the site, and with other structures;

    5.   The effects of the proposed work in creating, changing, destroying, or otherwise impacting the exterior architectural features of the resource upon which such work is done;

    6.   The condition of existing improvements and whether they are a hazard to public health and safety;

    7.   The effects of the proposed work upon the protection, enhancement, perpetuation and use of the resource;

    8.   The ability to comply with the Secretary of the Interior’s Standards for Rehabilitation and Guidelines for Rehabilitating Historic Buildings, a section of the Secretary of the Interior’s Standards for The Treatment of Historic Properties, of the Department of the Interior Regulations (36 C.F.R. Part 67), as may be amended from time to time; and

    9.   Guidance provided by the National Park Service Historic Preservation Briefs, as the same may exist from time to time.

    F.   Historic Districts—Additional Criteria for Contributing Buildings. In addition to the considerations set forth in Subsection E above, in reviewing a proposed alteration of a contributing building within a historic district, the Commission shall consider the following:

    1.   The effect upon the general historic and architectural character of the building;

    2.   The architectural style, arrangement, texture and material used on the existing and proposed buildings and their relation and compatibility with other historic landmarks, including state and national designations;

    3.   The effects of the proposed work in creating, changing, destroying or otherwise affecting the exterior architectural features of the building upon which such work is done;

    4.   The effects of the proposed work upon the protection, enhancement and perpetuation of the building;

    5.   The condition of existing improvements and whether they are a hazard to public health and safety;

    6.   The compatibility of accessory buildings, structures and fences with the main building and with other historic landmarks; and

    7.   Substantial compliance with the Secretary of the Interior Standards as they apply to building exteriors only, except those relating to paint color, which shall not apply.

    G.  Historic Districts—Additional Criteria for Noncontributing Buildings. In addition to the considerations set forth in Subsection E above, in reviewing a proposed alteration of a noncontributing building within a historic district, the Commission shall consider the following:

    1.   Noncontributing buildings should be compatible with contributing building;

    2.   Noncontributing buildings should not attempt to mimic or duplicate the historic features of contributing buildings; and

    3.   Contemporary designs that creatively draw upon the important characteristics of a historic district are favored.

    H.  If an alteration certificate is approved, the designated resource will retain its historic designation.

    I.    If an alteration certificate is denied, any of the affected property owners may appeal the Commission’s decision by filing a written appeal with the City Council within thirty (30) days of the Commission’s decision. (Ord. 27-2018 § 1)

 

12.30.110 Certificate of exemption.
    A.  If an alteration certification is denied or the affected property owner(s) cannot comply with the recommendations from the Commission for changes necessary for the issuance of an alteration certificate, the owner or owners may make application for a certificate of exemption.

    B.   Application for a certificate of exemption shall be made on a form prepared by the Commission. The Commission shall schedule a public hearing and provide notice as outlined in Section 12.30.080.

    C.   The Commission shall consider the following factors in determining whether to issue a certificate of exemption:

    1.   The cost of the proposed construction, alteration, restoration, or demolition, and the estimated additional cost, if any, of complying with the recommendations of the Commission for changes necessary for the issuance of an alteration certificate;

    2.   A report from a licensed engineer or architect concerning the structural soundness of the historic resource and their suitability for rehabilitation;

    3.   The estimated market value of the historic resource in its current condition, after completion of the proposed work, after any changes in the proposed work recommended by the Commission, and in the case of a demolition, after renovation of the historic resource for other uses;

    4.   The amount paid for the historic resource, the date of purchase, the party from whom the historic resource was purchased, and the relationship, if any, between the applicant and the person from whom the historic resource was purchased;

    5.   If the historic resource is income-producing, the annual gross income and itemized operating and maintenance expenses from the historic resource for the previous two (2) years;

    6.   The remaining balance on any mortgage or other financing secured by the historic resource;

    7.   Any appraisals of the historic resource’s value obtained by the applicant or other affected property owners within the previous two (2) years;

    8.   Any listing of the historic resource, or a portion thereof, for sale or rent, price asked and offers received, if any, during the previous two (2) years;

    9.   The real estate taxes on the historic resource for the previous two (2) years; and

    10. Any other information that may be relevant for the Commission’s consideration of the application.

    D.  The Commission shall review the evidence and testimony presented and issue written findings and conclusions within forty-five (45) days of receipt of the application. If a certificate of exemption is granted, the applicant may proceed with the construction, alteration, restoration, removal or demolition without further delay imposed by this chapter.

    E.   If a certificate of exemption is denied, the affected property owners may appeal the Commission’s decision by filing a written appeal with the City Council within thirty (30) days of the Commission’s decision. (Ord. 27-2018 § 1)

 

12.30.120 Revocation, enforcement and penalties.
    A.  If a structure or special feature of a designated historic resource has been altered in such a way so as to negate the features necessary to retain designation, the owner may apply to the Commission for a revocation of the designation or the Commission shall recommend revocation of the designation to the City Council in the absence of the owner’s application to do so. The procedure for revoking a designation shall be the procedure outlined in Section 12.30.080.

    B.   Revocation of the designation shall be the only enforcement and penalty recourse for a violation of this chapter. (Ord. 27-2018 § 1)

Title 13 PUBLIC UTILITIES*

Chapter 13.18 DUTY OF FRANCHISEES TO REIMBURSE THE CITY FOR COSTS INCURRED BY THE CITY IN INVESTIGATING, NEGOTIATING AND “PROVING FRANCHISES AMENDMENTS THERETO AND PROPOSED TRANSFERS OF FRANCHISES

Chapter 13.04 WATER REGULATIONS
13.04.010 Application of chapter provisions.
    The provisions of this chapter apply to the installation, operation and maintenance of all water distribution facilities under the control of the Water Department and to the physical aspects of connecting the properties and structures of water users to the water system operated by the Water Department and providing water service to such water users. See Chapter 13.08 regarding tap fees and water rates. (Ord. 8-2008 § 1)

 

13.04.020 Definitions.
    A.  As used in this chapter and Chapter 13.08, the meaning of certain words and phrases shall be as set out in this section:

    0.5 “Accessory Dwelling Unit (ADU)” means a secondary dwelling unit established in conjunction with, but clearly subordinate to, a single-family dwelling unit that is the principal structure on the lot, attached to the principal structure or as a separate accessory structure or portion thereof on the same lot as otherwise defined in Chapter 17.15 Cañon City Municipal Code.

    1.   “Association” means a unit owner’s association organized under Section 38-33.3-301, C.R.S, or any other applicable state statute, and may include an organization established to own and maintain common open space in a planned unit development. Association also means a homeowner’s association authorized to transact business in Colorado.

    2.   “Bulk Water User” means users who are not connected to the City water system and who provide their own transportation containers and vehicles to purchase water in bulk at the City’s water dispensing station in accordance with Department regulations.

    3.   “Common Interest Community” means real estate described in a declaration with respect to which a person, by virtue of such person’s ownership of a unit, is obligated to pay for real estate taxes, insurance premiums, maintenance, or improvement of other real estate described in a declaration. Ownership of a unit does not include holding a leasehold interest in a unit of less than forty (40) years, including renewal options. The period of the leasehold interest, including renewal options, is measured from the date the initial term commences. (See Section 38-33.3-10103(8), C.R.S.)

    4.   “Condominium” means a common interest community in which portions of the real estate are designated for separate ownership and the remainder of which is designated for common ownership solely by the owners of the separate ownership portions. A common interest community is not a condominium unless the undivided interests in the common elements are vested in the unit owners. (See Section 38-33.3-103(9) C.R.S.) Condominium may also mean real property that was divided into individual air space units pursuant to the Colorado Condominium Ownership Act. (See C.R.S. Section 38-33-101, et seq.)

    5.   “Cooperative” means a common interest community in which the real property is owned by an association, each member of which is entitled by virtue of such member’s ownership interest in the association to exclusive possession of a unit. (See C.R.S. Section 38-33-103(10).)

    6.   “Contractor” means a person duly licensed to work in the city in accordance with the requirements of the laws and codes applicable in the City of Cañon City.

    7.   “Correctional Facility” means any prison and/or prison complex operated by the Colorado Department of Corrections (“CDOC”) that is served by the Water Department through one or more master meters for distribution within the prison or complex and any similar facility operated by a person other than CDOC.

    8.   “Department” means the Water Department of the City, a water activity enterprise.

    9.   “Developer” means any person who participates as owner, promoter, developer or sales agent in the planning, platting, development, promotion, sale or lease of a planned development district, planned unit development, subdivision or other residential, commercial, industrial or other land development.

    10. “Duplex” means a structure or facility in single ownership situated upon a single lot or parcel that contains two (2) separate dwelling units connected by a common sidewall that, for purposes of metering, are considered one user.

    11. “Dwelling Unit” means living quarters that include facilities for sleeping and the preparation of meals, but does not include living quarters furnished in a hotel or motel for which a daily rental rate is charged. The term “dwelling unit” does not include motor homes, trailers, or other recreational vehicles using the facilities of a park furnishing facilities for such vehicles, nor does the term “dwelling unit” include hospital rooms or living quarters in a rest home certified as such by the state of Colorado.

    12. “Engineer” means the City Engineer.

    13. “Group User” means any person that, pursuant to an agreement with the Department, purchases water from the Department for sale and/or distribution to third parties who are connected to the water system of the group user.

    14. “Inside Water User” or “Inside User” means the owner of any property located within the corporate limits of the City of Cañon City that is directly connected to the Department’s system.

    15. “Meter” means a device that is approved by the Department, meets the City of Cañon City Standard Construction Specifications and is used for the purpose of measuring and recording the amount of water that passes through the device, indicating the volume of water consumed by a water user. In most cases, the meter constitutes the point of delivery of water sold by the Department and separates the “system side” of a water service line from the “customer side” of such line.

    15.5 “Meter Charge” means the basic charge billed to and payable by each water user connected to the water system for the privilege of being so connected. The meter charge is one of the two (2) components of water rates payable by such users and is billed without regard to actual water consumption. Consumption charges are the second component of water rates applicable to such users.

    16. “Mixed-Use Facility” means a building designed, planned, approved, constructed and/or used partly for residential use and partly for commercial or other non-residential use. Mixed-use facilities include residences containing Home Occupations, as defined in Title 17. For purposes of tap fees and metering, mixed-use facilities shall be considered to be one user.

    17. “Multi-Unit Facility” means a structure, facility or complex that contains two (2) or more units, each capable of being separately owned and/or occupied, including, but not limited to, shopping centers, strip malls and other commercial centers, condominiums, townhouse complexes, duplexes, single-family residences with accessory dwelling units, mobile home parks, mixed-use facilities, motels, hotels, lodges, bed and breakfast operations, retirement homes, group homes, hospitals and similar operations.

    18. “Multi-Unit,” when used to describe a class of water rate, means the water rate chargeable with respect to a multi-unit facility that is served through a single water meter, subject to certain limited exceptions provided for in Sections 13.08.060 and 13.08.070 of Chapter 13.08.

    19. “Non-residential,” when used to describe a class of water rate, means the water rate chargeable with respect to water delivered by the Department to: any property, structure, building or facility that does not contain dwelling units and is not a multi-unit facility.

    20. “Open Space” or “Parks” mean areas or parcels that are designated and/or approved by the City as open natural areas, groomed park lands, golf courses, rest areas, outdoor recreational areas, drainage facilities or other similar facilities that may or may not contain accessory non-dwelling structures, such as restrooms, maintenance facilities, pavilions, and/or buildings of similar function.

    21. “Outside Water User” or “Outside User” means any person owning real property located outside the corporate limits of the City of Cañon City that is connected to the Department’s water system, including group users.

    22. “Person” means any individual, corporation, government or governmental subdivision or agency, municipality, quasi-municipal entity, business trust, estate, trust, limited liability company, partnership, association, or other legal entity capable of entering into binding contracts.

    23. “Property Owner” means the person holding record title to any real property who applies for or receives water service from the Department at such property. “Property Owner” and “Water User” will generally have the same meaning in this title, unless the context clearly indicates otherwise.

    24. “Residential Structure” means a structure or facility used solely for the inhabitance of human beings as a single dwelling unit.

    25. “Service Lines” means the two (2) sections of pipe used for conveying water from the water main to the premises of the water user, as follows:

    a.   That section of the line installed by the property owner and maintained by the Department between the main and the shutoff or water meter, whichever is closest to the property line or the property line, if there is no shutoff and the meter is contained within a structure on the property (sometimes called the “system-side” service line); and

    b.   That section of the service line installed and maintained by the property owner which is on the premises side of either the water meter or the curb box, whichever is closest to the property line or the property line (sometimes called the “customer-side” service line).

    26. “Shutoff” or “Curbstop/Meterstop” means a device that is approved by the Department and meets the City of Cañon City Standard Construction Specifications and is used for the purpose of shutting off and/or isolating the “customer-side” of the water service line from the “system-side” of the water service line.

    27. “Specific Standards” or “Department Standards” or “City Standards” mean the specifications regarding material, maintenance and/or installation of water system facilities prepared by the Water Superintendent or the City Engineer including, but not necessarily limited to, applicable provisions of the City of Cañon City Standard Construction Specifications.

    28. “Tap” or “Water Tap” means the physical connection to a Department water main of a service line leading to the property of a water user that is made for purposes of providing water service to such property.

    29. “Tap Fee” means the raw water and plant investment charge made by the Department for the initial privilege of connecting to the Department system to receive water service, a portion of which must be deposited into the City’s Raw Water Acquisition and Preservation Fund, and the balance of which must be deposited into the City’s Water Fund. Tap fee also means the raw water and plant investment charges associated with increasing the size of any existing water tap.

    30. “Townhouse” means a one-family dwelling unit, with a private entrance, which is part of a structure whose dwelling units are attached horizontally in a linear arrangement, divided by a lot and/or parcel line, that is or is capable of being separately owned or occupied, and has a totally exposed front and rear wall to be used for access, light, and ventilation. For purposes of tap fees and water metering, each individual townhouse owner shall be considered one water user.

    31. “Transmission Main” means a water pipe that is intended by the Department to be used exclusively for the transmission of water and not for distribution of water to individual customers. Except in rare instances, transmission mains will not be tapped for water service to individual water users.

    32. “Undersized Water Main” shall include any water main that is less than four (4) inches in diameter and such other water mains as are designated as undersized on the Department’s water main master plan.

    33. “Unit,” as used in this chapter and in Chapter 13.08, means an enclosed area consisting of a free-standing, detached building or structure, or a portion thereof, having vertical and horizontal boundaries and characterized by at least one private entrance, that is or is capable of being separately owned and/or occupied.

    34. “Water Department” has the same meaning as “Department.”

    35. “Water Mains” or “Mains” mean water pipes in streets, easements or other rights-of-way, used for the conveyance of potable water, to which individual service lines are or may be connected. Individual water users may be served directly from water mains by means of service lines connected thereto.

    36. “Water Superintendent” means the City Administrator or the City employee assigned by the City Administrator to perform the functions of the Water Superintendent under this title, or the designee of the Water Superintendent when duties under this title have been delegated by the Water Superintendent.

    37. “Water User” or “User” means a person that owns property to which water service is made available by the Department. After a water service connection has been made and water service has been established, water user and property owner shall generally have the same meaning.

    B.   If a term used in this chapter or in Chapter 13.08 is not defined in this section, but is defined in Title 17 or in the City’s Subdivision and Development Regulations or in the City of Cañon City Standard Construction Specifications, the definition used in Title 17 or in such regulations or standards shall apply, unless the context clearly indicates otherwise. (Ord. 13-2011 §§ 1, 2; Ord. 10-2010 § 1; Ord. 8-2008 § 1)

 

13.04.030 Water records.
    Under the direction of the Engineer, there shall be prepared and maintained records of this City that show, as nearly as practicable from available information, records and notes, an accurate description of the entire waterworks of the City and its Water Department, including all grounds belonging to the City and/or Department for the purpose of the waterworks, as the same are at present completed, in sections most convenient for the proper keeping of such records. Under the direction of the Water Superintendent, there shall be prepared and maintained additional records that indicate, as nearly as practicable from the information in such records and notes, the locations of all active water mains and all points where such mains are believed to have been tapped. (Ord. 8-2008 § 1)

 

13.04.040 Permit authority.
    A.  Possession of permits required by Subsections B or C, or both B and C, of this section shall be the authority for a contractor to perform work specified in this chapter within the city’s rights-of-way. All work undertaken pursuant to either such permit shall be done with reasonable dispatch and in accordance with applicable City standards. All contractors applying for either such required permit must be licensed with the City and bonded to perform work within the city’s rights-of-way.

    B.   No person, other than employees of the Department, shall perform any excavation work required or authorized in this chapter within the city’s rights-of-way without first having obtained a valid excavation permit pursuant to Chapter 12.20 of this Code.

    C.   No person shall connect any service line to a water main without first having obtained a valid permit provided for in Section 13.04.050. Such permit shall be in addition to an excavation permit if the person making the connection also performs associated excavation work within a city right-of-way. (Ord. 8-2008 § 1)

 

13.04.050 Connecting to mains—Permit and procedures.
    A.  An application shall be made to the Engineer’s office for a permit to tap the mains of the Department. If granted, such permit shall be signed by the Engineer or designee and shall contain the following information:

    1.   The name of the person for whose benefit such permit is granted;

    2.   The size of the tap/stop for discharging the water from the main to the service line and the point (as nearly as possible) at which the tap is to be made;

    3.   The address and legal description of the property to be served;

    4.   The contemplated use of the water to be delivered through the connection authorized in the permit; and

    5.   Any other information reasonably requested by the Water Superintendent or Engineer on a written application form or in written instructions to applicants.

    B.   A record of all such permits shall be kept in a book maintained for that purpose at City Hall, which record shall set forth the substance of every such permit. No water user served by the Department shall be entitled to more water than is necessary for the use stated on the permit. No water user shall use water for a purpose that is different than that stated on the permit. When no use is specified on the permit, domestic household uses shall be the presumed use unless and until the Water Superintendent and the water user agree otherwise in writing.

    C.   The burden of proving the issuance of a permit with respect to any property shall be on the owner of such property. Such proof must be made prior to the Department’s authorizing any service connection. No person shall be entitled to a water service connection unless proof of such permit is presented to the Department and/or is clearly evidenced in the Department’s permanent records.

    D.  All service connections or taps on all mains served by the Department shall be made by Department personnel or by persons specifically engaged by the Department to perform such work. Connections will be made only after the mains have been inspected, tested, approved and accepted by the Department. Any excavation necessary for tapping shall be completed prior to the arrival of Department personnel. The property owner or other applicant shall provide, at no cost to the Department, the tapping saddle or tapping sleeve and corporation stop necessary to make the service connection.

    E.   Each service connection may be used to serve only the property identified in the water tap application and permit. Permitted taps may not be moved from one property to another; provided however that the subdivision of a lot or parcel shall not result in the loss of water service to one of the resulting lots created through the subdivision of a lot or parcel, if such subdivided lot or parcel had been receiving or was entitled to receive water service pursuant to valid permit and/or water service connection prior to the subdivision of such lot or parcel. (Ord. 8-2008 § 1)

 

13.04.060 Connecting to mains—Supervision and enforcement.
    Following the issuance of any permit required by Section 13.04.040 to any person to lay service lines in place in the City, it shall be the duty of the Water Superintendent to see that all connections are made and that all other work is performed in accordance with the ordinances, regulations, requirements, standards, policies and administrative directives of the City. No developer, property owner or contractor acting on behalf of any property owner shall deny Department personnel access to places were water service connections are to be made or have been made. The denial of such access shall be grounds for the denial of new water service by the Department or termination of existing water service, as the case may be. (Ord. 8-2008 § 1)

 

13.04.070 Mains, lines and meters—Ownership and maintenance.
    A.  The following shall be and remain City property and shall be maintained by the Department:

    1.   All water mains and transmission mains, including their fittings and appurtenances, which are located under public streets and rights-of-way or within any private right-of-way or easement dedicated, granted or conveyed to the City or otherwise owned or held by the City for the installation and maintenance of water mains and/or transmission mains;

    2.   All service lines extending from the water main to the meter or shutoff, whichever is closest to the property line;

    3.   All service lines extending from the water main to the property line if the meter of a water user is installed within an improvement on the property of the water user and there is no outside shutoff;

    4.   Any meter pit containing a meter that is one inch or less in diameter;

    5.   The meters, shutoffs, remote readout devices, fittings and installation appurtenances of each water user; provided that the Department’s cost of repairing or replacing any item listed in this paragraph may be billed to and payable by the water user.

    B.   Private water mains, backflow prevention devices and other facilities owned and/or controlled by a group user or an association are not Department property and will not be maintained or replaced by the Department.

    C.   The following shall be the property of the property owner and shall be maintained by or at the expense of the property owner:

    1.   All water pipelines and customer-side service lines and all appurtenances thereto, including private meters, service lines and fittings which are on the customer side of the curb stop, meter or shutoff.

    2.   All backflow prevention devices, assemblies and systems required by the Department.

    3.   Any meter pit containing a water meter that is larger than one inch in diameter.

 

    D.  All privately-owned items described or referred to in Subsections B and C of this section shall conform to the specific standards of the Department and shall be installed, maintained, tested, repaired and replaced as provided by applicable Federal, State and local laws, rules, regulations, standards and policies. The Department shall have the right to discontinue and/or withhold water service to any water user that fails to properly maintain any customer-side service line, including appurtenances thereto, or any backflow prevention device or assembly described or referred to in Subsection B or C. (Ord. 8-2008 § 1)

 

13.04.080 Service lines—Installation.
    A.  All water services shall be extended from water mains of the Department to specific properties, as described in the permits issued and/or records kept by the Department. Connections to service lines feeding adjacent or neighboring properties and/or dwelling units are prohibited, except when expressly permitted by specific provisions of this chapter or by a written contract permitted under this chapter and approved by City Council.

    B.   No water service line that is less than three-fourths of one inch in diameter shall be installed or used to transport potable water from a water main to the shutoff or meter of any water user. Larger service lines shall be installed and used when necessary to adequately serve the supply requirements of the water user.

    C.   Service lines shall be sized by the water user to adequately supply the requirements of the property and use or uses being or to be served. The Water Department will not be responsible for deficiencies in water service caused by a property owner’s installation of inappropriately sized taps, service lines and/or meters. The Water Department may refuse to provide water service through a proposed tap, service line or meter that, in the opinion of the Engineer or Water Superintendent, is too small to adequately serve the property and facilities proposed for water service.

    D.  Unless otherwise provided in the City of Cañon City Standard Construction Specifications, seamless copper tubing designated as Type K soft copper shall be used for service lines sized three-fourths inch through one inch. Materials meeting the specification of the Water Superintendent, such as ductile iron pipe or plastic pipe, may be used for service lines larger than one inch, unless otherwise provided in the City of Cañon City Standard Construction Specifications.

    E.   Service lines may not be installed in trenches containing pipes which carry any substance other than potable water. Such service lines shall be separated laterally from wastewater pipes by a minimum of ten (10) feet. (See the City of Cañon City Standard Construction Specifications.)

    F.   Service lines shall be the same size as the tap installed on the water main between the main and the meter. Additionally, the meter shall be the same size as the tap. (Ord. 8-2008 § 1)

 

13.04.090 Service lines—Shutoff requirements.
    A.  A shutoff of the same size as the service line shall be installed at the property line unless a pit meter with stop has been installed at the property line. The shutoff shall be equipped with a curb box and lid in accordance with City of Cañon City Standard Construction Specifications.

    B.   Any vault, meter pit or area containing a meter greater than one inch in diameter shall be kept accessible and in good working condition by the property owner. Any such box or meter pit that is not properly taken care of by the property owner shall be cleaned, repaired or relocated by the Water Department, if not promptly cleaned, repaired or relocated by the property owner’s qualified contractor following notice from the Department. Such costs shall be added to the water user’s utility billing statement and shall be payable in full on or before the due date for the payment of water service charges appearing on such billing statement, unless other payment arrangements are approved in writing by the Director of Finance.

    C.   The Department shall not be liable to any property owner, tenant, or other party in possession of any property to which water is conducted for the failure on the part of the Department and its personnel to readily find a shutoff, box or lid in order to shut off the water to any property. (Ord. 8-2008 § 1)

 

13.04.100 Service lines—Maintenance duties.
    A.  The owner or occupant of any property to which water is conducted shall keep all customer-side service lines and related fixtures tight and in good repair so as to prevent the waste of water. When aware of any leak, the water user shall forthwith eliminate the waste of water by repairing or replacing all defective water lines and/or fixtures that are causing or contributing to the cause of the leak.

    B.   The water user shall request the Department to turn off water service when repairs to the water service lines or any other component are necessary on the customer side of the meter and defer any work thereon until the water service has been turned off by Department personnel, who shall respond to such requests with reasonable dispatch.

    C.   Each water user shall be responsible for the repair of all leaks emanating from any segment of the customer-side service line through which water service is received. If any leak is of a serious nature and/or has not been repaired within a reasonable period of time, as determined by the Water Superintendent, the customer-side service line may be disconnected by the Department at either the shutoff, meter or main, and such user’s water service shall be discontinued until the customer-side service line has been repaired by the water user to the reasonable satisfaction of the Water Superintendent. (Ord. 8-2008 § 1)

 

13.04.110 Location of water facilities.
    A.  Department water mains, pumps, pump houses and storage tanks may be extended, enlarged or constructed within the service area of the Department, as defined from time to time by the Water Superintendent; provided that all such improvements are accomplished in conformance with the City of Cañon City Standard Construction Specifications and authorized by the Water Superintendent or Engineer. All such facilities may be located anywhere within the Department’s service area at sites designated or approved by the Water Superintendent or Engineer.

    B.   No transmission main, water main, or other water service facility shall be extended, enlarged, installed or constructed at any location other than upon real property owned or controlled by the City or the Department or within the right-of-way of a public street or other public way, a perpetual dedicated utility easement, or a perpetual easement otherwise created or existing for the benefit of the Department. The preferred location of all water mains shall be within public streets or within platted private streets open to public use.

    C.   Except as otherwise might be provided in this chapter or in a separate agreement authorized or approved by formal action of City Council, the costs of all water system improvements requested by any water user, applicant for water service, developer or property owner shall be borne by the person requesting the water service making such improvements necessary. (Ord. 8-2008 § 1)

 

13.04.115 Sizing of water mains.
    A.  Sizing of water mains shall be determined by the Engineer or Water Superintendent, subject to the following requirements:

    1.   Except for permanent cul-de-sacs of less than five hundred (500) feet in length, the minimum size of any new water main within the service area of the Water Department shall be eight (8) inches in diameter.

    2.   In streets that have a permanent cul-de-sac less than five hundred (500) feet in length, the Engineer or Water Superintendent may authorize a water main that is six (6) inches in diameter.

    3.   In locations where it is determined by the Engineer or the Water Superintendent that a water main must be larger than eight (8) inches in diameter, the water main shall be of such size as the Engineer or Water Superintendent shall specify.

    4.   All determinations made pursuant to Subsections 2 and 3 of this subsection shall take into account, among other relevant factors, the Water Department’s most recent water main master plan, copies of which shall be kept in the Engineer’s office and in the offices of the Department of Public Works. Such water main master plan, by necessity, is and will remain a fluid and flexible plan, the requirements of which may change from time to time, and at any time, depending upon existing and anticipated demands upon the water service system and the location, condition, age, sizing and functionality of existing water system facilities and components.

    5.   All water main and appurtenance designs shall be approved by the Engineer or Water Superintendent prior to commencement of installation. Such design shall conform to the City of Cañon City Standard Construction Specifications, and all installations shall conform to the approved design.

    6.   The water main sizing requirements set forth in this subsection shall apply in all new subdivisions and/or developments within the Department’s service area unless the Engineer or Water Superintendent approves a Water Service Development Plan providing for different sizing of one or more water mains, in which case the approved plans will control.

    B.   If, pursuant to Subsections 3 and 4 of Subsection A, the Engineer or Water Superintendent requires a water main larger than eight (8) inches fronting or abutting any or all sides of the real property to be served, the applicant shall pay for and install such larger water main(s). Upon the satisfactory completion of the installation any water main larger than eight (8) inches in diameter, the Water Department will promptly reimburse to the person that installed such water main a sum which represents the excess in the cost of materials for such water main over what would have been the cost of materials had only an eight (8) inch water main been installed, if the greater size of the water main(s) is due to a water system need, rather than a project need of the person who installed such main(s), as determined by the Engineer or Water Superintendent. The applicant will not be entitled to and will not be reimbursed for any excess labor or other costs that were incurred in connection with the installation of the larger water main. (Ord. 8-2008 § 1)

 

13.04.116 Cash-in-lieu of installation payments.
    If the Department requires an undersized water main fronting or abutting an applicant’s property to be replaced at the applicant’s expense in accordance with the provisions of this chapter, the applicant may, in lieu of making the installation, and with the consent of the Water Superintendent and Engineer, pay to the Water Department an amount equal to the cost of the required water main installation. The amount of any such “cash-in-lieu-of-installation” payment shall be determined by the Engineer, who shall establish and periodically review and adjust, when changing costs indicate a need for adjustment, a cost-per-linear-foot standard to be applied uniformly for purposes of calculating cash-in-lieu of installation payment amounts. (Ord. 8-2008 § 1)

 

13.04.117 Water main upgrades and extensions—Single lots/single units.
    A.  An applicant for new water service to any single unit on a single residential lot or parcel that is abutted by an existing water main shall be subject to water main sizing requirements and installation costs as follows:

    1.   Inside City Limits. If the size of a water main fronting or abutting any property located within the City, whose owner has applied for new water service, is less than four (4) inches in diameter, the applicant shall install an eight (8) inch water main across the full frontage of such property. If the property is abutted on more than one side by water mains that are less than four (4) inches in diameter, the applicant shall install an eight (8) inch water main across the full frontage of the side of the property where the water service line will enter the property and also shall pay one-half of the cash-in-lieu of installation amount for all the other frontage(s) of such property that abut such undersized water main(s). Cash-in-lieu of installation amounts shall be determined as provided in Section 13.04.116.

    2.   Outside City Limits. If an applicant requests new water service to a property located outside the City and if the size of a water main abutting the property to be served is less than four (4) inches, the applicant shall pay for and install an eight (8) inch water main across the full frontage of such property. If a property is abutted on more than one side by water mains that are less than four (4) inches in diameter, the applicant shall pay for and install an eight (8) inch water main across the full frontage of the side where the water service line will enter the property and also shall pay the full cash-in-lieu of installation amount for all other frontage(s) of such property that abut such undersized water main(s).

    3.   The Water Superintendent or Engineer may waive the water main upgrade requirement applicable to frontages not crossed by a water service line when doing so would not be inconsistent with the Department’s water main master plan or otherwise be detrimental to the water system.

    B.   In addition to the requirements set forth in Subsection A, an applicant for new water service to a single parcel may be required to install, at the applicant’s sole cost, a new water main, meeting the sizing requirements set forth in Section 13.04.115, connecting the water system to the property to be served. Such water main extension shall be necessary when there is no water main connecting the property to the water system or when a water main of inadequate size connects the property to the water system. A water main which fails to meet the minimum sizing requirements specified in Section 13.04.115 will be deemed to be of inadequate size for purposes of this subsection unless the Engineer determines in writing that the property may be adequately served using the existing undersized main to bring water to the property and that using the undersized main for such purpose will not be inconsistent with the Department’s water main master plan or otherwise detrimental to the water system.

    C.   No application for water service to any non-residential single lot or parcel that is abutted by an undersized water main shall be granted unless the water main(s) fronting such property are upgraded by replacing the existing water main(s) with new water main(s) sized in accordance with the applicable provisions of Section 13.04.115 on all sides of the lot or parcel that are abutted by undersized water mains.

    D.  Upgrades to existing water mains abutting lots or parcels that are proposed for subdivision or other development requiring a site plan review shall be addressed in Water Service Development Plans required pursuant to Section 13.04.125. (Ord. 8-2008 § 1)

 

13.04.118 Installation of meters—Components.
    A.  All water service to any water user, regardless of location, shall be metered. All meters, up to one inch, shall be furnished by the Department and paid for by the applicant according to a fee schedule established by the Water Superintendent. Meters larger than one inch shall be supplied by the applicant and shall meet or exceed Department specifications. Such meters, once installed, shall be owned by the Department and may be replaced or repaired at any time by the Department.

    B.   Applicants for water service shall be required to pay a meter fee in an amount set by the Water Superintendent to cover the actual cost of any meter furnished by the Department and the actual cost of purchasing and installing the components listed at paragraphs 1 and 2 of this subsection, when applicable:

    1.   When the meter is installed at the curb or property line, and without regard to whether the meter is located in the public right-of-way, the meter fee will cover the water meter with Automatic Meter Read (AMR) register, angle meter stop, approved backflow prevention device, meter pit, and meter pit top.

    2.   When the water meter is installed in the building to be served, and without regard to whether the shutoff is located in the public right-of-way, the meter fee will cover the water meter, shutoff and box, required approved backflow prevention device, and remote readout register.

 

    C.   The applicant must also provide and install at the applicant’s sole cost all system-side and customer-side service lines and all fittings and installation appurtenances not covered by the meter fee. (Ord. 8-2008 § 1)

 

13.04.119 Multi-unit facilities—Metering requirements.
    A.  Condominiums and Cooperatives—Single Building or Structure.

    1.   Condominiums and cooperatives contained in a single building or structure shall receive water service through a master meter and shall be treated as one multi-unit water user for the purposes of Title 13. In the event the owner, developer or association of such a condominium or cooperative desires to have the individual units within a condominium or cooperative treated by the Department as separate individual water users, application for such treatment shall be made to the Engineer.

    2.   If the Engineer approves any such application, each unit in such condominium or cooperative and the common elements of the condominium or cooperative shall be separately metered through outside pit meters. A water tap permit will be required for each such unit and/or common element that will be eligible to receive water service from the Department.

    3.   For new construction, all tap fees for all separately-metered units and all separately-metered common elements within a condominium or cooperative shall be paid prior to the connection of any unit or common element to the water system.

    4.   Each unit owner, once such owner’s unit has been connected to the water system, shall be billed for water consumed according to the applicable rate schedule for single unit inside or outside residential or non-residential water users, depending upon the location and use of the unit.

    5.   After a common element of a condominium or cooperative has been connected to the water system, charges for water service to such common element shall be paid for by the owner, developer or association, as arranged with the Department, according to the applicable rate schedule for single unit inside or outside residential or non-residential water users, depending upon the location and use of the element being served.

    B.   Detached Condominiums. Each unit, and the common areas of a common interest community consisting of detached condominium units, shall be separately metered and shall be treated by the Department as an individual water user for the purposes of Title 13.

    C.   Townhouses. Each dwelling unit, and the common areas of a common interest community consisting of townhouses (or of any other townhouse complex), shall be separately metered and each shall be treated by the Department as an individual residential water user for the purposes of Title 13.

    D.  Duplex Units. Each duplex shall receive water service through a master meter and shall be treated by the Department as a multi-unit water user for the purposes of Title 13.

    E.   Motels, Hotels, Lodges and Bed and Breakfast Facilities. Motels, hotels, lodges, bed and breakfast facilities and similar operations shall receive water service through a single meter and shall be treated by the Department as one multi-unit water user for the purposes of Title 13, except that tap fees for motels, hotels, lodges and bed and breakfast facilities, depending upon their location inside or outside of the city, shall be determined with respect to Schedule A-1 or B-1 of Appendix 13.08, whichever is applicable (and not with respect to Schedule A-2 or B-2).

    F.   Manufactured Home Parks. Manufactured home parks where spaces and/or units shall receive water service through a master meter and shall be treated by the Department as a multi-unit water user for the purposes of Title 13. If the owner of a manufactured home park elects to separately meter individual spaces within the manufactured home park—on the customer side of the master meter connecting the manufactured home park to the Department’s system—such separate metering of spaces shall not relieve the owner of the manufactured home park from the obligation to pay for all water sold and delivered to such owner at the master meter. Instead, such individual metering shall be a means by which the owner of the manufactured home park may determine the actual consumption by each space and common area within the manufactured home park. No occupant of a space within a manufactured home park shall be charged by the owner of the manufactured home park for water service at a rate that is in excess of the rate charged by the Department to such owner.

    G.  Mixed-Use Structures. Mixed-use structures and operations shall receive water service through a single meter and shall be treated by the Department as one multi-unit water user for the purposes of Title 13.

    H.  Multiple-Bed Facilities. Group homes, retirement homes, hospitals and similar multiple-bed facilities and operations shall receive water service through a single meter and shall be treated by the Department as one multi-unit water user for the purposes of Title 13, except that tap fees for such group homes, retirement homes, hospitals and similar multiple-bed facilities, depending upon their location inside or outside the city, shall be determined with respect to Schedule A-1 or B-1 of Appendix 13.08, whichever is applicable (and not with respect to Schedule A-2 or B-2). When any such facility is served by or through more than one master meter, the water service customer receiving water through each such master meter shall be treated as one multi-unit water user for purposes of Title 13.

    I.    Correctional Facilities. Meter locations relative to water service provided by the Department to correctional facilities shall be as provided by contract between the City/Water Department and the entity operating such correctional facilities.

    J.    Commercial Centers. Any commercial center or complex consisting of one or more buildings constructed on a single parcel by a common owner for lease to two (2) or more tenants for commercial or other non-residential uses or purposes, or for mixed-use, shall receive water service through a master meter and shall be treated as one multi-use water user for purposes of Title 13. The Engineer may authorize the owner of a commercial center to establish separate metering to spaces occupied by tenants; provided that such separate metering is on the customer-side of the master meter and is used for internal accounting and billing purposes only.

    K.  Accessory Dwelling Units. Each accessory dwelling unit shall receive water service through a master meter that serves the principal structure and shall be treated by the Department as a multi-unit water user for the purposes of Title 13, except that no second tap fee shall be charged or chargeable by the Department with respect to a property containing a principal single-family residential structure and an ADU.

    L.   For purposes of Title 13, the treatment of any project or facility that is not addressed in Subsections 13.04.119(A) through (K) shall be as determined by the Engineer, or by City Council in connection with its approval of any land use application requiring the approval of City Council. The Engineer and City Council shall be guided by the other provisions of this chapter, water system needs and capabilities, and sound engineering practices when making such determinations.

    M.  Additional Conditions Applicable to All Multi-Unit Facilities. Additional conditions, consistent with the water system master plan and the rules, regulations and policies of the Department, may be required or imposed by the Engineer, and/or by City Council, in connection with the approval of any land use application requiring the approval by the Engineer and/or City Council.

    N.  Nothing in this Section 13.04.119 shall be interpreted or construed to authorize any land use that is contrary to the provisions of the City’s Zoning Ordinance, Subdivision and Development Regulations and/or other land use laws and regulations. (Ord. 23-2011 § 2; Ord. 13-2011 §§ 3—5; Ord. 8-2008 § 1)

 

13.04.120 Special provisions with respect to water service to properties outside of city boundaries.
    A.  Water service to properties within the Department’s service area, but outside of the corporate limits of the city, will be authorized, if at all, only after the following requirements have been met:

    1.   All new water service to be provided to properties located outside of the corporate limits of the city shall be provided pursuant to the terms, provisions, conditions and limitations of a written water service contract, signed by the property owner and approved by formal action of City Council. Water service contracts must provide for the possible annexation of all properties to which such water service will be provided under such contract. In consideration of the Department’s agreement to provide water service, all such water service contracts also may require: (a) the delivery of water shares, as provided in Subsection 2 of this subsection; (b) the installation of certain infrastructure improvements, except those improvements related to the water system, and right-of-way dedication (to assure that development will be in accordance with standards applicable in the city) if property is located within the City Annexation Priority Areas identified in the City’s Comprehensive Plan, as amended; and (c) the payment of applicable impact fees and/or surcharges, if any.

    2.   Requests for residential water service for three (3) or more single-family residential dwelling units (or the equivalent thereof) involved in a subdivision (or other development) application to the Fremont County Board of Commissioners will require the delivery of water rights to the Department as a prerequisite to the Department’s agreement to provide water service. The Department will accept shares of the Cañon City Hydraulic and Irrigating Ditch Company (“Hydraulic Ditch shares”) in satisfaction of this requirement. For purposes of this subsection, each such share shall be considered to represent 0.02743 cubic feet per second of time (“cfs”) of water that may be diverted and used by the Department.

    a.   One Hydraulic Ditch share will allow water service for three (3) to twenty (20) single-family residential units. Any request for water service for more than twenty (20) residential units will require delivery of one additional Hydraulic Ditch share for each additional twenty (20) residential units or portion thereof. The Department will not accept any apportioned share providing for less raw water than is required in this Subsection (A)(2)(a), nor will it grant any credit or allowance for any unused portion of a previously surrendered water share.

    b.   Requests for a use other than water service to single-family residences will require the applicant to provide water demand data to the Department to enable it to determine equivalent dwelling units (EDU). For the purposes of conversion to EDUs, one EDU will be equal to a maximum daily usage of eight hundred seventy-five (875) gallons. The Engineer will have the final authority in determining the acceptability and accuracy of the data submitted.

    i.    For demand equal to three (3) to twenty (20) EDUs, one Hydraulic Ditch share will be required. All demands for greater than twenty (20) EDUs will require one additional Hydraulic Ditch share for each additional twenty (20) EDUs or portion thereof. Also, as with residential requests, the Department will not accept any apportioned Hydraulic Ditch share, nor will it grant any credit or allowance for any unused portion of a previously surrendered water share.

    ii    If the water demand of a business or industrial use entering into a water service contract with the Department increases, for any reason, to a level above what was approved at the time the water service contract was executed, then one or more Hydraulic Ditch shares or additional Hydraulic Ditch shares, as the case may be, will be required by and shall be due to the Department at or before a time specified in the water service contract or, if no delivery date for such water rights was specified in the water service contract, within sixty (60) days following the Department’s written notice to the water user. The benchmark for any such requirement shall be the same as applies in Subsection (A)(2)(b).

    3.   For purposes of Subsection 2, water rights acceptable to the Department and representing an equivalent volume of raw water may be substituted for Hydraulic Ditch shares, if such substitution is approved by the Water Superintendent. Water represented by such substituted water rights: must be capable of being diverted at one of the City’s approved points of diversion; must be decreed for use in a municipal water system; and must have an adjudication date acceptable to the Department.

    B.   The requirements set forth in this subsection shall apply with respect to all land proposed for annexation into the City. (Ord. 22-2017 § 1; Ord. 8-2008 § 1)

 

13.04.125 Water service to subdivisions and other developments.
    A.  Any person who develops land within the service area of the Department under circumstances that require a site plan and site plan review, a lot line adjustment, a minor subdivision plat or a major subdivision plat, shall be obligated to submit to the Engineer for review and approval a Water Service Development Plan prepared in accordance with: (1) the provisions and requirements of this section; (2) any applicable provisions of the City’s Subdivision and Development Regulations; and (3) the City’s Standard Construction Specifications.

    B.   Such Water Service Development Plan shall address both on-site and off-site water facilities necessary for the Department to provide adequate water service to the proposed subdivision or other development at full build out. Such plan also shall take into account the Department’s water main master plan regarding the sizing, routing, looping and/or other configuration of transmission and distribution lines, both within and outside of the site of the proposed subdivision or other development. Such plan also shall address water storage, water pumping and fire protection needs of the subdivision or other development and all water main extensions and/or enlargements that are or may be needed for the Department to provide adequate water service to the subdivision or other development in a manner that is not detrimental to the water system as a whole.

    C.   All owners, subdividers, developers, contractors and builders shall include in their Water Service Development Plan written details and specifications for the proposed water mains, fire hydrants, pumps and tanks in and around their subdivision or other development, which shall include demand, fire flows, capacity, size, type of material or manufacturer, and location of mains, fittings, fire hydrants, tanks, pumps and pump houses, and the location of loops and grids to existing Department mains.

    D.  The Water Development Plan for a multi-unit facility project shall include details of the proposed water metering system for the project, and such other items and information as the Engineer shall deem necessary to evaluate the water distribution and metering system for the project.

    E.   Unless otherwise provided in this chapter or in a written agreement between such party and the Department, the installation of all required items included in an approved Water Service Development Plan shall be at the sole expense of the owner, developer, subdivider, contractor or builder.

    F.   Any material, item or method not covered by the specific standards shall be determined by agreement of the Engineer and the engineer representing the project. If the two (2) engineers fail to agree on any issue addressed in a Water Service Development Plan, a final determination with respect to such issue will be made by the Engineer.

    G.  Department water mains, pipelines and service lines may be extended within the service area of the Water Department to make potable water available to areas that have been or are being annexed. All such extensions shall be in accordance with the provisions of any annexation agreement to which the City is a party and other applicable law, including the provisions of this chapter. (Ord. 8-2008 § 1)

 

13.04.127 Water line rebates and agreements.
    A.  The Water Superintendent may enter into contracts on behalf of the Department whereby a portion of the cost of the installation of a water main extension or enlargement required by the Department and paid for by the other party to the contract may be recovered, on an equitable pro-rata basis, from water users who subsequently tap such water main, as extended or enlarged. Such contracts shall be known as “water main rebate agreements.”

    B.   No water main rebate agreement shall be prepared or executed by the Water Superintendent unless such agreement is requested in a written application, the form of which shall be provided by the Water Superintendent, filed by the person or persons entitled to request such agreement. Such application must be filed no later than six (6) months from the date the subject water main extension or enlargement was accepted by the City, as determined by the records of the Engineer. Such date shall be the “acceptance date.”

    C.   No water main rebate agreement shall be executed by the Water Superintendent until the Engineer has received “as built”

documents and has received and reviewed complete and accurate records and supporting documentation showing the actual cost of the water main extension or enlargement that will be the subject matter of the agreement. Such records and documentation must be received within six (6) months of the acceptance date. Any application for a water main rebate agreement which is not supported by such as built drawings, records and other supporting documentation shall be an incomplete application. An incomplete application shall be void and of no force and effect.

    D.  No water main rebate agreement shall have a term which ends later than on the tenth (10th) anniversary date of the acceptance date provided for in Subsection B of this section unless a longer term is approved by Council. Following the end of such term, neither party to the rebate agreement shall have further rights or obligations under such agreement.

    E.   Every water main rebate agreement executed by the Water Superintendent shall be recorded at the expense of the other party to such agreement. Such party shall pay all recording costs prior to the recording of the agreement with the Fremont County Clerk and Recorder. Unless recorded, no such agreement shall be binding upon the Department.

    F.   No water main rebate agreement shall impose upon the Department a duty to collect refund amounts with respect to any new connection to the enlarged or extended water main from the person making such new connection unless the application for the agreement was received by the Department prior to the time such new connection was authorized by the Department.

    G.  Every water main rebate agreement shall provide that the Department’s obligations under such agreement shall be limited to the Department’s using its best efforts to collect prorated refund amounts from those who connect to the extended or enlarged water main after the written application for the agreement has been received by the Department and prior to the termination date provided for in the agreement.

    H.  Every water main rebate agreement also shall provide that the Department shall not be liable to any other party to the agreement for any failure by the Department to have collected the appropriate refund amount from a person connecting to the extended or enlarged water main, except that the Department may be liable with respect to such refund amount if it is proven by clear and convincing evidence in a legal proceeding that such refund was not collected or was not distributed after collection as a result of gross negligence or fraud.

    I.    Each other party to any such agreement must provide to the Department, prior to preparation and execution of the water main rebate agreement, their current address and give the Department written notice of any change of address occurring during the term of the rebate agreement. Funds collected by the Department pursuant to a water main rebate agreement that are not claimed by the party entitled to receive such funds within one year of the Department’s sending notice of the receipt of such funds to such party at the last known address of such party shall be forfeited to and become the exclusive property of the Department. The last known address of any such party shall be the address stated in the rebate agreement or the last address provided to the Department by the written notice of change of address required under this subsection.

    J.    All calculations of refunds to be collected by the Department and distributed to the other party to a water main rebate agreement shall be made by the Engineer under a formula approved by the Water Superintendent. Such formula shall take into account the actual cost of extending or enlarging the water main, as determined by the Engineer. Calculations of refund amounts shall be based upon the relationship between the frontage of the property receiving new water service and the total frontage of all properties abutting the extended or enlarged water main on both sides thereof.

    K.  Whenever the Department extends or enlarges a water main, or participates financially in a water main extension or enlargement (by paying a portion of the cost of materials, or otherwise) the Department shall be entitled to recover its actual costs of such extension or enlargement through rebates from the owners of adjacent property that is connected to such enlarged or extended main within ten (10) years following the completion of the extension or enlargement of such water main. The Department shall maintain for public reference a complete list of all water main improvements with respect to which rebates to the Department will be required pursuant to the provisions of this subsection, including the applicable cost per linear foot incurred by the Department to pay for each such improvement. The amount of any rebate that becomes payable pursuant to this subsection will be calculated in the same manner as rebates under water main rebate agreements are calculated.

    L.   Rebate amounts collectible by or otherwise owing to the Department pursuant to any of the provisions of this section must be paid in full prior to the making of any new water service connection(s) for the benefit of any person connecting to an extended or enlarged water main with respect to which such provisions apply. (Ord. 8-2008 § 1)

 

13.04.130 Fire hydrant use restrictions and exceptions.
    A.  Except as provided in Subsection B of this section, no water shall be drawn or used from any fire hydrant connected to the water system of the Department, whether such fire hydrant is located inside or outside of the corporate limits of the city.

    B.   Exceptions to General Prohibition. Water may be drawn from fire hydrants:

    1.   By employees and agents of the Cañon City Area Fire Protection District (or any other fire protection district or department responsible for extinguishing fires in the vicinity of the fire hydrant) only for purposes of extinguishing fires or for other purposes permitted by contract between the City and the District or Department.

    2.   By employees and authorized agents of the City, when used for any municipal purpose.

    3.   By persons under contract with the City for the performance of public improvement contracts let by the City, provided that such water so drawn is used exclusively for purposes authorized or otherwise contemplated in the contract with the City and further provided that all such water so used is measured by a meter issued by the Department. It shall be unlawful for any person under contract with the City for the performance of a public improvements contract to use water drawn from a fire hydrant for any project or other purpose that is not provided for or otherwise contemplated in the contract.

    4.   By other governmental or quasi-governmental entities, such as Fremont County or the Fremont County Sanitation District, pursuant to the terms of any agreement between the City and such other entity.

    5.   By licensed contractors, to whom the Department has issued a meter to measure such contractor’s water usage, for use in connection with any private project or projects.

    C.   Licensed contractors who are authorized to draw water from fire hydrants pursuant to Subsection (B)(5), shall be subject to the following conditions and requirements:

    1.   Unless otherwise authorized by the Water Superintendent, the meter issued by the Department shall be used at all times when water is drawn from a hydrant.

    2.   A deposit in an amount set by the Water Superintendent must be paid in advance.

    3.   No refund of such deposit shall be made until all sums associated with the use of the meter and the water drawn through the meter have been paid in full. No refund shall be due sooner than thirty (30) days following the contractor’s return of the meter.

    4.   A meter rental fee in an amount determined by the Water Superintendent may be charged.

    5.   The contractor shall pay or reimburse the Department for any and all costs incurred to repair any fire hydrant damaged by the contractor or its employees or agents and with respect to any damage to the meter itself, including replacement costs if the meter is returned in a damaged or broken condition.

    6.   The contractor shall pay at the applicable rate for all water from all hydrants that is drawn through such meter or otherwise used by the contractor.

    7.   No water drawn by any contractor pursuant to this subparagraph shall be resold or be used to supply drinking water to any person.

    8.   Any contractor drawing or attempting to draw water pursuant to this subsection shall immediately report to the Water Superintendent or designee any damage to or malfunction of any fire hydrant encountered by such contractor.

    9.   Each contractor entitled to draw water pursuant to this Subsection 9 shall keep an accurate written log with respect to such contractor’s use or attempts to use fire hydrants pursuant to this Subsection 9. Such log shall identify each such fire hydrant used by location, date and time of usage, and approximate water usage. Copies of such logs shall be delivered to the Department no less often than monthly, and in any event at any time the meter issued by the Department is returned to the Department.

    10. The Water Superintendent may require the contractor to sign a written agreement making reference to the contractor’s obligations under this subsection prior to authorizing such contactor to draw water from any fire hydrant.

    D.  The Water Superintendent may implement and enforce such rules, regulations and policies that are deemed by him or her to be necessary to regulate usage of water drawn by contractors and others pursuant to the provisions of this section. (Ord. 8-2008 § 1)

 

13.04.135 Temporary service.
    A.  Upon request, and at the discretion of the Engineer, temporary water service may be provided—through a temporary tap of a water main—by the Department for the benefit of users who are not otherwise connected to the water system, or for the benefit of existing users for temporary purposes not covered by their existing water tap permit. The duration of temporary water service shall be determined by the Engineer, and may be extended only with the written permission of the Engineer.

    B.   Charges for all water sold pursuant to this section shall be calculated according to the rate for temporary water service provided for in Schedule O to Appendix 13.08, and must be paid by the temporary water purchaser within ten (10) days following the date such charges are billed, unless a later due date is specified on the utility billing statement containing such charges.

    C.   Water purchased pursuant to this section shall be metered through a meter furnished and installed by the Department upon the user’s payment of a meter deposit in an amount which shall not be less than the full replacement value of the meter furnished.
