All deposits shall be in cash or certified funds delivered to the Department.

    D.  The refund of meter deposits respecting temporary water services shall be governed by the same rules that apply to the refund of meter deposits collected from contractors who temporarily draw water from fire hydrants. Nonrefundable turn on and turn off fee, at the rates stated in Schedule R to Appendix 13.08, also shall be charged to and paid by the user prior to delivery of the meter.

    E.   The recipient of temporary water service pursuant to this subsection shall bear all costs of connecting to, using and disconnecting from the water main from which temporary water service is provided.

    F.   The recipient of temporary water service also shall pay all applicable meter rental fees, in an amount determined by the Water Superintendent.

    G.  The receipt of temporary water service pursuant to this subsection will not create any vested rights to permanent water service for the recipient. If the recipient is receiving temporary water service in anticipation of receiving a water tap permit, there will be no vested or perfected right to permanent water service until such time as a water tap permit has been acquired pursuant to Section 13.04.050 and all applicable requirements of Chapter 13.08 have been fulfilled. (Ord. 8-2008 § 1)

 

13.04.140 Irrigation restrictions.
    The Council may, from time to time, by resolution, impose restrictions on the sprinkling or irrigation of lawns and shrubbery. Failure to comply with irrigation restrictions imposed by the City Council may result in the water service to the premises of the violator being turned off. Once water service has been turned off for reasons set forth in this section, it will not be restored until a fee in the amount set forth in Schedule R of Appendix 13.08 has been paid to the Water Department. (Ord. 8-2008 § 1)

 

13.04.150 Emergency use regulations.
    The City Administrator may make other rules and regulations governing the use of water in case of emergency, and when so made, such rules and regulations shall have the force and effect of an ordinance. Bulk water sales may be discontinued during an emergency. (Ord. 8-2008 § 1)

 

13.04.160 Unlawful acts designated.
    A.  No person shall:

    1.   Re-sell water purchased from the Department and received through a master meter to tenants of a mobile home park, apartment building, commercial building, or other similar facility for an amount greater than the amount charged by the Department for the same quantity of water;

    2.   Sell or re-sell water furnished by the Department to any person or group of persons, other than tenants, as identified in Subsection 1 of this subsection, without first having obtained written authorization to make such sales from City Council;

    3.   Remove any portion of any service line owned by the Department, or the meter, shutoffs and fittings used (or formerly used) in supplying water to any water user without first obtaining the written consent and approval of the Water Superintendent;

    4.   Open or close any valve, shutoff or fire hydrant without first obtaining the written consent and approval of the Water Superintendent or designee;

    5.   Make a connection to a water main without first having obtained a valid water tap permit or temporary water use permit authorizing such connection;

    6.   Receive water from a water main through a connection that was not authorized by a valid water tap permit or temporary water use permit;

    7.   Disconnect any active service line from a water main without first having obtained the permission of the Water Superintendent or designee;

    8.   Throw or cast any filth, trash or deleterious substance into any stream, reservoir, pipe, line, main or drain of the Department’s water system which may fill or obstruct any portion of the water treatment or distribution system or which may pollute the water therein;

    9.   Use water for any purpose other than for a beneficial purpose, or waste water by imprudent or excessive use for any purpose;

    10. Damage, destroy, impair or steal any portion of the Department’s water treatment, transmission, storage, pumping or distribution facilities; provided that any person who accidentally damages or destroys any portion of the Water Department’s water treatment or distribution facilities, when authorized by the Department to operate the facility prior to its being damaged or destroyed or, without such prior authorization, who damaged or destroyed the facility during an emergency which threatened to cause serious damage to a water user’s real or personal property shall not be guilty of an unlawful act under this subparagraph if the Water Department’s costs to repair or replace the damaged or destroyed facility are reimbursed not later than thirty (30) days following such repair or replacement;

 

    11. Draw or use water from a fire hydrant in violation of any of the provisions of Section 13.04.130;

    12. Use or permit the use of water provided by the Department for any purpose other than the purpose for which the water service was initially acquired, as evidenced by a valid water tap permit or other Department records;

    13. Use or permit the use of water provided by the Department at any location other than the location identified in a valid water tap permit;

    14. Use or permit the use of the water provided by the Department to serve more than one dwelling structure, including, but not limited to, mobile homes, garages, accessory dwelling units, and outbuildings used or usable as dwelling places (as determined by the Engineer), through a single service line or water meter without prior written approval from the Department;

    15. Tap or otherwise make any connection into a service line or main ahead of a water meter, by means of faucets, jumpers or other devices that allow for the usage of water that has not flowed through a meter;

    16. Modify in any manner a shutoff, box or lid connected to the City water system in a manner not specified by the rules and regulations of the City pertaining to facilities of the Department.

    B.   No plumber, contractor, water user or other person shall:

    1.   Use his or her key or any other tool or device capable of turning on or shutting off water to turn on or shut off water service from a water main unless such use is first authorized by the Water Superintendent or designee; or

    2.   Permit his or her key to be used by an unauthorized person for any reason. (Ord. 13-2011 § 6; Ord. 8-2008 § 1)

 

13.04.170 Shutoff rights reserved to City.
    The City reserves the right to cause the water to be shut off from the mains when deemed necessary for cleaning or repairing mains or waterworks, making connections or extensions to the same, or for any other similar purpose authorized by the Water Superintendent. (Ord. 8-2008 § 1)

 

13.04.180 Violation—Penalty—Additional remedies.
    A.  Any person, firm, association or corporation who violates any provision of this chapter shall, upon conviction thereof, be fined in accordance with the applicable provision of the following schedule:

    1.   For any violation of any provision of Section 13.04.130; or for any violation of any provision of this chapter that involves the receiving of Water Department water through a connection that allows such water to be used without first flowing through and being measured by a water meter issued or otherwise authorized by the Water Department; or for any violation of any provision of this chapter that involves usage of Water Department water received through a connection to a water service line on the customer side of the shutoff or meter by any person who occupies or otherwise uses a separate dwelling unit or structure which is required to be connected to the Water Department system by a separate service line connected to a Water Department water main after the payment of the tap fee provided for in Chapter 13.08 and the installation of a water meter issued by the Water Department as prerequisites to the user’s right to receive water service from the Water Department:

    a.   The fine for a first offense occurring within any seven (7) year period shall be not less than five hundred dollars ($500.00), nor more than one thousand dollars ($1,000.00);

    b.   The fine for a second offense occurring within any seven (7) year period shall be not less than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00), nor more than one thousand dollars ($1,000.00);

    c.   The fine for a third or subsequent offense occurring within any seven (7) year period shall be not less than one thousand dollars ($1,000.00), nor more than the maximum fine provided for in Section 1.28.010.

    2.   For any other violation of any other provisions of this chapter:

    a.   The fine for a first offense occurring within a seven (7) year period shall be not less than one hundred dollars ($100.00), nor more than one thousand dollars ($1,000.00);

    b.   The fine for a second offense occurring within a seven (7) year period shall be not less than three hundred dollars ($300.00), nor more than one thousand dollars ($1,000.00);

    c.   The fine for a third or subsequent offense occurring within a seven (7) year period shall be not less than five hundred dollars ($500.00), nor more than the maximum fine provided for in Section 1.28.010.

    B.   The seven (7) year period with respect to the foregoing fine schedule shall be determined with respect to the date of the occurrence of the violation or violations of which the convicted person was convicted, and not with respect to dates of conviction.

    C.   In no case shall the municipal court judge who imposes any fine provided for in Subsection A of this section waive or suspend any portion of the applicable minimum fine.

    D.  In addition to such fine provided for above, the Department may disconnect any water service of any water user who violates any of the provisions of this chapter.

    E.   As to every licensed plumber or contractor convicted of a violation of any provision of this chapter, the Water Department shall send to the licensing authority which issued such convicted plumber’s license a report notifying such authority of such conviction.

    F.   If any contractor licensed by the City shall be convicted of a violation of any provision of this chapter, proof of such conviction may be considered in proceedings concerning the revocation, suspension or denial of such contractor’s license. The license of any contractor issued a license by the City shall be immediately revoked upon the third conviction of such licensee, within any seven (7) year period, of any violation of this chapter and no new license shall be issued by the City to such licensee for a period of two (2) years from the date of such revocation; provided that such contractor shall be notified in writing of such revocation and shall be entitled to a hearing before the Council of Cañon City, if such hearing is requested in writing no later than thirty (30) days following the date of the notice of revocation. Should any such hearing be requested, the sole issue at such hearing will be whether such contractor was convicted in municipal court of violations of this chapter on three (3) or more occasions within a period of seven (7) years. (Ord. 17-2013 §§ 50, 51; Ord. 8-2008 § 1)

 

13.04.190 Process for voluntary administrative remedy.
    A.  Whenever it shall appear to the City Administrator that a violation of this chapter has occurred, the matter may be referred to the City Attorney’s office with instructions that a determination be made as to whether proceedings should be instigated against the apparent violator or violators in municipal court, and such proceedings may thereafter be instigated, or the City Administrator may attempt to resolve the issue administratively.

    B.   At his or her discretion, the City Administrator is hereby authorized, but not obligated, to cause the apparent violator or violators to be contacted and offered the opportunity to pay an administrative fee and, where applicable those charges referred to in Subsections G and H of this section, to resolve issues created by the apparent violation.

    C.   Any person to whom an offer authorized under Subsection B is made shall have not less than ten (10) or more than twenty (20) days within which to accept or reject the offer, unless this period is extended by the City Administrator. The offer shall be deemed accepted only if the violator signs a form prescribed by the City Administrator which shall contain the violator’s admission to the offense (which shall be described in the form by reference to municipal code section and approximate date of occurrence) and tenders payment of the appropriate administrative fee for the violation admitted and, if applicable, the charges under Subsection G and/or H of this section. At least two (2) counterpart originals of the form shall be executed by the violator and by the City Administrator, or designee, with one counterpart original to be furnished to the violator and a second counterpart original being held in the records of the City for a period of not less than seven (7) years from its execution. Any violator who wishes to attach to the City’s copy of the admission form his, her or its written explanation of the events giving rise to the violation admitted by such person may do so, and such explanation shall be attached to the counterpart original retained by the City.

    D.  No admission, once made, shall be withdrawn, and no administrative fee or other charge payable under this section, once paid, shall be refunded.

    E.   The administrative fee payable under such circumstances shall be an amount equal to the minimum fine that would be imposed by the municipal court upon a conviction of the violator of the offense admitted on the written form, after the City Administrator has determined whether the violation is a first, second, third or subsequent offense. Municipal court fines are as set forth in Section 13.04.180.

    F.   In cases where more than one person appears to have committed the same violation, such as when a plumber makes an illegal connection at the request of a water user, the admission of one such apparent violator shall not be grounds for excusing the apparent violation of the other. In such cases, the offer permitted under Subsection B may be communicated to the several apparent violators and may be accepted by some or all of them. An admission by one such violator shall not preclude the prosecution and possible conviction of the other in municipal court.

    G.  In cases where the property or facilities of the Water Department were damaged or destroyed during the commission, or as a direct result of the commission, of a violation of this chapter, the City Administrator may impose, as an additional condition of the offer, an additional charge in an amount equal to the Water Department’s cost of repairing or replacing the damaged or destroyed property or facilities, including the costs of labor and materials. When such a condition is contained in the offer, no admission will be accepted unless accompanied by the violator’s payment of the administrative fee and the charge imposed under this subsection.

    H.  In cases where Water Department water was received, but not paid for, by the violator or made available to and received by another through the efforts of or due to the acquiescence of the violator (such as when illegal or unauthorized connections are made in front of a violator’s water meter) either because its usage was not metered or because applicable minimum or other usage charges on metered water were not billed, the City Administrator may impose as an additional condition of the offer an additional charge in an amount equal to the City Administrator’s best reasonable estimate of the maximum revenues not paid to or received by the Water Department as a result of the alleged violation of this Chapter. Any alleged violator who wishes to make an admission pursuant to Subsection C, must, upon request by the City Administrator, provide reasonable cooperation by providing dates and other details important to the City Administrator’s estimate under this subparagraph. When such a condition is contained in the offer, no admission will be accepted unless accompanied by the violator’s payment of the administrative fee and the charges imposed under this subsection.

    I.    No alleged violator shall be obligated to accept any offer made pursuant to this section. No person who does make an admission pursuant to this section and pays the administrative fee and other applicable charges referred to in this section shall be prosecuted in municipal court with respect to the admitted violation. No refusal to accept any offer made by the City Administrator shall be offered as evidence in any municipal court proceeding that might be brought against any alleged violator.

    J.    No admission made pursuant to this section shall constitute a conviction for purposes of the penalties that must be imposed by the municipal court for second, third or subsequent convictions of violators under this chapter, but such prior admissions and prior municipal court convictions occurring within the seven (7) year period ending on the date of the violation admitted pursuant to this section shall be considered by the City Administrator in determining the amount of the administrative fee payable under this section.

    K.  The City Administrator, if such referral was not previously made, shall refer to the City Attorney’s office for possible prosecution a report with respect to all apparent violations of this chapter with respect to which the offer authorized under Subsection B was communicated and rejected.

    L.   The City Administrator is hereby authorized to adopt a schedule of administrative fees, rules, regulations and policies consistent with the provisions of this chapter for purposes of implementing this section. (Ord. 8-2008 § 1)

Chapter 13.06 BACKFLOW PREVENTION AND CROSS-CONNECTIONS
13.06.010 Definitions.
    Unless the context specifically indicates otherwise, the meanings of terms used in this chapter shall be as follows:

    A.  “Approved Backflow Prevention Assembly” means a backflow prevention assembly described in Foundation for Cross-Connection Control and Hydraulic Research’s (FCCC & HR) most current “list of approved backflow prevention assemblies” or American Society of Sanitary Engineers (ASSE).

    B.   “Backflow” means the undesirable reversal of the direction of flow of water or mixtures of water and other liquids, gases, or other substances into the distribution pipes of the potable water supply from any source(s) caused by backpressure and/or backsiphonage.

    C.   “Backflow Preventer” means a device designed to prevent backflow created by backpressure or backsiphonage.

    D.  “Backpressure” means backflow caused by a pump, elevated tank, boiler or means that could create an elevated pressure within the nonpotable system greater than the supply pressure.

    E.   “Backsiphonage” means the flow of water or other liquids, mixtures or substances into the distribution pipes of a potable water supply system from any source other than its intended source caused by negative or sub-atmospheric pressure in the potable water supply system.

    F.   “Certified Cross-Connection Control Technician” means a person who is certified in accordance with the provisions of Article 12 of the Colorado Primary Drinking Water Regulations.

    G.  “Colorado Cross-Connection Control Manual” means the most recent edition of a manual that has been published by the state addressing cross-connection control practices which will be used as a guidance document for the utility in implementing a cross-connection control program as outlined in Section 13.06.020.

    H.  “Containment” means the installation of an approved backflow prevention device, or method, on the water service line(s), so that water delivered to the service line cannot return to the City potable water distribution system due to any backpressure and/or backsiphonage condition which might arise.

    I.    “Contamination” means an impairment of the quality of the potable water by sewage, industrial fluids or waste liquids, compounds or other materials to a degree which creates an actual hazard to the public health through poisoning or through the spread of disease.

    J.    “Cross-Connection” means any physical arrangement whereby a public water supply is connected, directly or indirectly, with any other water supply system, sewer, drain, conduit, pool, storage reservoir, plumbing fixture or other device which contains, or may contain, contaminated water, sewage or other waste or liquid of unknown or unsafe quality which may be capable of imparting contamination to the public water supply as a result of backflow. Bypass arrangements, jumper connections, removable sections, swivel or changeover devices, four-way valve connections, and other temporary or permanent devices through which, or because of which, backflow could occur are considered to be cross-connections.

    K.  “Director” means the Director of Public Works of the City or, if none, a City Water Department employee designated by the City Administrator in writing.

    L.   Hazard, Degree of. “Degree of Hazard” means an evaluation of the potential risk to public health and the adverse effect of the hazard upon the potable water system.

    M.  “Isolation” means a backflow device installed on a branch of the internal plumbing to protect the customer’s water system.

    N.  “Nonpotable Water” means water that is not safe for human consumption or that is of questionable quality.

    O.  “Pollution” means the presence of any foreign substance (organic, inorganic, radiological or biological) in the water that may degrade the water quality so as to constitute a hazard or impair its usefulness.

    P.   “Potable Water” means water free from impurities in amounts sufficient to cause disease or harmful physiological effects. The bacteriological, chemical and radiological quality shall conform with State of Colorado Department of Public Health and Environment Primary Drinking Water Regulations.

    Q.  “Utility” means the City of Cañon City Water Department, a Water Activity Enterprise of the City of Cañon City.

    R.   “Water Service Connection” means the terminal end of the City’s service connection from the public potable water system; i.e., where the City loses jurisdiction and sanitary control over the water at its point of delivery to the customer’s stop box or shut-off valve or meter, whichever comes first, from the utility water main. If a meter is installed at the end of the service connection, then the service connection shall mean the downstream end of the meter. There shall be no unprotected takeoffs from the service line ahead of any meter or backflow prevention device located at the point of delivery to the customer’s water system. Service connection shall also include any water service connection from a fire hydrant and all other temporary or emergency water service connections from the public potable water system. (Ord. 6-2006 § 1)

 

13.06.020 Requirements.
    A.  Implementation and Enforcement of a Cross-Connection Control Program. The Director is vested with the authority and responsibility for implementing and enforcing an effective cross-connection control program in accordance with the provisions of this chapter.

    B.   Backflow Preventers Required At All Service Connections. An approved backflow preventer shall be required at each and every service connection to a water service customer’s premises for the safety and protection of the City water supply system and water users connected to that system.

    C.   The Director shall have the authority to specify the type of backflow preventer to be installed at each service connection. The Director’s decision with respect to the type of backflow preventer that will be required in any specific situation shall be based upon the degree of hazard posed by the facility connected or to be connected to the City water supply system. The degree of hazard shall be determined on a case-by-case basis, depending upon the circumstances of each particular case. In making determinations as to the degree of hazard and the type of device required, the Director shall rely upon the latest published edition of the Colorado Cross-Connection Control Manual for guidance and may rely upon other generally accepted authorities, including but not limited to the official publications of the American Society of Sanitary Engineering. The Director shall give notice in writing to the customer to install such an approved backflow prevention device at each service connection to the customer’s premises.

    D.  Inspections and Testing Procedures. The Director has the authority to inspect any system owned and maintained by a utility customer to determine the extent and degree of hazard.

    E.   The utility shall notify the utility customer at any premises where containment backflow preventers are installed to have certified inspections and operational tests made upon installation of the containment device and at least once per year thereafter. The Director may require certified tests at more frequent intervals if the Director deems the potential hazard to be great enough. These inspections and tests shall be performed by a certified cross-connection control technician.

    F.   The Director reserves the right to inspect or require the inspection of installed backflow preventers at any time to ensure the devices are in proper working order. The devices shall be repaired, overhauled or replaced whenever they are found to be defective. These inspections, tests and repairs shall be at the owners’ expense. Records of such tests, repairs and overhaul, including materials and parts changed, shall be filed with the Director within ten (10) days of such activities. The utility shall keep and maintain such records in accordance with the requirements of applicable law.

    1.   Containment devices will be tested annually according to the Colorado Revised Statutes and Colorado Department of Public Health and Environment Primary Drinking Water Regulations.

    2.   If such devices are allowed by the Director as an acceptable alternative to total containment, isolation devices used to isolate and lower the overall degree of hazard for a property will be tested on a schedule determined by the Director.

    3.   Isolation devices used on lawn irrigation sprinkler devices will be tested upon installation, repair or relocation, but in any event no less often than once annually.

    G.  Policy.

    1.   No water service connection to any premises shall be installed or maintained unless the water supply is protected as required by Colorado Revised Statutes, the regulations of the Colorado Department of Public Health and Environment and by this chapter.

    2.   Water service to any premises shall be denied or discontinued, as the case may be, by the utility if:

    a.   A backflow preventer required by this chapter is not installed within the time period specified by the Director;

    b.   An approved backflow preventer has been removed or bypassed; or

    c.   An unprotected cross-connection exists on the premises;

    d.   An approved backflow preventer is not maintained.

    3.   Whenever service is denied or discontinued, it shall not be provided or restored until the condition or defect identified in subparagraph (C)(2) has been corrected.

    4.   The customer’s system shall be open for inspection at all reasonable times to authorized representatives of the Director to determine whether cross-connections or other structural or sanitary hazards, including violations of this chapter, exist.

    5.   When, as a result of an inspection, a condition involving a violation of this chapter resulting in a health or sanitary hazard is determined to exist, or a utility customer fails to properly test, repair, or otherwise maintain a backflow preventer as required by this chapter, the Director shall have the option of immediate discontinuance of water service to the premises until the condition has been corrected, or the Director may specify a date for compliance after which time the Director may discontinue service until the customer has corrected the condition.

    H.  Installations of Backflow Prevention Devices.

    1.   Backflow preventers shall be installed immediately downstream of the water service customer’s water meter, whether the meter is a pit set or an interior set. In all cases, backflow preventers must be installed before the first branch line leading off the service line.

    2.   With the Director’s approval, a backflow preventer may be installed to isolate a hazard and lower the degree of hazard for containment. Such approval shall not be given unless the Director is convinced that the use of the isolation device will pose no threat to the public water supply system.

    3.   All backflow preventers shall be located and installed according to the manufacturer’s specifications and in accordance with this chapter and the City of Cañon City Design Standards and Construction Specifications or the Colorado Cross-Connection Control Manual. The Director shall review and approve all plans as to the type, location and installation of backflow prevention devices.

    4.   Utility customers shall be responsible for the design, installation and maintenance of properly sized and located drains and drain systems whenever the type of backflow preventer specified or approved by the Director requires a drain.

    5.   Plans shall not be modified relative to the type, location or installation of any backflow preventer approved by the Director without the Director’s prior knowledge and written authorization.

    6.   If the location or removal of the backflow preventer results in the meter becoming contaminated, the customer shall bear the cost of decontamination.

    I.    Device Testing Equipment.

    1.   The acceptability of any testing gauge or apparatus shall be determined by the utility.

    2.   Any testing gauge, apparatus or scientific instrument utilized for the testing of backflow prevention devices shall be checked for accuracy at least yearly and be in calibration. The Director may require certificates or other proof of calibration for such items to be filed with the utility.

    3.   At a minimum, all test gauges must meet ASSE-1064 Standards for Gauges.

    4.   All certified cross-connection technicians who perform work in the city shall file copies of their licenses with the utility, upon the Director’s request.

    J.    Listings Identifying Approved Backflow Prevention Devices. Any approved backflow prevention assembly required in this chapter shall be of a model and size approved by the Director and listed in the FCCC & HR’s List of Approved Backflow Prevention Assemblies and/or American Society of Sanitary Engineers (ASSE) Series 5000. (Ord. 6-2006 § 1)

 

13.06.030 Compliance procedures.
    A.  Installation of Required Devices.

    1.   Upon completion of inspection of the premises, or, in the case of new construction, on review of the construction plans, the Director shall notify the owner in writing of the type of device that will be required at each service connection within the owner’s facility.

    2.   The owner shall, at its expense, purchase and install the device and any necessary plumbing or construction. Such plumbing and construction shall meet all provisions of the Colorado Cross-Connection Control Manual and the City of Cañon City Design Standards and Construction Specifications and must be inspected and approved by the utility. The device, including any device installed prior to the effective date of the ordinance codified in this chapter, shall be the property of the owner.

    B.   Compliance Required.

    1.   The utility will take necessary action to ensure compliance with the Colorado Department of Health, Primary Drinking Water Regulations, 5 CCR 1003-1, and more specifically Article 12 thereof, and the Colorado Revised Statues, Section 25-1-114, as amended.

    2.   The owner of the premises is required to permit entry to the premises for inspection, testing and maintenance purposes at reasonable times. Failure to permit entry to the premises will result in the premises being regarded as a high hazard, and a reduced-pressure-principle device will be required to protect the City’s water supply system.

    3.   The owner is required to provide all necessary plumbing and construction needed for the installation of the device. Failure to provide such required plumbing and construction will result in action being taken as provided for in Section 13.06.060. (Ord. 6-2006 § 1)

 

13.06.040 Appeals.
    A.  Any decision of the Director regarding the type of backflow preventer required with respect to any water service connection may be appealed to the City Administrator, provided that a notice of appeal is filed in the office of the City Administrator not later than twenty (20) days following the date upon which the Director’s written notice specifying the type of device is delivered to the property owner or its agent.

    B.   The notice of appeal shall identify the property owner by name, mailing address, telephone number and email address, if any, and include the address of the owner’s facility. Such notice shall:

    1.   Identify the Director’s decision that is being appealed;

    2.   Identify the type of backflow preventer that the owner believes should be installed at the owner’s facility; and

    3.   Include the owner’s reasons for preferring such backflow preventer, instead of the backflow preventer designated by the Director, with or without written documentation supporting the owner’s position.

    C.   Within ten (10) days following the filing of the notice of appeal, the City Administrator, by written notice specifying the date, time and place of the hearing, shall schedule a hearing. Such hearing shall be conducted no later than thirty (30) days following the date upon which the notice of appeal was filed, unless the owner and the City Administrator both agree to a later hearing date. At the hearing, the owner may present testimony, evidence and arguments in support of the owner’s position and the Director may present testimony, evidence and arguments in support of the Director’s decision.

    D.  The Director’s decision shall be affirmed unless the City Administrator finds that the Director’s decision was arbitrary or capricious or that such decision violates applicable federal, state or local law. The City Administrator’s decision shall be rendered in writing no later than ten (10) days following the hearing and shall be final.

    E.   The paramount issue with respect to any appeal will be whether the type of backflow preventer authorized will adequately protect the public water supply system.

    F.   Before deciding any appeal, the City Administrator shall consider:

    1.   Whether the backflow preventer specified by the Director is necessary to adequately protect the City’s water supply system;

    2.   Whether the backflow preventer preferred by the owner would adequately protect the City’s water supply system;

    3.   Whether the use of the backflow preventer preferred by the owner, when compared to the backflow preventer designated by the Director, is likely to result in a material decrease in the level of protection to the public water supply system.

    G.  In cases where an existing structure is being remodeled or reconstructed or where a change in the use of an existing structure will or may create a greater degree of hazard to the public water supply system than previously existed, the City Administrator may consider:

    1.   Differences in the cost of devices and backflow prevention assemblies, when comparing the type of backflow preventer specified by the Director to the type of backflow preventer preferred by the owner;

    2.   Differences in the cost of installing and maintaining the two (2) types of backflow preventers being compared;

    3.   Other significant cost differences or practical difficulties associated with the use, installation and/or maintenance of the backflow preventers being compared;

    4.   Other relevant life, safety or health concerns raised by the Director or the owner. (Ord. 6-2006 § 1)

 

13.06.050 Jurisdictional issues and conflicts.
    In the event the provisions of this chapter are in conflict with the requirements of any plumbing code or regulation applicable in the city, the provisions of this chapter shall apply to the extent necessary to resolve the conflict and shall be binding upon all plumbing officials performing official duties within the city. (Ord. 6-2006 § 1)

 

13.06.060 Violation—Penalties.
    A.  The Director shall notify the owner, or authorized agent of the owner, of the building or premises of a violation of this chapter. The Director shall set a specific time for the owner to have the violation removed or corrected. If the owner fails to correct the violation in the specified time, the Director may, if in his or her judgment an imminent health hazard exists, suspend water service to the building or premises. Additional fines or penalties may also be invoked following suspension of service.

    B.   Violations of this Chapter 13.06 may be prosecuted in municipal court and, upon conviction thereof, a violator may be fined in an amount that does not exceed the maximum fine provided for in Section 1.28.010. (Ord. 17-2013 § 52; Ord. 6-2006 § 1)

Chapter 13.08 WATER RATES AND FEES*
* CodeAlert: This topic has been affected by Ordinance No. 23-2020. To view amendments and newly added provisions, please refer to the CodeAlert Amendment List.


13.08.010 Definitions.
    Definitions used in this chapter shall be those set forth in Chapter 13.04. (Ord. 8-2008 § 2)

 

13.08.020 Water tap permits—Perfecting applications for water service.
    A.  Persons seeking new water service connections to the Water Department’s system may apply for a water tap permit on forms provided by the Water Department. No permanent water service connection will be authorized unless the application for the water tap permit has been perfected in accordance with the requirements set forth in this section.

    1.   The applicant must file a complete and accurate application in accordance with the requirements of Section 13.08.030 containing such information as is requested by the City Engineer. Inaccurate and/or incomplete applications will be rejected.

    2.   The applicant must tender payment of the full tap fee as determined with respect to Section 13.08.040 and, if applicable, any impact fee provided for pursuant to Section 13.08.140 and/or any water line rebate required under Section 13.04.127.

    3.   The applicant (or someone on the applicant’s behalf) must complete, according to applicable City standards and specifications and to the reasonable satisfaction of the City Engineer, all infrastructure improvements necessary to make the desired connection and provide water service to the applicant’s property.

    4.   The property to be served generally must be a legally created lot or parcel. The recording of a subdivision plat creating the lot or parcel to be served will be a necessary prerequisite to water service in most instances.

    5.   If the property to be served is outside city boundaries, the owner of such property will be required to execute and perform a Water Service Contract approved by City Council and meeting the requirements of Section 13.04.120. In addition to the requirements set forth in this section, all prerequisites to the provision of water service that are set forth in such Water Service Contract must be performed before water service connections to the owner’s property will be permitted by the Water Department. (Ord. 8-2008 § 2)

 

13.08.030 Applications for water tap permits—Contents and process.
    Applicants requesting water service must file a completed application for water service with the Engineer. The application shall be made on such form as may be furnished or prescribed by the Engineer. Such application, at a minimum, shall contain the applicant’s name, address and telephone number; the legal description and street address, if any, of the real property to be served; a statement describing all structures, if any, existing on the property at the time the application is submitted; a statement advising whether the property is within or outside of the corporate limits of the city at the time the application is submitted; a statement describing all structures, if any, the applicant intends to construct or have constructed on the property described in the application and the estimated completion date of each such structure. Such application also may request other information deemed necessary by the Engineer relative to the operation of the Water Department’s system and the keeping of records with respect to such system. If an incomplete or materially inaccurate application is filed, this requirement will not have been met by the applicant and the applicant shall be so notified by the Engineer. No application shall be deemed filed until it has been determined to be complete and accurate by the Engineer. (Ord. 8-2008 § 2)

 

13.08.040 Tap fees.
    A.  General Provisions. Except for temporary service connections, as provided for in Section 13.04.135, no new water service connection and no new water service will be provided to any property until a tap fee has first been paid. The amount of the tap fee chargeable by and payable to the Water Department shall be determined with respect to: (1) the location of the property to be served; (2) the size of the connection to a Water Department main (as approved by the City Engineer); and (3) in some circumstances, the number of units to be served through such connection.

    B.   Inside Tap Fees—Single Units. Tap fees for single units located within the boundaries of the city or within the boundaries of the former Lincoln Park Water District shall be as set forth in Schedule A-1 to Appendix 13.08.

    C.   Inside Tap Fees—Multi-Unit. Tap fees for multi-unit facilities, structures or complexes located within the boundaries of the city or within the boundaries of the former Lincoln Park Water District that will be served through a single master meter shall be as set forth in Schedule A-2 of Appendix 13.08.

    D.  Outside Tap Fees—Single Units. Tap fees for single units located outside of the boundaries of the city and outside the boundaries of the former Lincoln Park Water District shall be as set forth in Schedule B-1 of Appendix 13.08.

    E.   Outside Tap Fees—Multi-Unit. Tap fees for multi-unit facilities, structures or complexes located outside of the boundaries of the city and outside the boundaries of the former Lincoln Park Water District that will be served through a single master meter shall be as set forth in Schedule B-2 of Appendix 13.08.

    F.   Tap Fees (or Equivalent) Required with Respect to Customers of Group Users. Unless otherwise specifically provided in a fully-executed written contract between the City or Department and the group user, no group user shall be authorized to provide water service to any customer of the group user using water sold to the group user by the Department unless an amount equal to the tap fee that would be payable by such customer to the Department if such customer were connecting directly to the Department’s water system has first been paid to the Department by or on behalf of such customer.

    G.  Inside Tap Fees for Parks and Open Space. Tap fees for approved water taps that will be used as a water source to irrigate a park, open space or other similar area (or as a source of water for any accessory structure within any such park open space or other similar area) located inside the boundaries of the city or inside the boundaries of the former Lincoln Park Water District shall be as set forth in Schedule A-1 of Appendix 13.08.

    H.  Outside Tap Fees for Parks and Open Space. Tap fees for approved water taps that will be used as a water source to irrigate a park, open space or other similar area (or as a source of water for any accessory structure within any such park, open space or other similar area) located outside the boundaries of the city and outside the boundaries of the former Lincoln Park Water District shall be as set forth in Schedule B-1 of Appendix 13.08.

    I.    Negotiated Tap Fees, Reductions and Payment Arrangements for Certain Industrial and Commercial Users.

    1.   It is the City’s policy to encourage industrial and commercial growth within the city and its urban growth boundaries. In aid of such policy, and in cases where a clear public purpose exists or where a clear public benefit will be achieved, the City Council may negotiate with applicants for water taps who request reduced tap fees, or who wish to make arrangements for the deferred payment of portions of their water tap fees.

    2.   The City Council shall, by resolution, specify guidelines and standards which must be followed and met by applicants seeking to negotiate agreements for reduced tap fees or payment arrangements under this subsection.

    3.   Nothing in this subsection will require City Council to agree to reduce the tap fee for any person or project.

    4.   All agreements negotiated pursuant to the provisions of this Subsection I shall be in writing and be signed by the property owner acquiring the subject water tap permit. Any such agreement that obligates or may obligate the property owner (and/or the property owner’s successors in interest) to make future payments shall run with the land and be recorded at the property owner’s expense.

    J.    Fees for Increase in Tap Size. For any increase in the size of an existing tap (accomplished by abandoning or removing an existing tap and installing a new tap in its place), the user who receives the larger tap shall pay to the Water Department the difference between the tap fee for the new tap, as determined by reference to the appropriate schedule of Appendix 13.08, and the tap fee for the abandoned or removed tap, as determined by reference to the same schedule and the size of the abandoned or removed tap. No request for a new tap of increased size will be honored in the absence of such payment. All new meters or fixtures installed pursuant to a request made under this subsection shall be equipped with appropriate back flow prevention devices specified by the Water Department and paid for by the applicant. No refund will be made by the Water Department when an existing tap is removed and replaced with a tap of lesser size. Additionally, when a user applies to increase the size of a tap located outside the corporate limits of the city, the Water Department may require that a new Water Service Contract be executed and performed as a condition to allowing the requested increase in tap size.

    K.  Fire Protection. In the event a water user wishes to tap a City water main for the purpose of conveying or furnishing water to a structure solely for fire protection purposes, and upon the user showing to the satisfaction of the City Engineer that the service line from such additional tap is solely for fire protection purposes, a fire protection water tap permit will be issued, for which the user shall pay no tap fee. The water user will, however, be required to install a double check detector assembly in a vault at the property line, on the fire line or at another location approved by the Water Superintendent. If any service line earmarked for fire protection shall at any time be used to deliver water for any purpose other than fire protection or suppression, the Water Superintendent may order the water user to pay the applicable tap fee for the connection used to deliver water for such other purpose (as determined with respect to the appropriate schedule of Appendix 13.08). If such order is given, the tap fee shall become immediately due and payable by the water user. Non-payment of such tap fee within thirty (30) days of such order shall be grounds for termination of all water service to the property of the water user.

    L.   City Facilities. Unless otherwise ordered by formal action of City Council, no tap fee will be charged with respect to the connection of a new City-owned or controlled park, green space, building, structure or facility to the water system. In addition, no tap fee shall be payable with respect to increasing the number or size of existing water taps serving any City-owned or controlled park, green space, building, structure or facility.

    M.  Correctional Facilities. Tap fees with respect to correctional facilities shall be established by written contract, including, but not necessarily limited to, the Mutual Benefit Water Service Agreement dated March 15, 1993 between the City and the State of Colorado, acting by and through the Colorado Department of Corrections. (Ord. 17-2010 § 1; Ord. 8-2008 § 2)

 

13.08.045 Abandonment of water tap permits and water taps.
    A.  Abandonment of Water Tap Permits—Credit. If a water tap permit is issued with respect to a lot or parcel upon which the applicant proposes to construct a structure, such permit will conclusively be deemed abandoned and become void upon the following occurrences:

    1.   If a building permit for such structure has not been issued within six (6) months following the date the water tap permit was issued; or

    2.   If the structure covered by a building permit issued within the six (6) months after the date the water tap permit was issued is not complete and a certificate of occupancy has not been issued within two (2) years following the date the water tap permit was issued.

    In such event, the applicant shall be entitled to reapply for a new water tap permit for the same lot or parcel and, if such permit is thereafter issued, the applicant shall be granted a credit against the tap fee payable with respect to the new application in an amount equal to ninety percent (90%) of the amount of the tap fee paid at the time the abandoned water tap permit was issued. No tap fee with respect to an abandoned permit shall be refunded if a physical connection to a service meter has been made.

    B.   Voluntary Abandonment of Water Tap Permits. If an owner of a lot or parcel determines to abandon a previously issued water tap permit and if no physical connection to the property’s service meter has been made, upon application by the owner, the City shall refund ninety percent (90%) of the amount of the tap fee originally paid to the owner.

    C.   Abandonment of Previously Valid Taps. Any previously valid connection to the Department water system will be deemed abandoned and null and void for all purposes if the site or structure previously receiving water service or entitled to receive water service has been disconnected or turned off for a period of twelve (12) or more consecutive months, beginning on any date after August 1, 2008 unless, during such period, meter charges and/or account maintenance fees provided for in Section 13.08.050, plus applicable interest and/or other accrued charges, if any, have been paid in full with respect to all months during which the water service was disconnected or turned off. The owner of property where a previously valid water tap was abandoned shall be treated as an applicant for new water service for all purposes under this chapter if such owner seeks to have water service restored to such owner’s property.

    D.  Removal of Abandoned Appurtenances and Facilities. The Department is authorized to remove all appurtenances and facilities associated with abandoned water taps, including, but not limited to, appurtenances and facilities that are not evidenced by any open and active water service account maintained by the Department. Taps shall be physically disconnected from the main by plugging, capping, or sealing in accordance with the Department’s specifications. In such cases, the meter, meter pit, and/or shutoff also shall be removed. The property owner shall be responsible for all costs associated with the disconnection. From time to time, the Department may find and remove abandoned taps, fixtures and appurtenances at its own expense for the benefit of the water system as a whole.

    E.   Removal of Unauthorized Appurtenances and Facilities. The Department is authorized to remove all appurtenances and facilities associated with unauthorized and/or illegal water taps, including, but not limited to, appurtenances and facilities that are not evidenced by any open and active water service account maintained by the Department and a valid water tap permit. (Ord. 4-2018 § 1; Ord. 10-2010 § 2; Ord. 8-2008 § 2)

 

13.08.050 Water service charges based on meter measurement and water.
    A.  Meter Charges. Except as otherwise might be provided in this chapter, every water user whose property or structure is physically connected to the water system shall pay a periodic meter charge for the privilege of being connected to the water system. Such meter charge shall be calculated with respect to the size of the water meter serving such property or structure and shall be billed and payable without regard to whether any water was actually consumed by the water user during the applicable billing period. Meter charges shall be assessed and billed either monthly or quarterly, depending upon the rate classification of the water user, as reflected in the various water rate schedules set forth in Appendix 13.08 to this Chapter 13.08. Meter charges shall be assessed, billed and payable notwithstanding any discontinuation of water service that is requested by a water user or imposed by the Department with respect to the failure of a water service customer who is connected to the water system to pay fees and charges payable pursuant to the provisions of this Chapter 13.08.

    B.   Water Consumption Charges Based Upon Metered Usage. In addition to the applicable meter charge, all water users shall be charged for water delivered to them by the Department according to meter measurement. Charges with respect to such water consumption shall be calculated, billed and payable in accordance with the rates provided for in the various schedules appended to this Chapter 13.08, as the same may be amended from time to time.

    C.   Monthly Account Maintenance Fee.

    1.   A monthly account maintenance fee shall be charged to and payable by any person holding a valid water tap permit for the period beginning with the purchase of the water tap permit and ending when a physical connection of the property identified in such water tap permit to a Department water main has been made or such water tap permit has been abandoned pursuant to Section 13.08.045. Following the making of such connection, periodic meter charges and water consumption rates calculated in accordance with the applicable rate schedule appended to this Chapter 13.08 shall become billable and payable with respect to such water service customer.

    2.   Subject to the provisions of Section 13.08.045, persons holding or claiming to hold a valid water tap permit with respect to a property that was previously connected to the water system but which is no longer connected to the water system shall be billed and shall pay a monthly account maintenance fee in order to retain any rights for such property to be reconnected to the water system.

    3.   Persons holding a valid water tap permit with respect to a property that is connected to the water system shall be charged and pay applicable meter charges, notwithstanding that no water is delivered or consumed through such water service connection. Any such permit holder may voluntarily abandon any rights under the water tap permit and relinquish any and all rights to future water service based upon such abandoned water tap permit by executing and delivering to the Department a notice of intent to abandon on a form prepared or approved by the Department and thereafter be relieved of all future fees and charges associated with the abandoned water service connection. As an alternative to abandonment, such permit holder may disconnect from the water system by causing the removal of the water meter and appurtenances associated with the physical connection of the property of the permit holder to the water system, provided that such disconnection is accomplished in accordance with the requirements of the Department after written permission to make such disconnection has been obtained from the Department. Following any such disconnection, the permit holder shall become obligated to timely pay monthly account maintenance fees in order to retain rights under the water tap permit and shall be subject to the provisions of Section 13.08.045 respecting abandonment.

    D.  Non-payment of meter charges or monthly account maintenance fees, whichever is applicable, together with all accrued fees, charges, late charges and other sums then owing, for a period of twelve (12) consecutive months will be conclusive evidence of a water user’s intention to abandon any rights to continued or future water service based upon a previously-issued water tap permit. (Ord. 10-2010 § 3)

 

13.08.060 Rates—Inside water users.
    A.  Inside Residential Rates. Inside residential water rates shall apply with respect to water sold and delivered to separately-metered dwelling units located within the corporate limits of the city and shall be calculated and billed in accordance with the provisions of Schedule D of Appendix 13.08.

    B.   Inside Non-Residential Rates. Inside non-residential water rates shall apply with respect to all water users who consume water delivered within the corporate limits of the city, except for users identified in Subsections 13.08.060(A) and (C) and in Section 13.08.080. Inside non-residential water rates shall be calculated and billed in accordance with the provisions of Schedule E of Appendix 13.08.

    C.   Inside Multi-Unit Rates. Unless otherwise specifically provided in this chapter, inside multi-unit water rates shall apply with respect to all multi-unit facilities receiving water sold by the Department and delivered through a single meter (sometimes called a “master meter”) at a location within the corporate limits of the City for distribution to two (2) or more dwelling units, two (2) or more non-residential users, or within any mixed-use facility. Inside multi-unit water rates shall be calculated and billed in accordance with the provisions of Schedule F of Appendix 13.08.

    D.  If such facilities are located within the boundaries of the city, the owners of the following types of multi-unit facilities shall pay inside non-residential water rates: duplexes; single-family residences with one accessory dwelling unit; residential properties legally used for business or commercial purposes, including, but not limited to, home occupation businesses; and/or approved mixed-use facilities consisting of only one residential unit and only one business or commercial unit. (Ord. 13-2011 § 7; Ord. 10-2010 § 4; Ord. 8-2008 § 2)

 

13.08.070 Rates—Outside water users.
    A.  Outside Residential Rates. Outside residential water rates shall apply with respect to water sold and delivered to separately-metered dwelling units located outside of the corporate limits of the city and outside of the boundaries of the former Lincoln Park Water District and shall be calculated and billed in accordance with the provisions of Schedule G of Appendix 13.08.

    B.   Outside Non-Residential Rates. Outside non-residential water rates shall apply with respect to all water users who consume water delivered outside of the corporate limits of the city, except for users identified in Subsections 13.08.070(A) and (C) and in Section 13.08.080. Outside non-residential water rates shall be calculated and billed in accordance with the provisions of Schedule H of Appendix 13.08.

    C.   Outside Multi-Unit Rates. Unless otherwise specifically provided in this chapter, outside multi-unit water rates shall apply with respect to all multi-unit facilities receiving water sold by the Department through a single meter (sometimes called a “master meter”) at a location outside the corporate limits of the city and outside of the boundaries of the former Lincoln Park Water District for distribution to two (2) or more dwelling units, two (2) or more non-residential users, or within any mixed-use facility. Outside multi-unit water rates shall be calculated and billed in accordance with the provisions of Schedule I of Appendix 13.08.

    D.  If such facilities are located outside the boundaries of the city, the owners of the following types of multi-unit facilities shall pay outside non-residential water rates: duplexes; single-family residences with one accessory dwelling unit; residential properties legally used for business or commercial purposes, including, but not limited to, home occupation businesses; and/or approved mixed-use facilities consisting of only one residential unit and only one business or commercial unit. (Ord. 13-2011 § 8; Ord. 10-2010 § 5; Ord. 8-2008 § 2)

 

13.08.080 Special rates.
    A.  Group Users. Group user water rates shall apply with respect to water sold and delivered to any municipality (other than the City), special district or other entity regulated by the Colorado Public Utilities Commission that distributes water purchased from the Department to water users within its jurisdiction through a water distribution system operated by such municipality, special district or other entity. Examples of group users include the Town of Brookside and the Orchard Park Water District. Water rates applicable to group users are those provided for in Schedule J of Appendix 13.08.

    B.   Golf Course Rates. Because golf courses within the Department’s water service area have been and will remain open to public play by local inhabitants, offer unique recreational opportunities, enhance quality of life, generate tourism and otherwise foster growth and economic development, the Department has deemed it to be in the public interest for water rates charged to golf courses to have been less than prevailing rates charged to other non-residential water users. It is the Department’s goal to bring water rates for golf courses into parity with those applicable to other non-residential water users and uses, but the Department seeks to achieve such parity over a period of years in order to avoid situations where increased costs of water, coupled with other difficult economic circumstances, could force the closure of one or more golf courses and the community’s loss of those unique public benefits enumerated in this subsection. Accordingly, unless otherwise specified by valid contract, water rates for all water sold by the Department to golf courses shall be as set forth in Schedule K of Appendix 13.08.

    C.   City Rates. City rates shall apply with respect to all water sold and delivered to the City of Cañon City, including its divisions and departments, regardless of location, and shall be calculated and billed in accordance with the provisions of Schedule L of Appendix 13.08.

    D.  Correctional Facilities. Rates charged for water service provided to correctional facilities within the City shall be “inside non-residential rates,” as provided for in Schedule E of Appendix 13.08. Rates charged for water service provided to correctional facilities located outside of the corporate limits of the city shall be “outside non-residential rates,” as provided for in Schedule H of Appendix 13.08.

    E.   Former Lincoln Park Water District. Rates applicable to water users who receive water sold by the Department at locations outside of the boundaries of the city, but within the boundaries of the former Lincoln Park Domestic Water District, as they existed on September 18, 1975 when the district was dissolved, shall be calculated and adjusted as provided for in that certain contract dated June 16, 1975, between the City and the former Lincoln Park Water District. Such rates, if different from those applicable to other outside water users pursuant to Section 13.08.070, will be reflected on Schedule M of Appendix 13.08.

    F.   Transmountain water rates shall apply to sales or leases of transmountain water to any water user that purchases or leases such water pursuant to a Water Court Decree or other lawful order approving the water user’s plan for substitution and exchange or augmentation that may be satisfied by the Department’s delivery of transmountain water at a place designated or authorized in such approved plan. Transmountain water shall mean Fryingpan-Arkansas Project water lawfully allocated to the Department that is available for such use in accordance with the provisions of applicable law, rules, regulations and policies. In addition, transmountain water shall be water that is not physically removed from the Arkansas River and/or storage facilities constructed or maintained as components of the Fryingpan-Arkansas Project. The rate applicable to sales or leases of transmountain water shall be as set forth in Schedule S. (Ord. 3-2012 § 2; Ord. 10-2010 § 6; Ord. 8-2008 § 2)

 

13.08.090 Bulk water sales.
    A.  The Department may operate a bulk water dispensing station and sell water to water purchasers who are not connected to the Department water system and who provide their own transportation containers and vehicles. Such purchasers shall be referred to as “bulk water users.”

    B.   All bulk water users shall be subject to such rules, regulations, policies and procedures governing the operation, hours and use of the bulk water dispensing station which may, from time to time, be imposed by the Water Superintendent. Copies of such rules, regulations, policies and procedures shall be available for inspection at City Hall and at the Public Works building during normal business hours.

    C.   Bulk water users shall pay for all water purchased from the Department at the rate specified in Schedule N of Appendix 13.08.

    D.  There will be no vested or perfected right to water service provided by this section for bulk water users. The Department may discontinue or limit water sales from its bulk water dispensing station at any time, with or without advance notice. (Ord. 8-2008 § 2)

 

13.08.100 Water rates for temporary water service.
    Rates with respect to temporary water service authorized pursuant to Section 13.04.135 shall be calculated and billed in accordance with the provisions of Schedule O of Appendix 13.08. (Ord. 8-2008 § 2)

 

13.08.120 Malfunctioning water meters.
    A.  If, with respect to any billing cycle applicable to any water user, it becomes apparent that the water meter intended to measure such user’s water consumption during such billing cycle became damaged, broken, inoperable or otherwise malfunctioned in a manner clearly suggesting that such water user’s actual consumption during the billing cycle, as measured by such damaged or defective water meter, was understated for the billing cycle, such water user’s charges for that billing cycle shall be estimated by the Department, based upon historic consumption records for the same location.

    B.   The Water Superintendent shall establish the formula or method by which water charges will be estimated under circumstances described in Subsection A of this section. The Director of Finance shall have the discretion to waive or reduce water charges in excess of minimum charges for the applicable billing cycle for good cause shown by any water users whose charges were estimated pursuant to the terms of this section. (Ord. 8-2008 § 2)

 

13.08.130 Water surcharge zone fees.
    A.  There are established certain water surcharge zones within the Department’s water service area. Water surcharge zones are areas within which water users are served with water pumped at the Department’s expense after such water leaves the Department’s water treatment plant. The Department is hereby authorized to charge water surcharge zone fees to its customers within such water surcharge zones. Water surcharge zones shall include the following:

    1.   Zone I(A) shall include territory within which water users receive water that is pumped once at the Department’s expense through the Department’s #1 Booster Pump Station before it is delivered to water users within such territory.

    2.   Zone I(B) shall include territory within which water users receive water that is pumped once at the Department’s expense through the Department’s North 9th Street Pump Station before it is delivered to water users within such territory.

    3.   Zone I(C) shall include territory within which water users receive water that is pumped once at the Department’s expense through the Department’s Four Mile Ranch Pump Station before it is delivered to water users within such territory.

    4.   Zone II. Zone II shall include territory within which water users receive water that is pumped twice at the Department’s expense (through the Department’s #1 and #2 Booster Pump Stations) after such water leaves the water treatment plant and before it is delivered to water users within such territory.

    5.   Zone III. Zone III shall include territory within which water users receive water that is pumped three (3) times at the Department’s expense (through the #1 and #2 Booster Pump Stations and then through the Greenhorn Pump Station) after such water leaves the water treatment plant and before it is delivered to water users within such territory.

    B.   Water Surcharge Zone Maps. The City Engineer shall prepare, maintain and modify, when warranted, a water system map clearly indicating the boundaries of all territory included with each water surcharge zone described and designated in subsection A of this section. Such maps shall be made available for public inspection at City Hall during normal business hours.

    C.   Zone Surcharge Fees. Water users within the various water surcharge zones shall be charged on their periodic water billing statements for zone surcharge fees calculated by multiplying the water user’s actual water consumption for the billing period times the applicable zone surcharge rate. Zone surcharge fees shall be in addition to all other charges payable by such water users.

    D.  Zone Surcharge Rates. Zone surcharge rates shall be based upon costs of electricity and the calculation thereof may also include costs of equipment maintenance, associated labor and depreciation that are specific to the pump station or stations that serve the applicable water surcharge zone. Rates to be used to calculate water zone surcharge fees shall be those set forth in Schedule P of Appendix 13.08. (Ord. 3-2012 § 1)

 

13.08.140 Impact fees.
    A.  The City Council from time to time may establish and the Department may charge impact fees to applicants for water service to properties located within certain areas impacted by development (“impact areas”) that are within the service area of the Water Department in order to recover costs incurred by the Department to pay for improvements made by the Department to ensure the Department’s ability to provide adequate water service to users within such impact areas.

    B.   The territory and rates to be included within each impact area shall be as provided for in Schedule Q of Appendix 13.08.

    C.   The Engineer shall prepare and maintain an impact area map or maps clearly indicating the boundaries of all territory included within each impact area. Territory included within an impact area need not be contiguous with other territory included in the same or in any separate impact area.

    D.  Impact fees provided for in this section, if not previously paid by a prior owner or developer, shall be billed to individual applicants for water service at the time such applicants apply for a water tap permit. No water tap permit shall be issued until both the impact fee and the applicable tap fee have been paid in full. Such impact fees shall be in addition to the applicant’s tap fee.

 

    E.   When impact fees provided for in this section are imposed as a condition of approval for a subdivision or other land development, which shall be the ordinary and preferred way of imposing the impact fees provided for in this section, the developer of such subdivision or other land development shall pay, as a lump sum and prior to the recording of the subdivision plat, all impact fees with respect to all lots within the subdivision. The amount to be paid by such developer shall be determined by multiplying the applicable per-lot impact fee times the anticipated number of water taps to be made available by the Department for use within the subdivision. Impact fees shall be in addition to all other charges payable by the developer and/or water user.

    F.   When City Council permits a planned development, a planned unit development, district, a subdivision or other land development to be developed in phases, the impact fee payable by the developer will be calculated and payable on a phase-by-phase basis, taking into account the number of water taps to be made available in each phase, unless City Council provides otherwise in its ordinance or resolution approving the subdivision or other land development.

    G.  As to each impact area with respect to which impact fees may be collected, the Engineer shall prepare, maintain and make available for public inspection accurate and reliable records with respect to costs incurred by the Department that are recoverable through the imposition and collection of impact fees pursuant to this section. Records reflecting impact fees actually collected also shall be kept and updated periodically by the Engineer.

    H.  Any person who has paid a rebate to the Department pursuant to the provisions of Subsection K of Section 13.04.127 shall be entitled to a credit (equal to the amount of such rebate payment) against an impact fee imposed pursuant to the provisions of this section if such rebate payment pertained to the same water system improvements that gave rise to the Department’s costs that were used to determine the impact fees to be imposed pursuant to this section. The purpose of this subsection is to ensure that no property owner (including successors in interest) pays for the same water system improvements twice. (Ord. 8-2008 § 2)

 

13.08.150 Fees for services.
    A.  The Department may charge fees to water users for any or all of the following services: turn off of water service; turn on of water service; final readings of water meters; rereading water meters; testing water meters; other services requested by water users that require the time and attention of Department service personnel.

    B.   The fees to be charged by the Department for services enumerated at Subsection A of this section shall be those provided for at Schedule R of Appendix 13.08.

    C.   The Director of Finance is hereby authorized, at his discretion, to waive or reduce the amount of any Department fee enumerated in Schedule R of Appendix 13.08 in cases where the Director determines that the charging of such fee would be unjust or inequitable under the circumstances that gave rise to the performance of the services for which the fee was charged. The Director shall consider waiving or reducing fees pursuant to this subsection when Department services associated with the fee were performed in connection with an emergency or as a result of extraordinary climatic or natural conditions. The authority and discretion herein granted to the Director of Finance may be delegated, on a case-by-case basis. All determinations made by the Director of Finance, or his/her designee, regarding requests for the waiver or reduction of fees made pursuant to this subsection shall be final administrative decisions. (Ord. 8-2008 § 2)

 

13.08.160 Owner responsibility for payment and service in owner names.
    A.  The owner of the real property where the water is to be used shall be responsible for the payment of all water rents for water delivered by the Department to such property. When the property receiving water service is owned in common by some or all of the unit owners in a common interest community, condominium or similar group or entity, the association formed by such unit owners may be treated by the Department as the owner of such property for all purposes under this Title 13.

    B.   All billings of charges and fees for water service provided by the Department shall be prepared in the name of, be mailed to and be payable by the owner of the real property where the water service is provided, regardless of whether such owner occupies the real property. Accounts for water service will not be established in the names of tenants. Requests made for turn on or turn off of water service made by tenants will not be honored by the Department, except in cases of extreme emergency, as determined by the Water Superintendent or designee. The Department also will not honor requests that are made by tenants for the rereading or testing of water meters or for any final meter reading. (Ord. 8-2008 § 2)

 

13.08.170 Lien by city—Amounts due.
    The City shall have a lien upon all real estate to which the Department sells and delivers water for the amounts of all water charges, fees and assessments owing to the Department for and with respect to such water and water service. Such lien shall commence when such charges, fees and assessments shall become due, and shall remain a lien until the same are paid in full. All such liens shall run with the land where water service was delivered by the Department. (Ord. 8-2008 § 2)

 

13.08.180 Lien by City—Owner notification.
    All water supplied by the Department shall be deemed to have been supplied at the instance and request of the owner(s) of the property so supplied. Such owner(s) and all persons claiming by, through or under such owner(s), shall be deemed to have notice of such lien, whether the property is occupied by an owner, tenant, or any other person. (Ord. 8-2008 § 2)

 

13.08.190 Late charges and interest.
    A.  In the event any sum due the Department for water sold or as fees, charges or assessments authorized under the provisions of this Title 13 shall not have been paid on or before the “due date” stated in the water bill sent to the water user, such sum shall bear additional charges and/or interest as set forth and determined with respect to Schedule R of Appendix 13.08.
