Chapter 15.04 INTERNATIONAL BUILDING CODE*
* CodeAlert: This topic has been affected by Ordinance No. 20-2020. To view amendments and newly added provisions, please refer to the CodeAlert Amendment List.


This topic has been modified. View the section for details. 15.04.010 Document adopted by reference—Contents.
    A.  Pursuant to Section 9 of Article XII of the Charter of the City and applicable provisions of Part 2 of Article 16 of Title 31 of the Colorado Revised Statutes, as amended, there is adopted as the building code of the City of Cañon City, by reference thereto, the International Building Code, 2006 Edition, published by the International Code Council, 500 New Jersey Avenue, NW, 6th Floor, Washington, DC 20001 including the Chapters of the Appendix to said Code, and together with the errata sheet accompanying said International Building Code (all of which is hereinafter referred to as the “International Building Code”), all to have the same force and effect as if set forth herein in every particular.

    B.   The subject matter of the adopted Code includes comprehensive provisions and standards regulating the erection, construction, enlargement, alteration, repair, moving, removal, conversion, demolition, occupancy, equipment, use, height, area and maintenance of buildings and structures, except for those certain detached one- and two-family dwellings and multiple single-family dwellings that are covered by the International Residential Code. (Ord. 11-2008 § 1)

 

This topic has been modified. View the section for details. 15.04.020 Copies for public use.
    At least one copy of the International Building Code, 2006 Edition, as published by the International Code Council, certified by the Mayor and the City Clerk to be a true copy, has been and is now on file in the office of the City Clerk and may be inspected by any interested person between the hours of eight a.m. and five p.m., Monday through Friday, holidays excepted. (Ord. 11-2008 § 1)

 

This topic has been modified. View the section for details. 15.04.030 Additions, amendments and deletions to 2006 International Building Code.
    A.  Section 101.1 is revised to read as follows:

 

      Section 101.1. Title. These regulations shall be known as the Building Code of the City of Cañon City, hereafter referred to as “this Code.”

 

    B.   Section 101.4.1 is hereby deleted in its entirety and the following section is substituted therefor:

 

      Section 101.4.1. International Existing Building Code. The provisions of these guidelines shall constitute the minimum standards for change of occupancy, alteration and repair of existing buildings and structures. These guidelines shall only be used when all other requirements as set forth in the International Building Code and other referenced codes have been exhausted.

 

      Nothing in the International Existing Building Code, as referenced in this section, shall be construed to defeat or limit the exercise of the right to elect to opt out with respect to accessibility standards set forth in Chapter 11 or Section 3409 of this Code (or both Chapter 11 and Section 3409) by any permit applicant or permit holder. (See IBC code Section 1101.4, 1101.5, 3409.1.5 and 3409.1.6).

 

    C.   Section 101.4.4 is hereby deleted in its entirety. The State of Colorado has jurisdiction over the Plumbing Code.

    D.  Section 101.4. 5 is hereby deleted in its entirety.

    E.   Section 101.4.6 is hereby deleted in its entirety. The Cañon City Area Fire Protection District has adopted and enforces within the City of Cañon City the International Fire Code.

    F.   Section 101.4.8 is added to the International Building Code to read as follows:

 

      Section 101.4.8. Conflict. In the event there shall be a conflict between the provisions of the International Building Code and the provisions of Title 17 (Zoning Ordinance) of the Cañon City Municipal Code, the provisions of Title 17 shall prevail and supersede any conflicting provisions of the International Building Code, but only to the extent necessary to resolve the conflict.

 

    G.  Section 102.4 is hereby amended by the addition of the following sentence:

      All references to the International Plumbing Code, International Private Sewage Disposal Code and the International Property Maintenance Code are hereby deleted.

 

    H.  Section 103 of the International Building Code is deleted in its entirety and the following section is substituted therefor:

 

      Section 103.       Organization and Enforcement.

 

      103.1 Creation of Enforcement Agency. There is hereby established in this jurisdiction a code enforcement agency which shall be under the administrative and operational control of the building official.

 

      103.2 Appointment. The building official shall be appointed by the City Administrator of the jurisdiction.

 

      103.3 Deputies. In accordance with the prescribed procedures of this jurisdiction and with the concurrence of the City Administrator, the building official shall have the authority to appoint technical officers, inspectors, plans examiners and other employees. Such employees shall have powers as delegated by the building official.

 

    I.    Section 105.2 of the International Building Code is deleted and the following section is substituted therefor:

 

      Section 105.2 Work Exempt from permit. A building permit shall not be required for the following:

 

      1.        One story detached accessory structures used as tool and storage sheds, playhouses and similar uses, provided the floor area does not exceed 120 square feet;

 

      2.        Retaining walls which are not over 4 feet in height measured from the bottom of the footing to the top of the wall, unless supporting a surcharge or impounding Class I, II or III-A liquids;

 

      3.        Water tanks supported directly upon grade if the capacity does not exceed 5,000 gallons and the ratio of the height to diameter or width does not exceed 2 to 1;

 

      4.        Sidewalks and driveways not more than 30 inches above adjacent grade and not over any basement or story below and are not part of an accessible route. (located entirely with property lines);

 

      5.        Painting, papering, tiling, carpeting, cabinets, counter tops and similar finish work;

 

      6.        Temporary motion picture, television and theater stage sets and scenery;

 

      7.        Prefabricated swimming pools accessory to a Group R, Division 3 Occupancy, in which the pool walls are entirely above grade and if the capacity does not exceed 5,000 gallons;

 

      8.        Shade cloth structures constructed for nursery or agricultural purposes and not including service systems;

 

      9.        Swings and other playground equipment accessory to detached one- and two-family dwellings.

 

      10.      Window awnings supported by an exterior wall that do not project more than 54″ from the exterior wall and do not require additional support of Group R-3 and Group U occupancies;

 

      11.      Nonfixed and movable fixtures, cases, racks, counters and partitions not over 5′9″ in height.

 

      Unless otherwise exempted, separate plumbing, electrical and mechanical permits shall be required for the above exempted items. The State of Colorado has jurisdiction over the Electrical and Plumbing Code and the gas piping section of the International Fuel Gas Code.

 

      Exemption from the permit requirements in this Code shall not be deemed to grant authorization for any work to be done in violation of the provisions of this Code or any other law or ordinance of this jurisdiction.

 

    J.    Section 110.2 of the International Building Code shall be amended to read as follows:

 

110.2 Certificate issued. After the building official inspects the building or structure and finds no violations of the provisions of this code or other laws that are enforced by the department of building safety, that all conditions imposed on the building permit have been satisfied and all applicable requirements of Chapters 16 and 17 of the Cañon City Municipal Code have been met, the building official shall issue a certificate of occupancy that contains the following:

 

    K.  Section 107.3 is hereby deleted in its entirety.

    L.   Section 108.6 of the International Building Code is hereby deleted in its entirety and the following substituted therefor:

 

      Section 108.6 Fee Refunds. The code official shall authorize the refunding of fees as follows:

 

      1.        The full amount of any fee paid hereunder which was erroneously paid or collected.

 

      2.        Not more than 50% of the fee paid when no work has been done under a permit issued in accordance with this Code.

 

      3.        Not more than 50% of the plan review fee paid when an application for a permit for which a plan review fee has been paid is withdrawn or canceled before any plan review effort has been expended.

 

      The code official shall not authorize the refunding of any fee paid, except upon written application filed by the original permittee not later than 180 days after the date of fee payment.

 

    M.  Section 108 of the International Building Code is hereby amended by the addition of the following:

 

      Section 108.7 Fee Schedule. The building permit fee schedule shall be that as set forth in Chapter 15.07 of the Cañon City Municipal Code.

 

    N.  Section 109.3.1 of the International Building Code is deleted in its entirety and the following section is substituted therefor:

 

      Section 109.3.1. Footing and Foundation Inspection. Footing, foundation and concrete slab and underfloor inspections shall be made at the option of the permit holder by either the City of Cañon City Building Department or by the registered design professional of record responsible for the design of the foundation. Inspections performed by the engineer or architect of record shall be recorded in the format as set forth on the Cañon City Foundation Signoff Letter. If in the opinion of the Building Official it is determined that the foundation system or any of its components are complex in nature the Building Official shall require said foundation system or its components be inspected by the registered design professional of record and said inspections shall be recorded in the format as set forth above. Setbacks must be verified by the Cañon City Building Department prior to pouring of concrete.

 

      Exception: Certain residential garages and storage buildings and commercial storage buildings are not required to be designed by a registered design professional as set forth in Section 1805.1.

 

    O.  The exception to Section 109.3.5 of the International Building Code is hereby deleted.

 

    P.   Section 113.4 of the International Building Code is hereby amended to add the following notation:

 

      “See Section 15.04.040 of the Cañon City Municipal Code, Penalties.”

 

    Q.  Section 1101 International Building Code is hereby amended by the addition of the following subsection:

 

    Section 1101.3. State and Federal Requirements Which Supersede International Building Code. In addition, any State or Federal requirements which are specifically required to be enforced by the local jurisdiction shall supersede conflicting provisions of the International Building Code. These may include: The Federal Fair Housing Act, The Americans with Disabilities Act, The 1973 Rehabilitation Act and Article 5 of Title 9, Colorado Revised Statutes, as amended (containing standards for accessible housing). The Council of Cañon City shall function as the board of appeals to hear and resolve appeals of orders, decisions, or determinations made by the Building Official regarding the application and interpretation of Article 5 of Title 9, C.R.S. See Chapter 2.52 of the Cañon City Municipal Code.

 

      Section 1101.4. Opt Out Right—Accessibility Standards.

 

      A.       Any owner required to obtain a permit under this Code, shall have the right to elect to opt out with respect to accessibility standards set forth in Chapter 11 of this Code for any project covered or to be covered by a permit.

      B.        An election to opt out may be made at or after the time the construction documents are submitted for review by delivering to the Building Official a notice of election to opt out (“Notice”) on a form provided by the Building Official.

      C.        Such Notice shall be dated and signed by the owner (or the owner’s authorized agent).

      D.       Such Notice shall contain:

      1.        A statement that the signatory on the Notice elects to opt out from the requirements of Chapter 11 of this Code;

      2.        A statement that said signatory understands and acknowledges that the project will be subject to applicable requirements of the Americans With Disabilities Act (and rules and regulations pertaining thereto, collectively “ADA”) notwithstanding the election to opt out;

      3.        A statement that the said signatory agrees to hold harmless, defend and indemnify the City of Cañon City and its officers and employees from and with respect to any claim based upon the City’s failure to enforce Chapter 11 of this Code in response to the Notice;

      4.        A statement that the signatory has provided (or will provide) a copy of the Notice to any general contractor or builder responsible for the project and to any other party considered by the owner to have a significant interest in the project;

      5.        A statement that the signatory understands, expects and agrees that the Building Official, in response to the Notice:

      i.         Will not enforce Chapter 11 with respect to the project;

      ii.        Will not inspect the work of the project for compliance with accessibility requirements set forth in Chapter 11;

      iii.       Will not withhold a certificate of occupancy for the project if it complies with all applicable code requirements other than those in Chapter 11.

      E.        A true and correct copy of any signed Notice shall be attached to the certificate of occupancy issued for the project. The original of such Notice shall be retained in the official records of the City.

      F.        All contractors, builders and owners, including those owners who elect to opt out, are encouraged by the City to adhere to the goals, intent and provisions of Chapter 11, the technical standards set forth in ANSI A117.1 and the accessibility standards provided for in the ADA.

      G.       The right to opt out provided for in this Section 1101.4 shall not be available with respect to new construction on raw ground and shall not apply with respect to the construction or installation of required infrastructure improvements, if any, that are associated with the project.

 

      Section 1101.5 Opting Out as a Means of Dispute Resolution.

 

      A.       An owner may elect to opt out with respect to Chapter 11 of this Code during the progress of the project if opting out will resolve a dispute between the owner and the Building Official (or the Building Official’s designee) regarding an accessibility requirement specified in Chapter 11. In such event, the Notice to be submitted to the Building Official shall be the same Notice as is provided for in Section 1101.4, except that the owner shall have the right to describe the disputed issue using an addendum to the form of Notice provided by the City. The right to opt out pursuant to this provision shall apply only to disputes concerning accessibility requirements set forth in Chapter 11 of this Code.

      B.        The right to opt out provided for in this Section 1101.5 shall not be available with respect to new construction on raw ground and shall not apply with respect to the construction or installation of required infrastructure improvements, if any, that are associated with the project.

 

    Q.  Section 1802.1 is hereby amended to add the following:

 

      The registered design professional shall be a geotechnical engineer or other individual with documented significant experience in this field. Such documentation shall be provided in the appropriate format from the State Board of Licensure for Architects, Engineers and Professional Land Surveyors when requested by the Cañon City Building Department.

 

    R.   Section 1802.2 of the International Building Code is hereby amended to add the following sentence:

 

      All foundation and soils investigations submitted shall be individual building site specific.

 

    S.   The exception to Section 1802.2 of the International Building Code is hereby deleted.

 

    T.   Section 1805.1 of the International Building Code is hereby amended to add the following after the first sentence of the first paragraph:

 

      The footings, foundations, floor slabs etc., shall be designed by a registered design professional and the plans depicting such professional design shall be signed, sealed and delivered to the Building Official along with the soils investigation and lab analysis required by Section 1802.1 of the International Building Code. This requirement shall not apply to one story detached residential garages and storage buildings not exceeding 800 square feet of floor area or to one story detached commercial storage buildings not exceeding 400 square feet of floor area.

 

    U.  Section 3001.2 of the International Building Code is hereby amended by the addition of the following:

 

      In the event there shall be a conflict between the International Building Code and the provisions of the Colorado Elevator and Escalator Certification Act, Article 5.5 of Title 9, C.R.S., the provisions of the Act shall prevail. In those instances the “Administrator” designated in said Act, or his or her designee, shall be solely responsible for all aspects of compliance with the Act. The City of Cañon City is not an “approved local jurisdiction” under the Act and will take no responsibility for enforcement of the Act.

 

    V.  Appendices B, D, E and F of the International Building Code are hereby deleted in their entirety.

    W.  Appendix G of the International Building Code shall read as follows:

 

      Appendix G. Requirements for flood-resistant construction shall be as set forth in the “Floodplain Regulations” as adopted by the City of Cañon City.

 

    X.  Section 3409 of the International Building Code is amended to add the following:

 

      Section 3409.1.5. Opt Out Right—Accessibility Standards for Existing Buildings.

 

      A.       Any owner required to obtain a permit under this Code, shall have the right to elect to opt out with respect to accessibility standards set forth in Section 3409 of this Code for any project within an existing building covered or to be covered by a permit.

      B.        An election to opt out may be made at or after the time the construction documents are submitted for review by delivering to the Building Official a notice of election to opt out (“Notice”) on a form provided by the Building Official.

      C.        Such Notice shall be dated and signed by the owner (or the owner’s authorized agent).

      D.       Such Notice shall contain:

      1.        A statement that the signatory on the Notice elects to opt out from the requirements of Section 3409 of this Code;

      2.        A statement that said signatory understands and acknowledges that the project will be subject to applicable requirements of the Americans With Disabilities Act (and rules and regulations pertaining thereto, collectively “ADA”) notwithstanding the election to opt out;

      3.        A statement that the said signatory agrees to hold harmless, defend and indemnify the City of Cañon City and its officers and employees from and with respect to any claim based upon the City’s failure to enforce Section 3409 of this Code in response to the Notice;

      4.        A statement that the signatory has provided (or will provide) a copy of the Notice to any general contractor or builder responsible for the project and to any other party considered by the owner to have a significant interest in the project;

      5.        A statement that the signatory understands, expects and agrees that the Building Official, in response to the Notice:

      i.         Will not enforce Section 3409 with respect to the project;

      ii.        Will not inspect the work of the project for compliance with accessibility requirements set forth in Section 3409;

      iii.       Will not withhold a certificate of occupancy for the project if it complies with all applicable code requirements other than those in Section 3409.

      E.        A true and correct copy of any signed Notice shall be attached to the certificate of occupancy issued for the project. The original of such Notice shall be retained in the official records of the City.

      F.        All contractors, builders and owners, including those owners who elect to opt out, are encouraged by the City to adhere to the goals, intent and provisions of Chapter 11 and Section 3409 of this Code, the technical standards set forth in ANSI A117.1 and the accessibility standards provided for in the ADA.

      G.       An election to opt out with respect to Section 3409 of this Code shall not relieve any permit holder and/or property owner of the obligation to construct or install required infrastructure improvements, if any, that are associated with the project.

 

      Section 3409.1.6. Opting Out as a Means of Dispute Resolution for Existing Buildings.

 

      A.       An owner may elect to opt out with respect to Section 3409 of this Code during the progress of the project if opting out will resolve a dispute between the owner and the Building Official (or the Building Official’s designee) regarding an accessibility requirement specified in Section 3409. In such event, the Notice to be submitted to the Building Official shall be the same Notice as is provided for in Section 3409.1.5 of this Code, except that the owner shall have the right to describe the disputed issue using an addendum to the form of Notice provided by the City. The right to opt out pursuant to this provision shall apply only to disputes concerning accessibility requirements set forth in Section 3409 of this Code and shall not apply with respect to the construction or installation of required infrastructure improvements, if any, that are associated with the project.

(Ord. 7-2019 § 1; Ord. 13-2012 §§ 1—5; Ord. 14-2009 § 1; Ord. 11-2008 § 1)

 

This topic has been modified. View the section for details. 15.04.035 Forms.
    The Building Official, with the assistance of the City Attorney, is hereby authorized to create, use, modify and/or replace any form contemplated or authorized in this Chapter 15.04, including, but not limited to, forms authorizing owners to “opt out” with respect to accessibility standards set forth in Chapter 11 and/or Section 3409 of the 2006 International Building Code, as adopted by the City. (Ord. 13-2012 § 6)

 

This topic has been modified. View the section for details. 15.04.040 Penalties.
    Any person who violates any provision of the International Building Code, as adopted and amended in this Chapter 15.04, is guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon conviction thereof, shall be punished by a fine in an amount that does not exceed the maximum fine provided for in Section 1.28.010. (Ord. 17-2013 § 53; Ord. 11-2008 § 1)

Chapter 15.06 INTERNATIONAL RESIDENTIAL CODE*
* CodeAlert: This topic has been affected by Ordinance No. 20-2020. To view amendments and newly added provisions, please refer to the CodeAlert Amendment List.


This topic has been modified. View the section for details. 15.06.010 Document adopted by reference—Contents.
    A.  Pursuant to Section 9 of Article XII of the Charter of the City and applicable provisions of Part 2 of Article 16 of Title 31 of the Colorado Revised Statutes, as amended, there is adopted as the one- and two-family residential building code of the City of Cañon City, by reference thereto, the International Residential Code, 2006 Edition, published by the International Code Council, 5203 Leesburg Pike, Suite 708, Falls Church, Virginia, 22041-3401, including the Chapters of the Appendix to said Code, and together with the errata sheet accompanying said International Residential Code (all of which is hereinafter referred to as the “International Residential Code”), all to have the same force and effect as if set forth herein in every particular.

    B.   The subject matter of the adopted Code includes comprehensive provisions and standards that shall apply to the construction, alteration, movement, enlargement, replacement, repair, equipment, use and occupancy, location, removal and demolition of detached one- and two-family dwellings and multiple single-family dwellings (townhouses) not more than three (3) stories in height with a separate means of egress and their accessory structures. (Ord. 11-2008 § 2)

 

This topic has been modified. View the section for details. 15.06.020 Copies for public use.
    At least one copy of the International Residential Code, 2006 Edition, as published by the International Code Council, certified by the Mayor and the City Clerk to be a true copy, has been and is now on file in the office of the City Clerk and may be inspected by any interested person between the hours of eight a.m. and five p.m., Monday through Friday, holidays excepted. (Ord. 11-2008 § 2)

 

This topic has been modified. View the section for details. 15.06.030 Additions, amendments and deletions to 2006 International Residential Code.
    A.  Section R101.1 is revised to read as follows:

 

      R101.1. Title. These provisions shall be known as the Residential Code for One- and Two-Family Dwellings of the City of Cañon City and shall be cited as such and will be referred to herein as “this Code.”

 

    B.   Section R102.4 is hereby amended by the addition of the following two paragraphs:

 

      All references to the International Plumbing Code, International Private Sewage Disposal Code and the International Property Maintenance Code are hereby deleted.

 

      In the event there shall be a conflict between the provisions of the International Residential Code and the provisions of Title 17 (Zoning Ordinance) of the Cañon City Municipal Code, the provisions of Title 17 shall prevail and supersede any conflicting provisions of the International Residential Code but only to the extent necessary to resolve the conflict.

 

    C.   Section R103 of the International Residential Code is deleted in its entirety and the following section is substituted therefor:

 

      Section R103. Organization and Enforcement.

      R103.1 Creation of Enforcement Agency. There is hereby established in this jurisdiction a code enforcement agency which shall be under the administrative and operational control of the building official.

      R103.2 Appointment. The building official shall be appointed by the City Administrator of the jurisdiction. In the absence of the building official, the City Administrator may appoint building inspectors to perform the duties and obligations of the building official under this Code.

      R103.3 Deputies. In accordance with the prescribed procedures of this jurisdiction and with the concurrence of the City Administrator, the building official shall have the authority to appoint technical officers, inspectors, plans examiners and other employees. Such employees shall have powers as delegated by the building official.

 

    D.  Section R105.2 of the International Residential Code is deleted and the following section is substituted therefor:

 

      Section R105.2 Work Exempt From Permit. A building permit shall not be required for the following:

 

      1.        One story detached accessory structures used as tool and storage sheds, playhouses and similar uses, provided the floor area does not exceed 120 square feet;

 

      2.        Moveable cases, counters and partitions not over 5 feet high;

 

      3.        Retaining walls which are not over 4 feet in height measured from the bottom of the footing to the top of the wall, unless supporting a surcharge or impounding Class I, II or III-A liquids;

 

      4.        Water tanks supported directly upon grade if the capacity does not exceed 5,000 gallons and the ratio of the height to diameter or width does not exceed 2 to 1;

 

      5.        Sidewalks and driveways not more than 30 inches above grade and not over any basement or story below (located entirely with property lines);

 

      6.        Painting, papering, tiling, carpeting, cabinets, counter tops and similar finish work;

 

      7.        Window awnings supported by an exterior wall of Group R-3, as applicable in Section 101.2 and Group U occupancies;

 

      8.        Prefabricated swimming pools accessory to a Group R, Division 3 Occupancy, in which the pool walls are entirely above grade and if the capacity does not exceed 5,000 gallons;

 

      9.        Temporary motion picture, television and theater stage sets and scenery;

 

      10.      Shade cloth structures constructed for nursery or agricultural purposes and not including service systems;

 

      11.      Swings and other playground equipment accessory to one- and two-family dwellings.

 

      Unless otherwise exempted, separate plumbing, electrical and mechanical permits shall be required for the above exempted items.

 

      Exemption from the permit requirements in this Code shall not be deemed to grant authorization for any work to be done in violation of the provisions of this Code or any other law or ordinances of this jurisdiction.

 

    E.   Section R107.3 is hereby deleted in its entirety.

    F.   Section R108.6 of the International Residential Code is hereby deleted in its entirety and the following substituted therefor:

 

      Section R108.6 Fee Refunds. The code official shall authorize the refunding of fees as follows:

 

      1.        The full amount of any fee paid hereunder which was erroneously paid or collected.

 

      2.        Not more than 50% of the fee paid when no work has been done under a permit issued in accordance with this Code.

 

      3.        Not more than 50% of the plan review fee paid when an application for a permit for which a plan review fee has been paid is withdrawn or canceled before any plan review effort has been expended.

 

      The code official shall not authorize the refunding of any fee paid, except upon written application filed by the original permittee not later than 180 days after the date of fee payment.

 

    G.  Section R108 of the International Residential Code is hereby amended by the addition of the following:

 

      Section R108.7 Fee Schedule. The building permit fee schedule shall be that as set forth in Chapter 15.07 of the Cañon City Municipal Code.

 

    H.  Section 109.1.1 of the International Residential Code is deleted in its entirety and the following section is substituted therefor:

 

      Section 109.1.1. Footing and Foundation Inspection. Footing, foundation and concrete slab and underfloor inspections shall be made at the option of the permit holder by either the City of Cañon City Building Department or by the registered design professional of record responsible for the design of the foundation. Inspections performed by the engineer or architect of record shall be recorded in the format as set forth on the Cañon City Foundation Signoff Letter. If in the opinion of the Building Official it is determined that the foundation system or any of its components are complex in nature the Building Official shall require said foundation system or its components be inspected by the registered design professional of record and said inspections shall be recorded in the format as set forth above. Setbacks must be verified by the Cañon City Building Department prior to pouring of concrete.

 

      Exception: Residential garage and storage buildings are not required to be designed by a registered design profession as set forth in Section R401.5.

    K.  Section R112 of the International Residential Code is deleted in its entirety. (See Chapter 2.52 of the Cañon City Municipal Code for appeals of administrative decisions.)

      Section 401.5. Footing, Foundation, Floor Slab, etc. Design. Chapter 15.07 BUILDING PERMIT FEES*
* CodeAlert: This topic has been affected by Ordinance No. 20-2020. To view amendments and newly added provisions, please refer to the CodeAlert Amendment List.


This topic has been modified. View the section for details. 15.07.010 Statement of intent.
    It is the intent and goal of the City to establish and collect building permit fees and charges that will generate sufficient revenue to cover the City’s direct and indirect costs of maintaining and operating its Building Department. (Ord. 1-2009 § 1)

 

This topic has been modified. View the section for details. 15.07.020 Basic formula.
    Except as otherwise provided in this chapter, building permit fees for construction of buildings within the City shall be calculated on a case-by-case basis using the following formula:

 

    Permit Fee = Gross Area x Square Foot Construction Cost x Permit Fee Multiplier

 

(Ord. 1-2009 § 1)

 

This topic has been modified. View the section for details. 15.07.025 Alternative method for calculating permit fees.
    A.  As an alternative to using the basic formula set forth in Section 15.07.020, an applicant for a building permit may elect to have the building permit fee calculated using the “permit value” for the building, structure or other improvement to be constructed, altered or repaired, as reasonably estimated in good faith by the applicant at the time of application.

    B.   If this alternative method of calculating the permit fee is elected by the applicant, such estimated permit value shall be multiplied times the Permit Fee Multiplier to determine the amount of the permit fee.

    C.   In order to document the estimate of permit value, the applicant, at the time of application, shall deliver to the Building Official a true and correct copy of a fully-executed construction contract or contracts, as the case may be, covering all work to be covered by the permit.

    D.  Should any such contract be amended or otherwise modified following the issuance of the building permit with a resulting change in the contract price, the applicant shall notify the Building Official in writing of such amendment or modification within ten (10) days following such amendment or modification and the permit fee shall be recalculated by multiplying the permit value indicated by the changed contract price times the Permit Fee Multiplier used in the original calculation of the permit fee.

    E.   Unless otherwise agreed in writing, any increase or decrease in the permit fee shall be paid or refunded, as the case may be, within thirty (30) days following the recalculation of the permit fee. Should subsequent amendments or modifications be made that increase or decrease the contract price, the same process will be followed with respect to each such amendment or modification until the project has been completed. The Building Official shall require: a final copy of each contract, as modified and/or amended; copies of all change orders; and other evidences of actual cost prior to issuing a certificate of occupancy. Final building permit value shall be set by the Building Official using the materials provided by the applicant as a guide. No certificate of occupancy shall be issued in the absence of full payment of the applicable permit fee, including any increases due to recalculation of the permit fee.

    F.   Permit valuations for purposes of the election that may be made pursuant to Subsection A of this section shall include the total value of all work, including labor and materials, for which the permit is to be issued, and shall include profit, design and construction activity, as well as all equipment and systems to be covered by the permit. All estimated permit valuations shall be verified by copies of one or more fully-executed construction contracts and/or other similar documentation deemed appropriate by the Building Official. All copies of such materials shall be retained by the Building Official in accordance with the City’s written records retention policy.

    G.  If the applicant fails to cooperate with the Building Official by failing to provide true and correct copies of contracts and/or copies of amendments and/or change orders affecting the cost of a project, the building permit fee shall be calculated or recalculated, as the case may be, using the basic formula set forth in Section 15.07.020. (Ord. 7-2013 § 1)

 

This topic has been modified. View the section for details. 15.07.030 Definitions.
    Unless the context clearly indicates otherwise, for purposes of this Chapter 15.07, the following terms shall have the following meanings:

    A.  “Net Cost Recovery Factor” means the annual proposed budget for the Building Department (representing the direct costs of operating and maintaining the Building Department) plus estimated indirect costs of the Building Department as certified by the Director of Finance on or before December 1st for use in calculating the Permit Fee Multiplier that will be used to calculate building permit fees during the following calendar year. All estimated indirect costs shall be based upon historical data and reasonable projections of indirect costs of operating and maintaining the Building Department during the calendar year with respect to which the annual proposed budget will apply.

    B.   “Gross Area” means the gross area of the building with respect to which the building permit fee is to be assessed, expressed in square feet.

    C.   “Permit Fee Multiplier” means the multiplier used in calculating building permit fees. For the period beginning February 1, 2009 and ending December 31, 2009, the permit fee multiplier shall be 0.00998. Thereafter, the permit fee multiplier will be recalculated annually as provided in Section 15.07.070, according to the following formula:

 

Permit Fee Multiplier = Net Cost Recovery Factor / Total Projected Construction Value

    D.  “Square Foot Construction Cost” means the average construction cost per square foot, taking into account the classification/occupancy group of any proposed building and the type of construction to be used, as determined with respect to the most recent Building Valuation Data table (“BVD table”) published by the International Code Council (“ICC”). (Note: BVD tables are currently published in the ICC’s Building Safety Journal during February and August of each year and may be accessed on the ICC’s website at www.iccsafe.com.)

    E.   “Total Projected Construction Value” means a reasonable projection of the value of all anticipated new construction in the City for the following calendar year. Total Projected Construction Value shall be determined by the Director of Finance (or designee) and approved by the City Administrator on or before December 1st of each year. (Ord. 1-2009 § 1)

 

This topic has been modified. View the section for details. 15.07.040 Other projects requiring permits.
    When a building permit is required under the International Building Code adopted by the City for which no average construction costs are shown on the BVD table published by the ICC, the building permit fee shall be calculated based upon good faith estimates of actual construction costs made by the permit applicant and approved by the Building Official. In such cases, the building permit fee will be determined by multiplying the approved estimated construction cost of the project times the then applicable permit fee multiplier. Examples of projects to which this provision may apply include: the construction of fences; installation of siding; and re-roofing of existing structures. (Note: See Section 105.1 of the IBC, 2006 Edition.) (Ord. 1-2009 § 1)

 

This topic has been modified. View the section for details. 15.07.050 Discontinuation of BVD table.
    If the ICC should discontinue publishing the BVD table, the last published BVD table shall be used to calculate and determine building permit fees until City Council has selected a suitable alternative by amending this chapter. (Ord. 1-2009 § 1)

 

This topic has been modified. View the section for details. 15.07.060 Other inspections and fees.
    In addition to building permit fees, the Building Department is authorized to bill and collect additional charges for certain services, as follows:

 

Service

Charge

A.

Inspections outside of normal business hours (minimum charge—two hours)

$50.00 per hour

B.

Reinspection fees assessed under provisions of Section 108.8

$50.00 per hour

C.

Inspections for which no fee is specifically indicated (minimum charge—one-half hour)

$50.00 per hour

D.

Additional plan review required by changes, additions or revisions to plans

$50.00 per hour

E.

For use of outside consultants for plan checking and inspections, or both

Actual Costs

(Ord. 1-2009 § 1)

 

This topic has been modified. View the section for details. 15.07.070 Annual revisions to permit fee multiplier.
    The permit fee multiplier shall be revised once annually, on or about December 1st, beginning December 1, 2009, for use in calculating building permit fees in the following calendar year. (Ord. 1-2009 § 1)

Chapter 15.08 UNIFORM HOUSING CODE*
* CodeAlert: This topic has been affected by Ordinance No. 20-2020. To view amendments and newly added provisions, please refer to the CodeAlert Amendment List.

    B.   At least one copy of the Uniform Housing Code have been or are now filed with the office of the City Clerk. (Ord. 5-1996 § 2)

(Ord. 5-1996 § 2)

 

This topic has been modified. View the section for details. 15.08.030 Additions, amendments and deletions.

The City Council is hereby designated as the board to finally interpret the provisions of this Code and to hear appeals provided for hereunder in accordance with Chapter 2.52 of this Municipal Code. Copies of all rules, regulations and decisions of the City Council shall be reduced to writing and made available to the general public and the appellant.

 

    C.   Wherever the term “Housing Advisory and Appeals Board” or “Board of Appeals” is used in said Uniform Housing Code, the same shall mean the City Council.

    D.  All references to “Uniform Mechanical Code” or “Mechanical Code” contained on the Uniform Housing Code are deleted.

    E.   All references made to the “Uniform Building Code” shall mean the 1994 Edition which is currently in effect.

    F.   Section 501 of the Uniform Housing Code is deleted and the following Section 501 is substituted therefor:

    G.  Section 502.2 of the Uniform Housing Code is deleted and the following of Section 502.2 is substituted therefor:

    H.  Chapters 12 and 13 of the Uniform Housing Code are deleted in their entirety.

    I.    Item 3 of Subsection (c) of Section 1401 of the Uniform Housing Code is deleted in its entirety.

    J.    Chapters 15 and 16 of the Uniform Housing Code are deleted in their entirety.

    K.  Subsection 1001.11 of Chapter 10 hereby repealed and re-enacted to read as follows:

 

      1001.11 Hazardous or unsanitary premises. Those premises on which an accumulation of weeds, vegetation, junk, unsightly or inoperable vehicles, unsightly vehicle parts, dead organic matter, debris, garbage, offal, rat harborage, stagnant water, combustible materials, and similar materials or condition constitute fire, health or safety hazards.

 

    L.   Section 401 of Chapter 4 is hereby amended by the addition thereto of definitions for “unsightly or inoperable vehicles” and “unsightly vehicle parts,” as follows:

 

      Unsightly or Inoperable Vehicle means any motor vehicle originally manufactured for operation on public streets and highways which; has:

      1.        More than two windows broken, shattered, or missing; or

      2.        One or more portions of the body missing or noticeably or strikingly damaged, such as hood, fender, trunk door, door, roof or panel; or

      3.        One or more of the wheels or tires missing and the vehicle is not supported by a jack or block; or

      4.        Had its power plant, drivetrain, axles, or other similar necessary parts removed.

      Unsightly Vehicles does not include a motor vehicle which:

      1.        Is within a fully enclosed building; or

      2.        Is completely encased or covered by a tarpaulin, canvas, cloth or plastic (not transparent) cover and made secure by attaching same to the vehicle or part or to the ground or hidden from sight by a 6-foot high privacy fence; or

      3.        Is exempt from registration under the provisions of Section 42-3-103, Colorado Revised Statutes.

 

      Unsightly Vehicle Part means a major body or mechanical part originally manufactured as part of a motor vehicle for replacement or repair of any motor vehicle, such as engine, differential, transmission, transfer case, axle housing, driveshaft, hood, fender, trunk, door, roof or panel.

 

      Unsightly Vehicle part does not include any motor vehicle part which is within a fully enclosed building.

(Ord. 5-1996 § 2)

 

This topic has been modified. View the section for details. 15.08.040 Inconsistencies.
    If there should be any inconsistency between the provision of the chapter and the provisions of Chapter 15.04 of this Municipal Code, the provisions of Chapter 15.04 shall prevail. (Ord. 5-1996 § 2)

 

This topic has been modified. View the section for details. 15.08.050 Unlawful acts designated—Misdemeanor.
    A.  The following penalty clause contained in the Uniform Housing Code is herewith set forth and adopted:

 

      Section 204. No person firm or corporation, whether as owner, lessee, sublessee or occupant, shall erect, construct, enlarge, alter, repair, move, improve, remove, demolish, equip, use, occupy or maintain any building or premises, or cause or permit the same to be done, contrary to or in violation of any of the provisions of this Code or nay order issued by the Building Official hereunder. Any person violating the provisions of this Section shall be guilty of a misdemeanor for each day such violation continues.

 

    B. (Ord. 17-2013 § 55; Ord. 5-1996 § 2)

Chapter 15.12 INTERNATIONAL MECHANICAL CODE*
* CodeAlert: This topic has been affected by Ordinance No. 20-2020. To view amendments and newly added provisions, please refer to the CodeAlert Amendment List.

    A.     B. The adopted Code shall also regulate those mechanical systems, system components, equipment and appliances specifically addressed therein. (Ord. 11-2008 § 3)

      Section 103. Organization and Enforcement.

      103.2 Appointment. The building official shall be appointed by the City Administrator of the jurisdiction.

 

      103.3 Deputies. Such employees shall have powers as delegated by the building official.

 

    D.  Section 106.5.2 is hereby amended by addition of the following:

 

      Section 106.5.2. Fee Schedule. The fees for work shall be as set forth in Table 1-A of the 1994 Uniform Mechanical Code.

 

    E.   Items 2 and 3 of Section 106.5.3 are hereby deleted and the following substituted therefor:

 

      Item 2. Not more than 50% of the permit fee paid when no work has been done under a permit issued in accordance with this Code.

 

      Item 3. Not more than 50% of the plan review fee paid when an application for a permit for which a plan review fee has been paid is withdrawn or canceled before any plan review effort has been expended.

 

    F.   Section 108.4 of the International Mechanical Code is hereby amended to add the following notation:

 

      “See Section 15.12.040 of the Cañon City Municipal Code, Penalties.”

 

    G.  Section 109 of the International Mechanical Code is hereby deleted in its entirety. (See Chapter 2.52 of the Cañon City Municipal Code for appeals of administrative decisions.)

    H.  Section 301.2 is hereby deleted in its entirety.

    I.    Section 301.6 is hereby deleted and the following substituted therefor:

 

Section 301.6. Plumbing Connections. Potable water supply and building drainage system connections to appliances regulated by this Code shall be in accordance with the Plumbing Code currently adopted by the State of Colorado.

 

    J.    The exception to Section 306.2 is hereby amended by the addition of a second paragraph to read as follows:

 

      Access openings to the passageway shall be of sufficient height, width and length to permit removal of the furnace, but in no case less than 30 inches wide, 30 inches high and 48 inches long if on the exterior, or if through a trap door located on the inside of the building, an opening 30 inches by 30 inches and a depth equal to the longest dimension of the appliance measured from the bottom of the floor joist.

(Ord. 11-2008 § 3)

 

This topic has been modified. View the section for details. 15.12.040 Penalties.
    Any person who violates any provision of the International Mechanical Code, as adopted and amended in this Chapter 15.12, is guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon conviction thereof, shall be punished by a fine in an amount that does not exceed the maximum fine provided for in Section 1.28.010. (Ord. 17-2013 § 56; Ord. 11-2008 § 3)

Chapter 15.42 FIRE PROTECTION AND EMS IMPACT FEE
15.42.010 Short title, authority, and applicability.
    A.  Specific authority to impose impact fees for the benefit of the Fire District was granted to the Council of Cañon City by the qualified electors of the City during the City’s general election on November 1, 2005. Additional general authority is identified in Ordinance No. 9, Series of 2005, through which the question decided by the voters was referred to them.

    B.   Prior to the distribution of any impact fees collected pursuant to this chapter, the Fire District must enter into an intergovernmental agreement with the City covering the collection, distribution and use of impact fees.

    C.   This chapter shall apply to all portions of the City, which is entirely within the boundaries of the Cañon City Area Fire Protection District. (Ord. 12-2019 § 9)

 

15.42.020 Intent and purpose.
    A.  The provisions of this chapter are consistent with City plans and policies, as identified in Ordinance 9, Series of 2005 and elsewhere, and also are intended to implement and be consistent with the Local Government Land Use Control Enabling Act, Section 29-20-101, C.R.S., et seq.

    B.   The purpose of this chapter is to regulate the use and development of land so as to ensure that new development bears a proportionate share of the cost of capital expenditures necessary to provide fire protection and emergency medical services in the city, as contemplated by Colorado state statutes and City plans and policies. (Ord. 12-2019 § 9)

 

15.42.030 Rules of construction.
    A.  The provisions of this chapter shall be liberally construed so as to effectively carry out its purpose in the interest of the public health, safety, and welfare.

    B.   The phrase used for includes arranged for, designed for, maintained for, or occupied for.

    C.   The word person includes an individual, a corporation, a partnership, an incorporated association, or any other similar entity.

    D.  The land use types listed in Section 15.42.060 shall have the same meaning as listed under the City’s Zoning Ordinance and subdivision regulations. (Ord. 12-2019 § 9)

 

15.42.040 Definitions.
    As used in this chapter:

    A.  “Building Permit” means an official document or certification which is issued by the City Building Department and which authorizes the construction, alteration, enlargement, conversion, reconstruction, remodeling, rehabilitation, erection, demolition, moving, or repair of a building or structure. In the case of a change in use or occupancy of an existing building or structure, the term shall specifically include certificate of occupancy and occupancy permits, as those permits are defined or required by City regulations, including, but not limited to, uniform codes adopted by the City.

    B.   “Capital Facility” includes planning, site improvements, off-site improvements associated with new or expanded facilities, buildings and equipment, including communications equipment, with an average useful life of at least five (5) years, but excludes maintenance and operations.

    C.   “City Official” means the City’s Zoning Administrator and/or any other City officer or official that the Council of Cañon City may designate to administer the various provisions of this chapter.

    D.  “Emergency Medical Services” commonly referred to as EMS, means the provision of advanced life support services, as defined and discussed in Title 25, Article 3.5, C.R.S.

    E.   “Fee Payer” is a person who applies to the City of Cañon City for the issuance of a building permit or manufactured home permit for a type of land development activity specified in Subsection 15.42.060(A) of this chapter.

    F.   “Fire District” means the Cañon City Area Fire Protection District, a Colorado special district (providing services within a geographic area that includes all land within the City of Cañon City) which is authorized to provide fire protection and/or emergency medical and rescue services and such other similar services as may be authorized by Colorado law.

    G.  “Fire Protection” means the prevention and extinguishment of fires; the protection of life and property from fire; and the enforcement of properly adopted fire prevention codes.

    H.  “Living Unit” is any temporary or permanent unit utilized for or designed or intended to be utilized for human habitation.

    I.    “Manufactured Home Permit” shall mean any certification of a permanent foundation for a manufactured home established upon a permanent foundation on any lot or parcel within the city. When no certification of a permanent foundation is required, “manufactured home permit” shall mean the required approval as to location (relative to applicable setback requirements) with respect to any manufactured home established within a mobile home park, mobile home subdivision or elsewhere within the city, provided that the manufactured home so located is the first living unit established on the space, lot or parcel in question. When no approval as to location is required, an application for City water service shall trigger the obligation for the owner of the land upon which a manufactured home is established, as the first living unit thereon, to pay the impact fee. It is City Council’s intention that this definition be broad enough to ensure that Fire Protection and EMS Impact Fees will be imposed and payable with respect to all new living units established in the city by reason of the installation of manufactured housing on lots, parcels or spaces where no living unit previously existed. When a manufactured home is established for the first time on a newly created lot or space within a mobile home park, the Fire Protection and EMS Impact Fee shall be paid by the owner of the mobile home park, but may be subject to reimbursement by the owner of the manufactured home pursuant to a written agreement between the owner of the mobile home park and the owner of the manufactured home.

    J.    “Rescue” means what commonly is called rescue, a service, which generally includes the provision of basic life support, and the extrication of accident victims from entrapment. (Ord. 12-2019 § 9)

 

15.42.050 Imposition of Fire Protection and EMS Impact Fee.
    A.  There is hereby imposed upon new development within the City a Fire Protection and EMS Impact Fee. Any person who, after the effective date of the ordinance adopting this chapter, seeks to develop land located within the City, by applying for the issuance of a building permit or manufactured home permit for one of the land use types specified in Section 15.42.060 of this chapter, shall be required to pay a Fire Protection and EMS Impact Fee in the manner and amount set forth in this chapter.

    B.   No building permit or manufactured home permit for any land use types specified in Section 15.42.060 of this chapter shall be issued by the City unless and until the impact fee hereby required has been paid. (Ord. 12-2019 § 9)

 

15.42.060 Computation of the amount of Fire Protection and EMS Impact Fee.
    A.  At the option of the fee payer, the amount of the fee may be determined by the schedules set forth below:

    1.   Single-family residence: three hundred four dollars ($304.00).

    2.   Multifamily residence: three hundred four dollars ($304.00) for each unit of family residence and/or for each apartment, town home, condominium or similar living unit (e.g., six hundred eight dollars ($608.00) for duplex; nine hundred twelve dollars ($912.00) for triplex, etc.).

    3.   Non-residential building not including hotel/motel: Total square footage of the building divided by two thousand (2000*) and multiplied by three hundred four dollars ($304.00) (e.g., nine thousand (9000) square foot nonresidential structure would be divided by two thousand (2000). The dividend of 4.5 would then be multiplied by three hundred four dollars ($304.00) for a total impact fee of one thousand three hundred sixty-eight dollars ($1368.00)).

 

*      2000 square feet is the average residential unit size for Fire District as projected by historic and current development and shall serve as one “residential equivalent unit” to be used in calculating a proportionate fee for commercial development.

 

    4.   Hotel/motel: Total square footage divided by two thousand (2000) and then multiplied by three hundred four dollars ($304.00) and additionally multiplied by 2.5**

**    It is apparent from examining Fire Department and EMS responses of different land use types that land uses with higher densities have more incidents requiring Fire Department responses than land uses with lower population densities. Hotels and motels demand the highest per square foot response. Conservatively, this factor is 2.5 times the residential equivalency.

 

    B.   When a change of use, redevelopment or modification of an existing use requires the issuance of a building permit or manufactured home permit, the impact fee shall be based upon the net increase in the impact for the new use, as compared to the impact of the previous use.

    C.   The person applying for the issuance of a building permit or manufactured home permit may, at such person’s option, submit evidence to the entity (i.e., Fire District or City) which provides fire protection and/or emergency medical services for the land in question indicating that the fees set out in subsection A of this Section 15.42.060 are not applicable to the particular development. Based upon convincing and competent evidence, said entity may adjust the fee accordingly and shall inform the City official of this adjustment. (Ord. 12-2019 § 9)

 

15.42.070 Payment of fee.
    A.  The fee payer shall pay the Fire Protection and EMS Impact Fee to the City, through its Building Department, prior to the issuance of a building permit or manufactured home permit which may be required for development listed in the schedule in Subsection 15.42.060(A). No building permit or manufactured home permit may be issued for any development listed in Subsection 15.42.060(A) until such fee has been paid.

    B.   No impact fee is required for the issuance of any building permit for residential use or manufactured home installation, which does not result in an additional living unit.

    C.   All monies collected pursuant to this chapter shall be properly identified as Fire Protection and EMS Impact Fees and earmarked and handled as provided in Section 15.42.080 of this chapter. (Ord. 12-2019 § 9)

 

15.42.080 Earmarking and handling of Fire Protection and EMS Impact Fees.
    A.  All monies collected and paid as Fire Protection and EMS Impact Fees pursuant to Sections 15.42.060 and 15.42.070, respectively, shall be earmarked as Fire Protection and EMS Impact Fees in a dedicated ledger account within the General Fund.

    B.   Monies so earmarked shall be transferred to the Fire District in the manner established by any relevant agreement, but at least once per fiscal period. All monies collected pursuant to this chapter must be used only in accordance with the provisions of Section 15.42.090.

    C.   The Director of Finance shall do all things necessary to ensure that all monies collected and handled by the City pursuant to this chapter shall be accounted for in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles. (Ord. 12-2019 § 9)

 

15.42.090 Use of funds.
    A.  Monies collected from Fire Protection and EMS Impact Fees shall be used for the purpose of contributing toward and defraying the cost of capital facilities of the Fire District that are used to provide fire protection and emergency medical services. Except as provided in Subsection C of this Section 15.42.090, impact fee collections shall be used exclusively for the acquisition and/or expansion of capital facilities of the Fire District needed to provide the fire protection and EMS services that are or will be made necessary by development within the city. Funds shall be expended in the order in which they are collected.

    B.   The City shall enter into one or more intergovernmental agreements, as authorized by the statutes of the State of Colorado, concerning the use of monies collected as the Fire Protection and EMS Impact Fees pursuant to this chapter. Such agreement shall provide for the collection, investment, transmission and expenditure of such impact fees and provide for full and accurate accounting with respect to said monies.

    C.   The City shall be entitled to retain up to four percent (4%) of all impact fees it collects as an administrative fee to offset the costs of administering this chapter. (Ord. 12-2019 § 9)

 

15.42.100 Refund of fee paid.
    A.  If a building permit or manufactured home permit expires and no construction has been commenced, then the fee payer shall be entitled to a refund of the Fire Protection and EMS Impact Fee paid as a condition for its issuance, minus the amount of the fee retained by the City as an administrative fee pursuant to Subsection 15.42.090(C), which amount shall be non-refundable. If the amount retained by the City was four percent (4%) of the impact fee collected, the fee payer shall be entitled to a refund equal to ninety-six percent (96%) of the impact fee paid. No interest will be paid to the fee payer on refunds due to the failure to commence construction.

    B.   Any funds not expended or encumbered by the end of the calendar quarter immediately following eight (8) years from the date the impact fee was paid shall, upon application of the fee payer within one hundred eighty (180) days of that date, be returned to the fee payer by the Fire District with interest at the rate of three percent (3%) per annum. Any intergovernmental agreement between the City and the Fire District shall so provide. (Ord. 12-2019 § 9)

 

15.42.110 Exemptions and credits.
    A.  The following shall be exempted from payment of the impact fee:

    1.   Alteration or expansion of an existing building or use of land where no additional living units are created, where the use is not changed, and where no additional demand for fire protection and EMS/rescue services will be produced over and above that produced by the existing use;

    2.   The construction of accessory buildings or structures which will not produce additional living units over and above those in the principal building or use of the land;

    3.   The replacement of a building, manufactured home, or structure that was in place on the effective date of the ordinance codified in this chapter, or the replacement of a building, manufactured home, or structure that was constructed subsequent thereto and for which the correct impact fee had been paid or otherwise provided for, with a new building, manufactured home, or structure of the same use, provided that no additional trips will be produced over and above those produced by the original use of the land;

    4.   By mutual agreement between the Fire District and the City, on the development of low- or moderate-income housing or affordable employee housing as defined by the City or state statutes; and

    5.   The construction or change in use of any building or structure owned or occupied by the City for purposes of conducting City business or performing City services, as determined solely by the Council of Cañon City.

    B.   Credits.

    1.   All improvements to and/or land dedications for fire protection and EMS required under a City development approval shall be credited against impact fees up to the total of the impact fees due. When the fee payer proposes credit for construction, he or she shall present cost estimates prepared by qualified professionals to be used in determining the amount of credit. When the fee payer proposes credit for land dedication, he or she shall present property appraisals prepared by qualified professionals and a certified copy of the most recent assessment of the property for tax purposes to be used in determining the amount of the credit. However, the Council of Cañon City and Fire District Board retain the right to determine the amount to be credited by preparing engineering and construction cost estimates and/or property appraisals, at the sole cost of the Fire District, for those improvements and/or land dedications. Such credits shall be calculated so as to be consistent with Section 29-10-104.5, C.R.S.

    2.   Fee payers claiming credits for construction and/or land dedication shall submit documentation sufficient to permit the City and/or Fire District to determine whether such credits claimed are due and, if so, the amount of such credits.

    C.   Exemptions or credits must be claimed by the fee payer at the time of the application for a building permit or manufactured home permit. Any exemptions or credits not so claimed shall be deemed waived by the fee payer. (Ord. 12-2019 § 9)

 

15.42.120 Appeal.
    Any decision made by the City official, his or her designee, or the Building Official in the course of administering this chapter may be appealed in accordance with those procedures set forth in Colorado statutes and court rules. Every intergovernmental agreement made pursuant to this chapter shall specifically incorporate this appeal procedure. (Ord. 12-2019 § 9)

 

15.42.130 Penalty and enforcement provision.
    A.  Any person who violates any provision of this chapter is guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon conviction thereof, shall be punished by a fine in an amount that does not exceed the maximum fine provided for in Section 1.28.010.

    B.   In addition to, or in lieu of, any criminal prosecution provided for in subsection A of this Section 15.42.130, the City of Cañon City or any fee payer shall have the power to sue for relief in civil court to enforce the provisions of this chapter; provided that all costs incurred by the City in bringing or defending any such suit shall be paid or reimbursed by the Fire District. The City will not file any suit permitted under this subsection unless asked to do so in writing by the Fire District Board. The City will promptly notify the Fire District if the City is sued (served with process naming it as a defendant) pursuant to this subsection.

 

    C.   Knowingly furnishing false information to the City and/or Fire District on any matter relating to the administration of this chapter shall constitute a violation of this chapter. (Ord. 12-2019 § 9)

 

15.42.140 Severability.
    If any section, phrase, sentence, or portion of this chapter is for any reason held invalid or unconstitutional by any court of competent jurisdiction, such portion shall be deemed a separate, distinct, and independent provision and such holding shall not affect the validity of the remaining portions thereof. (Ord. 12-2019 § 9)

Title 16 SUBDIVISIONS
Chapter 16.04 ANNEXATION POLICIES AND PROCEDURES
Chapter 16.08 GENERAL PROVISIONS PERTAINING TO THE SUBDIVISION AND DEVELOPMENT OF LAND AND ASSOCIATED FEES
Appendix A—Subdivision and Development Regulations
Appendix B—Fee Schedule for Subdivision and Development Applications

Chapter 16.04 ANNEXATION POLICIES AND PROCEDURES
16.04.010 Annexation procedure.
    A.  Compliance. All annexation of unincorporated territory to the City shall comply with the requirements and procedures set forth in the Municipal Annexation Act, Colorado Revised Statutes, Part 1 (Section 31-12-101, et seq.), as amended and the City’s Comprehensive Land Use Plan and applicable provisions of the Cañon City Municipal Code.

    B.   Conditions. No annexation of land in the City shall create an unreasonable burden on the physical, social, economic, or environmental resources of the City. The City may condition the annexation of land upon such terms and conditions as are reasonably necessary to ensure that this requirement is met.

    C.   Annexation Agreement. Applicants petitioning the City for annexation of their property shall enter into an annexation agreement with the City stating any terms and conditions imposed on the property, prior to the first reading of the annexation ordinance. Upon annexation, the annexation agreement shall be recorded to provide notice to future purchases of the property. (Ord. 35-2019 § 1)

 

16.04.020 Petitions.
    All petitions for annexation to the City shall comply with the applicable provisions of the Municipal Annexation Act, and in particular, C.R.S. Section 31-12-107. In addition to these requirements, any petition shall include a draft annexation agreement and the following, at the request of the City:

    A.  Information concerning the characteristics of the area, including, but not limited to, information concerning geologic, floodplain or wildlife hazards; mineral resources; wildlife resources; historical and archaeological resources; wetlands; and the environmental condition of the area;

    B.   Information addressing the short-term and long-term costs and benefits to the area proposed for annexation;

    C.   A description of necessary utility services; or

    D.  Such other information or studies as may be requested by the City Administrator, City Planner or the City Engineer. (Ord. 35-2019 § 1)

 

16.04.030 Fees and costs.
    A.  A non-refundable base fee of one thousand five hundred dollars ($1,500.00) will be payable upon the submission for consideration by City Council of any annexation petition (or group of petitions, when a serial annexation is proposed). In situations where there are multiple voluntary petitioners, the petitioner’s themselves, and not the City, shall determine how the fees and costs provided for in this section are to be divided among them. The base fee is subject to the following:

    1.   If an annexation impact report is required by either City Council or the Board of Fremont County Commissioners, or both, the base fee shall be increased by one hundred dollars ($100.00), which amount must be paid before any significant work is performed by City staff on the annexation impact report.

    B.   Unless otherwise agreed in writing with the City, no fees or costs shall be charged to or collected from any property owner who joins in a petition for annexation at the request of the City in an annexation initiated by the City, including, but not limited to, property owners who became contractually bound to join in such petitions as a precondition to City water service being provided to their property, and no fees or costs shall be charged to or collected from any property owner whose property is included in the area covered by a petition for annexation if such property owner has not joined in such petition. Property owners described and referred to in this subsection shall not be considered to be voluntary petitioners by the City or any other petitioner and shall not be treated as such for purposes of prorating and collecting fees and costs payable pursuant to the requirements of this section.

    C.   In all cases where multiple landowners are jointly petitioning for the annexation of their property (in a single annexation petition or in a serial annexation through multiple petitions), such landowners shall designate in a written statement (by name, address and telephone number) a single person or entity from among their group who shall be responsible for the tender of payment to the City of all deposits, fees and costs reimbursable or otherwise payable pursuant to this section. The City’s notices and invoices with respect to this section shall be submitted to such designated person or entity. (Ord. 35-2019 § 1)

Chapter 16.08 GENERAL PROVISIONS PERTAINING TO THE SUBDIVISION AND DEVELOPMENT OF LAND AND ASSOCIATED FEES
16.08.010 Divisions of land—Approval and recordation.
    All divisions of lots, tracts or parcels of land into two (2) or more lots or parcels, or the plat of any subdivision of land within the City, shall be filed and recorded in the office of the County Clerk and Recorder of Fremont County only after having been approved in accordance with the Subdivision and Development Regulations of the City pertaining to the subdivision and development of land within the jurisdiction of the City. The most recent version of such Subdivision and Development Regulations, which from time to time may be amended by resolution of the City of Cañon City Planning Commission, shall be attached to this Chapter 16.08 as Appendix A and shall be applicable and enforceable within the jurisdiction of the City from and after the March 1, 2007 effective date of such regulations. (Ord. 2-2007 § 1)

 

16.08.020 Activities prohibited prior to approval.
    No building shall be erected on any lot or parcel or real estate, nor shall a building permit or a water tap be issued for any such building, unless the owner of the land upon which such building will be erected complies with the applicable provisions of the Subdivision and Development Regulations of the City. (Ord. 2-2007 § 1)

 

16.08.030 Vesting of property rights.
    No vested property right, as defined in Article 68 of Title 24, Colorado Revised Statutes, shall occur in the subdividing process until such time as the City Council has given approval of the final plat presented by the subdivider, after notice and public hearing, and such plat has been filed for recording with the Fremont County Clerk and Recorder, unless the subdivider and the City have reached a written agreement providing for the vesting of real property rights at a different time. When a plan is required as a part of the approval process required by the Subdivision and Development Regulations or by any ordinance of the City, no plat shall be recorded until the required plan has been approved. If required by the Subdivision and Development Regulations or by an ordinance of the City, such plan also shall be recorded. (Ord. 2-2007 § 1)

 

16.08.040 Land use and development fees.
    Fees pertaining to the subdivision and   development of land in the City (including the processes provided for in the Subdivision and Development Regulations) shall be established and from time to time amended by ordinance of City Council. Schedules reflecting the City’s subdivision and development fees, as set forth in such ordinances, shall be attached to this Chapter 16.08 as Appendix B. Appendix B shall be amended from time to time as ordinances modifying the fee schedule are adopted by City Council. (Ord. 2-2007 § 1)

 

16.08.050 Applicability of state law to the subdivision process.
    The provisions of Part 2 of Article 23 of Title 31, Colorado Revised Statutes, when not in conflict with the specific provisions of this Chapter 16.08 or the Subdivision and Development Regulations appended to this chapter as Appendix A, shall apply as to the subdivision and development of land within the jurisdiction of the City. (Ord. 2-2007 § 1)

Chapter 17.20 SUPPLEMENTARY PROVISIONS AND DESIGN REQUIREMENTS

Chapter 17.28 OFF-STREET PARKING AND LOADING
Chapter 17.30 SIGNS

Chapter 17.34 MARIJUANA CULTIVATION FOR PERSONAL USE
