    F.   Provide for public access to an expanded riverwalk along the riverfront in a manner that complements development; and

    G.  Provide for a transition from the RF-MU district and other non-residential uses to residential and/or agricultural uses. (Ord. 27-2019 § 1)

 

17.18.020 Applicability.
    A.  General Location Within City Limits. The riverfront zone districts are intended to be utilized generally as follows:

    1.   Riverfront Mixed-Use (RF-MU): between 1st and 11th streets on the north side of the Arkansas River and south of the railroad tracks.

    2.   Riverfront Residential (RF-R): between 1st and 11th streets on the south side of the Arkansas River, within five hundred (500) feet of the edge of floodway and excluding existing in-use commercial or industrial property near 9th Street.

    B.   Framework Plan. The Framework Plan (Figures 1 and 2) provides guidance on general areas for application of the riverfront zone districts (RF-MU and RF-R). The Framework Plan also identifies key frontages for parcels and where sub-areas, depending on context, are accommodated.

    C.   Applicability of Other Provisions of Title 17. Unless otherwise expressly stated in this chapter, for matters not addressed in this Chapter 17.18, applicable provisions of Title 17 shall apply. In the event of a conflict between this chapter and other provisions of Title 17, the provisions of this chapter shall control.

 

Figure 1: Riverfront Mixed -Use (RF-MU) Framework Plan



 

Figure 2: Riverfront Residential (RF-R) Framework Plan



(Ord. 27-2019 § 1)

 

17.18.030 Definitions.
    The definitions listed in this section shall apply only to zone districts governed by this chapter. The words and terms used in this chapter shall have the meanings set forth below. If a definition is not listed below, then the definition listed in Section 17.08.010 of this Code shall govern. If there is a conflict between the definitions in Section 17.08.010 and the definitions in this chapter, then the definitions in this chapter shall govern. If a term is not found in this Code, the term shall have its common meaning.

    “Amenity zone” means the part of a public right-of-way that includes incidental public amenities such as benches, trash receptacles, and pedestrian light fixtures.

    “Conference/meeting facilities” means a type of use that has fundamental equipment, facilities and services necessary to hold and run conferences or meetings.

    “Court” means an open space enclosed by residential building(s) which front the open space for access.

    “Day spa” means a business that provides a variety of services for the purpose of improving health and beauty through personal services such as hair, facial, massage.

    “Dwelling. Multi-family” means a building used by three (3) or more attached dwelling units, including apartments and condominiums primarily, but not exclusively with common entries from the street, and not including hotels, motels, resorts or group accommodations.

    “Dwelling. Rowhome” means a residential building containing three (3) or more attached dwelling units, each on its own lot and with direct access to the outside, but not including hotels, motels, resorts or group accommodations.

    “Fitness center” means a business that is equipped to provide indoor exercise and health related functions, and may include incidental retail sales and food and beverage service.

    “Floorplate” means the horizontal structure at the base of a building and/or between stories of a building. The floorplate includes joists and other structural components, subflooring and finish flooring material. Floorplate area is the square feet of the length multiplied by the width of a floorplate.

    “Kennel, limited” means a commercial facility licensed by the State of Colorado Department of Agriculture to house dogs, cats or other small household pets, indoor only, for boarding or training purposes. This use shall not include the selling, transferring, adopting, or breeding of dogs.

    “Key frontage” means the frontage of a parcel identified of the Framework Plan to regulate setbacks and design standards.

    “Lane” means a public or private right-of-way designed to accommodate pedestrians, bicycles and vehicles equally, with a narrow design and slow speed of travel for vehicles.

    “Lot” means a parcel of land shown as a lot on a recorded plat or a parcel of land described by metes and bounds on a recorded deed.

    “Parapet” means the part of a wall that extends above the roof.

    “Personal services, limited” means an activity primarily engaged in providing services generally involving the care of the person including activities like day spas or travel agencies. This use does not include laundry, dry cleaning services, employment or answering services.

 

    “Primary frontage” means the key frontage as identified in the Framework Plan, the street frontage if a key frontage is not identified, or the primary entrance façade of a business that may not have street frontage.

    “Structure, accessory” means a structure located on the same lot as the principal structure. Accessory structures are incidental and subordinate to the principal structure. Accessory structures include items such as garages, sheds, barns, private greenhouses, decks and fences but do not include shipping containers or similar storage units.

    “Structured parking garage” means a building or structure, consisting of one or more levels or floors used for the parking or storage of vehicles. A parking structure maybe below grade or either partially or totally above grade with those levels or floors being either open or enclosed.

    “Structure, historic” means a structure that is designated at the state or national level as an individual structure or a contributing structure to a designated district for historic, cultural or architectural reasons.

    “Surface parking lot” means a site or a portion of a site, devoted to the off-street parking of vehicles, including parking spaces, aisles, access drives, and landscaped areas, and areas providing vehicular access to a public street.

    “Trade or repair shop, limited” means a shop where a form of occupation, skilled manual or limited mechanical work, manual craft, or artisan skills is conducted, such as by a jeweler, woodworker, metalworking, glass- blower, and leather craftsman, so long as the occupation or activity does not emit loud noises or noxious fumes. Shops may not employ more than fifteen (15) persons.

 

    “Use, accessory” means a use which is normally incidental to, subordinate to and devoted exclusively to the primary use of the property.

    “Utility services, public or essential government, limited” means the erection, construction alteration or maintenance by public utilities or municipal government of local provision gas, electrical, steam, cable, internet, or water services. No office, repair, storage, substation or production facilities are allowed. (Ord. 27-2019 § 1)

Article III. Development Standards and Guidelines
17.18.060 Building.
    A.  Standards. The following minimum design standards shall govern the applicable zone district.

    1.   Riverfront Mixed-Use (RF-MU).

    a.   Ground floor transparency.

    i.    A minimum seventy-five percent (75%) transparency (Figure 15) is required on key frontage per the Framework Plan (refer to Figures 1 and 2). If a building has >eighty percent (80%) lot frontage build out, then transparency can be lowered to sixty-five percent (65%).

    ii.   A minimum of sixty-five percent (65%) transparency is required on non-key primary fronts.

 

Figure 15: Minimum 75% Transparency



 

    b.   Materials.

    i.    No exterior insulation finishing system (EIFS) or stucco is permitted on the ground floor elevations facing a key river or street front per the Regulating Plan. EIFS/stucco shall not be installed within thirty-six (36) inches of the ground on remaining elevations.

    ii.   Only integrally colored concrete masonry unit (CMU) is permitted.

    iii.  Not permitted on exposed surface:

    (A) No smooth-faced CMU.

    (B) Faux wood finish on CMU or on poured concrete.

    iv.  All storefront glazing systems facing a key frontage shall be clear low-e glass with black, bronze, grey, or clear anodized frames. Remaining façades shall utilize the same frame color.

    v.   Frames of awnings shall match storefront glazing.

    vi.  Any roofing visible from the adjacent riverwalk, street or alley level view of a pedestrian (e.g. a shed roof that is on a shorter portion of a taller building with flat roof and parapet wall) shall be shingled or of metal roofing, no rolled roofing permitted. (See Figure 16.)

 

Figure 16: Roofing Visible From Adjacent View of a Pedestrian



 

    c.   Service entrances.

    i.    No service entrance shall be located on the key frontage identified on the Framework Plan.

    ii.   A service entrance may be located on a non-key street frontage but must be enclosed to the fullest extent possible and designed to minimize impact to pedestrians.

    d.   Structured parking.

    i.    Ground floor.

    (A) Maximum length:

    (1)  Key frontage per Framework Plan: Ground floor structured parking shall comprise of no more than thirty-five percent (35%) of the minimum frontage.

    (2)  Street frontage (other than key frontage per Framework Plan): No more than sixty-five percent (65%) of the building frontage on the street.

    (B) The façade of the ground level (level most at eye level of a pedestrian) shall be a minimum of twenty-five percent (25%) and a maximum of fifty percent (50%) transparency to eliminate both blank walls from the riverwalk/street and fully exposed parking.

    ii.   Upper floors. The façade of upper levels of structured parking shall be designed with a maximum fifty percent (50%) transparency.

    e.   Projections.

    i.    Second story or above balconies may project onto a street, lane or side yard easement as long as the projection does not extend beyond the property line. No projections are permitted into a river front easement.

    ii.   Umbrellas as part of outside cafes shall not obstruct any pedestrian way and shall not contain any signage.

    f.    Internal roof drains shall be required.

    g.   All rooftop appurtenances shall be screened from pedestrian view on an adjacent riverwalk, street or alley. Rooftop appurtenances shall also be screened from view from any riverwalk on the opposite bank of the river directly across from the site. (See Figure 17.)

 

Figure 17: Rooftop Appurtenance Screening



    2.   Riverfront Residential (RF-R).

    a.   No outside storage shall be visible from the riverwalk or a street.

    b.   Ground floor living spaces shall be raised a minimum of eighteen (18) inches above grade to provide a transition from the public realm to the private realm.

    B.   Guidelines. The following design guidelines are encouraged to be employed in any riverfront district.

    1.   Employ a strong sense of three hundred sixty (360) degree architecture.

    2.   Employ human scale design, particularly at the ground floor levels of buildings.

    3.   Utilize regional materials and colors (e.g. buff sandstone, ashlar patterns)

    4.   Design to LEED or other energy efficient/sustainable design parameters.

    5.   Avoid large blank expanses of façade without fenestration / variation / articulation. Similarly, avoid over articulation.

    6.   Utilize a high saturation level in exterior material colors to exude richness and counter the “washing out” impact that can occur with the Colorado sun.

    C.   Submittal Requirements. In addition to the elements required as part of a building permit application, the following shall be submitted.

    1.   A full product sample board of all site and building materials shall be submitted as part of site/building permit applications.

    2.   A building mock-up is required as part of the building permit process. (Ord. 27-2019 § 1)

 

17.18.070 General Site.
    The following minimum design standards shall govern the applicable zone district.

    A.  Riverfront Mixed-Use (RF-MU).

    1.   Utilize shared curb cuts between properties wherever feasible when accessing from a street.

    2.   Drop-off bays are only permitted for hotels and shall be designed to have minimal impact to the public realm.

    3.   Ground level or above grade structured parking shall be a minimum of five (5) feet from a street or river front façade. (See Figure 18.)

    4.   Ground level structured parking shall not extend beyond the front façade of the occupied portion of a building on a street front. (See Figure 19.)

 

Figure 18: Ground Level Structured Parking Setback



 

Figure 19: Ground Level Structured Parking Alignment



 

    5.   Access/loading shall not be from a primary frontage.

    6.   Storage units are not permitted except during construction.

    7.   Outdoor cafes:

    a.   Only durable metal or composite exterior furnishings and fencing/railings are permitted in colors to match the building storefront or in black.

    b.   No plastic or fiberglass materials are allowed.

    c.   Outdoor café furnishings shall be designed/secured in a way to be able to withstand strong winds.

    d.   Outdoor gas line fed fire pits must be contained on the private property.

    e.   Outdoor café encroachments must comply with Table 9.

 

Table 9: Outdoor Café Encroachments

    B.   Riverfront Residential (RF-R).

    1.   Provide a clear indication from a street or lane where the front door to a housing unit is if a lot must be garage/parking front loaded. (Figure 21.)

17.18.080 Landscaping, Fencing and Screening.
    The following minimum standards shall govern each applicable zone district to increase the visual appearance of the built environment.

    A.  Riverfront Mixed-Use (RF-MU).

    1.   Trees shall be planted as follows.

    a.   Street trees: One deciduous tree per thirty-five (35) feet of street frontage, minimum two (2) inch caliper.

    b.   Sideyard easement trees: One deciduous tree per thirty-five (35) feet of street frontage, minimum two (2) inch caliper.

    c.   Parking areas: refer to Section 17.18.100.

    2.   Pervious surfaces.

    a.   Any area that is not within the building footprint, parking lot footprint, walkways, or paved support areas such as trash enclosure or detention facilities shall be pervious surface.

    b.   A minimum of fifty percent (50%) of the pervious surface of a site shall be planted and maintained with live plant material.

    c.   Irrigation shall be installed to ensure longevity of turf/live plant material.

    d.   A variety of plant materials shall be employed to provide year-round interest.

    e.   Drought tolerant and native plant material shall be used to the greatest extent possible.

    3.   Fencing.

    a.   No wood fencing or plain faced CMU permitted.

    b.   Fencing up to forty-two (42) inches high (this does not include trash enclosures) is permitted.

    4.   Screening.

    a.   Solid masonry (no smooth faced CMU, EIFS or stucco permitted) or metal trash enclosures with metal gates are required to fully screen trash receptacles. Enclosures shall include metal gates for screening and to secure the area. Enclosures shall be designed in the color/material palette of the principal structure.

    b.   Parking areas:

    i.    Surface parking lots:

    (A) Shall have a minimum five (5) foot setback from any adjacent right-of-way.

    (B) Shall not extend beyond the street front or river front façade of a building.

    (C) Shall be screened from rights-of-way, riverwalk or adjacent properties by use of evergreen shrubs or low walls with seventy-five percent (75%) opacity.

    (D) Low screen walls shall be forty-two (42) inches tall and shall not be of wood, plastic/plastic composite or smooth-faced CMU.

    (E) Shrubs shall be a minimum five (5) gallon container at time of planting.

    (F)  Dead plant material shall be replaced in a timely manner.

    (G) Parking lot screening shall not impede vision triangles created at egress points from lots.

    ii.   Ground level parking structures:

    (A) Shall be screened by use of evergreen shrubs.

    (B) Shrubs shall be a minimum five (5) gallon container at time of planting.

    (C) Dead plant material shall be replaced in a timely manner.

    B.   Riverfront Residential (RF-R).

    1.   Trees shall be planted as follows.

    a.   Street trees: One deciduous tree per thirty-five (35) feet of street frontage.

    b.   Per lot:

    i.    Dwelling, Single-family, two-family, townhome: One deciduous tree per lot.

    ii.   Dwelling, Multi-family: One deciduous tree per five (5) units.

    2.   Pervious surfaces.

    a.   A minimum of sixty percent (60%) of the front yard shall be planted and maintained with live plant material.

    b.   A variety of plant materials shall be employed to provide year-round interest.

    c.   Drought tolerant and native plant material shall be used to the greatest extent possible.

    3.   Fencing up to seventy-two (72) inches is permitted in the front yard along a street or a lane if the opposite side of the property is abutting the floodway with no vehicular access, and vehicular access is from the street or lane. The fence shall be set back eighteen (18) inches from the property line and the top twelve (12) inches shall have fifty percent (50%) transparency. (Figure 22.)

    4.   Fencing and landscaping shall meet vision triangle requirements.

    5.   Structured parking for multi-family shall meet requirements for structured parking in RF-MU.

 

Figure 22: Fence



(Ord. 27-2019 § 1)

 

17.18.090 Lighting.
    The following minimum standards shall govern the applicable zone districts to minimize adverse glare, spillover and night sky impacts of lighting.

    A.  Riverfront Mixed-Use (RF-MU).

    1.   Site and building lighting shall be minimized to the extent necessary to meet safety purposes.

    2.   Lighting shall not be aimed nor spill onto adjacent properties.

    3.   Automatic switching controls that automatically extinguish all outdoor lighting when sufficient daylight is available using a control device shall be provided.

    4.   Full cut-off fixtures are required.

    5.   The following are not permitted:

    a.   Low pressure sodium and mercury vapor light sources.

    b.   Neon.

    c.   Exposed light source.

    d.   Uplighting.

    6.   Freestanding outdoor lighting fixtures shall:

    a.   Only be permitted for parking lots or drop off areas.

    b.   Not be taller than twenty-four (24) feet, or not be taller than sixteen (16) feet within fifty (50) feet of a residential zone district or on the rooftop of a parking structure.

    B.   Riverfront Residential (RF-R).

    1.   Site and building lighting shall be minimized to the extent necessary to meet safety purposes.

    2.   Lighting shall not be aimed nor spill onto adjacent properties.

    3.   Automatic switching controls that automatically extinguish all outdoor lighting when sufficient daylight is available using a control device shall be provided.

    4.   Full cut-off fixtures are required.

    5.   The following light sources are permitted:

    a.   Incandescent.

    b.   LED.

    c.   RF-MU allowed lighting sources may be approved by the Zoning Administrator at time of site plan review for multi-family buildings over twelve (12) units in size.

    6.   The following are not permitted:

    a.   Neon.

    b.   Pole mounted lighting over eight (8) feet in height. (Ord. 27-2019 § 1)

 

17.18.100 Parking.
    This section shall only apply to the zone districts governed by Chapter 17.18. If a parking requirement is not otherwise addressed in this section, the standards in Chapter 17.28 shall apply. If there is conflict between this section and Chapter 17.28, the standards in this section shall govern.

    A.  Purpose.

    1.   To allow for efficient parking ratios, offsite parking, shared parking, and other creative parking solutions within the riverfront area.

    2.   To minimize the visual impact of off-street parking areas.

    B.   General Regulations.

    1.   The long-term parking or storage of boats/recreational vehicles, semi-tractors and semi-trailers, and construction vehicles and equipment (except during periods of permitted construction activity and/or deliveries) is prohibited.

    2.   Circulation within a parking lot shall be designed to be as efficient as possible including minimizing the number of curb cuts/access points to a street.

    3.   Aisles with only one inlet/outlet shall provide “back outs” for end spaces.

    4.   A stacked or tandem parking arrangement (where one vehicle parked directly behind another) shall be allowed only for a structure containing two (2) or more dwelling units and the tandem spaces shall be allocated to one unit.

    5.   All required parking spaces (excluding those for single-family, duplexes and rowhomes) shall be outlined by white or yellow stripes not less than four (4) inches wide and painted on the surface area. Where existing parking spaces are not paved or an acceptable alternative surface is used an alternative material or bumper guards/wheel stops approved by the City Engineer shall be used to delineate the parking spaces.

    C.   Number of Off-Street Parking Spaces Required for Specific Uses.

    1.   Riverfront Mixed-Use (RF-MU).

    D.  Parking Reductions/Shared Parking.

    1.   On-Street Parking Credit. On-street parking may be counted towards the total parking spaces required pursuant to Section 17.28.080(A).

    2.   Off-Site Parking Credit. The following off-site parking credits are permitted in the RF-MU:

    a.   Distance. Off-site parking ownership or current lease of parking spaces within a one thousand (1,000) foot radius of the site dedicated to the use during its hours of operation shall be considered towards parking requirement.

    b.   Amount. This off-site parking credit shall account for no greater than the following percentage of total required spaces.

    i.    RF-MU-A: up to seventy-five percent (75%).

 

    ii.   RF-MU-B and -C: up to fifty percent (50%).

    c.   Off-site dedicated parking spaces shall be established through a lease/shared parking agreement, if not owned by the same property owner. An off-site shared parking agreement shall not be transferrable from one owner/use to another without the City’s approval. The shared parking agreement must be for a minimum of five (5) years.

    3.   Parking Reductions.

    a.   Shared parking shall comply with Section 17.28.080(B).

    b.   Affordable multi-family provided. A fifty percent (50%) reduction in required parking is permitted for multi­ family affordable units built to provide housing at<= 80% of AMI within the RF-MU-B and C sub-areas. The reduction is to be calculated only for those units deemed affordable.

    c.   Bike racks provided. For every eight (8) bike racks provided for Mixed-Use or Multi-family development over the minimum bike racks required, one parking space can be reduced.

    d.   Car share provided. For every one car share vehicle provided per parcel, a reduction of three (3) parking spaces can occur. The car share parking shall be available twenty-four (24) hours a day/seven (7) days a week to the designated tenants within the parcel. A parking spot shall be reserved and clearly signed for such use. Car share can provide for a reduction up to thirty-five percent (35%) of the required parking.

    E.   Internal Landscaping.

    1.   All off-street parking areas which serve twenty (20) vehicles or more shall be provided with landscape islands within the parking lot totaling not less than five percent (5%) of the surfaced area.

    2.   The minimum size of each landscape island shall be one hundred seventy (170) sq. ft.

    3.   Landscape islands shall consist of trees, shrubs and other low water plantings.

    4.   Any landscape island less than one hundred seventy (170) sq. ft. shall not count towards the requirement.

    5.   One deciduous canopy tree shall be provided for every twelve (12) parking spaces.

    6.   Deciduous canopy trees must be evenly distributed throughout the parking lot. Structurally covered or underground motor vehicle parking spaces are not included in calculating the required number and location of canopy trees.

    F.   Bicycle Parking.

    1.   Multi-family dwellings shall be required to provide one bicycle rack per three (3) units.

    2.   Commercial uses shall be required to provide one bicycle rack per eight (8) vehicular parking spaces. (Ord. 27-2019 § 1)

 

17.18.110 Signs.
    A.  Purpose.

    The purpose of this section is to promote public health, safety and welfare by:

    1.   Providing sign regulations in the riverfront area that support creation of a unique sense of place and character within the City;

    2.   Regulating the number, location, size, type, illumination and other physical characteristics of signs within the riverfront area to promote the public health, safety and welfare of the City; and

    3.   Supporting the City’s strategic prioritizes of economic development and improving the built environment while providing for effective means of communication consistent with constitutional guarantees.

    It is not the purpose or intent of this section to regulate the message displayed on any sign. The content of the message or speech displayed on the sign shall not be reviewed or considered in determining whether to approve or deny a sign.

    B.   Applicability. This subsection shall only apply to the zone districts governed by Chapter 17.18. Except as expressly stated in this section, the regulations in Chapter 17.30 shall not apply to the zone districts governed by this chapter.

    C.   Definitions. The definitions listed in this subsection shall apply only to this Chapter 17.18 and shall have the meanings set forth below. lf a definition is not listed below, then the definition listed in the other sections of Chapter 17.18 shall govern. lf the definition in not listed in this Chapter 17.18, then the definitions in Title 17 shall govern. If there is any conflict between a definition in this subsection and any other part of Title 17, than the definitions in this subsection shall apply. If the term is not found in this Code, the term shall have its common meaning.

    “Alteration” means any change, modification or addition to the structure of any sign, with the exception of a nonmaterial alteration such as simple maintenance and refurbishing of an existing message.

    “Area” means the greatest number of square feet of sign exposed to public view.           “Business” means a commercial establishment with a storefront.

    “Flag” means any fabric, banner or bunting containing distinctive colors, patterns or symbols and is attached to a pole and which is intended to be permanently affixed to the ground or attached to a building, but does not include a feather flag sign.

    ‘‘Flagging, streamers and pennants” means a continuous length of cord or other similar material to which long, narrow flags or pennants are attached, for the purpose of attracting attention to a business or location.

    “Height” means the distance from grade to the top of the sign structure, as erected, in a vertical line.

    “Level, ground” means the lowest level of a building in which the majority of the height of that level is exposed above the adjacent street or riverwalk ground elevation.

    “Level, upper” means any other level of a building above the ground level.

    “Multi-tenant building” means a building that provides leased space or condominium ownership to more than one tenant or owner, particularly a building that includes multiple ground level storefronts.

    “Mural” means a painted wall sign that does not contain a business logo, business name or commercial message.

    “Sign” means any display, device, figure, painting, drawing, message, placard, poster, billboard, or any other contrivance designed, intended, or used to promote the interest of any person, or to give information and being in public view.

    “Sign, animated” means any sign or part of a sign which changes physical position by any movement, rotation, or change in lighting.

    “Sign, awning” means any permanent sign printed and attached to the vertical valance or sloped area of an awning that is attached to a building.

    “Sign, directional” means a permanent freestanding sign reasonably necessary for the safe circulation of pedestrian or vehicular traffic within a given area and excluding those erected by the U.S. or State of Colorado Department of Transportation.

    “Sign, electronic message” means an automated sign, which may be programmed by computer, using moving illuminated words or graphics.

    “Sign, feather flag” means a temporary freestanding sign typically constructed of a single plastic or metal shaft driven in the ground with an attached pennant that is vertically elongated and attached to the shaft.

    “Sign. flashing” means any directly or indirectly illuminated sign either stationary or animated, which exhibits changing natural or artificial light or color by any means.

    “Sign, flexible banner” means a temporary sign of a flexible material that is mounted to a building, fence or to the ground via more than one structured pole.

    “Sign, freestanding” means a sign that is mounted to the ground and not to any other structure.

    “Sign, inflatable” means any temporary freestanding inflatable shape or figure designed or used to attract attention to an event or location.

    “Sign, monument” means a permanent freestanding sign, that has more than seventy-five (75%) of its bottom edge affixed to and/or touching the ground.

    “Sign, nonconforming” means any sign which does not conform to the requirements of this section, but, on the effective date of this section, was lawfully maintained and had been lawfully erected in accordance with prior applicable sign regulation.

    “Sign, official” means a sign required by law or constructed, placed or maintained by the state, the federal government or the City. The inclusion of “government” in defining such signs does not intend to subject the government to regulation, but instead helps describe the type of sign that falls within the immunities of the government from regulation.

    “Sign, off-premise” means a sign displaying advertising copy that pertains to a business, person, organization, activity, event, place, service or product not principally located or primarily manufactured or sold on the lot on which the sign is located. Also referred to as a billboard.

    “Sign, permanent” means a sign that is designed to be used on a permanent basis. Permanent signs include wall signs, freestanding signs, window signs, awning signs, directional signs, and projecting signs.

    “Sign, portable” means a sign that is constructed in a manner that it can be moved or relocated without involving any structural or support changes.

    “Sign, projecting” means a sign or marquee affixed to and projecting from any building or structure.

    “Sign, rigid banner” means a temporary sign of a rigid material that is mounted to the ground via structured poles.

    “Sign, roof” means any sign which is erected or constructed wholly upon and/or over the roof of any building and supported on the roof of the structure. Freestanding signs which pass through an overhang roof or canopy shall be considered roof signs.

    “Sign, sandwich board” means an A-frame-type sign that is portable and is hinged or unhinged, or is vertical and located on skids or runners and is readily movable. A sandwich board sign does not include a sign attached to or affixed on an individual.

    “Sign, temporary” means a sign that is designed to be used only temporarily and is not intended to be permanently attached to a building wall or sign structure or permanently installed in the ground. Temporary signs expressly include yard signs, feather flag signs inflatable signs flexible banner signs, and rigid banner signs

    “Sign, wall” means a permanent sign which is painted on or fastened to the wall or parapet of a building or structure in such a manner that the wall becomes the supporting structure or forms the background surface of the sign. A mural shall not be considered a wall sign.

    “Sign, window” means a permanent sign applied or attached to the exterior or interior of storefront glazing with vinyl graphics and meant to be legible from the exterior.

    “Sign, yard” means a temporary sign constructed of paper, vinyl plastic wood, metal or other comparable material that is mounted on a state or frame structure that includes one or more stakes.

    “Storefront” means the ground level primary frontage of a business that is readily accessible and visible to the general public.

    “Storefront glazing” means any glass area encompassed by a frame within the storefront of a business.

    “Structure” means that which is erected or constructed with a fixed location from the ground above grade any piece of work artificially built up or composed of parts joined together in some definite manner excluding poles, cables or other transmission or distribution facilities of public utilities.

    “Wall” means, for purposes of this chapter, an exterior surface of a building which has a slope of greater than sixty (60) degrees from the horizontal plane.

    D.  Rules of Measurement.

    The area of a sign shall be measured in conformance with the regulations identified in this section.

    1.   Determination of sign area. The following methods shall be used to determine the sign area of a sign:

 

Table 12: Determination of Sign Area

Wall Sign, Projecting Sign, Directional Sign

§ Structural elements used to attach the sign that do not contribute to the display will not be counted towards the calculation of sign area.



Monument Sign

§  The portion of the base of a monument sign that is eighteen (18) inches or less shall not be counted towards the calculation of sign area.

§ The base will be included in overall height of the monument sign.



 

    2.   Calculation of sign area. The following methods shall be used to determine what constitutes one sign and to calculate the total square footage of any sign:

 

Table 13: Calculation of Sign Area

§  Each area of a sign that can be enclosed by a line or an imaginary line shall be considered one sign. Each side of a two-sided sign shall be used to calculate the maximum allowed sign area.



§  The area of measurement of a sign contained within a cabinet or frame shall include the total area of the cabinet or frame.



§  The area of measurement of a sign that displays individual letters on a wall, awning, or canopy or as pan channel letters shall be determined by encompassing all the letters in a geometric form of no more than eight (8) rectilinear lines at right angles to each other.



§  The total surface area of multiple unit signs includes the vertical and horizontal spacing between signs.



§  The sign area of each sign face of monument, directional, projecting and yard signs that have two faces shall be measured to calculate the maximum allowed sign area.



 

 

    3.   Calculation of total number of signs. The following should be used to determine the number of permanent signs being proposed on a lot:

    a.   Monument and Projecting signs shall be counted as one sign.

    b.   Directional signs shall not be included in the total number of signs.

    c.   Any sign within twelve (12) inches of the interior of a window shall be considered a sign and counted towards the total allowed number of signs and towards the maximum area of sign allowed.

    E.   Sign Standards by Type. Signs types are organized in three categories: Permanent, Portable and Temporary. Please utilize Table 14 for regulations for each type. Refer to Section 17.18.110(E) for sign regulations by zone.

§     Allowed for no more than sixty (60) consecutive days prior to an election but must be removed ten (10) days after the conclusion of an election.

§     Allowed during the period of a property is for sale or lease, but must be removed from a lot three (3) days after the sale or lease of property.

    G.  General Sign Regulations for all Districts.

    1.   Maintenance.

    a.   Every sign shall be maintained in good condition at all times. A sign in good condition shall meet the following criteria:

    i.    Signs shall be rust free.

    ii.   Plastic, acrylic and other similar materials shall not be broken, cracked, torn or faded.

    iii.  Banners, awnings, flags and feather flags shall not be torn, faded or in disrepair.

    iv.  All lighting, where permitted, must be functional and no exposed light sources are permitted unless approved with the permit.

    b.   The City shall have the authority to inspect signs to ensure adequate maintenance and compliance with this section.

    c.   If upon inspection, staff determines a sign to be in violation of this section or a safety hazard, the staff may order the sign to be maintained or removed by the property owner.

    2.   Nonconforming signs.

    a.   Continuance. Subject to the termination hereinafter provided, any nonconforming sign may be continued in operation and be maintained after the effective date of the ordinance codified in this section or any amendment thereto; provided, however, that no such sign shall be modified in any manner that increases the nonconformity of such sign.

    b.   Termination of a nonconforming sign shall take place upon:

     i.      Structural change to any nonconforming sign.

     ii.     Structural alteration to prolong the life of the sign, except to meet safety requirements.

    iii.  Alteration or expansion in any manner which increases the degree of nonconformity.

    iv.  Damage or destruction if the estimated cost of reconstruction exceeds fifty percent (50%) of the value of the sign structure prior to being damaged.

    v.   Any violation of this section shall terminate immediately the right to maintain such sign.

    3.   Official signs, danger signs, emergency signs and legal notices may be placed by responsible persons upon approval of the City Administrator.

    4.   No sign shall be erected, constructed, maintained or altered within the City in violation of the Code of Cañon City, including but not limited to this Section.

    5.   Proper vision clearance shall be provided at all times.

    6.   No sign of any type shall be erected or placed so as to obstruct any necessary egress in case of fire.

    7.   All exterior signs shall be designed and constructed to resist the wind effects determined in accordance with applicable requirements of the duly adopted International Building Code.

    H.  Applicability of Chapter 17.30.

    The following sections of Chapter 17.30 are applicable to the signs within the RF-MU and RF-R zone districts to the extent no conflict exists between this section and the following sections:

    1.   17.30.030;

    2.   17.30.100;

    3.   17.30.110;

    4.   17.30.140;

    5.   17.30.180.

    I.    Violation-Penalty. It is unlawful for any person, firm or corporation to erect, maintain, replace or alter any sign in the City, or permit the same in violation of any of the provisions of this section. Any violation of the provisions of this section shall be punishable in accordance with the provisions of Section 17.44.050 of the Code. (Ord. 27-2019 § 1)

Chapter 17.20 SUPPLEMENTARY PROVISIONS AND DESIGN REQUIREMENTS
17.20.010 Maintenance of minimum requirements.
    No lot area, yard or other open space, or required off-street parking or loading area existing on or after the effective date of the ordinance codified in this title, shall be reduced in area, dimension or size below the minimum required by this title, nor shall any lot area, yard or other open space or off-street parking or loading area which is required by this title for one use be used as the lot area, yard or other open space or off-street parking or loading area requirement for any other use, except that a valid lease determined to be of adequate length by City Council be filed at the office of the City Clerk, Planning Administrator and City Engineer’s office. (Prior code § 17.16.030)

 

17.20.020 Access to street.
    All lots shall abut a street other than alley for a width of at least forty (40) feet. (Prior code § 17.16.170)

 

17.20.025 Agriculture.
    Agriculture shall be a permitted use in an R-L Zone District provided:

    A.  No offensive odors or excessive dust be created; and

    B.   No agricultural products be sold on the property which are not produced on said property. (Ord. 34-1992)

 

17.20.028 Animal boarding.
    Animal boarding may be permitted as a conditional use in the R-L, R-1, C and I zone districts, upon the issuance of a conditional use permit, according to the policies and procedures set forth in Chapter 17.23, Conditional Uses, and subject to the following conditions:

    A.  Every animal boarding facility shall, at all times, be licensed as a Pet Animal Care Facility with the Colorado Department of Agriculture;

    B.   Such facilities shall be maintained with regular and frequent cleaning to minimize the possibility of unhealthy or unsafe conditions. All manure, bedding, spillage and leftovers from feedings shall be removed and disposed of to prevent fly and rodent propagation or odor at least weekly;

    C.   Any structure used for the boarding of animals shall be located at least twenty (20) feet from any side or rear property line;

    D.  The boarding of animals shall, to the extent applicable, comply with the terms, conditions and limitations that apply to the keeping of livestock, as set forth in Section 17.20.114 of this title. (Ord. 2-2013 § 4)

 

17.20.029 Backyard chickens.
    Backyard chickens may be permitted in the R-1 and R-2 zone districts as an accessory use, and on properties used for residential purposes in the C and I zone districts upon the issuance of a conditional use permit according to the policies and procedures set forth in Chapter 17.23, Conditional Uses, and subject to the following conditions:

    A.  No more than eight (8) chicken hens shall be allowed on any property, unless the property meets the minimum area requirement for livestock, according to Section 17.20.114 of this title;

    B.   The ownership and keeping of roosters over six (6) months old is prohibited;

    C.   Chicken hens must be provided with a covered enclosure that is predator-resistant, properly ventilated, and easily accessed for cleaning and maintenance, and that provides not less than four (4) square feet per chicken;

    D.  During daylight hours, chicken hens must be provided access to an outside enclosure that is adequately fenced to prevent the escape of the chickens and to provide protection from predators. The outside enclosure must provide a minimum of ten (10) square feet of permeable space per chicken, and may be either attached to the covered enclosure or portable. A fully fenced backyard may be deemed to meet this requirement;

 

    E.   The chickens must be placed in the covered enclosure between the hours of dusk and dawn to provide protection from predators;

    F.   Setbacks:

    1.   Any enclosure for backyard chickens must be located in the backyard of the property, measured from the rear wall of the residential dwelling. The Zoning Administrator may allow exceptions to this requirement in cases of lots having unusual site dimensions, terrain limitations or other unique characteristics;

    2.   No covered enclosure may be located less than eight (8) feet from any abutting property line or less than thirty (30) feet from any residential dwelling on any adjoining lot;

    G.  The covered enclosure must be cleaned so that odors due to excessive dirt, waste, excrement, or old feed do not become a nuisance, safety hazard or health problem to adjoining property or uses;

    H.  The on-site slaughtering of backyard chickens is prohibited. (Ord. 2-2013 § 4)

 

17.20.031 Bed and breakfast.
    A bed and breakfast may be permitted as a conditional use upon the issuance of a conditional use permit, according to the policies and procedures set forth in Chapter 17.23, Conditional Uses, and subject to the following conditions:

    A.  Off-street parking shall be provided at the rate of one space for the dwelling owner and/or operator and one space for each lodging room;

    B.   Off-street parking areas shall be designed to provide safe ingress and egress;

    C.   In residential zone districts, landscaping and screening shall be provided to maintain the residential character of the building and preserve the right of neighboring residents to enjoy a peaceful occupancy of their homes;

    D.  Any outdoor lighting shall be shielded to minimize light shining onto adjacent properties;

    E.   All signage must comply with applicable provisions of Chapter 17.30, Signs, of this title;

    F.   The property used for a bed and breakfast facility shall also serve as the primary residence of the owner or manager;

    G.  Bed and breakfast facilities in residential districts may have no more than two (2) on-duty employees at any given time who do not reside in the bed and breakfast residence. (Ord. 2-2013 § 4)

 

17.20.032 Beekeeping.
    Domestic non-commercial beekeeping may be permitted as an accessory use in the R-L, R-1 and R-2 zone districts only, subject to the following conditions:

    A.  Hives. All bee colonies shall be kept in hives with removable combs, which shall be kept in sound and usable condition;

    B.   Setbacks. All hives shall be located in a side or rear yard only, and at least five (5) feet from any adjoining property, with the back of the hive facing the nearest adjoining property;

    C.   Colony Densities.

    1.   It is unlawful to keep more than the following number of colonies on any tract within the City, based upon the size or configuration of the tract on which the apiary is situated:

    a.   One-quarter (1/4) acre or less tract size—two (2) colonies;

    b.   More than one-quarter (1/4) acre but less than one-half (1/2) acre tract size—four (4) colonies;

    c.   More than one-half (1/2) acre but less than one (1) acre tract size—six (6) colonies;

    d.   One (1) acre or larger tract size—eight (8) colonies; and

    e.   Regardless of tract size, where all hives are situated at least two hundred (200) feet in any direction from all property lines of the tract on which the apiary is situated, there shall be no limit to the number of colonies;

    2.   For each two (2) colonies authorized under colony densities, there may be maintained upon the same tract one nucleus colony in a hive structure not exceeding one standard nine and five-eighths inch (9⅝″) depth ten (10) frame hive body with no supers attached as required from time to time for management of swarms. Each such nucleus colony shall be disposed of or combined with an authorized colony within thirty (30) days after the date it is acquired;

    D.  Fencing of Flyways. In each instance in which any colony is situated within twenty-five (25) feet of a property line of a developed public or private tract, as measured from the nearest point on the hive to the property line, the beekeeper shall establish and maintain a flyway barrier at least six feet (6′) in height consisting of a hedge, solid wall or fence parallel to the property line and extending ten feet (10′) beyond the colony in each direction so that all bees are forced to fly at an elevation of at least six feet (6′) above ground level over the property lines in the vicinity of the apiary;

    E.   Water. Each property owner or beekeeper shall ensure that a convenient source of water is available at all times to the bees so that the bees will not congregate at swimming pools, water spigots, pet water bowls, birdbaths or other water sources where they may cause human, bird or domestic pet contact. The water shall be maintained so as not to become stagnant;

    F.   Maintenance. Each property owner or beekeeper shall ensure that no bee comb or other materials that might encourage robbing are left upon the grounds of the apiary site. Upon their removal from the hive, all such materials shall promptly be disposed of in a sealed container or placed within a building or other bee proof enclosure;

    G.  Queens. In any instance in which a colony exhibits unusually aggressive characteristics by stinging or attempting to sting without due provocation or exhibits an unusual disposition towards swarming, it shall be the duty of the beekeeper to re-queen the colony. Queens shall be selected from stock bred for gentleness and non-swarming characteristics;

    H.  Prohibited. The keeping by any person of bee colonies in the City not in strict compliance with this section is prohibited. Any bee colony not residing in a hive structure intended for beekeeping, or any swarm of bees, or any colony residing in a standard or homemade hive which, by virtue of its condition, has obviously been abandoned by the beekeeper, is unlawful and may be summarily destroyed or removed from the City by the Code Enforcement Officer or Animal Control Officer. (Ord. 2-2013 § 4)

 

17.20.034 Boarding or rooming house.
    A boarding or rooming house may be permitted as a conditional use upon the issuance of a conditional use permit, according to the policies and procedures set forth in Chapter 17.23, Conditional Uses, and subject to the following conditions:

    A.  One off-street parking space shall be provided for each lodging room, plus one space for each on-duty employee;

    B.   Meals shall be prepared and served only to residents in a common eating area;

    C.   No individual kitchen facilities shall be provided in the lodging rooms;

    D.  The operator of a boarding or rooming house shall keep a complete record of the names of all persons residing therein, and shall make such record available for inspection to all appropriate agencies whose duties necessitate acquisition. (Ord. 2-2013 § 4)

 

17.20.040 Building height limitation exceptions.
    The following type of structures or structural parts are not subject to the building height limitations of this title: chimneys, tanks, church spires, belfries, domes, monuments, fire and hose towers, observation towers, transmission towers, flagpoles, radio and television towers, masts, aerials, cooling towers, elevator shafts, ranch and farm accessory uses, and other similar vertical projections. (Prior code § 17.16.060)

 

17.20.050 Buildings on the same lot.
    A.  Except in the case of commercial self-storage facilities and storage warehouses that are built to include more than one building, and except as provided in Subsection B of this section, only one principal building shall be permitted on any lot unless approved as part of a planned unit development under Chapter 17.16 of this title.

    B.   The establishment or use of additional principal buildings in the CB, Central Business, C, General Commercial or I, Industrial zone districts may be approved as a conditional use by the Zoning Administrator according to the policies and procedures set forth in Chapter 17.23, Conditional Uses, and subject to the following conditions and limitations:

    1.   Any additional principal buildings and uses shall, collectively, comply with all requirements of the zone district, and may require site plan approval; and

    2.   All buildings shall remain in common ownership; and

    3.   An off-street parking area adequate to accommodate the needs of the users of all principal buildings and uses, according to the requirements of Chapter 17.28, Off-Street Parking and Loading, of this title shall be provided; and

    4.   All signage for all buildings and uses shall conform to the provisions and limitations of Chapter 17.30, Signs, of this title. (Ord. 2-2013 § 5; Ord. 17-2011 § 17)

 

17.20.053 Community marijuana cultivation facility.
    Requirements and Restrictions. In zone districts where community marijuana cultivation facility is a use by special review, each such community marijuana cultivation facility, in addition to being subject to the general requirements and restrictions applicable to the use by special review process set forth in Chapter 17.24, shall be subject to the requirements and restrictions set forth in Chapter 5.67 of this Code. (Ord. 1-2017 § 3)

 

17.20.054 Design Requirements in the CBD, Central Business District.
    Portions of the Central Business District contain historic areas that should be preserved and where consideration should be given to the historic architectural styles of the commercial buildings in the area. The following regulations pertain to specific areas in the Central Business District:

    A.  Between 3rd and 8th Streets, any building situated on any lot that is adjacent to Main Street shall not exceed three (3) stories. A fourth (4th) or more stories may be authorized through the Special Review process. (Ord. 25-2014 § 3)

 

17.20.055 Discontinuance of certain sales activities.
    A.  Except as provided in Subsections B and C of this section, as of March 7, 2009, sales of new and/or used motor vehicles, boats, furniture or major appliances that are excluded from the definition of “outdoor retail sales” as set forth in Section 17.08.010, shall be prohibited on any lot or parcel listed in Section 17.24.050.

    B.   Nothing in this section shall be interpreted to prohibit sales of new and used motor vehicles, boats, furniture, and/or major appliances from permanent locations where such goods are regularly offered for sale on a year-round basis as a part of the stock-in-trade of the person owning, leasing or otherwise controlling such location, provided that such sales are conducted in conformity with the requirements of all other federal, state and local laws, rules and regulations.

    C.   Sales of new and/or used motor vehicles, boats, furniture and major appliances that were specifically authorized on certain lots and parcels pursuant to City Council’s adoption of a special review ordinance authorizing such sales, among others, as sales permitted by special review shall be subject to the termination provisions, if any, set forth in such ordinance and if no provision for termination was provided for in such ordinance, such sales shall be treated as nonconforming property uses that shall be discontinued in accordance with applicable provisions in Chapter 17.32.

    D.  Nothing in this section shall be construed to prohibit the sale of any items or articles of personal property included in the definition of outdoor retail sales, as clarified in Ordinance No. 4, Series of 2009, from lots or parcels authorized to conduct outdoor retail sales; provided that such sales are conducted in accordance with the requirements of applicable law. (Ord. 28-2010 § 10; Ord. 4-2009 § 4)

 

17.20.060 Building projections.
    Cornices, eaves, canopies, sunshades, gutters, chimneys, flues, beltcourses, leaders, sills, pilasters, lintels, ornamental features and other similar architectural features may project not more than three (3) feet into a required yard or into required open space, as established by coverage standards and in no case shall any feature of any structure project beyond the property line. Carports are not allowed to infringe upon the setback requirement building lines, whether attached or freestanding. (Ord. 25-1991 § 4)

 

17.20.070 Building setback lines.
    All building setback requirements for property lines abutting a public right-of-way are based upon the assumption that said right-of-way meets the standards set forth in the comprehensive plan. If the ROW does not meet the width standard called for, the building setback requirement shall be increased by the distance necessary to accommodate the required right-of-way. Said distance shall be found by measuring from the center line of the right-of-way, half the width required by the comprehensive plan to find the point from which the setback shall be measured. (Ord. 25-1991 § 6)

 

17.20.072 Stormwater and drainage easements.
    When a building, subject to the adopted building code, is located on property traversed by a drainage way including, but not limited to, a watercourse, swale, channel, irrigation ditch, or stream, the owner, prior to obtaining a certificate of occupancy, shall execute an easement agreement for stormwater and/or drainage purpose(s) for the benefit of the City. The easement shall conform substantially to the banks of the drainage way with such width as will be necessary to fulfill the purpose(s) of the easement, as determined by the City, and the agreement shall grant the City the right to access adjacent property to perform any necessary acts related to the easement. If necessary, the City may require a survey of the easement and the costs of such survey shall be paid by the applicant. Wherever possible, it is desirable that the drainage be maintained by an open channel with stabilized banks and adequate width for the one percent annual chance historic flow. (Ord. 7-2019 § 3)

 

17.20.075 Exotic animals.
    A.  No person shall own, keep, traffic in or sell, for any reason, any exotic animal unless that person first obtains a conditional use permit, according to the policies and procedures set forth in Chapter 17.23, Conditional Uses, which permit shall be subject to the following conditions and limitations:

    1.   The keeping or sheltering of exotic animals shall be in a manner as to not constitute a nuisance or health hazard under any ordinance of the City, or under any statute or case law of the state;

    2.   A conditional use permit for an exotic animal may be denied or revoked by the Zoning Administrator or designee if:

    a.   The permit holder is convicted of a violation of Subsection B of this section;

    b.   The applicant or permit holder fails to first obtain, and to keep in effect at all times during which the exotic animal is being kept, all applicable state and federal licenses or permits that may be required to keep the animal;

    c.   The applicant is found to have made any materially false or misleading statement in the application or has concealed relevant information;

    d.   The applicant has obtained the exotic animal through illegal means;

    e.   The applicant is not qualified to possess an exotic animal, does not have adequate facilities to keep the animal or proposes to keep the animal in an unsuitable location; or

    f.    The public health, safety and welfare justify the denial or revocation of the application;

    3.   No use of the property or structure thereon resulting from the issuing of this conditional use permit shall convey any right to future permits;

    B.   It shall be unlawful for any person to own, have custody of, sell, or traffic in any poisonous or dangerous animal;

    C.   It shall be unlawful for any person to keep any wildlife as a pet;

    D.  Nothing herein shall prohibit the keeping of wildlife by any person or organization holding a valid license for educational live possession, falconry, scientific collection or wildlife rehabilitation from the Colorado Division of Wildlife, so long as such licensee also complies with all applicable Municipal Code requirements. (Ord. 2-2013 § 4)

 

17.20.076 Farm stand.
    A farm stand may be permitted in the R-L, R-1, R-2 and I zone districts as a conditional use according to the policies and procedures set forth in Chapter 17.23, Conditional Uses, and subject to the following additional conditions:

    A.  A sketch plan showing the proposed size and location of the stand and the location of any other existing structures, as well as activity areas such as parking, loading, waste disposal, and storage, with sufficient detail to permit the Zoning Administrator to determine their appropriateness and potential impact on surrounding properties shall accompany an application for conditional use;

    B.   Agricultural products sold must have been raised on the land on which the stand is located;

    C.   The farm stand shall not exceed three hundred (300) square feet in area or ten (10) feet in height;

    D.  The farm stand shall meet the setback requirements applicable for an accessory structure in the zone district in which it is located;

    E.   Signs on farm stands shall be limited to two (2) unlighted signs, which may be wall-mounted or freestanding. No sign shall exceed thirty-two (32) square feet in area and eight (8) feet in height, and must be located at least ten (10) feet from any public right-of-way and at least five (5) feet from any interior lot line;

    F.   The area of the farm stand shall be kept clear of litter, debris, spoiled fruits or vegetables, garden waste, and material from cider operations at all times;

    G.  Any lighting used shall be indirect and shielded to avoid light intrusion onto adjacent residential properties. (Ord. 20-2017 § 2; Ord. 2-2013 § 4)

 

17.20.077 Farmers’ market and flea market.
    A farmers’ market or flea market may be approved as a conditional use in the C and CB zone districts according to the policies and procedures set forth in Chapter 17.23, Conditional Uses, and subject to the following additional conditions:

    A.  Off-street parking shall be provided at the rate of one and one-half (1.5) spaces per vendor stall, unless the farmers’ market or flea market is located in an area adjacent to public parking that is adequate to accommodate the needs of the farmers’ market or flea market in addition to the needs of the general public.

    B.   A plan shall be in place for the disposal of trash and other debris.

    C.   The owner/operator of a flea market or a farmers’ market must obtain and maintain all required City, county and state sales tax or other business licenses at all times. (Ord. 16-2014 § 9; Ord. 2-2013 § 4)

 

17.20.080 Fences, walls and hedges.
    A.  Fences, walls and hedges may be permitted in any required setback area or along the property line in residential districts, provided that within the front yard setback they do not exceed thirty (30) inches or, if the fence is at least fifty percent (50%) open, it may be constructed to a maximum height of forty-eight (48) inches, except as provided for below. Fences, walls and hedges erected in other than the required front yard setback in residential districts may not exceed seventy-two (72) inches in height.

    Fence height may extend up to seventy-two (72) inches within the front yard setback where the front yard setback is greater than fifteen (15) feet and where a dwelling is located within the required front yard setback under the following conditions: 1) the fence may not extend into the front yard setback beyond the main structural part of the dwelling (attached porches, open entryways and the like do not count towards this exception); 2) regardless of the placement of the residential structure on the lot or parcel, the fence may not be constructed any closer to the front property line than fifteen (15) feet; and 3) notwithstanding the other provisions of this section, the fence may not create a vision clearance hazard.

    B.   Fences and walls erected in the industrial, general commercial and central business districts shall be reviewed and may be approved by the City Engineer only if the engineer has determined that the structure will not create a visual clearance or traffic hazard. In making such determination, the City Engineer shall give due consideration to applicable sections of this title, including but not limited to Sections 17.20.170 and 17.20.200.

    C.   Fences and walls erected in any zone district for purposes of public safety, health and welfare shall be reviewed and approved or disapproved by the City Engineer and the City Administrator. (Ord. 24-2014 § 1; Ord. 22-1996 § 1; Ord. 9-1990; Ord. 13-1989)

 

17.20.085 Food carts or trucks (stand-alone).
    A.  A stand-alone food cart or truck whether motorized or non-motorized may be set up on a regular, semi-regular or one-time basis in the C, CB, and I zone districts and in the R-L, R-1, R-1A, R-2, and R-3 zone districts as specified herein through the issuance of a temporary use permit (application fee required) as authorized by the City Administrator so long as the applicant complies with each of the following criteria, which are established as the minimum criteria for food carts or trucks:

    1.   Food carts or trucks must be inspected and licensed as mobile retail food establishments by the Colorado Department of Public Health and Environment (CDPHE). A copy of the CDPHE license shall accompany the temporary use permit application.

    2.   The owner or operator of the food cart or truck must obtain and maintain all required City, County and State sales tax licenses at all times.

    3.   The owner or operator of such food cart or truck, shall provide, with the temporary use permit application, certificates evidencing the existence of general liability insurance coverage for such food cart or kiosk in amounts equal to or greater than the maximum amounts that may be recovered from a public entity under the Colorado Governmental Immunity Act and naming the City as an additional insured. Cancellation or reduction in coverage below such standards shall automatically void an approved permit.

    4.   The temporary use permit authorized in this section shall be permanently displayed to the public in a visible location on the food cart or truck.

    5.   Operations shall not obstruct parking lot circulation or block access to a public street, alley or sidewalk.

    6.   The operation of the food cart or truck shall not infringe on or upon the ability of pedestrians to negotiate the sidewalks or other common public areas, or cause damage to any improvements within the public right-of-way.

    7.   Operations of any food cart or truck shall be at least one hundred (100) feet from any eating and drinking establishment lawfully existing at the time the permit or renewal permit was issued and is open for business, unless written permission is granted by the eating or drinking establishment located within that distance.

    8.   No food cart or truck shall be set up on any privately owned lot or parcel without written permission of the property owner.

    9.   Trash receptacles shall be provided and the owner/operator shall be responsible for keeping the area surrounding the food cart or truck clear of any litter and properly cleaned.

    10. Signs must be permanently affixed to or painted on the food cart or truck. Each food cart or truck may have one sandwich board sign which may not be located in any right-of-way or impede pedestrian or vehicular traffic and must be within twenty-five (25) feet of the food cart or truck.

    11. Canopies, umbrellas, and outdoor tables and chairs may not be placed in any location that infringes upon the ability of pedestrians to use the sidewalk or other public area, or creates a visual obstruction to traffic.

    12. Food carts or trucks may locate on the same lot or parcel so long as each vendor has the property owner’s written permission and all other provisions contained herein can be met.

    13. No food cart or truck shall be located within fifty (50) feet of the established outer boundary of any City-permitted or licensed event where the sale of merchandise and food has been allowed.

    14. When not in operation, a food cart or truck shall be stored on private property.

    15. If located in a City right-of-way: (a) no merchandise shall be offered, displayed or sold and no customers served except from the sidewalk, (b) only non­motorized carts may be located on sidewalks, (c) carts or trucks must be located at least twenty-five (25) feet from any intersection (measured from the edge of sidewalk to the cart or truck) and fifteen (15) feet from any driveway, (d) in the CB zone district, food carts or trucks are not allowed on Main Street between 2nd and 8th Streets, but may locate on side numbered streets as long as all other provisions contained herein can be met, (e) food carts or trucks shall comply with all traffic and parking ordinances of the City, as they may be amended, (f) food carts or trucks may not cater private events from either the sidewalk or road right­of-way without an approved street closure permit. In addition, any location in a City right-of-way, including sidewalks, may be subject to temporary suspension or revocation without cause, but for reasons that may include construction, repairs, maintenance or emergencies as determined by the City.

    16. In residential zone districts a food cart or truck may locate on Cañon City Fremont RE-1 School District property and Cañon City Area Recreation and Park District property with written permission from the property owner. Food carts or trucks may also locate in the right-of-way adjacent to Fremont RE-1 School District property, Cañon City Area Recreation and Park District property and City park property. No permit is required for a private, catered event occurring on private property (private parties, reunions, weddings and the like) or for a mobile vendor pursuant to Subsection B below.

    17. In City parks and plazas, food carts or trucks may be allowed. A separate park permit application is required and may be date and time specific.

    18. All permit requests, including locations in City parks and/or plazas, shall be processed by the City Planning Department. The City Administrator shall have the discretion to impose such other requirements and restrictions as are deemed appropriate and which are intended to provide for the health, safety, comfort and convenience of the City and its inhabitants.

    B.   Mobile food trucks, food carts and other mobile vendors that operate on a motor route and/or do not conduct business in any single location for longer than one hour are required to be licensed to operate in the public right-of-way in accordance with the provisions of applicable law and are not subject to these permit requirements.

    C.   These permit requirements do not apply to food carts or trucks that are: (1) part of a City-permitted event; or (2) for a private, catered event occurring on private property (private parties, reunions, weddings and the like) in any zone district.

    D.  A street closure permit may be required in order to locate on any city street or right-of-way where the provisions contained herein cannot be met.

    E.   The provisions of this section shall not apply to any minor-operated business. (Ord. 2-2020 § 12; Ord. 23-2016 § 1)

 

17.20.090 Garages, detached.
    The front yard setback requirement for detached garages in zone districts R-1, R-2 and R-3 shall be twenty-five (25) feet from the front property line and in the R-1A zone district detached garages shall be fifteen (15) feet from the front property line. (Ord. 15-2016 § 7; Ord. 25-1991 § 7)

 

17.20.100 Home occupations.
    Within residentially zoned districts, home occupations shall be allowed as permitted accessory use governed by the following regulations and limitations:

    A.  “Home occupation” means an occupation carried on in the dwelling or accessory building by members of the family occupying the dwelling, with no servant, employee or other person being engaged, provided the residential character of the building is maintained and the occupation is conducted in such a manner as not to give an outward appearance nor manifest any characteristic of a business in the ordinary meaning of the term, nor infringe upon the right of neighboring residents to enjoy a peaceful occupancy of their homes.

    B.   Home occupations must be clearly secondary to the use of the building, and shall not occupy more than twenty percent (20%) of the total floor area of the main building or, if located in an accessory building, shall not occupy more than ten percent (10%) of the total lot area.

    C.   Home occupations shall be operated entirely from an enclosed structure with no exterior storage of materials, equipment or products.

    D.  A home occupation shall be entitled to one unlighted wall sign with sign area of two (2) square foot installed on the wall of the principal or the accessory building, but not on both buildings.

    E.   The operation shall not generate objectionable traffic in the area, and off-street parking must be provided to accommodate all needs created by the home occupation.

    F.   The operation shall not be objectionable due to odor, dust, smoke, noise, vibration or other similar causes. (Ord. 20-2017 § 3; prior code § 17.16.010)

 

17.20.102 Household pets.
    Household pets may be permitted as an accessory use in any zone district on property used for residential purposes, subject to the following conditions and limitations:

    A.  Household pets may not be used to supplement food supplies, or for any commercial purpose whatsoever other than the offering for sale of one litter, brood or offspring of a household pet domiciled on the premises;

    B.   Household pets which are customarily let outdoors for exercise or elimination or are kept outdoors or in an accessory structure, may number no more than four (4) per household;

    C.   Animals that are poisonous, vicious, or known to attack are prohibited within the city limits;

    D.  The premises upon or within which any animal is kept within the city limits shall at all times be maintained with regular and frequent cleaning to minimize the possibility of unhealthy or unsafe conditions;

    E.   The keeping or sheltering of household pets shall be in a manner so as to not constitute a nuisance or health hazard under any ordinance of the City, or under any statute or case law of the state;

    F.   All dogs shall be kept in compliance with the requirements and limitations contained in Chapter 6.08, Dogs, of the Municipal Code. (Ord. 2-2013 § 4)

 

17.20.105 All industrial uses.
    In addition to all other applicable provisions of this Code, all uses, including but not limited to permitted uses, in any I District shall be subject to the following standards:

    A.  Light fixtures on buildings and in parking areas shall not exceed twenty-five (25) feet in height and shall be oriented in such a way as to not shine into residential areas. Downward facing and shielded lighting is recommended.

    B.   Outdoor storage, equipment and refuse areas, as allowed, shall be concealed from view from abutting rights-of-way and from adjoining residential streets.

    C.   Travel and parking portions of any lot(s) shall be surfaced and maintained as required in Section 17.28.070, Parking lot layout standards.

    D.  If available, access to the use shall be provided from an arterial or collector street.

    E.   Reasonable steps shall be taken to confine dust, fumes, odors, smoke, vapor and noise to the site. (Ord. 1-2015 § 2)

 

17.20.107 Intermodal shipping containers.
    Intermodal shipping containers are permitted as an accessory structure (as a garage or storage shed, not as a habitable structure) in all zone districts and are subject to the following conditions:

    A.  Such container shall not be located in the front yard or side yard along a street, and shall otherwise meet all setback requirements for accessory structures in the zone district in which it is located.

    B.   Such container shall be painted, and may also be enclosed or architecturally altered to be compatible with the appearance of the on-site principal structure and surrounding neighborhood. Such enclosure or alteration(s) may require a building permit.

    C.   Stacking of containers is not allowed. (Ord. 3-2018 § 5)

 

17.20.110 Junkyards.
    A.  It is unlawful to establish or maintain a junkyard within any residential zone district and junkyards on residential property are hereby declared to be prohibited, a nuisance and detrimental to the health, safety, convenience and general welfare of the citizens of the City of Cañon City.

    B.   It is the intent and purpose of this section to discourage, prohibit and abate certain conditions affecting the health, safety and general welfare of the citizens of the City, particularly the children, which pose a danger because of broken glass, sharp protrusions, insecure objects, or further create habitat for rodents, insects and other pests or further constitute a blighting influence upon the area in which they are located which causes a loss of value to surrounding property. (Ord. 3-2011 § 3; Ord. 25-1991 § 8; Ord. 11-1991 § 3)

 

17.20.111 Kennels.
    A kennel may be approved as a conditional use in the R-L, C, and I zone districts, according to the policies and procedures set forth in Chapter 17.23, Conditional Uses, and subject to the following additional conditions:

    A.  Every kennel shall, at all times, be licensed as a Pet Animal Care Facility with the Colorado Department of Agriculture;

    B.   Any kennel established within the City limits shall also be licensed pursuant to the requirements and provisions of Section 6.08.040, Kennel license requirements, of the Municipal Code;

    C.   All structures used to house the animals, including dog runs and outdoor exercise areas, shall meet a minimum twenty-five (25) foot setback from all property lines;

    D.  Any outdoor area where animals are confined shall be fenced to prevent the animals from escaping;

    E.   Any outdoor area where animals are confined shall be graded and surfaced to provide proper drainage of stormwater and to prevent runoff from entering nearby ditches or other watercourses or neighboring property;

    F.   All animal waste shall be properly disposed of on a daily basis to prevent offensive odors, minimize disease hazards, and prevent vermin infestation. (Ord. 2-2013 § 4)

 

17.20.114 Livestock.
    A.  Livestock may be kept in the R-1, R-2 and R-3 zone districts only on a contiguous tract of land which is in excess of one acre in area. Livestock may be kept in the R-L zone district only on a contiguous tract of land which is in excess of fifteen thousand (15,000) square feet.
